PREFACE
This Municipal Code of the Village of Lake Bluff, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 2025-23, passed July 28, 2025.
Ordinances of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions
of this Municipal Code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent
therewith. Consult the Village office in order to ascertain whether any
particular provision of the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not amend the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
 
 
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
LAKE BLUFF MUNICIPAL CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Code Designated And Cited
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Distribution Of Code
1-1-4: Record Of Ordinances
1-1-1: CODE DESIGNATED AND CITED:
The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute
and be designated the LAKE BLUFF MUNICIPAL CODE and may be so cited. (2009
Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in all administrative tribunals of this
state as the ordinances of the village of general and permanent effect. (1988
Code § 1-1-2)
1-1-3: DISTRIBUTION OF CODE:
All of the printed copies of this code belonging to the village shall be
deposited with the village clerk. The village clerk shall deliver one copy
thereof to each member of the board of trustees and additional copies to such
other persons as the board of trustees may direct. The board of trustees shall
have the power to extend or to reciprocate courtesies of other municipalities
by presenting to them, at the expense of the village, copies of this code.
Copies of this code shall be made available for purchase at a price determined
by the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-1-5)
1-1-4: RECORD OF ORDINANCES:
All ordinances enacted by the board of trustees shall be consecutively numbered
and prefixed with the last two (2) numbers of the year of passage by the
village clerk in a separate ordinance book and appropriately indexed. (1988
Code § 1-1-6)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Ordinances Not Affected By Code
1-2-2: Effect On Prior Offenses And Rights
1-2-3: Provisions As Continuation Of Existing Ordinances
1-2-4: Catchlines Of Sections; History Notes; References
1-2-5: Effect Of Repeal Of Ordinances
1-2-6: Amendments
1-2-7: Severability
1-2-8: Public Ways And Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-9: Supplementation Of Code
1-2-1: ORDINANCES NOT AFFECTED BY CODE:
A.   Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any
of the following:
1.   Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money
for the village or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the village or any
evidence of the village indebtedness.
2.   Any appropriation ordinance or resolution providing for the levy of taxes
or for an annual budget.
3.   Any ordinance annexing territory to the village or excluding territory as
a part of the village.
4.   Any ordinance granting any franchise, permit or other right.
5.   Any ordinance approving, authorizing or otherwise relating to any
contract, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument.
6.   Any zoning or subdivision ordinances.
7.   Any ordinance naming, renaming, opening, accepting or vacating streets or
alleys in the village.
8.   Any ordinance levying special assessments.
9.   Any ordinance relating to the salaries of village officers or employees.
10.   Any ordinance providing regulations for cable television and other
telecommunications franchises and facilities.
11.   Any ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets or
other public ways or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of
public utilities not codified.
12.   Any ordinance whose purpose has been accomplished.
13.   Any ordinance which is special although permanent in effect.
14.   Any ordinance which is temporary although general in effect.
B.   All such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and effect
to the same extent as if set out at length herein. (2009 Code)
1-2-2: EFFECT ON PRIOR OFFENSES AND RIGHTS:
A.   Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any
offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any
contract or right established or accruing, before the effective date of this
code.
B.   The adoption of this code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or
allowing any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in
violation of any ordinance of the village in effect on the date of adoption of
this code. (2009 Code)
1-2-3: PROVISIONS AS CONTINUATION OF EXISTING ORDINANCES:
The provisions of this code, insofar as they are substantially the same as
ordinance provisions previously adopted by the village relating to the same
subject matter, shall be construed as restatements and continuations thereof
and not as new enactments. (2009 Code)
1-2-4: CATCHLINES OF SECTIONS; HISTORY NOTES; REFERENCES:
A.   Catchlines: The catchlines of the several sections of this code printed in
boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the
section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as
any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or
reenacted.
B.   History Or Source Notes: The history or source notes appearing in
parentheses after sections in this code are not intended to have any legal
effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in
the section. Cross references and state law references which appear after
sections or subsections of this code or which otherwise appear in footnote form
are provided for the convenience of the user of this code and have no legal
effect.
C.   References: All references to chapters, articles, or sections are to the
chapters, articles, and sections of this code unless otherwise specified. (2009
Code)
1-2-5: EFFECT OF REPEAL OF ORDINANCES:
When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be
itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former
ordinance, clause or provision unless it shall be therein so expressly
provided. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty
incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding
pending at the time of the repeal, or an offense committed or cause of action
arising under the ordinance repealed. (2009 Code)
1-2-6: AMENDMENTS:
All ordinances passed subsequent to this code which amend, repeal or in any way
affect this code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of
this code and printed for inclusion herein, or in the case of repealed
chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent
ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the code by omission
from reprinted pages affected thereby, and the subsequent ordinances as
numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie
evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this code and
subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted. (2009 Code)
1-2-7: SEVERABILITY:
The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this code are
severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this
code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by a valid
judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such
unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the
remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this code.
(2009 Code)
1-2-8: PUBLIC WAYS AND PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinances relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and
other public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, services or rates of
public utilities shall be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this code or by
virtue of section
1-2-7 of this chapter, excepting as this code may contain provisions for such
matters, in which case, this code shall be considered as amending such
ordinance or ordinances in respect of such provisions only. (1988 Code § 1-2-2)
1-2-9: SUPPLEMENTATION OF CODE:
A.   Preparation And Printing: Supplements to this code shall be prepared and
printed whenever authorized or directed by the village administrator. A
supplement to the code shall include substantive permanent and general parts of
ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes
made thereby in the code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that
they will fit properly into the code and will, where necessary, replace pages
which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so
prepared that, when they have been inserted, the code will be current through
the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement.
B.   Repealed Portions: In preparing a supplement to this code, all portions of
the code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the code by the
omission thereof from reprinted pages.
C.   Changes In Ordinances: When preparing a supplement to this code, the
person authorized to prepare the supplement may make formal, nonsubstantive
changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement
insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For
example, the person may:
1.   Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions;
2.   Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and
subdivisions of the code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such
catchlines, headings and titles;
3.   Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be
inserted in the code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change
existing section or other subdivision numbers;
4.   Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this
chapter", "this article", "this section", etc., as the case may be, or to
"sections        to       " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections
of the code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated
into the code); and
5.   Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original
meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the code; but in no case may any
change be made in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the
supplement or already embodied in the code. (2009 Code)
CHAPTER 3
RULES AND DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Rules Of Construction
1-3-2: Definitions
1-3-1: RULES OF CONSTRUCTION:
A.   In the construction of this code and of all ordinances, the rules and
definitions set out in this chapter shall be observed unless such construction
would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of trustees. The
rules of construction and definitions set out herein shall not be applied to
any section of this code which shall contain any express provision excluding
such construction or where the subject matter or the context of such section
may be repugnant thereto.
B.   All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this
code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of
the board of trustees may be fully carried out. In the interpretation and
application of any provision of this code, they shall be held to be the minimum
requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort,
convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the code imposes
greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the other provisions of the
code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be
deemed to be controlling. (2009 Code)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
BOARD, BOARD OF TRUSTEES OR VILLAGE BOARD: The board of trustees of the village
of Lake Bluff, which shall consist of the president and trustees.
CODE OR THIS CODE: The Lake Bluff municipal code as designated in section
1-1-1 of this title.
COMPREHENSIVE FEE SCHEDULE: That certain schedule that is annually adopted by
the board of trustees setting forth the applicable fees and charges due for the
various licenses, permits and services authorized by this code and by other
ordinances of the village, as set out in chapter 12 of this title.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The village president and the board of trustees.
CORPORATE SEAL: The village seal shall be in circular form with the words and
figures "Seal of the Village of Lake Bluff, Lake County, Illinois" on its outer
circle and in the interior of said circle the words, "Incorporated September
21, 1895".
COUNTY OR THIS COUNTY: The county of Lake, Illinois.
DATUM FOR GRADES 1 :
A.   A base or datum for the grades and levels of the village is hereby fixed
at a point one hundred two and six-tenths feet (102.6') below a cut on the top
of the water table stone at the southeast corner of the village hall. The base
or datum hereby established shall be known as "the datum of the village of Lake
Bluff".
B.   Flood base elevations hereinafter established by the village shall be
measured and fixed in accordance with and, with reference to the datum of the
village.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this code to a village employee by
title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words, "of the
village of Lake Bluff".
FEE: A sum of money charged by the village for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation.
FISCAL YEAR: The "fiscal year" of the village shall begin on May 1 of each year
and end on April 30 next following.
LICENSE: The permission or authority granted to carry on a business,
profession, occupation or activity on public or private property.
MAYOR: That individual serving as village president of the village of Lake
Bluff, who may be referred to as "mayor".
MISDEMEANOR: Any offense for which a sentence to a term of imprisonment in
other than a penitentiary for less than one year may be imposed.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive, obnoxious or detrimental to the health, safety,
and welfare and property values of the inhabitants of the village; or any act
or thing repugnant to, or creating a hazard to, or having a detrimental effect
on the property of another person or to the community.
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, this term shall include any person
who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or
with others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OFFICERS: Whenever any officer is referred to by title, such as "village
clerk", "chief of police", "president", etc., such reference shall be construed
as if followed by the words "of the village of Lake Bluff".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the
entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land.
PERSON: Shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, and societies,
firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Every description of money, goods, chattels, effects,
evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any pecuniary
obligation or right or title to property is created, acknowledged, transferred,
increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or interest
therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, this term shall be understood
to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small
quantities direct to the consumer.
STATE OR THIS STATE: The state of Illinois.
STREET: Shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads,
alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public ways in the village and shall
include all areas thereof embraced between property lines and dedicated to the
public use.
TENANT OR OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person
holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such
building or land, either alone or with others.
VILLAGE: The village of Lake Bluff, Lake County, Illinois.
VILLAGE PRESIDENT: The president of the village may be referred to as "mayor"
or "president" of the village. The president is also a member of and included
in the definition of the "board of trustees".
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, such
terms shall be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles
or things in quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: Shall be construed to include any representation of words,
letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. (1988 Code § 1-3-2; amd.
2009 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  11-1-3 of this code, definition of "Lake Bluff datum for grades".
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty; Continuing Violations; Exception
1-4-2: Citations Or Complaints
1-4-3: Offenses Punishable Under Several Sections; License Revocation
1-4-4: Service Of Citations Or Complaints
1-4-5: Service Of Summons
1-4-6: Liability Of Officers
1-4-7: Defense And Indemnification
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY; CONTINUING VIOLATIONS; EXCEPTION:
A.   Whenever in this code, or in any ordinance of the village, any act or
omission is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a
violation of this code, or whenever in such code or ordinance the doing of any
act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a violation of this code, where no specific penalty is provided
therefor, the violation of any such provision of this code or any ordinance is
hereby declared to be an offense and shall be punishable by a fine of not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day or part
thereof on which a violation occurs or continues or is permitted to occur or
continue.
B.   Whenever a minimum but no maximum fine is imposed as a penalty by any
section or paragraph of this code, the court may, in its discretion, fine the
offender any sum exceeding the minimum fine, but the fine shall not exceed
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
C.   Unless otherwise provided, a separate offense shall be held to have been
committed on each day that any violation of any section of this code shall
occur or continue.
D.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this code or any other ordinance of
the village, where service of summons in connection with any alleged code or
ordinance violation is made by certified mail pursuant to section
1-4-4 of this chapter, the maximum fine for each violation or offense shall not
exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00).
E.   No provision of this code designating the duties of any village officer or
employee shall be construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any
fine or penalty provided in this code for a failure to perform such duty,
unless the intention of the board of trustees to impose such a fine or penalty
on such officer or employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the
section creating the duty. (2009 Code)
1-4-2: CITATIONS OR COMPLAINTS:
A citation or complaint for any ordinance violation or a violation of this code
may encompass more than one day. (2009 Code)
1-4-3: OFFENSES PUNISHABLE UNDER SEVERAL SECTIONS; LICENSE REVOCATION:
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable under more than one
section or subsection of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect under
which to proceed, but in no case shall more than one penalty be imposed upon a
person for a single offense; except, that the revocation of a license or permit
(or other civil action of a nonpenal character to enforce any provision of this
code) shall not be considered a penalty so as to bar any other penalty being
imposed. (2009 Code)
1-4-4: SERVICE OF CITATIONS OR COMPLAINTS:
A.   A citation or complaint for any ordinance violation or any violation of
this code may be served by certified mail, return receipt requested; by
personal service by a police or fire officer of the village; or by personal
service by the director or a designated employee of the village administrator.
B.   Personal service of a citation shall be made either by personally
delivering the citation or complaint to the defendant, or by leaving a copy at
the defendant's usual place of abode with some person of the defendant's family
of the age of thirteen (13) years or older, and informing that person of the
contents thereof; provided, that a copy of the citation or complaint shall also
be sent in a sealed envelope with postage fully prepaid, addressed to the
defendant at his or her usual place of abode. (2009 Code)
1-4-5: SERVICE OF SUMMONS:
A.   In all actions initiated by the village for the enforcement of any
provision of this code, or of any other ordinance of the village, where the
fine or penalty specified by the village for each separate offense or violation
does not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00), service of summons may be by
certified mail, return receipt requested, whether service is to be made inside
or outside the state.
B.   Subject to all applicable provisions of the Illinois code of civil
procedure, the Illinois supreme court rules and the local rules of the circuit
court, in all actions initiated by the village for the enforcement of any
provision of this code or of any other ordinance of the village, service of
summons may also be made personally by a police officer of the village. Where
service of summons is made by a police officer, service of summons may be made
either by personally delivering the summons to the defendant, or by leaving a
copy at the defendant's usual place of abode with some person of the
defendant's family of the age of thirteen (13) years or older, and informing
that person of the contents thereof, provided the police officer making such
service on anyone other than the defendant shall also send a copy of the
summons in a sealed envelope with postage fully prepaid, addressed to the
defendant at his usual place of abode.
C.   Nothing in this section shall be deemed or interpreted as precluding or
preventing service of summons as permitted by all applicable provisions of the
Illinois code of civil procedure, the Illinois supreme court rules and the
local rules of the circuit court. (2009 Code)
1-4-6: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the board of trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (1988 Code § 1-4-3)
1-4-7: DEFENSE AND INDEMNIFICATION:
A.   Proceedings Against Officials: The village shall defend, save harmless and
indemnify its current and former trustees, commissioners, board members,
officers, employees, attorneys and any village representatives serving on other
bodies who have been appointed by the Lake Bluff board of trustees against any
civil, criminal or administrative investigation, claim, action, suit or
proceedings instituted or threatened to be instituted against them, based upon
any act, error or omission that could be reasonably construed to be within the
exercise of their respective lawful duties or scope of employment and against
judgments, fines and other costs and liabilities, including amounts paid in
settlement sustained as a result of, and reasonable expenses (including
attorney fees) incurred in connection with, the investigation, defense, adverse
decision, compromise or settlement of any such investigation, claim, action,
suit or proceedings or threat thereof.
B.   Actions On Behalf Of Village: This section shall not apply to providing
defense or indemnification to any such trustee, commissioner, board member,
officer, employee or representative in any such investigation, claim, action,
suit or proceedings instituted by or on behalf of the village against such
trustee, commissioner, board member, officer, employee or representative.
C.   Rights Not Exclusive: The rights expressed in this section shall not be
exclusive of any other rights which any current or former trustee,
commissioner, board member, officer, employee or representative may have as a
matter of law. The foregoing rights shall, in the case of the death of a
trustee, commissioner, board member, officer, employee or representative,
accrue to the benefit of his or her successors.
D.   Village Liability: The liability of the village for payments under this
section may be insured to the extent permitted by law, but to the extent not
insured shall be payable out of the funds and monies of the village.
E.   Village Authority: Nothing in this section shall be deemed to limit or
modify the authority of the village under state law to defend or indemnify
parties or persons as otherwise provided and permitted by law. (Ord. 94-17, 5-
23-1994)
CHAPTER 5
VILLAGE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-5-1: Meetings
1-5-2: Quorum; Order Of Business
1-5-3: Rules Of Order And Procedure
1-5-4: Committees; Reports
1-5-5: Ordinances
1-5-6: Bills, Vouchers; Exception
1-5-7: Budget System
1-5-1: MEETINGS:
A.   Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of the board of trustees shall be held
on the second and fourth Monday of each month at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M., at
the village hall, unless otherwise ordered at a regular meeting. (Ord. 93-6, 5-
24-1993)
B.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be held at any time on call of the
village president. Such call may be in writing, signed by the village
president, and shall set forth the object of the meeting, the place of the
meeting, and the time of the meeting, and shall be hand delivered or sent by
United States mail, postage prepaid, properly addressed to each trustee to his
residence in the village, and shall be hand delivered or mailed at least two
(2) days prior to such meeting. Special meetings may be called in the manner
aforesaid by any three (3) or more of the village trustees. Special meetings
may also be called by the village president, giving notice in person or by
telephone to all village trustees, the village clerk and village administrator
at least one day in advance of a special meeting date. Special meetings may
also be scheduled during any regular meeting date of the board of trustees. The
office of the village clerk shall be responsible for giving notices required
under the open public meetings act of the state of Illinois 1 . Only that
business specified in the notice to the village trustees, village clerk,
village administrator and news media may be taken up and discussed at a special
meeting. (1988 Code § 1-5-1)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
1-5-2: QUORUM; ORDER OF BUSINESS:
At the hour selected for the meeting, the village clerk, or someone appointed
by the village president to fill his place, shall proceed to call the roll of
members, mark the absentees and announce whether a quorum (a majority of all
members elected) be present. Upon the appearance of a quorum, the board of
trustees shall be called to order, the presiding officer taking the chair, if
present, and the board of trustees appointing a temporary chair, if he should
be absent. If a quorum does not appear within thirty (30) minutes of the time
designated for commencement of the meeting, the board of trustees shall thereby
automatically stand adjourned, and all agenda matters for said meeting shall be
set over to the next regular meeting of the board of trustees unless a special
meeting is held pursuant to the provisions of subsection 1-5-1B of this
chapter. When a quorum is present, the board of trustees shall proceed to the
business before it in the order set forth on the meeting agenda unless
otherwise determined by a majority vote of the board of trustees. An
opportunity for public comment and participation shall be provided on the
agenda for each regular and special meeting of the board of trustees and its
committees and shall proceed pursuant to the rules concerning public comment
and participation adopted by resolution of the board of trustees, which rules
shall apply equally to meetings of all village commissions and boards. (Ord.
2011-3, 4-11-2011)
1-5-3: RULES OF ORDER AND PROCEDURE:
Rule 1. All questions relating to the priority of business shall be decided by
the chair, without debate, subject to appeal.
Rule 2. The presiding officer shall preserve order and decorum, and may speak
to points of order in preference to other members, and shall decide all
questions of order, subject to an appeal to the board of trustees, on which
appeal no member shall speak more than once without the unanimous consent of
the board of trustees.
Rule 3. While the presiding officer is putting the question or while business
is being transacted, no member shall walk across or out of the board of
trustees room, except by consent of the board of trustees, unless to secure
data or material required for some specific purpose to be considered by the
board of trustees, or for purposes of an emergency.
Rule 4. Every member, previous to his speaking, making a motion, or seconding
the same, shall address himself to the presiding officer, and say: "Mr.
president", or "madame president", and shall not proceed with his remarks until
recognized and named by the chair.
Rule 5. When two (2) or more members shall address the chair at once, the
presiding officer shall name the member who is to speak first.
Rule 6. During sessions of the board of trustees, only village officers and
designated village officials and employees shall be permitted at the board of
trustees' table unless upon invitation of the president. Lobbying shall not be
permitted in the board room of the trustees.
Rule 7. In case of disturbance or disorderly conduct, the presiding officer
shall have power to require the chamber to be cleared, if necessary.
Rule 8. No member, without leave of the board of trustees, shall present more
than one communication, petition, ordinance or other original matter, until
every member desirous of presenting any communication, petition, ordinance, or
other original matter shall have presented the same.
Rule 9. No member, without leave of the board of trustees, shall speak more
than once upon the same subject until every member desirous of speaking shall
have spoken, and no member shall speak longer than five (5) minutes at any one
time except by consent of the board of trustees.
Rule 10. A member called to order by the chair shall immediately cease to
speak, unless permitted to explain. If there be no appeal, the decision of the
chair shall be conclusive, but if the member appeals from the decision of the
chair, the board of trustees shall decide on the case.
Rule 11. While a member is speaking, no member shall hold any private discourse
nor pass between the speaker and the chair.
Rule 12. Every member who shall be present when a question is presented shall
vote thereon unless directly interested in the question, in which case, such
member shall disclose such interest and shall not vote. In the event of a pass,
failure or refusal to vote, the village clerk shall record the vote of such a
member to be the same as other members' vote on the prevailing side.
Rule 13. No member shall be allowed to leave the board of trustees while in
session unless excused by the presiding officer.
Rule 14. Any matter before the board of trustees may be set down as a special
order of business at a certain time, if two-thirds (2/3) of the members present
vote in the affirmative, but not otherwise. (1988 Code § 1-5-3)
Rule 15. No motion shall be put or debated unless it is seconded. When a motion
is seconded, it shall be stated by the presiding officer before debate, and
every such motion shall be reduced to writing if required by a member. The
maker of the motion shall be entitled to the floor. The right to vote in any
particular manner as otherwise allowed shall not be restricted in any way as a
result of the board member having made or seconded the motion under
consideration. (Ord. 2002-01, 1-28-2002)
Rule 16. After a motion or resolution is stated by the presiding officer, it
shall be deemed to be in possession of the board of trustees, but may be
withdrawn at any time before decision or amendment, by unanimous consent of the
board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-5-3)
Rule 17. If the question under consideration contains several distinct
propositions, any member may have the same divided so as to clarify each part.
(1988 Code § 1-5-3; amd. 2009 Code)
Rule 18. In all cases where a resolution or motion is entered upon the minutes
of the board of trustees, the name of the member moving the same shall be
entered also.
Rule 19. If any member requires it, the yeas and nays upon any question shall
be taken and entered on the minutes, but the yeas and nays shall not be taken
unless called for previous to any vote on the question.
Rule 20. The result of all votes by yeas and nays shall be announced by the
village clerk, and no individual vote shall be changed after the vote has been
announced.
Rule 21. When the question is under debate, the only motion in order shall be:
1.   To adjourn to a day certain.
2.   To adjourn.
3.   To lay on the table.
4.   To move or call for the previous question.
5.   To refer.
6.   To amend.
7.   To substitute.
8.   To postpone indefinitely or to a day certain.
      Motions 2, 3 and 4 above shall be decided without debate.
Rule 22. A motion to adjourn the board of trustees shall always be in order,
except:
1.   When a member is in possession of the floor;
2.   When the yeas and nays are being called;
3.   When the members are voting;
4.   When adjournment was the last preceding motion; and
5.   When it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken.
Rule 23. A motion simply to adjourn cannot be amended or debated, but a motion
to adjourn to a time named may be amended and is open to debate.
Rule 24. When the previous question is moved and seconded, it shall be put in
this form: "I move we vote now." If carried, all further amendments and debates
shall be excluded, and the questions and the chair shall at once state and put
the question on the motion that is then immediately pending, upon pending
amendments in proper order, and then upon the main questions. (1988 Code § 1-5-
3)
Rule 25. A motion simply to lay a question on the table is not debatable, but a
motion to lay on the table and publish or any other condition, is subject to
amendment and debate. A motion to remove a subject matter from the table may be
proposed at the same meeting, provided two-thirds (2/3) of the board of
trustees present vote therefor. (1988 Code § 1-5-3; amd. 2009 Code)
Rule 26. A motion to lay any particular proposition on the table shall apply to
that proposition only.
Rule 27. When a motion is postponed indefinitely, it shall not be again taken
up at the same meeting.
Rule 28. A motion to refer to a standing committee shall take precedence to a
similar motion for an ad hoc committee.
Rule 29. A motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but one to amend an
amendment to an amendment shall not be entertained.
Rule 30. An amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in order,
but an amendment relating to a different subject shall not be in order.
Rule 31. On an amendment to "strike out and insert", the paragraph to be
amended shall first be read as it stands, then the words proposed to be
stricken out and those to be inserted, and finally, the paragraph as it will
stand as so amended shall be read.
Rule 32. A substitute for any original proposition in debate may be entertained
when further amendment is not admissible; and if accepted by the mover of such
original proposition, or by the board of trustees by vote, it shall entirely
supersede such original proposition, and cut off all amendments appertaining
thereto. Any substitute proposition can be amended only by adding thereto.
Rule 33. A vote or question may be reconsidered at any time, during the same
meeting, or at the first regular meeting held thereafter. A motion for
reconsideration being once made and decided in the negative, shall not be
renewed, nor shall a vote to reconsider be reconsidered, unless there is
unanimous consent by the board of trustees to allow a motion to be made
therefor preceding the vote on reconsideration.
Rule 34. A motion to reconsider must be made only by a member who voted with
the prevailing side; provided, however, that when a motion is lost by reason of
not receiving a two-thirds (2/3) or more vote required for its passage, a
motion to reconsider may be made by a member voting in the minority. The
president shall be included in the total of board of trustees members for this
purpose. The seconder of such motion need not have voted with the prevailing
side on such question, or have voted at all.
Rule 35. The board of trustees shall, at all regular meetings, resume old
business at the same order on which it was engaged immediately preceding the
last adjournment, unless agreed to by majority vote of the corporate
authorities. (1988 Code § 1-5-3)
Rule 36. Reserved. (Ord. 2011-3, 4-11-2011)
Rule 37. Any other matters of rules of order and procedures not provided for
herein or by the Illinois statutes will be governed by the latest edition of
"Robert's Rules Of Order". (1988 Code § 1-5-3)
1-5-4: COMMITTEES; REPORTS:
A.   Standing Committees:
1.   Established: The following shall be the standing committees of the board
of trustees:
      Economic development
      Finance
      Public safety
      Public works
2.   Appointment; Composition: The standing committees shall each consist of
three (3) duly elected or appointed members of the board of trustees. The
village president shall have the authority to appoint, replace or remove the
chairman and members of the standing committees. The village president shall
notify the board of trustees of any change in the composition of any of the
standing committees at the first regular meeting of the board of trustees after
such change in composition has occurred.
3.   General Purpose: The standing committees shall evaluate existing and
proposed policies and practices of the village in their areas of
responsibility, and make any recommendations with respect thereto which they
deem appropriate to the village president, board of trustees and village
administrator.
4.   Specific Purpose: The purpose of each of the standing committees shall be
as follows:
a.   Economic Development: To assist and advise the village president, board of
trustees and village administrator in developing, maintaining and improving the
economic vitality of commercial enterprises within the village and those that
seek to relocate in the village and to solicit advice and cooperation from such
enterprises on such matters.
b.   Finance: To assist and advise the village president, board of trustees and
village administrator with regard to the village budget and tax levies, the
reports of independent auditors and the financial policies and practices of the
village.
c.   Public Safety: To assist and advise the village president, board of
trustees and village administrator in assessing and formulating policies with
respect to the village police and fire departments to maintain and protect the
safety of persons within the village and to safeguard real and personal
property located in the village.
d.   Public Works: To assist and advise the village president, board of
trustees and village administrator in assessing and formulating the policies of
the village engineering and public works departments with regard to the orderly
and efficient provision of municipal utility services, including water
distribution, sanitary and storm sewer collection, refuse and recycling
collection and disposal and street and sidewalk repair and replacement.
5.   Administration: The standing committees shall be staffed and administered
by the village administrator or his or her designee.
6.   Public Notice: All meetings of the standing committees shall be open to
the public. The village administrator shall arrange for the proper public
notice of the time and place of meetings of the standing committees as
requested by the chairperson or a majority of the members of the standing
committee. (Ord. 93-6, 5-24-1993)
B.   Ad Hoc Committees: The president shall be empowered to appoint from time
to time such select or additional committees deemed necessary and proper.
C.   Report; Discharge: On the acceptance of a final report from an ad hoc
committee, the said committee shall be discharged without a vote unless
otherwise ordered.
D.   Referrals To Committees:
1.   When two (2) or more committees have jurisdiction, the board of trustees
shall decide to which committee the subject matter shall go.
2.   Standing and ad hoc committees to whom references are made shall, in all
cases, report, at least once in each month, unless further time be granted by a
vote of the board of trustees, the statement of facts with their opinions
thereon, signed by the members concurring therein. Separate or minority reports
of committee members may be rendered at the same time as majority reports or
reports of committee chairmen.
E.   Committee Reports: All reports of committees shall be addressed "To the
president and board of trustees". They shall briefly describe the matter
referred and the conclusion to which the committee has arrived; which
conclusion may be summed up in the form of an ordinance, order, resolution,
recommendation or some other distinct proposition. (1988 Code § 1-5-4; amd.
Ord. 93-6, 5-24-1993)
1-5-5: ORDINANCES:
A.   Action Upon First Proposal: No ordinance shall be acted upon at any
meeting in which the same is first proposed or introduced unless this provision
is waived by a vote of at least two-thirds (2/3) of the members of the board of
trustees, including the president. This provision shall not apply to
resolutions, orders and expenditures and in those instances where such an
ordinance is required by law to be passed by a certain date which cannot be
complied with except by a special meeting date of the board of trustees. (Ord.
89-2, 1-23-1989)
B.   Referral To Committee: All ordinances, petitions, resolutions, orders or
communications shall, at the discretion of the president or the vote of four
(4) or more trustees, be referred to the appropriate committee, board or
commission, as determined by the president, for their report and
recommendation. (1988 Code § 1-5-5)
1-5-6: BILLS, VOUCHERS; EXCEPTION:
All bills and vouchers shall be approved in writing. Each bill shall be
accompanied by a voucher made out at the direction of the village treasurer,
and together they shall be referred, with his written approval, or otherwise,
to the finance committee. Such committee shall then reexamine and rerefer all
bills thus referred to it, to the board of trustees, accompanied by the proper
voucher, approved or otherwise, and the board of trustees may call upon any
village officer or officers for information concerning bills before it. The
same shall then be ready for payment upon the requisite vote of the board of
trustees but not otherwise. This rule shall apply to all bills and expenses
incurred by the village, except for the salaries and wages of the village
officers and employees specifically provided for and which shall be paid
monthly upon such officers or employees signing the monthly payroll therefor.
Any bill or bills adversely reported by the board of trustees shall be, on
request of any two (2) trustees, referred to a special committee for a further
report thereon before the same is allowed or disallowed. (1988 Code § 1-5-6)
1-5-7: BUDGET SYSTEM:
A.   Adoption: The village hereby adopts the budget system of operation set
forth in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.1 and 5/8-2-9.2 through 5/8-2-
9.10, as amended.
B.   Effective Date: Said budget system shall take effect for the fiscal year
commencing May 1, 1992, and thereafter, until said system of operation is
terminated pursuant to law.
C.   Powers: The village and its designated officer shall have those powers
enumerated in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.2 through 5/8-2-9.10,
inclusive. (Ord. 91-17, 12-9-1991)
CHAPTER 6
OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE CLERK
SECTION:
1-6A-1: Election; Term
1-6A-2: Bond And Oath
1-6A-3: Duties
1-6A-4: Deputy Clerk
1-6A-5: Fees
1-6A-1: ELECTION; TERM:
There shall be elected at the village election in the year 1989, and biennially
thereafter, a village clerk who shall have resided within the corporate limits
of the village at least one year next preceding the election at which he is a
candidate, and who shall hold the office of village clerk for a term of two (2)
years and until a successor is elected and qualified. (1988 Code § 1-6A-1)
1-6A-2: BOND AND OATH:
The village clerk shall execute, acknowledge and deliver to the village a bond
in the penal sum of such amount determined by the board of trustees, but not
less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), in the usual form, or as is, or
shall hereafter be, provided by law, with good and sufficient surety to be
approved by the board of trustees, and the cost of the premium of said bond to
be borne by the village, said bond conditioned upon the faithful performance of
his official duties, and the village clerk shall also take the customary oath
of office before entering upon the duties of such office. (1988 Code § 1-6A-2)
1-6A-3: DUTIES:
Whenever used in this code, the term "village clerk" shall also refer to the
office of the village clerk and to the deputy village clerk and such
individuals who perform duties in the office of the village clerk. Unless
prohibited by statute, any duty of the village clerk may be performed by the
deputy village clerk or an employee in such office. It shall be the duty of the
village clerk, in addition to all other duties prescribed by law and the
ordinances of the village, to perform the following duties:
A.   Office: To maintain the office of the village clerk for the transaction of
village business at the village hall, or at such place as the board of trustees
may otherwise designate.
B.   Keep Corporate Seal: The village clerk shall keep the corporate seal in
the office of the village clerk in the village hall and affix the same to all
papers which require it.
C.   Records; Attendance At Board Meetings: The village clerk shall keep all
records and papers belonging to the village, and shall attend all meetings of
the board of trustees, and shall keep a full record of its proceedings in the
journal at the village hall.
D.   Copy Records For Court Use: The village clerk shall make copies of all
papers duly filed in the office of the village clerk and transcripts from the
journals and other records and files of his office, certified by the clerk
under the corporate seal of the village, for use in evidence in courts when
required.
E.   Election Notices: It shall be the duty of the village clerk, within five
(5) days after the result of any election is declared or appointment made, to
notify all persons elected or appointed to any village office, of their
election or appointment. This notification shall be in addition to that which
may be required of the county clerk, and shall inform the individual of the
time and place for the administration of the oath of office and the next
scheduled meeting date for the position to which the individual was appointed
or elected.
F.   Record Of Ordinances: All ordinances passed by the board of trustees shall
be recorded by the village clerk in a book to be kept for that purpose, before
the next regular meeting after their passage. The village clerk shall be
responsible for the publication in pamphlet form or otherwise, or posting of
all ordinances requiring the same. The village clerk shall note, at the end of
the record copy of each ordinance, a memorandum of the date of such publication
or posting, the date of its passage, and the date of its approval, if approved,
by the village president, and if published or posted. This record and
memorandum, or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie evidence of the
passage and publication or posting of such ordinance for all purposes
whatsoever. The original shall be filed in the office of the village clerk with
a certificate of publication attached thereto, or if posted, a certificate
under seal by the village clerk stating the same has been posted and giving the
date thereof. "Publication", as used herein, shall include publication in
pamphlet form when so ordered by the board of trustees.
G.   Tax Levy Ordinance: The village clerk shall, on or before the second
Tuesday of September of each year, file with the county clerk a certified copy
of the tax levy ordinance showing the total amount of appropriations for all
corporate purposes of the village, the levy and assessment therefor, any
resolutions for road and bridge purposes, and certification of compliance with
truth in taxation statutes of the state of Illinois.
H.   Communications To Board: All petitions, remonstrances, bids, bills or
other communications addressed to the board of trustees shall be received by
the village clerk and read by the village clerk at the meeting of the board of
trustees next succeeding their receipt, unless otherwise ordered by the board
of trustees.
I.   Additional Duties: The village clerk shall perform such duties as the
board of trustees may from time to time direct by resolution, order or
ordinance. (1988 Code § 1-6A-3)
1-6A-4: DEPUTY CLERK:
The village clerk may appoint, by and with the approval of the board of
trustees, a deputy village clerk who shall be empowered, in the absence of the
village clerk, to perform the duties and be invested with the powers of the
village clerk, and shall hold office for and during the term of office of the
village clerk. (1988 Code § 1-6A-4)
1-6A-5: FEES:
Unless otherwise specifically provided, the village clerk is hereby authorized
to demand and receive as fees the amounts as set out in section
1-12-3 of this title. (1988 Code § 1-6A-5; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION:
1-6B-1: Creation; Appointment; Term
1-6B-2: Bond
1-6B-3: Compensation
1-6B-4: Powers And Duties
1-6B-5: Authority As Budget Officer
1-6B-6: Removal From Position
1-6B-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
A.   There is hereby created the office of village administrator, which officer
shall be appointed by a two- thirds (2/3) majority vote of the board of
trustees for an indefinite term. The village administrator shall be chosen by
the board of trustees who shall consider the appointee's executive and
administrative qualifications with special reference to actual experience in or
knowledge of accepted practice in respect to the duties of office hereinafter
set forth. At the time of such appointment, the village administrator need not
be a resident of the village, but shall move into and, during the tenure of the
village administrator, shall reside within the village. No trustee shall
receive such appointment while serving in that capacity.
B.   Except for the purpose of inquiry, the board of trustees and its members
shall deal with the administrative personnel solely through the village
administrator. (1988 Code § 1-6B-1)
1-6B-2: BOND:
The village administrator shall furnish a surety bond in the penal sum of such
amount determined by the board of trustees, but not less than ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00), to be approved by the board of trustees, said bond to be
conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of the village
administrator. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the village. (1988 Code
§ 1-6B-2)
1-6B-3: COMPENSATION:
The village administrator shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed
from time to time by the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-6B-3)
1-6B-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The village administrator shall be the chief administrative officer of the
village. The village administrator may head one or more departments and shall
be responsible to the board of trustees for the proper administration of all
affairs of the village. To that end, the village administrator shall have power
and shall be required to:
A.   Employees; Contract Employees: Appoint, establish contract terms if any
for, and when necessary in the interests of the village, suspend or remove any
employee of the village; provided further, that the village administrator may
authorize the head of a subordinate department or office to appoint, suspend,
or remove subordinates in such department or office.
B.   Officers; Other Board Appointed Positions: Recommend to the board of
trustees the appointment, annual compensation, contract terms if any,
suspension, or removal of the following: 1) all officers of the village,
including, without limitation, the offices of the deputy village administrator,
village attorney, village treasurer, chief of police, fire chief, director of
public works, health officer, plumbing inspector, building commissioner,
building inspector, coordinator of ESDA, director of finance, and any other
officers that are by village ordinance or other applicable law to be appointed
upon recommendation of the village administrator by the board of trustees or
its president and 2) the position of deputy chief of police, which is a
contract employee position. (Ord. 2014-4, 2-24-2014)
C.   Prepare Budget: Prepare the budget annually and submit same to the board
of trustees by April 15 of each year, together with a message describing the
important features and be responsible for its administration after adoption.
D.   Financial Report: Prepare and submit to the board of trustees as of the
end of the fiscal year, a complete report on the finances and administrative
activities of the village for the preceding year.
E.   Advise Board Of Financial Condition: Keep the board of trustees advised of
the financial condition and future needs of the village, and make such
recommendations as he may deem desirable.
F.   Pay Schedules: Recommend to the board of trustees a standard schedule of
pay for each appointive office and position in the village service, including
minimum, intermediate and maximum rates.
G.   Recommend Measures For Improvement: Recommend to the board of trustees
from time to time adoption of such measures as the village administrator may
deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety or welfare of the community
or for the improvement of administrative services.
H.   Consolidate Offices: Consolidate or combine offices, positions,
departments or units under his jurisdiction, with the approval of the board of
trustees.
I.   Attend Meetings: Attend all meetings of the board of trustees, unless
excused therefrom, and take part in the discussion of all matters coming before
the board of trustees. The village administrator shall be entitled to notice of
all regular and special meetings of the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-6B-4)
J.   Purchase Of Materials: Supervise the purchase of all materials, supplies
and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget; let contracts
necessary for operation or maintenance of village services and purchases of
materials, supplies and equipment pursuant to the "Village Of Lake Bluff
Purchasing Policies And Procedures Manual", as amended from time to time, for
amounts up to and including the limits set forth in the purchasing policies and
procedures manual; receive sealed bids for purchases in excess of the limits
set forth in the purchasing policies and procedures manual, and present them to
the board of trustees for consideration; and advise the board of trustees on
the advantages and/or disadvantages of contract and bid proposals. No purchase
shall be made, contract let, or obligation incurred for any item or service
which exceeds the current budget without a budget amendment approved by the
board of trustees. No contract in excess of the limits set forth in the
purchasing policies and procedures manual shall be let except by the board of
trustees. The village administrator may issue such rules governing purchasing
procedures within the administrative organization as the board of trustees
shall approve. Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary, the
village administrator may direct the payment of any and all lawful obligations
of the village pursuant to the village cash management and investment policy,
as amended from time to time. Report of such payment shall be given to the
board of trustees at the next meeting. (Ord. 2009-16, 4-27-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
K.   Enforcement Of Laws And Ordinances: See that all laws and ordinances are
duly enforced.
L.   Investigate Affairs Of Departments: Investigate the affairs of any
department or division under his jurisdiction. Investigate all complaints in
relation to matters under the jurisdiction of the village administrator
concerning the administration of the government of the village, and in regard
to service maintained by the public utilities in the village, and see that all
franchises, permits and privileges granted by the village are faithfully
observed.
M.   Perform Other Duties: Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by
the board of trustees, not inconsistent with the village ordinances. (1988 Code
§ 1-6B-4)
1-6B-5: AUTHORITY AS BUDGET OFFICER 1 :
The president and board of trustees hereby delegate authority to the village
administrator (budget officer), to delete, add to, change or create subclasses
within object classes budgeted previously within all departments and/or funds.
(Ord. 92-9, 4-27-1992)
 
Notes
1 1. See also article K of this chapter.
1-6B-6: REMOVAL FROM POSITION:
The board of trustees may remove the village administrator at any time by a
two-thirds (2/3) majority vote of its members but shall continue his/her salary
for one month following this action if said village administrator has served in
that capacity for six (6) months or more, or one-half (1/2) month's salary if
service has been for less than six (6) months, or in the event such appointment
is accompanied with an employment contract, any termination in office of the
village administrator shall be governed by the specific terms and conditions
contained in any such employment contract. (1988 Code § 1-6B-5)
ARTICLE C. DEPUTY VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION:
1-6C-1: Creation; Appointment; Term; Qualifications
1-6C-2: Bond
1-6C-3: Compensation
1-6C-4: Powers And Duties
1-6C-5: Removal From Position
1-6C-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERM; QUALIFICATIONS:
A.   Office Created: There is hereby created the office of deputy village
administrator for the village.
B.   Appointment; Term; Qualifications: The deputy village administrator shall,
upon the recommendation of the village administrator, be appointed by a two-
thirds (2/3) majority vote of the board of trustees for an indefinite term.
Said deputy administrator shall be chosen by the village administrator and
board of trustees who shall consider the appointee's executive and
administrative qualifications with special reference to actual experience in or
knowledge of accepted practice in respect to the duties of the office as
hereinafter set forth. At the time of such appointment, the deputy village
administrator need not be a resident of the village, but shall, during the
tenure in office of the deputy village administrator, move into and reside
within the village. No trustee shall receive such appointment while he is
serving in that capacity. (1988 Code § 1-6C-1)
1-6C-2: BOND:
The deputy village administrator shall furnish a surety bond in the penal sum
of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), to be approved by the board of trustees,
said bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of the duties of the
office of the deputy village administrator. The premium of the bond shall be
paid by the village. (1988 Code § 1-6C-2)
1-6C-3: COMPENSATION:
The deputy village administrator shall receive such compensation as shall be
established from time to time by the village administrator with the approval of
the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-6C-3)
1-6C-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The deputy village administrator shall be the chief deputy administrative
officer of the village. The deputy village administrator may head one or more
departments as directed by the village administrator and shall be responsible
to the village administrator and the board of trustees for the proper
administration of all affairs of the village assigned to be performed by the
deputy village administrator. To that end, the deputy village administrator
shall have power and shall be required to:
A.   Recommendations:
1.   Recommend to the village administrator the appointment, annual
compensation, and when necessary for the good of the village, the suspension or
removal of any employee of the village; provided further, he may recommend to
the village administrator to authorize the head of a subordinate department or
office to appoint, suspend or remove such department or office.
2.   Recommend to the village administrator the appointment, annual
compensation, contract terms if any, suspension, or removal of those officers
and other positions that the village administrator is responsible to recommend
under subsection 1-6B-4B of this chapter. (Ord. 2014-4, 2-24-2014)
B.   Assist Budget Preparation: Assist the village administrator in the annual
preparation of the budget and assist in its submission to the board of trustees
by April 15 of each year, together with a message describing the important
features, and be responsible to the village administrator for its
administration after adoption.
C.   Assist Financial Report: Assist the village administrator in the
preparation and submission to the board of trustees as of the end of the fiscal
year, a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the
village for the preceding year.
D.   Assist Administrator; Make Recommendations: Assist the village
administrator in keeping the board of trustees advised of the financial
condition and future needs of the village, and make such recommendations to the
village administrator as he may deem desirable.
E.   Recommend Pay Schedules: Prepare recommendations to the village
administrator for a standard schedule of pay for each appointive office and
position in the village service, including minimum, intermediate and maximum
rates.
F.   Recommend Measures For Improvement: Recommend to the village administrator
from time to time, adoption of such measures as the deputy village
administrator may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety or welfare
of the community or for the improvement of administrative services.
G.   Assist In Development Of Policies: Assist the village administrator in the
development of personnel policies, and office management plans and studies for
offices, positions, departments or units under his jurisdiction or that of the
village administrator for review and action by the board of trustees.
H.   Attend Meetings: Attend all meetings of the board of trustees as directed
by the village administrator, unless excused therefrom, and take part in the
discussion of all matters coming before the board of trustees. The deputy
village administrator shall be entitled to notice of all regular and special
meetings of the board of trustees.
I.   Assist In Purchase Of Materials:
1.   Assist the village administrator in the supervision and purchase of all
materials, supplies and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget;
let contracts necessary for operation or maintenance of village services and
purchases of materials, supplies and equipment for amounts up to and including
two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00); receive sealed bids for
purchases in excess of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) and
present them to the village administrator for action, and advise the village
administrator on the advantages or disadvantages of contract and bid proposals.
No purchase shall be made, contract let, or obligation incurred for any item or
service which exceeds the current budget appropriation without a supplemental
appropriation by the board of trustees. No contract in excess of two thousand
five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) and no contract for new construction shall be
let except by the board of trustees. The deputy village administrator shall be
guided by such rules governing purchasing procedures within the administrative
organization as the board of trustees shall approve. (1988 Code § 1-6C-4)
2.   In case of accident, disaster or other circumstances creating a public
emergency, the deputy village administrator, with approval of the village
president, or two (2) trustees, may award contracts and make purchases for the
purpose of meeting said emergency for amounts up to and including five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00), but the deputy village administrator shall promptly inform
the village administrator of his action, and shall simultaneously file promptly
with the board of trustees, a certificate showing such emergency and the
necessity for such action, together with an itemized account of all
expenditures. (1988 Code § 1-6C-5)
J.   Enforcement Of Laws: See that all laws and ordinances are duly enforced.
K.   Investigate Affairs Of Departments: Investigate the affairs of any
department or division under his jurisdiction. Investigate all complaints in
relation to matters under the jurisdiction of the deputy village administrator
or referred to him by the village administrator concerning the administration
of the government of the village, and in regard to service maintained by the
public utilities in the village, and see that all franchises, permits and
privileges granted by the village are faithfully observed.
L.   Official Duties: Devote his entire time to the discharge of his official
duties.
M.   Other Duties: Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the board
of trustees and village administrator, not inconsistent with the village
ordinances. (1988 Code § 1-6C-4)
1-6C-5: REMOVAL FROM POSITION:
The board of trustees, upon recommendation of the village administrator, may
remove the deputy village administrator at any time by a two-thirds (2/3) vote
of its members, but shall continue his salary for one month following this
action if he has served in that capacity for six (6) months or more, or one-
half (1/2) month's salary if he has served for less than six (6) months, or in
the event such appointment is accompanied with an employment contract, any
termination in office of the deputy village administrator shall be governed by
the specific terms and conditions contained in any such employment contract.
(1988 Code § 1-6C-6)
ARTICLE D. VILLAGE TREASURER
SECTION:
1-6D-1: Appointment; Term; Compensation
1-6D-2: Bond And Oath
1-6D-3: Powers And Duties
1-6D-4: Deliver Records To Successor; Violation, Penalty
1-6D-1: APPOINTMENT; TERM; COMPENSATION:
A.   Appointment; Term: There shall be appointed annually by the village
president, upon the recommendation of the village administrator and by and with
the approval of the board of trustees, a village treasurer, who shall hold his
office for one year and until his successor is appointed and qualified. The
village treasurer shall be a qualified elector of the village and shall have
resided therein at least one year next preceding the date of his appointment.
B.   Compensation: The village treasurer shall receive such compensation as
shall be established by the village administrator and approved by the board of
trustees from time to time. (1988 Code § 1-6D-1)
1-6D-2: BOND AND OATH:
The village treasurer shall execute, acknowledge and deliver to the village a
bond with good and sufficient sureties, to be approved by the board of
trustees, in such form, manner and sum as is or shall hereafter be provided by
law or by resolution of the board of trustees. The village treasurer shall also
take the customary oath of office before entering upon the duties of such
office. (1988 Code § 1-6D-2)
1-6D-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the village treasurer, in addition to the duties
prescribed by law, to perform the duties hereinafter mentioned in this article.
In the performance of such duties, the village treasurer may be assisted by
such employees required therefor as approved by the village administrator.
(1988 Code § 1-6D-3)
A.   Village Funds:
1.   Receive Monies: The village treasurer shall keep a true and accurate
account of all monies paid into the treasury, by whom, and on what account
received; pay out such sums of money as may be ordered by the board of
trustees, and only on warrants signed by the village treasurer, and
countersigned by the village administrator or deputy village administrator and
either the village president or a trustee, and in all such cases, such warrants
must state upon what particular fund they are drawn. Any bond or interest
coupon issued by the village, and due and payable, shall be considered as a
warrant duly authorized for payment by the village treasurer.
2.   Deposit, Invest Funds:
a.   The village treasurer shall deposit all monies belonging to the village,
which shall come into his hands, with a regularly designated village depository
in the appropriate fund account within forty eight (48) business hours of the
time that such monies come into his hands. Such depository shall be designated
by the board of trustees in such manner as may be required by law.
b.   No person or institution shall be designated or used as a village
depository excepting a properly organized bank doing business in the state of
Illinois, according to law.
c.   The village treasurer is authorized to invest such funds in the working
cash fund of the village in such investments as permitted by law, and to
transfer any and all interest income therefrom to the general corporate fund of
the village to the credit of such fund as directed by the board of trustees.
3.   Payments From Particular Fund: No money shall be paid by the village
treasurer upon any warrant, bond or coupon, except from the monies belonging to
the particular fund or appropriation upon which such warrant shall have been
drawn; nor shall money be transferred by the village treasurer from one fund to
another after it has been received by him, nor appropriated to any other
purpose than that for which it has been collected or paid, without a vote of
the majority of the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-6D-3-1)
B.   Records, Accounts:
1.   Books Of Accounts: The village treasurer shall keep such books of accounts
as the board of trustees or village administrator shall from time to time
direct. The books which must be kept by the village treasurer shall at all
times show the exact condition of the monies under his control, of each account
and appropriation and of all receipts and disbursements; and such books,
together with all others belonging to the village and in his custody, shall be
by him handed over to his successor. The village treasurer shall, upon receipt
of all monies, enter and appropriate the same to the credit of the several
accounts upon which such monies were paid, stating from whom they were
received. The village treasurer shall keep a separate account with each fund or
appropriation, stating at the head of each account the amount so appropriated,
and giving the several debits and credits belonging thereto.
2.   Special Assessments: The village treasurer shall also keep an account with
each special assessment under its general description and number, and said
account shall show at its head the amount assessed for public benefits and also
that for special benefits. All monies received on any special assessment shall
be held by the village treasurer as a special fund to be applied to the payment
of the improvement for which the assessment was made, and said monies shall be
used for no other purpose whatever, except as may have been provided in the
ordinance for the improvement.
3.   Balancing; Inspections; Audits:
a.   Balancing Accounts: The books of accounts provided in this article shall
be properly balanced at least once in each month, in such a manner that the
same, when so balanced, shall show the true status and condition of each and
every account therein shown.
b.   Inspections: The village treasurer shall keep all books, papers, vouchers,
warrants, documents and all other instruments in writing, appertaining to his
office, at the village hall, which said books and documents shall at all times
be open for inspection by or at the direction of the village president, board
of trustees, village clerk, village administrator or deputy village
administrator.
c.   Audits: The board of trustees shall appoint annually, prior to the
termination of each fiscal year, and also upon the expiration of the term of
office of the village treasurer, whether caused by resignation, removal from
office or otherwise, a certified public accountant or firm of certified public
accountants as an auditor to audit all books, papers, vouchers or other
documents or instruments pertaining to the office of the village treasurer for
said fiscal year or for such period as may have elapsed since the previous
audit has been made. Said auditor shall thereupon make a full and complete
report thereof to the board of trustees, and a copy of such report shall be
made available for public inspection. Such audits shall include all funds of
the village, whether maintained by the village treasurer or not. The board of
trustees may, for such cause deemed appropriate, cause interim audits to be
conducted as provided for herein. (1988 Code § 1-6D-3-2)
C.   Reports:
1.   Receipts And Disbursements: The village treasurer shall, at the end of
each and every month, and more often if required, render an account to the
board of trustees and village administrator showing all receipts and
disbursements in detail during the month, and the state or condition of every
account not closed on the village treasurer's books, the whole to be a balance
sheet and a complete abstract of the financial affairs of the village. The
village treasurer shall annually, before the second Monday of May, make out and
file with the village clerk a full and detailed account of all such receipts
and expenditures and of all transactions during the preceding fiscal year. Such
annual report shall be presented to the board of trustees and village
administrator and shall be published or posted as may be required by law.
2.   Cancel Warrants: The village treasurer shall cancel all warrants paid and
redeemed by him, and upon rendering of any monthly report, shall cause the same
to be accompanied by all warrants, duplicate receipts in detail for all monies
received, and such other vouchers as will fully and entirely cover all
transactions for the month of such report.
3.   Finance Committee Approval: Upon examination and approval by the finance
committee, the village clerk shall take charge of the village treasurer's
report, warrants and vouchers, and shall keep the same on file in the office of
the village clerk. (1988 Code § 1-6D-3-3; amd. 2009 Code)
1-6D-4: DELIVER RECORDS TO SUCCESSOR; VIOLATION, PENALTY:
Whenever the treasurer's term of office shall expire, whether caused by
resignation, removal from the village, removal from office by the village
administrator upon the approval of the board of trustees, the appointment of a
successor or other cause, it shall be the duty of such village treasurer, or
person, to at once deliver to the successor in office of the village treasurer,
or such other person as may be specially designated by the village
administrator upon approval by the board of trustees, all monies, property,
books and effects of every description in the possession of the village
treasurer, belonging to the village or appertaining to his office, and the
village treasurer shall, at once, account for and pay over to such successor or
other person so designated, all monies that he shall be accountable for, or owe
to the village, in his capacity as village treasurer. Any person who served as
village treasurer, on the expiration of the village treasurer's term of office
by any reason whatsoever, and who has violated any of the provisions of this
section, shall remain liable for all damages caused thereby, and shall further
forfeit and pay to the village a penalty of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than the maximum penalty provided in section
1-4-1 of this title for each such violation, and each day such a violation
continues shall be considered a separate violation. (1988 Code § 1-6D-4; amd.
2009 Code)
ARTICLE E. VILLAGE ATTORNEY AND VILLAGE PROSECUTOR
SECTION:
1-6E-1: Village Attorney
1-6E-2: Village Prosecutor
1-6E-1: VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
A.   Creation; Appointment; Term; Qualifications:
1.   There is hereby created the office of village attorney.
2.   The village attorney shall have the status of an independent contractor.
3.   The village attorney shall be appointed by the village president, by and
with the approval of a majority of the board of trustees.
4.   The village attorney shall hold office until his successor shall be
appointed and qualified.
5.   The village attorney shall be a regular licensed and practicing member of
the Illinois bar.
B.   Compensation: The village attorney shall be compensated in the manner
recommended by the village administrator and approved by the board of trustees.
C.   Duties: The duties of the village attorney shall include, without
limitation, the following:
1.   Provide advice to the village president and board of trustees, committees
thereof, the village administrator and officers of the village on legal
questions.
2.   Attend all regular meetings of the board of trustees.
3.   Render legal opinions on questions submitted.
4.   Draft ordinances and legal documents on behalf of the village; provided,
however, that no such drafting shall commence without the authorization of the
village president, the village administrator, or three (3) or more of the
members of the board of trustees.
5.   Appear for and defend the village in all suits at law or in chancery to
which it may be a party, and perform such other duties on behalf of the village
as pertains to the office.
D.   Removal: The board of trustees may remove the village attorney at any time
by and with the approval of a two-thirds (2/3) majority vote of the members of
the board of trustees. (Ord. 93-2, 2-8-1993; amd. 2009 Code)
1-6E-2: VILLAGE PROSECUTOR:
A.   Creation; Appointment; Term; Qualifications:
1.   There is hereby created the office of village prosecutor.
2.   The village prosecutor shall have the status of an independent contractor.
3.   The village prosecutor shall be appointed by the village president, by and
with the approval of a majority of the board of trustees.
4.   The village prosecutor shall hold office until his successor shall be
appointed and qualified.
5.   The village prosecutor shall be a regular licensed and practicing member
of the Illinois bar.
