1-12-4: PAYMENT OF FEES, CHARGES AND RATES:
A.   Payment Period: All fees, service charges, charges, rates or similar
impositions (collectively referred to as "fees") required to be paid pursuant
to this Code shall be fully paid and satisfied within thirty (30) days after
the Village request for payment is made by invoice or otherwise. In the event
that a shorter or longer payment period is expressly stated in this Code or
otherwise established by the Village with respect to a specific fee, such
shorter or longer payment period shall govern for that specific fee.
B.   Failure To Pay: The failure to pay any fee within the applicable time
period for payment shall:
1.   Constitute an offense by the party applying for the service, permit or
matter for which the fee is imposed; and
2.   Constitute an offense by the user of the service, permit or matter for
which the fee is imposed; and
3.   Constitute a lien on the real property, if any, to or upon which the
service, permit or matter is applied or used; provided, however, that:
a.   The Village Administrator shall file, or cause to be filed, a notice of
such lien in the Office of the County Recorder of Deeds, or Registrar of Titles
if the property is registered under the Torrens system, which notice shall
consist of a sworn statement setting out:
(1)   A legal or other description of the property sufficient for the
identification thereof;
(2)   The amount of the money due;
(3)   The date when such amount became due;
(4)   Notice that costs of collection, including attorney fees, will be added
to the unpaid amount; and
b.   No less than ten (10) days prior to the filing of the notice of lien, the
Village Administrator shall mail, or cause to be mailed, by certified mail,
return receipt requested, a copy of the notice of lien to the current or last
known owner of the property.
c.   Any lien filed pursuant to this section may be foreclosed in the manner
provided by statute for mortgages or mechanics' liens. (2009 Code)
TITLE 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
BOARD OF HEALTH
SECTION:
2-1-1: Creation; Composition; Appointment And Term; Compensation
2-1-2: Meetings
2-1-3: Health Officer
2-1-4: Secretary
2-1-5: Powers And Duties
2-1-6: Violation
2-1-1: CREATION; COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT AND TERM; COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created and established a board of health in and for the
village, which board shall consist of three (3) members appointed by the
village president, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees.
One of such members shall be the health officer of the village who shall act as
president of the board of health. Each such member shall hold office for a term
of one year, and until their successors shall be appointed and qualified. All
members of the board of health shall serve without compensation. (1988 Code §
2-1-1)
2-1-2: MEETINGS:
Meetings of the board of health may be called by the president of said board,
who shall designate the time and place of such meetings. Meetings of said board
of health may also be called by the village president, who shall designate the
time and place of such meetings, or by a written notice signed by the other two
(2) members of said board of health, which notice shall state the time and
place of such meetings and the purpose for which they are called. (1988 Code §
2-1-2)
2-1-3: HEALTH OFFICER:
The health officer shall be a physician licensed by the state, appointed by the
village president, with the approval of the board of trustees, and shall hold
said office until the health officer's successor is duly appointed and
qualified. (1988 Code § 2-1-3)
2-1-4: SECRETARY:
A.   Appointment: The president shall designate one of the other two (2)
members of the board to act as secretary for the board.
B.   Duties: The secretary shall attend all meetings of the board of health,
shall keep a record, in a book provided for that purpose, of all minutes and
all business transacted by the board of health, and shall perform such other
duties as the board of trustees may direct. All official books, records and
minutes shall be maintained in the village hall, and copies of minutes of all
meetings shall be turned over to the village clerk after their preparation and
approval. To assist in such duties, the board may employ the services of a
stenographer at such compensation approved by the village administrator. Such
employment shall not relieve the secretary of the duties set forth herein.
(1988 Code § 2-1-4)
2-1-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of health shall have the powers and perform the duties assigned to it
by statute or ordinance and shall act in all cases within its jurisdiction when
other health agencies possessing similar power and authority are unable or
unwilling to act. The board of health shall have power to make such rules and
regulations and to employ such measures as are necessary, including the posting
of notices, to promote the health, cleanliness and sanitation of the village,
and to prevent, restrict and suppress communicable diseases. For the purpose of
carrying out the provisions of this chapter, the members of the board of health
and its officers, or any of them, with proper authority, shall be permitted to
enter, at any reasonable hour, any premises, store, house, stable, manufactory
or other buildings, and the board members, or any of them, shall have the right
to arrest or cause to be arrested any persons who violate any of the provisions
of this chapter. (1988 Code § 2-1-5)
2-1-6: VIOLATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or refuse to obey any order of
the board of health or to destroy, mutilate or conceal any notice posted by or
under the authority of said board. (1988 Code § 2-1-6)
CHAPTER 2
BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
2-2-1: Membership; Compensation
2-2-2: Powers And Duties
2-2-3: Secretary
2-2-1: MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION:
The members of the village board of trustees shall act as members of the board
of local improvements of the village, unless hereinafter provided by ordinance.
Said members, together with the village president, shall constitute the members
of the board of local improvements of the village. The village president shall
act as president of the board of local improvements. All members of the board
of local improvements shall serve without compensation. (1988 Code § 2-2-1)
2-2-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of local improvements shall be responsible for the administration of
the construction of local improvements as set forth in the Illinois statutes
and shall, when directed by the board of trustees, perform such duties and
responsibilities as directed and as set forth in any local improvements
ordinance. (1988 Code § 2-2-2)
2-2-3: SECRETARY:
A.   Designated: The village clerk shall act as secretary of the board of local
improvements for the village.
B.   Records Of Business: The secretary shall record, in a book to be kept for
that purpose, before the next regular meeting after their passage, all
estimates and resolutions passed by the board of local improvements, and a
record of all business transacted by the board of local improvements.
C.   Communications: All petitions, remonstrances, bids, bills or other
communications addressed to the board of local improvements shall be received
by the secretary and read by the secretary at the meeting of the board of local
improvements next succeeding the receipt thereof by the secretary unless
otherwise ordered by said board.
D.   Notification Of Meetings: It shall be the duty of the secretary to notify
the village president and all members of the board of local improvements of all
special, called or adjourned meetings.
E.   Custodian Of Records: The secretary shall be the custodian and keeper of
all the books, records, estimates, resolutions and papers of the board of local
improvements, except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance. (1988 Code § 2-
2-3; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 3
PLAN COMMISSION 1
(Rep. by Ord. 2012-10, 4-9-2012, eff. 5-1-2012)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 5 of this title.
CHAPTER 4
ARCHITECTURAL BOARD OF REVIEW
SECTION:
2-4-1: Established; Composition; Appointment And Term; Quorum; Compensation
2-4-2: Meetings
2-4-3: Vacancies
2-4-4: Powers And Duties
2-4-5: Secretary; Records
2-4-1: ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT AND TERM; QUORUM; COMPENSATION:
There is hereby established an architectural board of review for the village.
The board shall consist of seven (7) members, to be appointed by the village
president, subject to the confirmation by the board of trustees. Each such
member shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years of staggered terms. The
president shall designate the chair of the board from the membership thereof. A
majority of the members appointed to the architectural board of review must be
either architects duly licensed by the state of Illinois or, if sufficient
number of licensed architects are not available to serve, a combination of
licensed architects and otherwise qualified design professionals. For purpose
of a quorum, or acting upon any matter properly before the board, any four (4)
members shall constitute a quorum. The building commissioner shall be an ex
officio member of the architectural board of review, and all members shall
serve without compensation. (Ord. 93-6, 5-24-1993; amd. Ord. 2022-4, 1-24-2022)
2-4-2: MEETINGS:
Whenever any business is pending before the architectural board of review, they
shall meet on the fourth Tuesday in each month, commencing at the hour of seven
forty five o'clock (7:45) P.M., in the board room, village hall. Special
meetings of the architectural board of review shall be held on call of the
chair of the board, provided notice required by law is given of such a public
meeting. (1988 Code § 2-4-2)
2-4-3: VACANCIES:
In the event of the death, resignation, retirement or inability of any
architect to serve as a member of the architectural board of review, following
appointment, notwithstanding the requirement of a majority of architects on
said board, during the period of time until a successor or successors are
appointed, the remaining members of the board may act on any matter with full
authority, provided a quorum of those who are members of said board are
present. (1988 Code § 2-4-3)
2-4-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The architectural board of review shall also function as an architectural board
of appeals. The architectural board of review shall have those powers as
provided by the ordinances of the village heretofore and hereinafter enacted,
including powers granted to the architectural board of appeals. (1988 Code § 2-
4-4)
2-4-5: SECRETARY; RECORDS:
A.   The village administrator or his designee shall serve as secretary to the
architectural board of review. The secretary shall keep minutes of all
proceedings, record the vote of each member upon every question and all
findings of fact and keep all records of the architectural board of review. To
assist in such duties, the architectural board of review may employ the
services of a stenographer at such compensation approved by the village
administrator.
B.   All official books, records and minutes shall be maintained in the village
hall, and copies of minutes of all meetings shall be turned over to the village
clerk after their preparation and approval. (1988 Code § 2-4-5)
CHAPTER 5
JOINT PLAN COMMISSION AND ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS ("PCZBA")
SECTION:
2-5-1: Creation; Appointment; Terms Of Office; Chair; Compensation
2-5-2: Duties
2-5-3: Rules Of Procedure
2-5-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERMS OF OFFICE; CHAIR; COMPENSATION:
A.   Creation; Appointment: The joint plan commission and zoning board of
appeals ("PCZBA") is hereby created. The PCZBA shall have seven (7) members,
except that, as of the May 1, 2012 effective date of this amendatory provision,
the initial members of the PCZBA shall be the thirteen (13) then current
members of the plan commission and zoning board of appeals. Upon the
resignation of an initial member of the PCZBA or the expiration of that initial
member's term, no further members will be appointed to the PCZBA unless such
appointment is necessary for the PCZBA to have seven (7) members.
B.   Terms Of Office: Each initial PCZBA member shall serve for the remainder
of that member's then current term with the plan commission or zoning board of
appeals. All subsequent terms of PCZBA members shall be for three (3) years.
C.   Chair; Vice Chair: One PCZBA member shall be designated as chair and one
PCZBA member shall be designated as vice chair by the village president. The
initial PCZBA chair shall be the then current chair of the zoning board of
appeals.
D.   No Compensation: All PCZBA members shall serve without compensation. (Ord.
2012-10, 4-9-2012, eff. 5-1-2012)
2-5-2: DUTIES:
A.   The PCZBA shall have all the duties and responsibilities specified in this
code, including, without limitation, to hear and decide any appeal from an
order, decision, or interpretation of the administrative officer charged with
enforcement of, or any matter referred thereto or upon which it is required to
pass, under title 10 of this code.
B.   Any reference in this code to the plan commission or the zoning board of
appeals shall be construed as a reference to the PCZBA, and any duties and
responsibilities of the plan commission and the zoning board of appeals
described in this code shall be considered duties of the PCZBA. (Ord. 2012-10,
4-9-2012, eff. 5-1-2012)
2-5-3: RULES OF PROCEDURE:
A.   Chair: The chair shall preside at all public hearings and meetings of the
PCZBA. In the chair's absence, the vice chair shall perform the functions of
the chair.
B.   Secretary; Records:
1.   The village administrator or his designee shall serve as the secretary to
the PCZBA. The secretary shall keep minutes of all proceedings, record the vote
of each member, the absence or failure to vote of any member and records of
hearings and other official actions. In the absence of the secretary of the
PCZBA, the village clerk or deputy village clerk shall have the duties of the
secretary under this section.
2.   All records of the PCZBA shall be kept in the office of the village clerk
and shall be public records.
C.   Minutes: Minutes of the PCZBA will be considered for approval by the PCZBA
at the next available meeting after their preparation.
D.   Meetings:
1.   Time And Place: PCZBA meetings shall be held on the third Wednesday in
each month commencing at the hour of seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. in the board
room, village hall, and at such other times and places as may be called by the
chair, and at such other times as the PCZBA shall determine, upon proper notice
pursuant to the open meetings act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/1 et seq.
2.   Quorum: A quorum of the PCZBA shall consist of four (4) members.
E.   Appeals; Time For Filing: Appeals from orders or decisions based on the
zoning regulations may be taken to the PCZBA by any person aggrieved or by any
officer or department of the village. Such appeal shall be filed in duplicate
with the secretary of the PCZBA within forty five (45) days from the order or
decision, and one copy thereof shall be filed with the officer or department
whose decision or order is being appealed. The notice of appeal shall specify
the particular grounds for the appeal. Upon receipt of the appeal, the officer
or department from whom the appeal is taken shall transmit to the PCZBA the
record concerning the decision which is being appealed.
F.   Fees: A filing fee as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, shall be delivered to the village at the time of the
filing of the application.
G.   Stay Of Proceedings: An appeal to the PCZBA stays all proceedings
concerning the action appealed from, unless the village determines that such
stay would cause imminent harm to the public health, safety, or welfare, in
which case the proceedings shall not be stayed unless the circuit court enjoins
the proceedings.
H.   Hearing On Appeals: Appeals shall be set for hearing within a reasonable
time from the date of filing of a notice of appeal, upon due notice being given
to the parties, as well as any and all required notice by publication and to
property owners within two hundred fifty feet (250') in all directions,
excluding public ways, streets, roads, alleys and the like, of the premises at
issue. Such hearing may be continued from time to time by direction of the
PCZBA. Upon the hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or by
attorney. Within a reasonable time following the completion of hearings, the
PCZBA shall complete its consideration of the appeal by reversing, affirming,
or modifying, in whole or in part, the order, requirement, decision or
determination appealed from, and to that end has all the powers of the officer
from whom the appeal is taken.
I.   Procedure At Hearings: The PCZBA may adopt rules of procedure to govern
its hearings.
J.   Final Decisions Subject To Review: All final administrative decisions of
the PCZBA shall be subject to review under the Illinois administrative review
act, 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq. (Ord. 2012-10, 4-9-2012,
eff. 5-1-2012)
CHAPTER 6
FIRE INSURANCE BOARD
SECTION:
2-6-1: Purpose
2-6-2: Creation; Composition; Term Of Office; Vacancies; Compensation
2-6-3: Disposition Of Proceeds
2-6-4: Powers And Duties
2-6-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish procedures and standards for the
management and administration of foreign fire insurance taxes collected by the
village pursuant to title 1, chapter 8, article F of this code and 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-1 and 5/11-10-2. (Ord. 93-13, 7-26-1993)
2-6-2: CREATION; COMPOSITION; TERM OF OFFICE; VACANCIES; COMPENSATION:
A.   Creation; Composition; Officers: There is hereby created for the village a
fire insurance board consisting of three (3) members. The fire chief shall
serve as a member of the board and shall be the president of the board. The
other two (2) members of the board shall be elected by the members of the fire
department from among themselves to serve as treasurer and secretary of the
board.
B.   Term Of Office; Vacancies: The members so elected from the department
shall serve for a term of one year. No member shall hold any office after
termination or resignation from the fire department. Any vacancy that may occur
as a result of a member leaving office or expiration of a term of office that
has not been filled by election shall be filled for the balance of the
unexpired term by appointment of the fire chief.
C.   Compensation: All members of the board shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 93-13, 7-26-1993)
2-6-3: DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS:
The village treasurer shall receive the monies paid to the village in
accordance with title 1, chapter 8, article F of this code and shall pay to the
treasurer of the fire insurance board all such monies into an account
designated as the "foreign fire insurance account". (Ord. 93-13, 7-26-1993)
2-6-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A.   Generally: The fire insurance board shall have the power to administer and
to enter into contracts and agreements for the expenditure of monies from the
foreign fire insurance account for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the
fire department. All actions of the fire insurance board shall be in accordance
with the standards for the foreign fire insurance account established by this
section and all other requirements provided by law.
B.   Foreign Fire Insurance Account: The foreign fire insurance account shall
be administered in accordance with the following standards:
1.   Use Of Funds: Expenditures may be made for furthering the training,
safety, health, welfare, morale and recruitment of members as well as for the
purchase of firefighting equipment. Any firefighting equipment purchased with
monies from the account shall thereupon become the property of the village.
Monies from the account shall not be used for the personal benefit of any
person; or for any person's use or function not directly related to
maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department. The fire insurance board,
upon a majority vote, shall refuse any request for expenditure of funds from
the account made by a majority of the members of the fire department if it does
not meet the requirements of this code or other requirements provided by law.
The fire insurance board shall not enter into any contract or agreement
obligating expenditures from the foreign fire insurance account in excess of
the amount of monies currently on deposit in and currently available for use
from the account.
2.   Designation Of Uses:
a.   Meeting Required; Notice: The fire insurance board shall authorize the
expenditure of money from the foreign fire insurance account only at a meeting
conducted at the fire department building and open to all members of the fire
department. Notice of each such meeting shall be given at least forty eight
(48) hours in advance of such meeting by posting notice thereof in a prominent
location at the fire department building.
b.   Necessary Vote: An affirmative vote of a majority of the fire department
members present at any duly noticed meeting shall be required to authorize any
expenditure of money from the foreign fire insurance account by the fire
insurance board.
3.   Payouts: All checks or other withdrawals from the account shall be signed
by the fire insurance board treasurer and fire chief.
4.   Investment Of Funds: Foreign fire insurance tax monies shall be deposited
only in one or more of the following: checking account, interest bearing
savings account, or interest bearing time deposit of any bank insured by the
banking insurance fund of the FDIC. Total deposits in any one bank may not
exceed the FDIC insured limits.
5.   Records:
a.   The fire insurance board treasurer shall keep accurate and current records
of the foreign fire insurance account, including all deposits thereto,
withdrawals or disbursements therefrom, balances and the like.
b.   The fire insurance board secretary shall keep accurate and current minutes
of the meetings conducted by and decisions made by the officers of the fire
insurance board related to the foreign fire insurance account. (Ord. 93-13, 7-
26-1993)
6.   Reports And Audits: The fire insurance board treasurer shall report on the
expenditures and balance of the funds to the members of the board and the fire
department at the monthly meeting or at any special meeting called by the fire
insurance board. The treasurer shall remit a detailed list of the withdrawals,
deposits, balance and a copy of the bank statement to the director of finance
within forty five (45) days after the end of each month. The foreign fire
insurance account shall be subject to review during the annual independent
audit of village funds to be conducted after the end of each fiscal year and
during any special audits of village funds that may be conducted from time to
time. (Ord. 93-13, 7-26-1993; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 7
EMERGENCY DISASTER SERVICE AGENCY
SECTION:
2-7-1: Department Established
2-7-2: Purpose
2-7-3: Organization
2-7-4: Coordinator
2-7-5: Mobile Support Teams
2-7-6: Mutual Aid
2-7-7: Emergency Action
2-7-8: Compensation
2-7-9: Reimbursement Of Expenses
2-7-10: Purchases And Expenditures
2-7-11: Oath Of Office
2-7-12: Office Facilities
2-7-13: Appropriations And Tax Levies
2-7-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created and established a department of the municipal
government of the village to be known as the Lake Bluff emergency disaster
service agency (LBEDSA). (1988 Code § 8-3A-1)
2-7-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of LBEDSA shall be to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate
injury or damage resulting from hostile action, or from natural or manmade
disasters, in accordance with the Illinois emergency management agency act of
1992, as amended 1 . (1988 Code § 8-3A-2)
 
Notes
1 1. 20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.
2-7-3: ORGANIZATION:
The LBEDSA of the village shall consist of a coordinator, and such additional
members as may be authorized by the village, and thereafter selected by the
coordinator. (1988 Code § 8-3A-3)
2-7-4: COORDINATOR:
A.   Appointment: The coordinator of the LBEDSA shall be appointed by the
village president and confirmed by the other members of the board of trustees,
and shall serve during the pleasure of the entire board of trustees. (1988 Code
§ 8-3A-4)
B.   Duties:
1.   The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization,
administration, training and operation of the LBEDSA, subject to the direction
and control of the village president, as provided by the village ordinances in
such cases made and provided.
2.   In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability of the
coordinator to serve, the village president, or any person designated by said
president shall be and act as director until a new appointment is made as
provided in this chapter. (1988 Code § 8-3A-5)
C.   Additional Duties: The LBEDSA shall perform such emergency management
functions within the village as shall be prescribed in and by the state IEMA
plan and program prepared by the governor, and such orders, rules and
regulations as may be promulgated by the governor, and in addition, shall
perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to
any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality,
or, quasi-municipality entered into as provided in the Illinois emergency
management agency act of 1992, as amended. (1988 Code § 8-3A-6)
2-7-5: MOBILE SUPPORT TEAMS:
A.   Designation: All or any members of the LBEDSA organization may be
designated as members of a mobile support team created by the director of the
state Illinois emergency management agency (IEMA) as provided by law.
B.   Leader: The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the
coordinator of the LBEDSA organization.
C.   Compensation: Any member of a mobile support team who is a village
employee or officer while serving on call to duty by the governor or the state
director shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and
immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a
paid officer or employee of the village, while so serving, shall receive from
the state, reasonable compensation as provided by law. (1988 Code § 8-3A-7)
2-7-6: MUTUAL AID:
The coordinator of LBEDSA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other cities
or political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be
effective until it has been approved by the president and board of trustees of
the village and by the state director of IEMA. (1988 Code § 8-3A-8)
2-7-7: EMERGENCY ACTION:
If the governor of Illinois proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the
event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within
the state of Illinois of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or
other hostile action, or from manmade or natural disaster, it shall be the duty
of the LBEDSA to cooperate fully with the state IEMA and with the governor in
the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. (1988 Code § 8-3A-9)
2-7-8: COMPENSATION:
Members of the LBEDSA who are paid employees or officers of the village, if
called for training by the state director of IEMA, shall receive for the time
spent in such training, the same rate of pay as is attached to the position
held; members who are not such village employees or officers shall receive for
such training time, such compensation as may be established from time to time
by the president and board of trustees of the village. (1988 Code § 8-3A-10)
2-7-9: REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENSES:
The village treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund, any
reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training
members of the LBEDSA as prescribed by the state director of IEMA, compensation
for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving
outside the village in response to a call by the governor or state director of
IEMA, as provided by law, and any other reimbursement made by the state
incident to LBEDSA activities as provided by law. (1988 Code § 8-3A-11)
2-7-10: PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES:
A.   Contracts: The village president may, on recommendation of the village
coordinator of LBEDSA, authorize any purchases or contracts necessary to place
the village in a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the
explosion of any nuclear or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public
health and safety, protect property and provide emergency assistance to victims
in the case of such disaster, or from manmade or natural disaster.
B.   Materials: In the event of enemy caused or other disaster, the coordinator
of LBEDSA is authorized, on behalf of the village, to procure such services,
supplies, equipment, or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view
of the exigency without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities
normally prescribed by law pertaining to village contracts or obligations, as
authorized by the Illinois emergency management agency act of 1992, as amended;
provided, that if the village board meets at such time, the coordinator shall
act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. (1988 Code
§ 8-3A-12)
2-7-11: OATH OF OFFICE:
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the LBEDSA organization
shall, before entering upon his or her duties, subscribe to the following oath,
which shall be filed with the coordinator:
I,        , do solemnly swear (or affirm), that I will support and defend and
bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the
Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions, and
facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and
domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or
purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties
upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do
not advocate nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or
organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United
States or of this State by force or violence; and that during such time as I am
affiliated with the Lake Bluff Emergency Disaster Service Agency organization,
I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization
that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of the
State of Illinois by force or violence.
(1988 Code § 8-3A-13)
2-7-12: OFFICE FACILITIES:
The village president is authorized to designate space in a village building or
elsewhere, as may be provided by the village president, for the LBEDSA as its
office. (1988 Code § 8-3A-14)
2-7-13: APPROPRIATIONS AND TAX LEVIES:
The president and board of trustees may make an appropriation for LBEDSA
purposes in the manner provided by law and may levy, in addition, for LBEDSA
purposes only, a tax as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "taxes", which said tax shall be in
addition to all other taxes, as provided by the Illinois emergency management
agency act of 1992, as amended. (1988 Code § 8-3A-15; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 8
ATTENDANCE OF COMMISSION MEMBERS
SECTION:
2-8-1: Automatic Resignation For Repeated Absences
2-8-2: Definitions
2-8-3: Written Warning Notice
2-8-4: Effective Date Of Resignation And Vacancy
2-8-5: Determination Of "Valid Reason"
2-8-1: AUTOMATIC RESIGNATION FOR REPEATED ABSENCES:
Any member of a commission who, for no valid reason, is absent from, or fails
to attend, either: a) three (3) consecutive meetings of the applicable
commission, or b) at least sixty five percent (65%) of the total of all
meetings of the applicable commission commenced during any one year period,
shall, effective as of the date set forth in section
2-8-4 of this chapter, be deemed to have resigned from the commission and that
member's office shall, automatically and without further action, be deemed to
be vacant as of such date. (Ord. 2012-18, 8-13-2012)
2-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter:
COMMISSION: Any board, commission, committee or other group whose members are
appointed by the village president or the village board.
ONE YEAR PERIOD: January through the following December 31.
VALID REASON: Only as determined by the village board in accordance with
section
2-8-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 2012-18, 8-13-2012)
2-8-3: WRITTEN WARNING NOTICE:
The village administrator, or his designee, shall, prior to the next regularly
scheduled meeting of the applicable commission, deliver a written warning
notice to any member who, by failing to attend any future regular or special
meeting of the commission during the remainder of the applicable year, is at
risk of automatic removal pursuant to section
2-8-1 of this chapter. The failure of a member to receive such written notice
shall not constitute a valid reason for absence from a meeting. (Ord. 2012-18,
8-13-2012)
2-8-4: EFFECTIVE DATE OF RESIGNATION AND VACANCY:
The member's resignation, and the vacancy of the member's office, shall be
effective on the date that is ten (10) days after the date of the final absence
that triggers the removal action set forth in section
2-8-1 of this chapter, unless a timely request for a determination of "valid
reason" has been filed pursuant to section
2-8-5 of this chapter, in which case the resignation and vacancy shall be
effective upon final resolution of such request. (Ord. 2012-18, 8-13-2012)
2-8-5: DETERMINATION OF "VALID REASON":
Except for excused absences as described in subsection C of this section, the
determination of a "valid reason" for a member to be absent from, or fail to
attend, an applicable commission meeting shall be made only by the village
board, by a majority vote of those present and voting at a regular or special
meeting of the village board. The decision of the village board shall be final
and binding.
A.   Preabsence Determination: A member shall have the right to request that
the village board determine, in advance of an anticipated absence, whether a
valid reason exists for such absence. Such request shall be made in writing and
delivered to the village administrator at least seven (7) days prior to the
village board meeting.
B.   Postabsence Determination: A member shall have the right, within ten (10)
days after the occurrence of any absence, to request that the village board
determine whether a valid reason existed for that particular absence. Such
request shall be made in writing and delivered to the village administrator at
least seven (7) days prior to the village board meeting.
C.   Excused Absences: The village board will presume that a valid reason for
an absence exists when the member's request demonstrates that the absence is an
excused absence due to: 1) personal illness or disability, 2) employment
purposes or the business of the public body, or 3) a family or other emergency,
unless the village board determines within two (2) board meetings after receipt
of the request that the member did not demonstrate an excused absence pursuant
to this subsection. (Ord. 2012-18, 8-13-2012)
CHAPTER 9
HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-9-1: Creation; Appointment; Terms Of Office; Chair; Compensation
2-9-2: Duties
2-9-3: Procedure
2-9-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERMS OF OFFICE; CHAIR; COMPENSATION:
A.   Creation; Purpose. There is hereby created the Lake Bluff Historic
Preservation Commission. The purpose of the Commission is to assist the Village
Board in making decisions and establishing policies regarding the preservation,
protection, enhancement, rehabilitation, reconstruction, maintenance, and use
of historic structures, buildings, sites, and landscapes in the Village, and to
educate Village residents on the importance of historic preservation, all as
further provided in this chapter.
B.   Appointment; Qualifications. The Commission consists of seven members
appointed by the Village President, with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. The Village President will attempt to appoint to the Commission at
least one person each from the board of the Lake Bluff History Museum, the
Joint Plan Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals, and the Architectural Board
of Review, and three Village residents. Commissioners are appointed on the
basis of expertise, experience, and interest in historic preservation,
architectural history, building construction and engineering, finance,
neighborhood organization, and real estate development. Consideration is to be
given to appointment of residents from a variety of geographic areas within the
Village.
C.   Terms of Office. Commissioners serve for a term of four years and until
their successors have been appointed and have qualified for office.
Commissioners are eligible for reappointment. The Village Board has the power
to remove any commissioner for cause. Any vacancy that may occur will be filled
for the balance of the unexpired term by appointment by the Village President,
with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
D.   Chair. The Village President, with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees, will designate one Commissioner as Chairperson.
E.   No Compensation. All members serve without compensation. (Ord. 2022-10, 3-
28-2022)
2-9-2: DUTIES:
Subject to the laws of the State of Illinois, this chapter, and any other
ordinances and resolutions of the Village, the Commission has the following
powers and duties:
A.   To perform those functions set forth in the Village’s Historic
Preservation Regulations, as codified in Title 9, Chapter 14 of the Municipal
Code.
B.   To inform and educate the residents of the Village concerning the historic
and architectural heritage of the Village by preparing appropriate publications
and by conducting programs and seminars.
C.   To provide information and assistance concerning the preparation of any
application set forth in the Village’s Historic Preservation Regulations, or
any application for a State or Federal program or designation concerning
historic preservation.
D.   For Protected Features pursuant to the Historic Preservation Regulations,
to seek designation of “historic buildings” with the Illinois Historic
Preservation Agency and the United States Department of the Interior under the
Illinois Property Tax Code, 35 ILCS 200/1-1 et seq., or as “certified historic
structures” under the Tax Reform Act of 1986, 26 USC section 1 et seq., or
under other legislation subsequently enacted by the State of Illinois or the
United States.
E.   To develop and maintain technical information relating to historic
preservation, rehabilitation, and restoration, and to provide assistance
relating to such matters to architects, contractors, property owners, and other
persons involved in real estate development and construction within the
Village.
F.   Upon referral by the Building Commissioner or another Village board or
commission, to review and provide recommendations regarding any application for
subdivision, site plan approval, or other zoning relief that may involve
historic preservation considerations; provided that the Commission’s
recommendation is not a prerequisite to the consideration, approval, or denial
of said applications.
G.   To study and make recommendations to the Village Board of Trustees other
desirable changes to Village rules, regulations, and policies to promote
historic preservation within the Village, including without limitation changes
to the Village’s building, subdivision, or zoning regulations or the fees
charged for development.
H.   To submit an annual report to the Village Board of Trustees summarizing
the Commission’s activities during the preceding year and reviewing current
preservation issues in the Village.
I.   To seek certified local government status from the United States
Department of the Interior for purposes of qualifying for financial and other
assistance available through the Department of the Interior and other sources.
J.   To perform such other functions as directed by the Village Board of
Trustees, including those functions provided in 65 ILCS 5/11-48.2 not otherwise
provided for in the Historic Preservation Regulations. (Ord. 2022-10, 3-28-
2022)
2-9-3: PROCEDURE:
A.   Meeting Schedule. Commission meetings are held on the second Wednesday of
each month commencing at the hour of 7:00 P.M. in the Board Room of Village
Hall, and at such other times and places as may be called by the Chairperson,
and at such other times as the Commission may determine, upon proper notice
pursuant to the Open Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/).
B.   Presiding Officer. The Chairperson will preside over all meetings and
hearings of the Commission. In the absence of the Chairperson, a temporary
Chairperson (or chair pro-tempore) must be elected by the Commission to assume
the duties and responsibilities of the Chairperson.
C.   Quorum. A quorum of the Commission consists of four members.
D.   Secretary; Records. The Village Administrator or his or her designee
serves as the secretary to the Commission. The secretary will keep minutes of
all proceedings, record the vote of each member, the absence or failure to vote
of any member and records of hearings and other official actions. All records
of the Commission are kept in the office of the Village Clerk and are public
records.
E.   Open Meetings. All meetings and hearings of the Commission are conducted
in accordance with the Open Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/).
F.   Rules. The Commission may adopt its own rules of procedure. In the absence
of such rules, the Commission will conduct its business, as nearly as
practicable, in accordance with “Robert’s Rules Of Order”.
G.   Disqualification From Voting. No member of the Commission can vote on any
matter involving any property in which such Commissioner has a legal or
beneficial ownership interest or on any other matter where such Commissioner’s
interest would violate any other applicable law. (Ord. 2022-10, 3-28-2022)
TITLE 3
BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL LICENSE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
3-1-1: Applications For Licenses; Qualifications Of Licensees
3-1-2: Issuance Of Licenses
3-1-3: Prorated Fee; New License Applications
3-1-4: License Transfers
3-1-5: Violations; Penalty; Revocation Of License
3-1-1: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES; QUALIFICATIONS OF LICENSEES:
All applications for licenses shall be made to the office of the village clerk,
upon the terms specified in this chapter, and all licenses shall be issued to
such persons as shall comply in all respects with the provisions hereof, and
who shall be deemed suitable and proper persons to be licensed. (1988 Code § 3-
1-1)
3-1-2: ISSUANCE OF LICENSES:
A.   Village Clerk To Issue; Contents: Unless otherwise provided in this code,
each and every license authorized and required by the village shall be issued
by the village clerk upon payment of the amount of the license fee or tax, and
upon compliance with this chapter, and each license shall express for what it
is granted and the time it is to continue, if the license is limited as to
time. (1988 Code § 3-1-2; amd. 2009 Code)
B.   Expiration; Signatures Required: All licenses shall expire on or before
April 30 next following, unless otherwise provided. Each license shall be
signed by the village president and countersigned by the village clerk under
the corporate seal. (1988 Code § 3-1-2)
3-1-3: PRORATED FEE; NEW LICENSE APPLICATIONS:
Unless otherwise provided, any license which is issued after six (6) months
have elapsed for the license period and the license was not due and payable
prior thereto, the fee therefor shall be one-half (1/2) of the yearly license
fee; and provided further, that no person shall be entitled to the benefit of
this section who shall be engaged in the business for which he applies for a
license at the time of his application. (1988 Code § 3-1-3)
3-1-4: LICENSE TRANSFERS:
A.   Village Permission Required: No license granted under any village
ordinance shall be assignable or transferable without permission of the board
of trustees, nor shall any such license authorize any person to do business or
act thereunder, but the person named therein, unless otherwise provided by
ordinance. (1988 Code § 3-1-4)
B.   Fee: Unless otherwise provided, the fee for transferring a license for any
purpose shall be as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees", to be paid to the
village treasurer for the use of the village. (1988 Code § 3-1-4; amd. 2009
Code)
C.   Duty Of New Licensee; Bond: Any person to whom any license may have been
issued under any ordinance of the village who, with the permission of the board
of trustees, assigns or transfers the same to any other person than the person
to whom such license was issued, or the assignee of such license, shall
surrender such license, and such assignee shall apply for a new license for the
unexpired term of the old license authorizing the assignee to carry on the same
business or occupation at such place as may be named in such new license;
provided, that in all cases, the party applying for such new license shall give
a bond with sureties, which shall conform as near as may be to the bond upon
which such surrendered license was issued. (1988 Code § 3-1-4)
3-1-5: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY; REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
All licenses shall be subject to the ordinances and regulations which may be in
force at the time of issuing thereof, or which may subsequently be made by the
board of trustees, and if any person so licensed shall violate any of the
provisions thereof, he shall be liable to be proceeded against for any fine or
penalty imposed thereby, and the license may be revoked at the discretion of
the village president. (1988 Code § 3-1-5)

LIQUOR CONTROL

3-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms, as used in this
chapter, shall be construed according to the definitions given below:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Includes alcohol, spirits, wine, beer and every liquid or
solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer and capable
of being consumed as a beverage by a human being. The provisions of this
chapter shall not apply to any liquid or solid containing one-half of one
percent (0.5%) of alcohol by volume or less, or to liquids or solids containing
in excess of one-half of one percent (0.5%) of alcohol by volume if dispensed
by a licensed pharmacy pursuant to a medical prescription.
BAR SERVICE AREA: Any public place, ancillary and accessory to, and within the
same building as, a restaurant, that is kept, used, maintained, advertised and
held out to the public to be a place within which alcoholic liquor is intended
to be consumed. For purposes of this chapter, "bar service area" shall include
all areas intended to be devoted to the storage, preparation, sale, service and
consumption of alcoholic liquor.
BEER: A beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or
concoction of barley or other grain, malt or hops in water and includes, among
other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter and the like.
BREWPUB: Premises that are subject to and maintain a valid brewpub license from
the state of Illinois pursuant to section 5/5-1(n) of the Illinois liquor
control act, 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-1(n), as may be amended from
time to time, and that contain facilities used for the manufacture of beer for
the purposes of: a) making sales to importing distributors, distributors, and
to nonlicensees for use and consumption only; b) storing beer manufactured at
the premises, and c) conducting retail sales at the premises of beer
manufactured at the premises or another designated location.
CATERING ESTABLISHMENT: A business conducted by a person, firm, or corporation
for the purpose of providing food and service for a banquet or dinner which may
occur in a location other than premises leased, owned, and/or operated by the
catering establishment; the recipients of such food and/or service being
persons specially invited to such banquet or dinner rather than members of the
general public.
GROCERY STORE: Every building or other structure kept, used, maintained,
advertised, and held out to the public to be a retail store that primarily
conducts the retail sale of food and food items and the incidental retail sale
of other nonfood items.
IDENTIFICATION CARD: A written, printed or photostatic document issued by a
public officer of a federal, state, county or municipal government, or
subdivision or agency thereof, in the performance of his or her official duties
and evidencing the age and identity of a person, including, without limitation,
a motor vehicle operator's license, a registration certificate issued under the
federal selective service act, or an identification card issued to a member of
the armed forces.
KNOWINGLY: Having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief or
ground for belief which warrants further inquiry or inspection.
LEGAL AGE: The minimum age designated by law of a person to whom it is lawful
to sell, give or deliver a particular type of alcoholic liquor.
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor by a
circuit court of this state, but does not include a person appointed guardian
or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 405/1-1 et seq.
LICENSEE: Any person, firm or corporation or partnership or club holding a
license under the provisions of this chapter.
MINOR: A person under the age of twenty one (21) years.
ORIGINAL PACKAGE: Any bottle, flask, jug, can, cask, barrel, keg, hogshead or
other receptacle or container, whatsoever used, corked or capped, sealed and
labeled by the manufacturer of alcoholic liquor, to contain and to convey any
alcoholic liquor.
OUTDOOR SERVICE AREA: Any outdoor location that is adjacent and accessory to a
grocery store, restaurant or brewpub that is kept, used, maintained, advertised
and held out to the public as a place within which alcoholic liquor may be sold
and consumed.
PARENT: A natural or adoptive parent or a court designated guardian.
PRIVATE CLUB: A corporation organized under the laws of this state, operated
for recreational and social purposes on a private membership basis, which may
include the service of food and alcoholic liquor.
RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to
the public to be a place where meals are served, and where meals are actually
and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such space being
provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and
capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees
to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests. For purposes of this
chapter, "restaurant" shall include all screened in or otherwise enclosed areas
and rooms of such public place.
RETAIL SALE: The sale for use or consumption and not for resale.
SALE: Any transfer, exchange or barter in any manner or by any means whatsoever
and includes all sales made by any person, whether principal, proprietor,
agent, servant or employee.
TO SELL: Includes to keep or expose for sale and to keep with intent to sell.
UNEMANCIPATED MINOR: A minor still under the care and custody of at least one
of his or her parents or a legal guardian.
VEHICLE OR PREMISES: Any privately owned and operated motor vehicle, conveyance
or vessel; any house or apartment; any hotel, motel or bed and breakfast room,
or any similar premises to which the general public is not normally admitted.
WINE: Any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural
contents of fruits or vegetables containing sugar, including such beverages
when fortified by the addition of "alcoholic liquor" as defined in this
section. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992; amd. Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995; Ord. 96-9, 4-8-
1996; Ord. 2005-4, 2-28-2005; Ord. 2009-12, 4-13-2009; Ord. 2010-19, 8-23-2010;
Ord. 2011-6, 4-11-2011; Ord. 2014-23, 10-27-2014)
3-2-2: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
A.   Village President Serve As: The village president is hereby authorized to
be the local liquor control commissioner and shall be charged with the
administration of the liquor control act, 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes, and
of such ordinances and resolutions relating to alcoholic liquor as may be
passed from time to time by the village board of trustees.
B.   Assistants: The village president may appoint a person or persons to
assist him in the exercise of the powers and performance of the duties provided
for such local liquor control commissioner. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-3: LICENSE REQUIRED; GENERAL CONDITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
A.   License Required: No person shall sell or offer for sale in the village
any alcoholic liquor without having a license, or in violation of the terms of
such license.
B.   Conditions And Restrictions: Every license issued pursuant to this chapter
shall be subject to such conditions and restrictions of operation as the local
liquor control commissioner, with approval of a majority of the board of
trustees, may deem necessary and appropriate in connection with the public
health, safety, and welfare. Any such conditions and restrictions shall be
approved by a resolution duly adopted by the board of trustees, which
resolution shall be incorporated by reference into the license by the local
liquor control commissioner. (Ord. 96-23, 9-9-1996)
3-2-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
A.   Contents Of Application: Applications for such licenses shall be made to
the local liquor control commissioner. Such applications shall be made in
writing and shall be signed by the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly
authorized agent thereof, if a club or corporation, verified by oath or
affidavit, and shall contain the following information and statements:
1.   The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual;
in the case of a copartnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits
thereof; and in the case of a corporation for profit or a club, the date of
incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the names and addresses
of the officers and directors and if a majority of the stock of such
corporation, in interest, is owned by one person or his nominee, the name and
address of such person.
2.   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and if a naturalized
citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.
3.   The character of business of the applicants; and in the case of a
corporation, the objects for which it was formed.
4.   The length of time that said applicant has been in business of that
character, or in the case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was
issued.
5.   The location and description of the premises or place of business which is
to be operated under such license.
6.   A statement as to whether the applicant has made similar application for a
similar license, on premises other than described in the application, and the
disposition of such application.
7.   A statement that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is
not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any manner or thing
contained in this chapter, laws of the state or ordinances of the village.
(Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
B.   Application Fee; Liability For Costs: The applicant shall be required to
pay to the village, at the time an application for a liquor license is
submitted, a nonrefundable application fee as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees". The application fee
shall not apply to applicants seeking the renewal of an existing license
pursuant to section
3-2-11 of this chapter. In addition, the applicant shall be responsible for all
costs incurred by the village in the course of processing the application,
including, without limitation, the cost of fingerprinting, federal bureau of
investigation charges, and legal fees. (Ord. 2010-5, 3-8-2010)
3-2-5: RESTRICTIONS ON ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
No license shall be issued to:
A.   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in
which he resides.
B.   A person who is not a resident of the United States.
C.   A person who has been convicted of a felony under any federal or state
law.
D.   A person who has been convicted of being the keeper of or is the keeper of
a house of ill fame.
E.   A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor
opposed to decency and morality.
F.   A person whose license issued under the state act or this chapter has been
revoked for cause.
G.   A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license issued
hereunder, would not be eligible for such license under a first application.
H.   A copartnership, unless all the members of such copartnership shall be
qualified to receive a license.
I.   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any
stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%)
of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license
hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the
village.
J.   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless
said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
K.   A person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought, or
does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is to
be issued.
L.   Any law enforcing public official, village president, or any member of the
board of trustees, and no such official shall be interested in any way, either
directly or indirectly, in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic
liquor.
M.   Any person, association or corporation not eligible for a state retail
liquor dealer's license. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992; amd. 2009 Code)
3-2-6: TERM OF LICENSE:
Unless otherwise stated herein to the contrary, each such license shall begin
on May 1 and shall terminate on April 30 next following its issuance. (Ord. 92-
7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-7: EXAMINATION OF APPLICANTS AND LICENSEES:
A.   Rights Of Commissioner: The local liquor control commissioner shall have
the right:
1.   To examine, or cause to be examined, under oath, any applicant for a local
license or for a renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of
revocation or suspension has been served as provided by statute.
2.   To examine or cause to be examined the books and records of any such
applicant or licensee.
3.   To hear testimony and take proofs for his information in the performance
of his duties, and for such purpose, to issue subpoenas which shall be
effective in any part of this state.
B.   Agent Of Commissioner: For the purpose of obtaining any of the information
desired by the local liquor control commissioner under this section, the local
liquor control commissioner may authorize his agent to act on his behalf, as
provided by statute. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-8: CLASSES OF LICENSES:
Every person engaged in the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in the Village
shall possess a license of one of the following classes:
A.   Class A, which shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, in the
original package and not for consumption on the premises where sold, and
limited alcoholic liquor tasting activities as provided in section
3-2-20 of this chapter.
B.   Class B, which shall authorize the retail sale of beer and/or wine, in the
original package and not for consumption on the premises where sold, and
limited winetasting activities as provided in section
3-2-20 of this chapter.
C.   Class C, which shall authorize the retail sale by conference centers of
alcoholic liquor by the drink for consumption:
   1.   On the premises of the conference center by conference center guests;
   2.   In the private and public rooms of the conference center for privately
sponsored parties, receptions, and similar gatherings where attendance is
limited to conference center guests or invited guests;
   3.   In the conference center restaurant; provided, however, that alcoholic
liquor shall only be consumed within the restaurant area in which it is sold,
and the sale and service of alcoholic liquor shall be incidental and
complementary to the sale and service of a complete meal, which meal shall be
served and eaten at a table in the restaurant area;
   4.   In a lounge (bar service) area that is accessory to a restaurant, with
or without the sale and service of a meal; provided, however, that:
      a.   Alcoholic liquor shall only be consumed within the lounge area;
      b.   The square footage of the lounge area shall not exceed two thousand
(2,000); and
      c.   The license shall only be issued to the owner or operator of the
restaurant to which the lounge area is accessory.
D.   Class D, which shall authorize the retail sale, by private clubs in their
“restaurants” as defined in section
3-2-1 of this chapter, of alcoholic liquor by the drink for consumption on the
premises by customers of the restaurant, and which shall also authorize the
retail sale of alcoholic liquor for privately sponsored parties, lunches,
dinners, receptions and similar gatherings where attendance is limited to
members or invited guests.
E.   Class L, special events license, which shall authorize the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor by educational, political, civic, fraternal, religious or
other nonprofit organizations, at a picnic, outing, festival or other such
similar special event only for consumption on the premises or within the area
specifically designated in such license and shall in no event be valid for more
than forty eight (48) hours. Satisfactory evidence from the owner of the
premises shall be furnished showing the authorization to the applicant for the
use of said premises, including the sale of alcoholic liquor, for the period
for which the license is requested. No applicant may apply for more than four
(4) Class L licenses in any calendar year.
F.   1. Class P-1, which shall authorize for consumption on the premises where
sold, the retail sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises of property owned
(or controlled) and operated by or on behalf of a park district having a
population of less than five hundred thousand (500,000) inhabitants organized
under the provisions of the Park District Code of the State of Illinois.
   2.   Class P-2, which shall authorize for consumption on the premises where
sold, the retail sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises of property owned
(or controlled) by a park district having a population of less than five
hundred thousand (500,000) inhabitants organized under the provisions of the
Park District Code of the State of Illinois, and operated by an entity on the
park district’s behalf for park district purposes.
G.   Class R, which shall authorize the retail sale by restaurants of alcoholic
liquor; provided, that: 1) such alcoholic liquor shall be consumed only within
the restaurant premises in which it is sold; and 2) such a sale must be
incidental and complementary to the sale and service of a complete meal, served
and eaten at a table within the restaurant.
H.   Class S, which shall authorize the retail sale by restaurants of beer and
wine; provided, that: 1) beer and wine shall be consumed only within the
restaurant premises in which it is sold; and 2) such a sale must be incidental
and complementary to the sale and service of a complete meal, served and eaten
at a table within the restaurant. Class S licensees may serve beer and wine in
outdoor service area(s) approved by the Village.
I.   Class T, which shall authorize and allow the retail sale by businesses of
alcoholic beverages in original packages or containers not for consumption on
the premises where sold but packaged and made available to customers curbside
for pickup and by delivery.
J.   Class U, which shall authorize retail sale and service by restaurants of
alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises, with or without the sale and
service of a meal, in either or both:
   1.   One (1) bar service area no larger than eight hundred (800) square feet
in area, provided that the licensee must serve food prepared on site incidental
to the retail sale of alcoholic liquor; and
   2.   Within outdoor service area(s) approved by the Village. In addition to
the bar service area permitted by subsection 3-2-8.J(1), a separate service
area no larger than one hundred twenty (120) square feet may be used to provide
sales and service in such outdoor service area(s).
K.   Class V, which shall authorize the retail sale and service by restaurants
of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises by the customers of the
restaurant, as follows:
   1.   In a restaurant dining area; provided that the sale is incidental and
complementary to the sale and service of a complete meal, served and eaten at a
table within the restaurant; and
   2.   In one (1) bar service area, with or without the sale and service of a
meal; provided that (i) the square footage of the bar service area shall not
exceed ten percent (10%) of the total square footage of the restaurant to which
it is accessory; and (ii) the only public access to the bar service area is
through the restaurant to which it is accessory; and
   3.   In outdoor service area(s) provided that the sale is incidental and
complementary to the sale and service of a complete meal, served and eaten at a
table in an outdoor service area approved of by the Village and accessory to
the restaurant.
L.   Caterer’s license:
   1.   Class W annual license, which shall authorize the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor by caterers solely between the hours of eleven o’clock (11:00)
A.M. and twelve o’clock (12:00) midnight, in connection with, and as an
incidental part of, the catering of food for private events at a premises not
otherwise licensed for the retail sales of alcoholic liquor. A “private event”
shall be defined as an event not available to the general public except by
appointment or special invitation. A licensee with a Class W annual license
does not need a separate Class W license for each private event.
   2.   Class W event license, which shall authorize the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor by caterers solely between the hours of eleven o’clock (11:00)
A.M. and twelve o’clock (12:00) midnight, in connection with, and as an
incidental part of, the catering of food for a single private event at a
premises not otherwise licensed for the retail sales of alcoholic liquor. A
“private event” shall be defined as an event not available to the general
public except by appointment or special invitation. A Class W event license
shall only be valid for an event lasting no more than forty eight (48) hours.
No applicant may apply for more than four (4) Class W event licenses in any
calendar year.
M.   Class X, available only to a restaurant that is the holder of a valid
Class R, S, U, or V alcoholic beverage license pursuant to this section, which
shall authorize the retail sale by restaurants:(i) to patrons of the restaurant
of beer and wine in the original packages or containers and not for consumption
on the premises where sold; and (ii) of beer and wine by delivery; provided
that such sales, collectively, may not exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the
total retail sale and service of alcoholic beverages by the restaurant.
N.   Class Y licenses, which shall authorize the retail sale at a brewpub of:
(i) beer that is brewed by the licensee at the brewpub or at another designated
location for consumption on or off the premises of the brewpub, as well as (ii)
all other alcoholic liquor, including beer brewed by others, for consumption on
the premises of the brewpub incidental to the retail sale of the licensee’s own
beer. Class Y licensees must provide some service of food at the brewpub
incidental to the retail sale of beer or other alcoholic liquor but need not
operate as a restaurant. Class Y licensees may conduct limited tasting
activities on the premises as provided in section
3-2-20 of this chapter. Class Y licensees may serve alcoholic liquor in outdoor
service area(s) approved by the Village. Class Y licensees shall also be
authorized to conduct delivery of sales of beer.
O.   Class Z, available only to a business that is the holder of a valid Class
A or Class B liquor license pursuant to this section, which shall: (i)
authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises
where sold, including within outdoor service area(s) approved by the Village if
the licensee has a Class A liquor license; or (ii) authorize the retail sale of
beer and wine only for consumption on the premises where sold, including within
outdoor service area(s) approved by the Village if the licensee has a Class B
liquor license.
P.   Class AA, civic special events license, which shall authorize the retail
sale of alcoholic liquor at Village designated civic special events only for
consumption on the event premises or within such other area within the event
premises as specifically designated in such license. The license shall be valid
only for the duration of the specified civic special event and shall be subject
to such conditions as the Liquor Commissioner or his or her designee may impose
regarding the conduct of the civic special event, including, without
limitation, that the licensee must provide the Village with written
documentation, in a form approved by the Village, that the licensee will
indemnify, hold harmless, defend, and insure the Village against any claims
arising out of or relating to the service of alcoholic liquor by the licensee
at the civic special event.
Q.   Class AB, tasting license, which shall allow a State licensed
manufacturer, non-resident dealer, foreign importer, importing distributor, or
distributor to conduct tastings or product samplings as provided by section
3-2-20 of this chapter at:
   1.   An establishment licensed by the Village for the retail sale of liquor
for consumption on the premises where sold;
   2.   An establishment licensed by the Village for the retail sale of liquor
not for consumption on the premises where sold; and,
   3.   At a Village designated civic special event, only for consumption on
the event premises or within such other area within the event premises as
specifically designated in the approval. The licensee must provide the Village
with a written commitment, in a form approved by the Village, that the licensee
will indemnify, hold harmless, and defend the Village against any claims
arising out of or relating to the service of liquor by the licensee at the
civic special event.
R.   Class AC, which shall authorize retail sale and service by restaurants:
   1.   Of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises incidental and
complementary to the sale and service of a complete meal, served and eaten at a
table:
      i.   Within the restaurant’s dining area; and
      ii.   Within an outdoor service area(s) approved by the Village;
   2.   Of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises with or without the
sale and service of a meal in: a single bar service area where both (i) the bar
service area does not exceed ten percent (10%) of the total square footage of
the restaurant to which it is accessory; and (ii) the only public access to the
bar service area is through the restaurant to which it is accessory;
   3.   Of alcoholic liquor in the original package and not for consumption on
the premises where sold, and limited alcoholic liquor tasting activities as
provided in section 3-2-20 of this chapter; and
   4.   Of beer and wine by delivery.
S.    Class AD Bring-Your-Own which shall authorize the consumption of beer or
wine only, brought onto the premises of a restaurant by a patron 21 years of
age or older, for their personal consumption while being served a meal in the
establishment subject to the following conditions and restrictions:
1.   A licensee may provide corkscrews, bottle openers, glassware, ice,
disposal services, and similar items for its patrons, but the licensee and its
agents, and employees are prohibited from opening, serving, pouring, or storing
of any alcoholic liquor for its patrons.
2.   Licensees are prohibited from allowing any customer to take any opened
alcoholic liquor from the premises, except only a single wine bottle that has
been sealed in compliance with the requirements of 6-33 of the Illinois Liquor
Code.
3.   A licensee may not permit a customer to consume alcoholic liquor on the
premises between the hours of 1:00 A.M. and 6:00 A.M. each day of the week.
(Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992; amd. Ord. 95-30, 9-11-1995; Ord. 96-9, 4-8-1996; Ord.
2002-14, 9-23-2002; Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007; 2009 Code; Ord. 2010-5, 3-8-2010;
Ord. 2010-14, 6-28-2010; Ord. 2011-6, 4-11-2011; Ord. 2014-23, 10-27-2014; Ord.
2015-7, 5-11-2015; Ord. 2016-24, 9-26-2016; Ord. 2019-12, 4-22-2019; Ord. 2019-
14, 5-13-2019; Ord. 2020-12, 7-13-2020 Ord. 2020-17, 10-12-2020; Ord. 2022-8,
3-14-2022; Ord. 2022-32, 11-14-2022; Ord. 2023-3, 2-14-2023; Ord. 2023-18, 6-
26-2023)
3-2-9: LICENSE FEES:
A.   The annual license fees for liquor licenses shall be as set out in section
1-12-3 of this Code under the category "license fees".
B.   Fees for all annual liquor licenses that are issued on or after November 1
shall be prorated on a semiannual basis. (Ord. 2019-14, 5-13-2019; amd. Ord.
2020-12, 7-13-2020)

The maximum number of alcoholic beverage licenses by classification thereof
available at any time for issuance shall be as follows:

14, 4-28-2025)
3-2-11: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof; provided, that he
is then qualified to receive a license, and the premises for which such renewal
license is sought is suitable for the purpose. In addition, the renewal
privilege herein provided shall not be construed as a vested right which shall
in any case prevent the Village President from decreasing the number of
licenses to be issued within his jurisdiction or examining the application for
renewal as provided in section
3-2-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-12: CLOSING HOURS:
No person shall:
A.   Off Premises Sales: Sell or offer for sale alcoholic liquor in the
original package for consumption off the premises between the hours of eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. each day of the week.
B.   On Premises Sales: Sell or offer for sale alcoholic liquor for consumption
on the premises between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock
(6:00) A.M. each day of the week.
C.   Restaurants: Keep open for business or admit the public to any premises in
or upon which alcoholic liquor is sold at retail during the hours within which
the sale of such alcoholic liquor is prohibited; provided, that restaurant and
club establishments may be kept open during such hours but no alcoholic liquor
may be sold to or consumed by the public, employees or the membership during
such hours. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-13: ENTRY POWERS OF LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
The Local Liquor Control Commissioner hereby is given the power to enter or to
authorize any law enforcement officer to enter at any time upon any premises
licensed hereunder to determine whether any of the provisions of the Liquor
Control Act, 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes, or any rules or regulations
adopted by him or by the State Liquor Commission have been or are being
violated and at such time to examine the premises of said licensee in
connection therewith. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-14: RECORDS KEPT:
The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall keep or cause to be kept a complete
record of all such licenses issued by him. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-15: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
A.   Personal Privilege: A license shall be a purely personal privilege, good
for not to exceed one year after issuance unless sooner revoked as in this
chapter provided, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to
being encumbered or hypothecated.
B.   Deceased Or Insolvent Licensee: Such license shall not descend by the laws
of the testate or intestate devolution. It shall cease upon the death of the
licensee; provided, that executors or administrators of the estate of any
deceased licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may
continue the business of the sale or manufacture of alcoholic liquor under
order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the deceased
or insolvent or insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license,
but not longer than six (6) months, after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency
of such licensee. No refund shall be made of that portion of the license fees
paid for any period in which the licensee shall be prevented from operating
under such license in accordance with the provisions of this subsection. (Ord.
92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-16: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
A.   A liquor dealer's license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only
in the premises described in the application and license. Such location may be
changed only upon the written permit to make such change issued by the Village
President.
B.   No change of location shall be permitted unless the proposed new location
is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor under the Statutes of
the State and this Code and the ordinances of the Village. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-
1992)
3-2-17: SANITARY CONDITIONS OF PREMISES:
All premises used for the sale of alcoholic liquor or for the storage of such
liquor for sale shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be
kept in full compliance with this Code and the ordinances regulating the
condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human
consumption, and those statutes, regulations and directions of all governmental
bodies having jurisdiction. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-18: HEALTH CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYEES:
A.   No person shall employ in any premises used for the sale of alcoholic
liquor any person who is afflicted with, or who is a carrier of any contagious
or infectious disease.
B.   No person afflicted with or who is a carrier of any such disease shall
work in or about any such premises or engage in any way in work on or about any
such premises. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-19: RESTRICTIONS; SERVING AND DRINKING ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR:
A.   Compliance With Laws:
1.   No person shall serve or drink any alcoholic liquor in any restaurant,
dining room, lunchroom, bowling alley or other place of public resort in the
Village, other than one where the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on
the premises is permitted under license and said service takes place during the
hours permitted by the license. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
2.   Nothing in this chapter shall excuse or relieve the owner, proprietor or
person in charge of any tavern or other place in the Village where alcoholic
liquor is sold, served or delivered from the restrictions and requirements of
any other provision of this Code, any ordinance of the Village, or any State or
Federal laws or regulations. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
B.   Drinking On Public Ways: No person shall drink any alcoholic liquor in any
public street, alley, parkway, driveway or parking lot in the Village, unless
authorized by an appropriate license.
C.   Bringing Liquor Into Licensed Premises: No person shall consume or be in
possession of any alcoholic liquor on licensed premises other than such
premises where alcoholic liquor is sold and dispensed by the licensee. The
licensee or his agent shall have the authority to order the immediate removal
of any alcoholic liquor carried onto licensed premises in violation of this
subsection. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
