D.   Restricted Areas: With regard to all premises for which a Class C, D, L,
P, R, S, U or V license has been issued pursuant to this chapter, consumption
of alcoholic liquor shall be restricted to designated serving areas on the
licensed premises and shall not take place in any other areas, parking lots, or
adjoining property. No person, and no licensee under this chapter, nor any
officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of such
licensee, shall hand, offer, deliver, carry or pass off or out of the licensed
premises any alcoholic liquor, nor shall any such person cause or facilitate
any alcoholic liquor to be handed, offered, delivered, carried or passed off or
out of the licensed premises. (Ord. 96-23, 9-9-1996; amd. Ord. 2005-4, 2-28-
2005)
3-2-20: GIVING AWAY PROHIBITED; TASTING EXCEPTED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to give away or otherwise dispense free of
charge, by the drink or in any other manner, within the Village, an alcoholic
beverage with the intent of promoting the sale of an alcoholic beverage;
provided, however, when approved in advance by the Local Liquor Commissioner,
upon application of a Class A, Class B, Class L, Class Y, Class AA, or Class AB
licensee, and subject to the terms and conditions as the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner may determine necessary, that Class A and Class L licensees may
give away alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises, and Class B licensees may
give away wine on the licensed premises, and Class Y licensees may give away
beer or wine on the licensed premises, and Class AA or AB licensees may give
away liquor in accordance with the conditions of their license, without charge,
in small and limited amounts for tasting purposes only. Up to three (3)
samples, consisting of no more than: a) one-fourth (1/4) ounce of distilled
spirits, b) one ounce of wine, or c) two (2) ounces of beer may be served to a
consumer in one day. (Ord. 2019-21, 7-8-2019)
3-2-21: HAPPY HOURS PROHIBITED:
A.   Schedule Of Prices: All retail licensees shall maintain a schedule of the
prices charged for all drinks of alcoholic liquor to be served and consumed on
the licensed premises or in any room or part thereof. Whenever a multiuse
establishment which holds a valid retailer's license operates on its premises
more than one establishment at which drinks of alcoholic liquor are sold at
retail, a multiuse establishment shall maintain at each such establishment a
separate schedule of the prices charged for such drinks at that establishment.
B.   Prohibited Acts: No retail licensee or employee or agent of such licensee
shall:
1.   Serve two (2) or more drinks of alcoholic liquor at one time to one person
for consumption by that person, except selling or delivering wine by the bottle
or carafe;
2.   Sell, offer to sell or serve to any person an unlimited number of drinks
of alcoholic liquor during any set period of time for a fixed price, except at
private functions not open to the general public; (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3.   Sell, offer to sell or serve any drink of alcoholic liquor to any person
on any one day at a reduced price other than that charged other purchasers of
drinks on that day which such reduced price is a promotion to encourage
consumption of alcoholic liquor; (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992; amd. 2009 Code)
4.   Increase the volume of alcoholic liquor contained in a drink, or the size
of a drink of alcoholic liquor, without increasing proportionately the price
regularly charged for the drink on that day;
5.   Encourage or permit, on the licensed premises, any game or contest which
involves drinking alcoholic liquor or the awarding of drinks of alcoholic
liquor as prizes for such game or contest on the licensed premises; or
6.   Advertise or promote in any way, whether on or off the licensed premises,
any of the practices prohibited under subsections B1 through B5 of this
section.
C.   Activities Permitted: Nothing in subsection B of this section shall be
construed to prohibit a licensee from:
1.   Offering free food or entertainment at any time.
2.   Including drinks of alcoholic liquor as part of a meal package.
3.   Negotiating drinks of alcoholic liquor as part of a contract between a
multiuse establishment and another group for the holding of any function,
meeting, convention or trade show.
4.   Selling pitchers (or the equivalent, including, but not limited to,
buckets), carafes or bottles of alcoholic liquor which are customarily sold in
such manner and delivered to two (2) or more persons at one time.
5.   Increasing prices of drinks of alcoholic liquor in lieu of, in whole or in
part, a cover charge to offset the cost of special entertainment not regularly
scheduled.
D.   Violation; License Suspension Or Revocation: A violation of this section
shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of the retailer's license as
provided herein. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-22: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS; EXEMPTIONS:
No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor
within one hundred feet (100') of any church or school; provided, that this
prohibition shall not apply to clubs, restaurants, food shops or other places
where the sale of alcoholic liquor is not the principal business carried on, if
such place of business not exempt shall have been established for such purpose
prior to the effective date hereof; nor to the renewal of a license for the
sale of alcoholic liquor on premises within one hundred feet (100') of any
church where such church has been established within such one hundred feet
(100') since the issuance of the original license. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-23: CLEAR VIEW OF INSIDE FROM STREET REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
A.   View Inside Premises: In premises in which the sale of liquor for
consumption on the premises is licensed, other than in restaurants, hotels, or
clubs, no screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall be
permitted in the windows or upon the doors of such licensed premises, not
inside such premises, which shall prevent a clear view into the interior of
such licensed premises from the street, road or sidewalk at all times, and no
booth, screen, partition or other obstruction, nor any arrangement of lights or
lighting, shall be permitted in or about the interior of such premises which
shall prevent a full view of the entire interior of such premises, and the
entire space used by the public must be so located that there shall be a full
view of the same from the street, road or sidewalk.
B.   Lighting: All rooms where alcoholic liquor is sold for consumption on the
premises shall be continually lighted during business hours by natural or
artificial white lights so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall
be clearly visible.
C.   Violation; License Revocation: In case the view into any such licensed
premises required by this section shall be wilfully obscured by the licensee or
by him wilfully suffered to be obscured or obstructed, such license may be
revoked in the manner herein provided.
D.   Enforcement; Filing Of Plans: In order to enforce the provisions of this
section, the local liquor control commissioner shall have the right to require
the filing with him of plans, drawings and photographs showing the clearance of
the view as required in this section. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-24: PROHIBITIONS REGARDING MINORS:
A.   Acts Prohibited: Subject to the exceptions set forth in subsection B of
this section, it shall be unlawful:
1.   For any person to sell, give, deliver, dispense or furnish alcoholic
liquor to any minor.
2.   For any minor to purchase, obtain, receive, accept, have in his or her
possession or control, sell, give, deliver, mix, dispense, serve, furnish or
consume alcoholic liquor.
3.   For any minor to misrepresent his or her age to circumvent the provisions
of this chapter, including, without limitation, presenting or offering to any
person any identification card that is false, fraudulent, forged or not
actually his or her own.
4.   For any minor to possess or use any identification card that is false,
fraudulent, forged, or the identification card of another, or to obtain an
identification card by means of false information.
5.   For any person to sell, give, deliver or furnish to any minor any
identification card that is false, fraudulent, forged, or of another person.
6.   For any person to transfer, forge, alter or deface any identification
card.
7.   For any retail liquor dealer's licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to suffer, permit
or allow any minor to be or remain on such licensee's licensed premises, or in
any room or compartment adjoining or adjacent to such licensed premises.
8.   For any owner of, or other person having control over, any vehicle or
premises to knowingly initiate, suffer, permit or allow one or more occupants,
invitees, visitors, guests, trespassers or other persons under the age of
twenty one (21) years to assemble or be assembled in such vehicle or premises
in possession of any alcoholic liquor in violation of this section.
9.   For any person to rent or pay for any hotel, motel or bed and breakfast
room or facility from the proprietor or agent thereof for the purpose of or
with knowledge that such room or facility shall be used for the consumption of
alcoholic liquor by any minor.
10.   For any parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor to knowingly
suffer, permit or allow such minor to violate any provision of this chapter.
B.   Exceptions:
1.   The possession, mixing, dispensing and serving or consumption of alcoholic
liquor by a minor in the performance of a bona fide religious service or
ceremony is not prohibited by this section.
2.   The possession, mixing, dispensing and serving or consumption of alcoholic
liquor by a minor under the direct supervision and approval of a parent or
legal guardian in the privacy of such parent's or legal guardian's residence is
not prohibited by this section; provided, however, that this exception shall
not extend to any other occupant, invitee, visitor or guest that is a minor.
3.   The possession and serving of alcoholic liquor by a minor as an employee
of any licensee under this chapter in such licensee's licensed premises is not
prohibited by this section; provided, however, that this exception shall not
extend to those persons under the age of nineteen (19) years, nor shall this
exception extend to the mixing or dispensing of alcoholic liquor or to
bartending by any minor.
4.   The possession and delivery of any alcoholic liquor in its original
package and not for consumption on the premises where sold by a minor as an
employee of any licensee under this chapter or pursuant to the order of his or
her parent or legal guardian is not prohibited by this section.
5.   The location or assembly of any minor in any retail premises licensed
under this chapter or in any room or compartment adjoining or adjacent to any
such licensed premises is not prohibited by this section if such person is
accompanied by his or her parent or legal guardian; or if such licensed
premises derives its principal business from the sale or service of commodities
other than alcoholic liquor; or if such minor is an employee of any licensee
under this chapter in such licensee's licensed premises whose duties do not
include the mixing or dispensing of alcoholic liquor or bartending and, if
under the age of nineteen (19) years, whose duties do not include the handling
or serving of alcoholic liquors.
6.   The action or omission to act of any person at the express lawful, or
apparently lawful, direction of a law enforcement officer in the performance of
his or her official duties is not prohibited by this section.
C.   Presumptions Of Knowledge And Permission: For purposes of this chapter, a
person shall be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to have
knowingly permitted a violation of this chapter if: 1) such person is present
within any vehicle or premises of which such person is the owner, lessee,
permittee, bailee, legal possessor or occupier thereof at the time that a
violation of the provisions of this chapter is occurring; and 2) such person
has not informed the Lake Bluff police department thereof.
D.   Reliance On Identification Card: Proof that any person demanded, was
shown, and reasonably relied upon an identification card evidencing: 1) the
identity of a person; and 2) that such person is of lawful age in any
transaction prohibited by this section, shall constitute an affirmative defense
in any criminal prosecution therefor, in any prosecution for a violation of
this section, or in any proceedings for the suspension or revocation of any
license or the imposition of any fine or penalty based thereon; provided,
however, that it shall not be an affirmative defense if such person accepted
the identification card knowing it to be false, fraudulent, forged or the
identification card of another person.
E.   Violation; License Revocation Or Suspension: In addition to all other
fines and penalties, the local liquor control commissioner may revoke or
suspend the retail liquor dealer's license for any violation of this section.
(Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
3-2-25: PREVENTING VIOLATIONS BY MINORS 1 :
A.   Warning Required: In any place in the village where alcoholic liquor is
sold or distributed pursuant to a village retail liquor dealer's license, there
shall be displayed at all times, in a prominent and conspicuous place, a
printed card supplied by the village clerk reading substantially as follows:
      WARNING TO PERSONS UNDER 21
      YOU ARE SUBJECT TO A FINE OF UP TO $750.00 UNDER THE LAWS OF THE VILLAGE
OF LAKE BLUFF IF YOU PURCHASE ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR OR MISREPRESENT YOUR AGE FOR THE
PURPOSE OF PURCHASING OR OBTAINING ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR.
(Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995; amd. 2009 Code)
B.   Identification Required: If any retail liquor dealer's licensee, or any
officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee,
believes or has reason to believe that the sale, delivery or giving of
alcoholic liquor to a person, or the employment, location or assembly of a
person in such licensee's licensed premises, is prohibited by section
3-2-24 of this chapter because of the age of such person, such licensee,
officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee shall, before
making such sale, delivery or service and before allowing such person to remain
on such licensee's licensed premises, demand presentation of an identification
card. In addition, the licensee shall also demand a second form of positive
identification which confirms the authenticity of the first. For purposes of
preventing a violation of section
3-2-24 of this chapter, any such licensee, officer, associate, member,
representative, agent or employee may refuse to sell, deliver or give alcoholic
liquor to any person who is unable to produce a satisfactory identification
card, and may refuse to allow such person to remain on such licensee's licensed
premises.
C.   Violation; License Revocation Or Suspension: In addition to all other
fines and penalties, the local liquor control commissioner may revoke or
suspend the retail liquor dealer's license for any violation of this section.
(Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 5-8-2 of this code.
3-2-26: PROHIBITIONS REGARDING OTHER PERSONS:
No retail liquor dealer's licensee, nor any officer, associate, member,
representative, agent or employee of such licensee, shall sell, give, deliver,
dispense or furnish alcoholic liquor to any intoxicated person. (Ord. 95-42,
12-11-1995; amd. 2009 Code)
3-2-27: GAMBLING ON PREMISES PROHIBITED:
There shall be no card games or gambling allowed on any premises licensed to
sell alcoholic liquor, except for those which have been issued a permit from
the Illinois department of revenue. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-28: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
The village president may suspend for not more than thirty (30) days or revoke
for cause any liquor dealer's license for any violation of any provision
pertaining to the sale of alcoholic liquor, as provided in this chapter and in
the manner provided in 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/7-5. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-
1992)
3-2-29: REFILLING ORIGINAL PACKAGES PROHIBITED:
A.   Refilling Prohibited: Except for containers used by class Y licensees for
the retail sale at a brewpub for off premises consumption of beer brewed at the
brewpub or other designated location, no person licensed under this chapter or
his employee or agent shall fill or refill, in whole or in part, any original
package of alcoholic liquor with the same or any other kind or quality of
alcoholic liquor.
B.   Possession In Original Packages: No person shall have in his possession
for sale at retail any bottles, casks or other containers containing alcoholic
liquor, except in original packages. (Ord. 2010-19, 8-23-2010)
3-2-30: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
Every licensee shall cause his liquor license to be framed and hung in plain
view in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-31: STATE LICENSE REQUIRED:
No licensee under this chapter shall operate a liquor business without having
obtained a liquor license issued by the Illinois liquor control commission.
(Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-32: SOLICITATION FOR PROSTITUTION AND PURCHASE OF LIQUOR ON PREMISES
PROHIBITED:
No holder of a liquor license, his agent or employee, shall allow, permit or
suffer to remain on his premises any person who shall solicit for herself/
himself or for others for prostitution, or solicit any patron to purchase
alcoholic beverages. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-33: REPORT BY CORPORATE LICENSEE OF INTERNAL CHANGES:
All corporations licensed under this chapter shall report to the local liquor
control commissioner, within thirty (30) days, all internal changes in such
corporation pertaining to the persons whose names are indicated on the liquor
license application. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-34: ADVERTISING:
A.   Prohibited Advertising: It shall be unlawful for:
1.   Any holder of a retail liquor license of any class to maintain any
permanent sign or permanent advertising material visible from outside the
licensed premises which directs attention to specific products or brands of
alcoholic liquor, beer or wine. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
2.   Any holder of a class A, B, C, D, P, R, or S license to maintain more than
one sign or advertising material, either permanent or temporary, on any one
side of the licensed premises visible from outside the licensed premises which
directs attention to the service and availability of alcoholic liquor, beer or
wine within the licensed premises. (Ord. 93-17, 9-13-1993)
B.   Sign Regulations: A permitted sign or advertising material shall not
exceed a size of one square foot. Signs advertising specific products and
brands of alcoholic liquor, beer or wine maintained at licensed premises of the
type governed by this section are specifically prohibited. All signs or
advertising materials not prohibited by this section shall be erected and
maintained in conformity with sign ordinances of the village 1 . (Ord. 92-7, 4-
13-1992)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 10, chapter 10 of this code.
3-2-35: CONSUMPTION IN BUILDINGS OWNED BY LAKE BLUFF PARK DISTRICT 1 :
A.   Authority To Sell: Pursuant to authority granted by the general assembly
of Illinois by public act 82-917, 70 Illinois Compiled Statutes 1205/8-19, the
board of commissioners of the Lake Bluff park district are authorized to sell
alcoholic liquors in buildings owned by the Lake Bluff park district to persons
attending events sponsored by civic, social or cultural groups or attending
private parties in said buildings which shall be permitted in conformity with
the terms and provisions of statute and the ordinances, rules and regulations
of the park district and in conformity with the applicable provisions contained
in this chapter.
B.   Conditions For Use Of Facilities: Unless the ordinances of the Lake Bluff
park district shall be hereinafter amended to prohibit the same, alcoholic
liquor may be consumed in facilities owned by the Lake Bluff park district upon
the satisfaction of the following conditions:
1.   Sale Of Liquor Prohibited: The sale or offering for sale of alcoholic
liquor by any person and/or group using the park district facilities except
pursuant to a special permit described below is expressly prohibited.
2.   Special Permit Required: All persons and/or groups proposing to exercise
the privileges granted in this section, whether incorporated or unincorporated,
for profit or not for profit, shall first apply for and obtain from the
director of parks and recreation of the park district a special permit to be
issued for each function on a single basis and shall strictly comply with the
terms and conditions thereof, as well as all policies, rules and regulations of
the park district from time to time in effect applicable to the use of the park
district facilities.
3.   Limitations: Any special permit issued shall specify any limitations on
the type of alcoholic liquor to be served, the hours the building may be so
utilized and any other special conditions imposed by the director of parks and
recreation. All such special permit holders and attendees at functions shall
strictly abide by the laws and municipal ordinances governing the use and
consumption of alcoholic liquors, including, without limitation, the
prohibitions against furnishing of alcohol to minors and intoxicated persons.
4.   Notification Of Police Department: Written notification of the intended
use of a park district building for the consumption of alcoholic liquors,
describing all conditions contained in said special permit, shall be given to
the village police department on the first day of the month in which the event
is to occur.
5.   Enforcement By Police Department: The village police department shall
enforce any and all terms and limitations contained in a special permit issued
by the director of parks and recreation in addition to all other applicable
regulations contained in this section. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
 
Notes
1 2. See also section 7-4-1 of this code.
3-2-36: CONSUMPTION PROHIBITED IN PUBLIC PLACES:
Except as otherwise explicitly provided in, and authorized pursuant to, section
3-2-35 of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to sell, consume or
possess open containers of alcoholic liquor on any village property, or in any
village building, or on any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place in
the village, or in any place open to the public, including, without limitation,
parking lots; provided, however, that the sale, consumption and possession of
open containers of alcoholic liquor specifically authorized by a license issued
pursuant to this chapter, confined to the premises for which such license is
issued, and otherwise in conformity with the provisions of this chapter, is not
prohibited by this section. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
3-2-37: DELIVERY OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR:
Where a class of liquor license authorizes delivery of packaged liquor for off-
premises consumption, sales must be made in the original, unopened package.
(Ord. 2020-12, 7-13-2020; amd. Ord. 2023-3, 2-14-2023)
3-2-38: LIQUOR SERVICE IN OUTDOOR SERVICE AREAS:
Where a class of liquor license authorizes liquor service to be conducted in a
outdoor service area accessory to the licensed premises, service in the outdoor
service area is subject to the following requirements:
A.   The sale and service of alcoholic liquor in the outdoor service area shall
be permitted only when the indoor area of the establishment is open and in no
case between the hours of eleven o’clock (11:00) P.M. and six o’clock (6:00)
A.M.
B.   If the outdoor service area is separated from pedestrian traffic on the
adjoining sidewalk by the use of a fence, planters, railing, or other barrier,
then such barrier must be at least three feet (3') in height and provide for
emergency egress from the outdoor service area sufficient to comply with all
applicable Life Safety Codes and regulations.
C.   No sale or service of alcoholic liquor shall be made from the outdoor
service area to any person on the adjacent sidewalk, parking area, or public
street.
D.   The outdoor service area shall be supervised by an employee of licensee at
all times while the outdoor service area is used by customers. (Ord. 2020-12,
7-13-2020)
CHAPTER 3
PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
SECTION:
3-3-1: Definitions
3-3-2: Certificate Of Registration
3-3-3: License Fees
3-3-4: Religious Or Charitable Solicitations
3-3-5: Appeals
3-3-6: Exemption
3-3-7: Mobility Of Peddlers
3-3-8: Misrepresentation And Fraud By Licensee
3-3-9: Village Policy On Soliciting
3-3-10: Notice Regulating Soliciting
3-3-11: Duty Of Solicitors
3-3-12: Uninvited Soliciting Prohibited
3-3-13: Time Limit On Soliciting And Peddling
3-3-14: Solicitations On Highways
3-3-15: Penalties
3-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms, as used in this
chapter, shall be construed according to the definitions given below:
PEDDLER: Every person who shall sell or offer for sale, barter or exchange any
goods, wares, merchandise or other commodities, while traveling from residence
to residence on, along or upon the streets and sidewalks of the village.
REGISTERED PEDDLER OR SOLICITOR: Means and includes any person who has obtained
a valid certificate of registration as hereinafter provided, and which
certificate is in the possession of the solicitor on his or her person while
engaged in soliciting.
RESIDENCE: Means and includes every separate living unit occupied for
residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of
building structure.
SOLICITING: Means and includes any one or more of the following activities:
A.   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise,
foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or description whatever, for any
kind of consideration whatever; or
B.   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for applications or purchase of
insurance of any type, kind or character; or
C.   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals,
newspapers and every other type or kind of publications; or
D.   Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other
valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit
association, organization, corporation or project. (1988 Code § 3-4-1)
3-3-2: CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION:
A.   Application Required: Every person desiring to engage in soliciting or
peddling within the village is hereby required to make written application upon
a form provided by the office of the village administrator and filed with the
office of the village administrator.
B.   Contents Of Application: The applicant shall truthfully state in full the
information requested on the application, as follows:
1.   Name and address of present place of residence and length of residence at
such address; also business address, if other than residence address; also
social security number.
2.   Address of place of residence during the preceding three (3) years, if
other than present address.
3.   Age of applicant and marital status; and if married, the name of spouse.
4.   Physical description of the applicant.
5.   Name and address of the person, firm or corporation or association by whom
the applicant is employed or whom he or she represents; and the length of time
of such employment or representation.
6.   Name and address of each employer during the preceding three (3) years, if
other than the present employer.
7.   Description of the subject matter of the soliciting in which the applicant
will engage or description of the commodities or articles of merchandise in
which the peddler intends to deal.
8.   Period of time for which the certificate is requested.
9.   The date, or approximate date, of the most recent previous application for
certificate under this chapter, if any.
10.   Statement whether a certificate of registration issued to the applicant
under this chapter has ever been revoked.
11.   Statement whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of
any provision of this chapter, or the ordinances of any other Illinois
municipality regulating soliciting.
12.   Statement whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission
of a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state, or
under the laws of the United States.
13.   Such additional information as the village may deem necessary to process
the application.
C.   Statements Under Oath: All statements made by the applicant under the
application or in connection therewith shall be under oath.
D.   Record Of Applications: The office of the village administrator shall
cause to be kept in his office an accurate record of every application received
and acted upon, together with all information and data pertaining thereto, and
all certificates of registration issued under the provisions of this chapter
and of the denial of application. Applications for certificates shall be
numbered in consecutive order as filed, and every certificate issued, and any
renewal thereof, shall be identified with the duplicate number of the
application upon which it was issued.
E.   Ineligibility For Certificate: No certificate of registration shall be
issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under
the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state, or under the laws of the
United States, within five (5) years of the date of application; nor to any
person who has been convicted of any violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter, nor to any person whose certificate of registration issued hereunder
has previously been revoked as herein provided.
F.   Acceptance Or Denial Of Application: The office of the village
administrator, after consideration of the application and all information
obtained relative thereto, shall deny the application if the applicant does not
possess the qualifications for such certificate as herein required, or if the
issuance of a certificate of registration to the applicant would not be in
accord with the intent and purpose of this chapter. Endorsement shall be made
by the office of the village administrator upon the application of the denial
of the application. When the applicant is found to be fully qualified, the
certificate of registration shall be issued forthwith. If the office of the
village administrator fails to provide the applicant with a decision within
five (5) working days of the date of application, the application shall be
deemed to have been accepted.
G.   Contents Of Certificate: The certificate of registration shall state the
expiration date thereof.
H.   License Card:
1.   Issuance: If the character, qualifications and record of the applicant are
found to be in proper order, the office of the village administrator shall then
issue a license card to the applicant, signed by the village administrator and
bearing the applicant's photograph similar to the one on file in the office of
the village administrator.
2.   Display Of Card: Such license card, when issued, shall be worn by the
solicitor and shall be visible at all times, and such solicitor shall exhibit
the same at the request of any police officer or any citizen of the village and
shall exhibit such license card and properly identify himself upon making any
solicitation of a prospective purchaser. Upon the conclusion of his day's work,
the solicitor shall deposit his license card with the office of the village
administrator and call for the same the following morning before commencing his
day's work.
I.   Revocation Of Certificate: Any certificate of registration issued
hereunder shall be revoked by the office of the village administrator if the
holder of the certificate is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions
of this chapter, or has made a false material statement in the application, or
otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of
registration under the terms of this chapter. Immediately upon such revocation,
written notice thereof shall be given by the office of the village
administrator to the holder of the certificate in person or by certified U.S.
mail addressed to his residence address as set forth in the application.
Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the certificate of registration
shall become null and void. (1988 Code § 3-4-2)
3-3-3: LICENSE FEES:
A.   Established; Payment: The fees for peddlers' or solicitors' licenses shall
be paid to the village treasurer for the use of the village at the time the
application for a license shall be filed, and the license fees for each peddler
or solicitor shall be as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees", for one year or any
portion thereof.
B.   Refunds: Should the application for any license be denied, the fee
theretofore deposited shall be refunded to the applicant. (1988 Code § 3-4-3;
amd. 2009 Code)
3-3-4: RELIGIOUS OR CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS:
   A.   Definition: "Religious or charitable solicitations" shall mean the
request, by a person on sidewalks and at residences within the village,
directly or indirectly, of money, credit, property, financial assistance or
other thing of value on the plea or representation that such money, credit,
property, financial assistance or other thing of value will be used for a
religious or charitable purpose as those purposes are defined herein. These
words shall also mean and include the following methods of securing money,
credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value on the plea or
representation that it will be used for a religious or charitable purpose as
herein defined:
      1.   Any oral or written request or exchange of religious literature for
money or other thing of value.
      2.   The distribution, circulation, posting or publishing of any
handbill, written advertisement or publication.
      3.   The public making of any announcement concerning an appeal,
assemblage, athletic or sports event, bazaar, benefit, campaign, contest,
dance, drive, entertainment, exhibition, exposition, party, performance,
picnic, sale or social gathering to be held within the village, which the
public is requested to patronize or to which the public is requested to make a
contribution for any religious or charitable purpose connected therewith.
      4.   The sale of, offer or attempt to sell, any advertisement,
advertising space, book, card, chance, coupon, device, magazine, membership,
merchandise, subscription, ticket or other thing in connection with which any
appeal is made for any religious or charitable purpose or where the name of any
religious or charitable person is used or referred to in any such appeal as an
inducement or reason for making any such sale, or when or where, in connection
with any such sale, any statement is made that the whole or any part of the
proceeds from any such sale will go or be donated to any religious or
charitable purpose. (1988 Code § 3-4-4)
   B.   Waiver Of License Fee: On written request, the Village Administrator
may, waive license fees for non-profit, religious or charitable solicitors and
may impose additional restrictions and conditions on any permit for which the
fee has been waived. (1988 Code § 3-4-5; amd. Ord. 2024-18, 9-9-2024)
3-3-5: APPEALS:
In the event any applicant shall be refused a license by the office of the
village administrator, or shall feel otherwise aggrieved, he shall have the
right to appeal from the decision of the office of the village administrator to
the board of trustees, which board shall have the power to reverse or otherwise
modify the decision of the office of the village administrator. Such appeal
shall be in writing, addressed to the chairman or the president and board of
trustees setting forth in detail the grounds of such appeal. (1988 Code § 3-4-
6)
3-3-6: EXEMPTION:
This chapter shall not be interpreted or construed to deprive any person of any
right secured unto him by the constitutions of the state or of the United
States. Any person applying for a license hereunder or who shall be required by
the provisions of this chapter to make such application, and who shall claim
exemption from the payment of the license fees required hereunder by virtue of
any such constitutional right may apply to the office of the village
administrator for the waiver or remission of such license fee. The office of
the village administrator may waive or remit any such license fee when the
infringement of any right secured by the constitution of the state of Illinois
or of the United States of America shall be established to his satisfaction.
This section shall not be construed, however, to exempt any person from the
requirements of section
3-3-2 of this chapter. (1988 Code § 3-4-7)
3-3-7: MOBILITY OF PEDDLERS:
All peddlers must keep moving from place to place except when in the act of
showing foods or selling the goods to customers. (1988 Code § 3-4-8)
3-3-8: MISREPRESENTATION AND FRAUD BY LICENSEE:
All licensed peddlers and solicitors shall not engage in any fraud,
misrepresentation or imposition, while acting as a peddler, and shall offer for
sale, barter or exchange only those goods, wares or merchandise specified in
the license. (1988 Code § 3-4-9)
3-3-9: VILLAGE POLICY ON SOLICITING:
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the corporate authorities of the
village that the occupant or occupants of the residences in the village shall
make the determination of whether solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited
to their respective residence. (1988 Code § 3-4-10)
3-3-10: NOTICE REGULATING SOLICITING:
   A.   Compliance By Solicitor: Every person desiring to secure the protection
intended to be provided by the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained
in this chapter, shall comply with the directions set forth in this section.
   B.   Specifications: Notice of the determination by the occupant or the
refusal of invitation to solicitors to any residence shall be given in the
manner following:
      1.   A weatherproof card or decal, at least three inches by four inches
(3" x 4") (8 cm x 10 cm) in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main
entrance door to the residence, indicating the determination by the occupant,
containing the applicable words, as follows:
            NO SOLICITORS INVITED
            or
            NO SOLICITORS
      2.   The letters shall be at least one-third inch (1/3") (8 mm) in
height.
   C.   Card Sufficient Notice: Such card so exhibited shall constitute
sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the
residence of the information contained thereon. (1988 Code § 3-4-11)
3-3-11: DUTY OF SOLICITORS:
   A.   Compliance With Notice: It shall be the duty of every solicitor, upon
going onto any premises in the village upon which a "residence", as defined in
section
3-3-1 of this chapter, is located, to first determine whether the notice
provided for in this chapter, if any is attached, and to further be governed by
the statement contained on the notice. If the notice states "No Solicitors
Invited" or "No Solicitors", then the solicitor, whether registered or not,
shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises.
   B.   Depart Upon Request: Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any
residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from
the premises when requested to do so by the occupant. (1988 Code § 3-4-12)
3-3-12: UNINVITED SOLICITING PROHIBITED:
It is hereby declared unlawful and a trespass for any person to go upon any
premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or create any sound in
any manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such
residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof
and engage in "soliciting", as defined in section
3-3-1 of this chapter, in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (1988 Code § 3-4-13)
3-3-13: TIME LIMIT ON SOLICITING AND PEDDLING:
It is hereby declared unlawful and a nuisance for any person, whether or not
registered under this chapter, to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell
upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any
door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the
attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an
audience with the occupant thereof and engage in "soliciting", as defined in
section
3-3-1 of this chapter, prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M., or after seven
o'clock (7:00) P.M. of any weekday, Saturday, or at any time on a Sunday or a
state or national holiday. (1988 Code § 3-4-14)
3-3-14: SOLICITATIONS ON HIGHWAYS:
A.   Prohibitions:
1.   No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride
from the driver of any vehicle 1 .
2.   No person shall stand on a highway for the purpose of soliciting
employment or business from the occupant of any vehicle.
3.   No person shall stand on a highway within the corporate limits of the
village for the purpose of soliciting contributions from the occupant of any
vehicle, except as hereinafter provided. (1988 Code § 3-4-15)
B.   Permit, Conditions And Requirements: The village administrator may grant a
permit to solicit charitable contributions on highways, subject to the
following provisions: (1988 Code § 3-4-15; amd. 2009 Code)
1.   Before the village clerk may issue any permit hereunder, the organization
seeking such permit shall be required to set forth the following:
a.   The name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the
organization, and of the persons who manage such organization and who will
oversee the activity for which the permit is requested.
b.   The exact use for which the permit is requested.
c.   The date and times for which such permit is requested.
d.   The locations of the intersections within the village for which such
permit is requested.
e.   The number of solicitors expected.
2.   In addition, the soliciting agency shall provide evidence that:
a.   It is registered with the attorney general as a charitable organization as
provided by an act to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for
charitable purposes, providing for violations thereof, and making an
appropriation therefor 2 , approved July 26, 1963, as subsequently amended; and
b.   The soliciting agency must be engaged in statewide fundraising activity;
and
c.   The soliciting agency must agree, in writing, to be liable for any
injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which are causally
related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent.
C.   Regulations:
1.   Such solicitation shall be allowed only at intersections where all traffic
is required to come to a full stop and shall be limited to daylight hours only.
Solicitation shall not interfere with traffic in any way or impede or slow the
flow of traffic.
2.   All persons engaged in the act of solicitation, as herein described, shall
be sixteen (16) years of age or older and shall be required to wear a high
visibility vest.
3.   No person shall stand on or in the proximity of a highway for the purpose
of soliciting the watching or guarding of any vehicle while parked or about to
be parked on a highway.
D.   Liability Insurance: In addition to the above requirements, the soliciting
agency shall present to the village clerk written evidence that it has obtained
insurance providing coverage for bodily injury liability, as well as property
damage liability, in the amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00)
for any individual and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for any
occurrence, and said evidence shall name the village as an additional insured.
(1988 Code § 3-4-15)
E.   Penalty: Any person who violates any of the terms and provisions of this
section or who unnecessarily hinders, obstructs, delays or attempts to hinder,
obstruct or delay any person lawfully driving or traveling along or upon any
street or thoroughfare within the village shall be guilty of a violation of
this section and shall be subject to a fine not to exceed the maximum provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1988 Code § 3-4-15; amd. 2009 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 6-6-2C of this code.
2 1. 225 ILCS 560/0.01 et seq.
3-3-15: PENALTIES:
A.   Violators of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a
fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and each day or part of a day on which
such violation occurs shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
B.   Any person, while acting as a solicitor, who shall be guilty of any fraud,
cheating, misrepresentation, or imposition, or who shall solicit orders,
subscriptions or applications, or who shall offer for sale by sample, or by
description on approval, for subsequent acceptance, or for future delivery, at
retail, any publications, books, pictures, photographs, goods, wares,
merchandise or services, other than stated in the license issued to such
person, shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each such offense. (1988 Code § 3-4-16; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 4
SCAVENGERS
SECTION:
3-4-1: Definitions
3-4-2: License Required; Fees
3-4-3: Classes of License
3-4-4: Application for License; Issuance
3-4-5: Operations Of Scavengers
3-4-6: Required Reports
3-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The terms used in this Chapter have the same meaning attributed to them in
Title 4, Chapter 2 of this Code (“Municipal Waste and Recycling Regulations”).
(Ord. 2021-14, 7-12-2021)
3-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEES:
A.   Except as provided in Section 3-4-2.B, no person or legal entity may
engage in the business of scavenger or may provide any scavenger services
within the corporate limits of the Village except upon issuance by the Village
of a valid scavenger license pursuant to the procedures and requirements of
this Chapter. All scavenger licensees must comply with the regulations and
restrictions set forth in this Chapter.
B.   Exception for Specialized Services: A person or legal entity that
exclusively provides specialized services within the corporate limits of the
Village is not required to obtain a license.
C.   The annual fee for the scavenger license classes provided in this Chapter
shall be at the rate set forth in Section 1-12-3. (Ord. 2021-14, 7-12-2021;
amd. Ord. 2022-34, 11-14-2022)
3-4-3: CLASSES OF LICENSE:
A.   Residential Franchise License (1). The Village will issue no more than one
scavenger license authorizing the collection of scavenger materials from
residential customers. The residential franchise license may only be issued to
the scavenger with whom the Village Board, by resolution duly adopted, has
entered into a residential franchise agreement.
B.   Commercial Franchise License (1). The Village will issue no more than one
scavenger license authorizing the collection of scavenger materials from
commercial customers. The commercial franchise license may only be issued to
the scavenger with whom the Village Board, by resolution duly adopted, has
entered into a commercial franchise Agreement.
C.   Exempt Service License (Unlimited). An unlimited number of licenses may be
issued to authorize the collection of scavenger materials from commercial
customer that are exempt from franchise service pursuant to Section
4-2-2(G). A scavenger must provide proof that it has entered into a contractual
agreement with the owner or occupant of an exempt property to provide scavenger
services in order to receive an exempt service license, and, after the
Village’s exclusive commercial franchise takes effect on November 1, 2022 as
provided by Section
4-2-2(D), may only serve exempt properties under this license. It is the duty
of the scavenger holding an exempt service license to verify that each customer
maintains a current exemption during the provision of service. Prior to the
effective date of the Village’s commercial franchise, exempt service licensees
may serve any commercial customers in the Village pursuant to a valid contract.
(Ord. 2021-14, 7-12-2021)
3-4-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE:
A.   Application Required; Contents. Every application for a scavenger license
must be submitted on a form provided by the Village Administrator, shall be
verified by the applicant, and shall contain at least the following
information:
1.   The name and address of the applicant and of all directors, partners,
registered agents, and shareholders of the applicant business.
2.   The location of the applicant’s main office and garage or fleet yard;
3.   A copy of any licenses or permits required by the State of Illinois or any
other regulatory agency that licenses or permits waste collection and disposal;
4.   The collection options to be offered by the applicant, as well as the
location(s) and the manner of final disposal of each class of scavenger
materials to be collected;
5.   The number and kind of vehicles to be used by the applicant in collection,
transportation and disposal of scavenger materials from customers within the
Village, as well as the year, make, model, and registration number of each
individual vehicle;
6.   A policy or certificate of insurance, issued by a company acceptable to
the Village, demonstrating that the applicant has procured all insurance
required by pursuant to this Chapter for the full term of the license, and
providing that such insurance may not be cancelled except upon ten days prior
written notice to the Village Administrator.
7.   A hold harmless agreement providing the indemnity required by this Chapter
in a form acceptable to the Village Attorney.
B.   Approval of Application. The Village Administrator or his or her deputy
shall approve the application and cause the requested license to be issued upon
payment of the annual fee and upon finding that:
1.   The applicant is not in default to the Village;
2.   The applicant has conducted its business in accordance with the ordinances
and regulations of the Village;
3.   The equipment used in the applicant’s business meets the requirements of
the ordinances and regulations of the Village;
4.   That the issuance of the license is in the best interests of the Village
and that the quality of service to be rendered will serve the public health,
safety and welfare; and
5.   That all information, insurance, certificates, and agreements required by
this Chapter have been provided and approved.
C.   Change of Information. Any change in the information required to be
included in the license application shall be filed with the Village no later
than ten days after a change occurs. (Ord. 2021-14, 7-12-2021)
3-4-5: OPERATIONS OF SCAVENGERS:
In addition to all other duties and obligations imposed by this Code upon
scavengers, every scavenger license will include the following duties and
obligations:
A.   Equipment.
1.   Each licensee must collect all scavenger materials in fully enclosed,
leak-proof trucks.
2.   Open body trucks, dump trucks, and similar equipment may be used only for
special collections of large bulky items such as discarded furniture, fixtures,
and household appliances or loads consisting of other dry scavenger materials
provided such loads are completely protected and securely covered by tarpaulins
or other such covers in such a manner as to prevent such scavenger materials
from being spilled or scattered.
3.   All truck bodies must be maintained in good repair and clean condition and
must be completely emptied at the end of each day of use and flushed thoroughly
at the end of each day of use, weather permitting.
B.   Disposal. Every day, Licensees will transport all scavenger materials
collected for disposal to designated and approved disposal facilities out of
the Village, except as may otherwise be provided in a Franchise, and shall
deposit same at a proper lawful site designated and maintained for such purpose
under the laws of the State of Illinois.
C.   Insurance. Each licensee must obtain and maintain, at a minimum, the
following insurance coverages at all times that they are conducting scavenging
services within the Village:
1.   Workers’ Compensation Insurance with a company authorized under the laws
of the State of Illinois a policy to protect itself against liability under the
Workers’ Compensation & Occupation Diseases Statutes of the State of Illinois;
2.   Automobile Liability Insurance under a comprehensive policy to insure each
Vehicle to which the license applies with limits of not less than $1,000,000.00
each person and $1,000,000.00 each accident bodily injury liability and
$1,000,000.00 each accident for property damage liability;
3.   General Liability under a comprehensive liability policy for its
operations other than vehicular operations with limits of at least
$1,000,000.00 each person and $1,000,000.00 each accident bodily injury
liability, $1,000,000.00 each accident for property damage liability; and
4.   Any additional insurance requirements set forth in a franchise agreement
with the Village.
D.   Indemnification. As a condition of the issuance of a scavenger license,
each licensee will indemnify and save harmless the Village against any and all
damages to property or injury to or death of any person or persons, including
property and employees, agents, or invitees of the Village, and shall defend,
indemnify and save harmless the Village from any and all claims, demands,
suits, actions, or proceedings of any kind or nature, including Workers’
Compensation claims, or by anyone whatsoever, in any way resulting from or
arising out of the licensee’s collection of scavenger materials from Village
customers in connection with the license issued pursuant to this Code,
including operations of sub-contractors and actions or omissions of employees
or agents of the licensee or its sub-contractors. Without limitation of the
foregoing, each licensee shall also indemnify and save harmless the Village to
the extent required pursuant to any Franchise.
E.   Care and Performance. Each licensee shall undertake to perform all
collection and disposal services rendered hereunder in a neat, orderly and
efficient manner, to use care and diligence in the performance of its services,
and to provide neat, orderly and courteous employees and personnel on its
crews.
F.   Collection of Recyclable Materials Required. Every scavenger shall offer
collection of recyclable materials to each of its customers. Recyclable
materials collected by a scavenger shall not be deposited into a landfill or
incinerator unless all reasonable efforts have been made by the hauler to
recycle the material.
G.   Compliance with the Requirements of Law. Each licensee shall conduct its
activities within the Village in full compliance with all applicable statutes,
laws, ordinances, and regulations. (Ord. 2021-14, 7-12-2021)
3-4-6: REQUIRED REPORTS:
Each scavenger that receives a license shall, upon the written request of the
Village Administrator, make available the following reports to the Village:
A.   The total weight of all municipal waste collected in the Village by the
scavenger;
B.   The total weight of all recyclable materials collected in the Village by
the scavenger;
C.   The total weight of each category or class of recyclable materials
collected in the Village by the scavenger;
D.   The total volume of all organic materials collected in the Village by the
scavenger; and,
E.   The names, street addresses, and class of service received (including
types of materials collected, container size, and service frequency) for each
of the scavenger’s customers.
The Village Administrator may not request the reports described in this Section
more frequently than once in any three-month period. In addition to any
penalties provided for violating this Chapter, if the reports required by this
Section are not submitted in a timely manner, or if the information provided in
such reports is incomplete, the Village may withhold the responsible
Scavenger’s license until the report is submitted and/or made complete. (Ord.
2021-14, 7-12-2021)
CHAPTER 5
TAXICABS
SECTION:
3-5-1: License Required; Definition
3-5-2: Application For License; Issuance
3-5-3: License Fees And Term
3-5-4: Insurance Required; Compliance With State Law
3-5-5: Rates And Charges; Taximeter
3-5-6: Payment Of Fare; Transporting Passengers
3-5-7: Vehicle Requirements; Inspections
3-5-8: Conduct Of Drivers
3-5-9: Revocation Of License
3-5-10: Penalty
3-5-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; DEFINITION:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a taxicab business or to operate a
public passenger vehicle for hire without having first obtained a license
therefor as herein provided. "Taxicab" is defined to include a livery or
limousine service. (1988 Code § 3-7-1)
3-5-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE:
A.   Contents Of Application: Applications for such licenses shall be made in
writing to the office of the village clerk. Each application shall state
thereon the full name, age, residence address and place of birth of the
applicant, whether or not the applicant is a citizen of the United States, and
the occupation or business of the applicant for the past five (5) years with
names and addresses of employers. The applicant shall obtain and attach to his
application on forms to be provided by the office of the village clerk,
affidavits of his good character from two (2) reputable persons not related to
him by blood or marriage, who have known the applicant personally and observed
his conduct during at least one year next preceding the date of the
application.
B.   Vehicle Information: The application shall also set forth the class of
vehicle intended to be operated, the length of time the vehicle has been in
use, the number of persons it is capable of carrying, the motor power thereof
and the most recent license number issued therefor by the state.
C.   Investigation Of Applicant; Issuance Of License: Every application shall
be referred by the village clerk to the office of the village administrator who
shall investigate the statements contained therein and the fitness of the
applicant to conduct the business for which the license is requested and shall,
within thirty (30) days after such application is referred, make a report to
the village president on such application. The village president shall then
direct the village clerk to issue the license to such persons as shall comply
in all respects with the provisions of this chapter and as the village
president, in his discretion, shall deem suitable and proper persons to be so
licensed. (1988 Code § 3-7-2)
3-5-3: LICENSE FEES AND TERM:
A.   Taxicab Service: The annual license fee for a public passenger vehicle
(taxicab) license shall be as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees", for each company
engaged in such business. Such license fee shall be in addition to any fees or
licenses heretofore established. All licenses issued under the provisions of
this chapter shall be for a term not to exceed one year commencing May 1 in
each year and shall expire on April 30 in the following year. In the case of a
license issued on or after November 1 in each year, one-half (1/2) of the above
fee shall be paid.
B.   Livery Service: The annual license fee for a livery service license shall
be as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees", for each company
engaged in such business. Such license fee shall be in addition to any fees or
licenses heretofore established. All licenses issued under the provisions of
this chapter shall be for a term not to exceed one year commencing May 1 in
each year and shall expire on April 30 in the following year. In the case of
licenses issued on or after November 1 in each year, one-half (1/2) of the
above fee shall be paid. "Livery", as used herein, shall include all public
passenger vehicles (taxicabs) with a capacity of seven (7) or more adult
individuals including the driver thereof, and must comply with all of the
provisions of ordinances applicable to public passenger vehicles (taxicabs).
(Ord. 89-16, 3-20-1989; amd. 2009 Code)
3-5-4: INSURANCE REQUIRED; COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW:
A.   Insurance Requirements: It shall be unlawful to conduct such a business or
so operate a public passenger vehicle, and no license therefor shall be issued,
until such applicant shall cause to be issued and kept in full force and effect
a policy of insurance in a solvent and responsible company authorized to do
business in the state insuring such applicant against liability for any injury
to, death of, or damage to the property of any person resulting from the
negligence of such applicant or his agent in the operation of such vehicle.
Said policy of insurance shall insure and bond such applicant as provided in
the amount established by statutes of the state, but in no event less than
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for each accident or less than three
hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for death or injury to any one person or
five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for death or personal injury of
more than one person in a single accident. Said policy shall further indemnify
and hold harmless the village, its officers and employees from any liability,
and a copy of such policy shall be delivered to the village. Said insurance
policy shall provide that the insurance carrier or surety on any bond may not
withdraw from such bond or cancel said insurance until after serving ten (10)
days' previous notice in writing upon the village by registered mail. Whenever
any such policy shall be so canceled or bond withdrawn, said applicant shall
furnish a new policy of insurance or bond in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter before continuing to exercise any of the authority granted by this
chapter.
B.   Certificate Of Compliance: All applicants applying for a license shall, at
the time the license is issued, deposit with the village clerk a certificate
from the secretary of state of compliance with statutory requirements of the
state for the operation of a taxicab. (1988 Code § 3-7-4)
3-5-5: RATES AND CHARGES; TAXIMETER:
A.   Schedule Of Rates; Posting Required: Every person licensed to operate
taxicabs shall file a schedule of the rates and charges for such taxicabs with
the village clerk from time to time and within five (5) days of any change or
amendments thereto. The taxicabs shall also have affixed thereon inside or
outside of each cab and in a conspicuous place where it may be easily and
conveniently read by any passenger, a card upon which shall be printed in plain
legible type the rates of fare. (1988 Code § 3-7-5)
B.   Taximeters: Every taxicab licensed to operate in the village shall be
equipped with an accurate and dependable taximeter designed or intended to
measure the distance traveled, register the time the vehicle is waiting, and
record the charge of fare therefor. The taximeter must be placed so as to be
readily visible to passengers and shall be maintained in good operating
condition. The taximeter shall be inspected and sealed by a representative of
the police department on complaint. (1988 Code § 3-7-5; amd. 2009 Code)
C.   Receipt: Any passenger paying a fare shall be entitled to a receipt
showing the amount paid, if requested by the passenger at the time of payment.
(1988 Code § 3-7-5)
3-5-6: PAYMENT OF FARE; TRANSPORTING PASSENGERS:
Every driver of a public passenger vehicle shall have the right to demand
payment of the fare in advance and may refuse employment unless so prepaid, but
no driver of a public passenger vehicle shall otherwise refuse or neglect to
convey any orderly person or persons upon request anywhere in the village
unless previously engaged or unable to do so. No driver of a taxicab shall
carry any other person than the passenger first employing such vehicle without
the consent of the passenger. (1988 Code § 3-7-6)
3-5-7: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS; INSPECTIONS:
All vehicles used for taxicabs or for the conveyance of passengers for hire
must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and must be properly equipped
with brakes, lights, warning signals and such other devices or items of safety
as required by the state. (1988 Code § 3-7-5; amd. 2009 Code)
3-5-8: CONDUCT OF DRIVERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person driving a taxicab or public passenger
vehicle to act in other than a proper manner at all times while so occupied or
while in charge of a vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any such driver to shout
to prospective passengers or to drivers or operators of other vehicles, or to
be guilty of using profane or boisterous language. (1988 Code § 3-7-8)
3-5-9: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the
village president for a violation of any provision hereof or upon proof
satisfactory to the village president that the business of the licensee was
conducted in a manner detrimental to the public safety, health or morals. Such
revocation may be in addition to the imposition of a fine or other penalty for
a violation of any provision of this chapter, and shall be no defense to a
prosecution for such violation. (1988 Code § 3-7-9)
3-5-10: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than
twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1988
Code § 3-7-10; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 6
GASOLINE STATIONS
SECTION:
3-6-1: Definitions
3-6-2: License Required
3-6-3: Application For License; Plans And Specifications
3-6-4: Consent Of Landowner Required
3-6-5: Site Inspections; License Fee
3-6-6: Term Of License
3-6-7: No Smoking Signs
3-6-8: Revocation Of License
3-6-9: Effect On Building Requirements
3-6-10: Penalty
3-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
GASOLINE STATION: Any building, structure, premises, enclosure or other place
within the village where containers or tanks, either portable or stationary,
and containing alcohol, gasoline, kerosene, ethyl gasoline or other vehicular
fuels and lubricants, having a flashpoint below one hundred sixty five degrees
Fahrenheit (165°F), are kept or located for the purpose of selling, offering
for sale or distributing any such liquids from such containers or tanks;
provided, however, that the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any
place where such inflammable liquids are kept or sold for medicinal or
household purposes only. The term "gasoline station" shall also exclude any
facility maintained by the village for the purpose of servicing village owned
vehicles.
STREET: Means and includes such highways as have been dedicated by either
common law or statutory dedication as public streets and are actually in use as
such, and shall not be construed to include or mean service highways which are
commonly known as alleys. (1988 Code § 3-8-1)
3-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall erect or alter any building or structure or install any tank,
vessel or other container in or upon any premises in the village to use,
operate and maintain the same as a gasoline station, nor shall any person
operate or maintain any of the existing gasoline stations in the village,
without first having obtained a license therefor. Gasoline stations with self-
service must also offer full service to its customers. (1988 Code § 3-8-2)
3-6-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
Applications for licenses shall be made to the village clerk, in writing, over
the signature of the owner or his agent, on printed blanks to be furnished by
the village. Every application shall be accompanied by complete plans and
specifications, signed by the owner, which shall be in conformity with the Lake
Bluff building code (title 9, chapter 2 of this code). If such plans provide
only for the installation of a tank, vessel or other container, the location,
the space desired to be used, the length, breadth and depth, together with the
measurement in feet from the surface of the ground to the top of such tank, its
connections, fittings, openings and safety appliances, shall be shown therein.
All plans shall be subject to review by the village fire chief. (1988 Code § 3-
8-3)
3-6-4: CONSENT OF LANDOWNER REQUIRED:
No gasoline station shall be constructed, operated or maintained in the village
unless there is first obtained the written consent of the owners of a majority
of the land, measured by frontage along the public streets in the village,
within the squared area, the center of which shall be the center of the
proposed location, and the sides of which shall be one thousand feet (1,000')
long and at right angles to and parallel with the boundary of the street upon
which such gasoline station location abuts. (1988 Code § 3-8-4)
3-6-5: SITE INSPECTIONS; LICENSE FEE:
A.   Initial Inspection; Fee: Before issuing such license, the building
commissioner shall inspect or cause to be inspected the site of such proposed
gasoline station, and if the same is satisfactory and such use thereof is
permitted by the ordinances of the village pertaining thereto, he shall so
certify to the village clerk, and thereupon, the applicant shall pay to the
village clerk a license fee as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees". The fee shall be paid
prior to the issuance of such license and shall cover the cost of inspection
thereof. (1988 Code § 3-8-5; amd. 2009 Code)
B.   Other Inspections: No tank, container or other vessel located in or upon
such site shall be covered over or used until the installation, material and
workmanship have been finally inspected, approved and certified by the building
commissioner. All such facilities shall be subject to inspection by the village
fire chief at any time during business operations. (1988 Code § 3-8-5)
3-6-6: TERM OF LICENSE:
All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire on April
30 following the date of issuance. If, at the time of the application for a
license under the provisions of this chapter, six (6) months or more have
expired, the applicant shall be required to pay one-half (1/2) of such license
fee. (1988 Code § 3-8-6)
3-6-7: NO SMOKING SIGNS:
The owner, occupant or lessee of any gasoline station shall install and
maintain signs worded "No Smoking" in such numbers and locations as the fire
chief or building commissioner may require. (1988 Code § 3-8-7)
3-6-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
If any person obtaining a license hereunder shall at any time fail or neglect
to comply with the terms of this chapter, then such license as may have been
issued may or shall be revoked by the fire chief or the building commissioner.
(1988 Code § 3-8-8)
3-6-9: EFFECT ON BUILDING REQUIREMENTS:
Nothing herein contained shall be construed as in any way modifying the
building code, requirements of the village ordinances relative to fees for
building permits and all ordinances amendatory thereto. (1988 Code § 3-8-9)
3-6-10: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed for each day during or on which such violation occurs or continues.
(1988 Code § 3-8-10; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 7
FOOD AND BEVERAGES
ARTICLE A. RESTAURANTS AND FOOD STORES
SECTION:
3-7A-1: Definitions
3-7A-2: Permits And Licenses Required; Fees
3-7A-3: Sampling By Health Officer; Right To Prohibit Sale
3-7A-4: Inspections By Health Officer
3-7A-5: Premises Sanitation Requirements
3-7A-6: Grading Requirements
3-7A-7: Regrading Or Reinstatement Of Permit
3-7A-8: Employee Sanitation Requirements
3-7A-9: Regulatory Agencies
3-7A-10: Violation; Penalty
3-7A-11: Interpretation Of Provisions
3-7A-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this article:
EMPLOYEE: Any person who shall handle food or drink during preparation, serving
or sale, or who comes in contact with eating or cooking utensils, or who is
employed in a room in which food or drink is prepared, served or sold.
FOOD DEALER: Includes "restaurant", "itinerant restaurant", "food store" and
"itinerant vendor" as defined herein.
FOOD STORE: Grocery store, butcher store, delicatessen store, confectionery
store, bakery store, milk store, butter and egg store, fruit and vegetable
store, fish store, drugstore, ice cream store, or any combination of the
foregoing, or any place where food or drink is prepared, handled, stored,
offered for sale or sold at wholesale or retail, and all vending and dispensing
machines which contain or dispense such products.
HEALTH OFFICER: The health officer of the village or his authorized
representative duly appointed by the health officer by and with the consent and
approval of the board of trustees, except as to sections
3-7A-2 and
3-7A-3 of this article where such term shall mean only the duly appointed
health officer of the village.
ITINERANT RESTAURANT: A restaurant operating for a temporary period in
connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition or other similar
gathering.
ITINERANT VENDOR: Any person traveling from place to place who shall deal in,
sell or offer for sale any article of food or drink at wholesale or retail in
the village and who does not operate within the village a regular, established
store or warehouse for the merchandising of foods, and who does not operate a
restaurant or food store.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation or association.
RESTAURANT: Restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette,
tavern, sandwich stand, soda fountain, school lunch, kitchen, and all other
establishments where foods or drinks are sold, as well as kitchens or other
places in which foods or drinks are prepared for sale elsewhere.
UTENSILS: Any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, utensils, containers
or other equipment with which food or drink comes in contact during storage,
preparation or serving. (1988 Code § 3-9A-1)
3-7A-2: PERMITS AND LICENSES REQUIRED; FEES:
A.   Permits: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant or
food store in the village who does not possess an unrevoked permit from the
health officer, and any other governmental or regulatory body having
jurisdiction. Only persons who comply with the requirements of this article and
such rules and regulations as may be adopted by the board of health shall be
entitled to receive and retain such a permit. A person conducting an itinerant
restaurant, or an itinerant vendor, shall also be required to secure a permit.
Permits shall not be transferable. Such a permit may be temporarily suspended
by the health officer as herein provided upon the violation by the holder of
any of the terms of this article or of the rules and regulations adopted by the
board of health, or may be revoked after an opportunity for a hearing by the
board of health upon serious or repeated violations. (1988 Code § 3-9A-2)
B.   Licenses: Each person keeping, maintaining or operating a "restaurant" or
"food store" in the village, and each "itinerant restaurant" and each
"itinerant vendor", as defined in section
3-7A-1 of this article, shall annually, on or before May 1 of each year or
prior to the commencement of such operations if such operations are commenced
after May 1 of the license year, procure a permit issued by the health officer
as provided in this section and the county health department, and shall pay to
the village clerk, for each such establishment or privilege, a license fee as
set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees"; whereupon, the village
clerk shall issue a license to such person, which license shall be for a period
not to exceed one year ending the following April 30 unless otherwise revoked
prior thereto. The fee for such license shall be as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees", for each year or part
thereof. (1988 Code § 3-9A-2; amd. 2009 Code)
3-7A-3: SAMPLING BY HEALTH OFFICER; RIGHT TO PROHIBIT SALE:
A.   Examine Samples: Samples of food or drink offered for human consumption in
the village may be taken and examined by the health officer or his designee as
often as may be necessary for the detection of unwholesomeness or adulteration.
The health officer shall forbid the sale of any food or drink found by him to
be unwholesome, adulterated or unfit for human consumption, and shall cause the
same to be forthwith removed from sale or destroyed.
B.   Sale Of Unwholesome Food Prohibited: No unwholesome or adulterated food or
drink, or food or drink unfit for human consumption, shall be prepared, stored,
served or sold. (1988 Code § 3-9A-3)
3-7A-4: INSPECTIONS BY HEALTH OFFICER:
A.   Inspection Schedule; Reports: At least once every six (6) months the
health officer shall inspect food stores, restaurants, itinerant restaurants
and itinerant vendors. One copy of the inspection report shall be given to the
licensee. Another copy of the inspection report shall be filed with the records
of the health department.
B.   Second Inspection; Degrading And Suspension: In case the health officer
discovers the violation of any item of sanitation required for the grade then
held, he shall make a second inspection after the lapse of such time as he
deems necessary for the defect to be remedied, and the second inspection shall
be used in determining compliance with the grade requirements of this article.
Any violation of the same item of this article on such second inspection shall
justify immediate degrading or suspension of permit.
C.   Applicants To Allow Inspections: The applicant for permit or the licensee
shall, upon request of the health officer, permit inspection by the health
officer of the food or drink establishment, food or drink utensils, machinery,
fixtures, furniture, conveyances and records used in connection therewith, and
the health officer shall have power to do so. (1988 Code § 3-9A-4)
3-7A-5: PREMISES SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
A.   Grade A: All grade A restaurants and food stores shall comply with all of
the following items of sanitation:
1.   Floors: The floors of all food and drink establishments, as defined in
section
3-7A-1 of this article, shall be of such construction as to be easily cleaned,
shall be smooth and shall be kept clean and in good repair.
2.   Walls And Ceilings: Walls and ceilings in all food and drink
establishments, as defined in section
3-7A-1 of this article, shall be finished with washable surfaces up to the
level reached by splash or spray, and shall be kept clean and in good repair.
3.   Doors And Windows: When insects are prevalent, all openings into the outer
air in the food or drink establishment, as defined in section
3-7A-1 of this article, shall be effectively screened and doors shall be self-
closing, unless other effective means are provided to prevent the entrance of
insects.
4.   Lighting: All rooms in which food or drink are stored or prepared, or in
which utensils are washed, shall be well lighted.
5.   Ventilation: All rooms in which food or drink are stored, prepared or
served, or in which utensils are washed, shall be well ventilated.
6.   Toilet, Lavatory And Washroom Facilities: Adequate and conveniently
located toilets and lavatories shall be provided for employees of restaurants
