participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
F.   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in the
management or operation of the raffle.
G.   A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the winning chance or
chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under this
chapter and such premises must be within the Village.
H.   Winning chances must be determined only at a location within the Village
specified on the license.
I.   No person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the
conducting of raffles or chances. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years
may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when
accompanied by his or her parent or guardian.
J.   The operation and conduct of all raffles shall be under the supervision of
one (1) raffles manager designated by his or her organization. The manager
shall give a fidelity bond in the sum of not less than an amount equal to two
hundred percent (200%) of the aggregate retail value of all prizes in favor of
the organization conditioned upon his or her honesty in the performance of his
or her duties. The bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to
the Village not less than thirty (30) days prior to its cancellation.
K.   Each organization licensed hereunder shall keep records of its gross
receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single gathering or occasion at
which winning chances are determined. All deductions from gross receipts for
each single gathering or occasion shall be documented with receipts or other
records indicating the amount, a description of the purchased item or service
or other reason for the deduction and the recipient. The distribution of net
proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and date of payment.
Gross receipts from the operation of raffles shall be segregated from other
revenues of the organization of every kind and nature and placed in a separate
account. Each organization shall have separate records of its raffles and the
person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the
operation of raffles shall not be the same person who accounts for other
revenues of the organization.
L.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles under the terms of this
chapter shall report promptly after the conclusion of each raffle to its
membership and to the Village its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds
from raffles and the distribution of net proceeds, itemized as required in this
chapter.
M.   All records required by this chapter shall be preserved for three (3)
years and shall be open for public inspection at reasonable times and places.
(Ord. 2017-11, 6-12-2017)
3-14-11: LICENSE FEE:
Licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid for one (1) raffle only
and may be suspended or revoked for any violation of this chapter. The license
fee shall be as set forth in the Village's comprehensive fee schedule contained
in title 1 chapter 12 of this Code. (Ord. 2017-11, 6-12-2017)
3-14-12: GAMBLING PROHIBITION:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to authorize the conduct or
operation of any gambling scheme, enterprise, activity or device other than
raffles as provided for in this chapter. (Ord. 2017-11, 6-12-2017)
3-14-13: PENALTY:
Any person or firm violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to
the general penalty set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 2017-11, 6-12-2017)
CHAPTER 15
CONTRACTORS
SECTION:
3-15-1: Definitions
3-15-2: License Required
3-15-3: Application For License
3-15-4: License Fee
3-15-5: Revocation Or Denial Of License
 
3-15-6: Penalty
3-15-1: DEFINITIONS:
 
             Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of
             constructing, enlarging, altering, removing or remodeling any
CONTRACTOR : structure by furnishing labor, materials or methods necessary to
             accomplish a given result, and who retains for himself the control
             of the means, method and manner of accomplishing this desired
             result.
VILLAGE:     The Village of Lake Bluff, Lake County, Illinois. (Ord. 2025-5, 2-
             10-2025)
 
3-15-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No contractor may engage in electrical, plumbing, heating, air conditioning,
sewer work, water, septic or sewage disposal systems, storm sewer, fence,
concrete, driveway, patio, roadway, or construction work of any nature and
description in the village, without first having obtained a license thereof
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2025-5, 2-10-2025)
3-15-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person, firm or corporation desiring to engage in the business of
contractor must apply to the village for a contractor's license. The
application form for such license requires the following information:
   A.   Name of applicant;
   B.   Whether the applicant is an individual, partnership or a corporation;
   C.   Contact information for the applicant;
   D.   A copy of the liability insurance certificate, workers compensation
insurance certification, including amounts and expiration dates; and
   E.   The type of construction to be performed by the applicant. (Ord. 2025-
5, 2-10-2025)
3-15-4: LICENSE FEE:
Licenses issued pursuant to this chapter will be valid until the end of the
current fiscal year and may be suspended or revoked for any violation of the
village code. The license fee is set forth in section 1-12-3 of the village
code. (Ord. 2025-5, 2-10-2025)
3-15-5: REVOCATION OR DENIAL OF LICENSE:
   A.   Any license issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the
village administrator, or any application for issuance or renewal of such
license may be refused by the village building codes supervisor, if either
determines after notice and hearing:
      1.   That the application of the applicant or license holder contains any
false, fraudulent or misleading material statement;
      2.   That the applicant or license holder has made any false, fraudulent
or misleading material statement, or has been convicted of perpetrating a fraud
upon any person, whether or not such fraud was perpetrated in the course of
conducting any business in the village, or that the applicant or license holder
has committed a felony; or
      3.   That the applicant or license holder has violated provisions of the
village code, or has conducted any activities directly related to his business
in the village in an unlawful manner, or in such a manner as to constitute a
breach of the peace or a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the
public.
   B.   Notice of the hearing provided for in subsection A will be given in
writing to the applicant or license holder as the case may be.
      1.   The notice will be mailed by certified mail, postage prepaid, return
receipt requested, to the applicant or license holder, as the case may be, at
his last known address at least five days prior to the date set for hearing.
The date of such mailing will be deemed the date of such notice.
      2.   The applicant or license holder, as the case may be, will have the
right to be represented at the hearing by counsel.
   C.   Any applicant or license holder, as the case may be, aggrieved by the
action of village officials in refusing to issue any license or in revoking any
license already issued will have the right to appeal to the village's
architectural board of review.
      1.   Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the village building codes
supervisor of the village within fourteen (14) days after the action complained
of, a written statement fully setting forth the grounds of appeal.
      2.   The architectural board of review will set a time and place for a
hearing on such appeal and notice of the hearing will be given to the appellant
in the same manner as provided in subsection B(1).
      3.   The appellant will have the right to be represented at the hearing
by counsel.
      4.   The decision of the architectural board of review on appeal will be
final and conclusive.
      5.   No license will be revoked during any of the following:
         a.   During the pendency of an appeal before the architectural board
of review;
         b.   While litigation is pending in any court challenging the
architectural board of review's action;
         c.   While any appeal is pending from any court's action overring or
reversing the architectural board of review's action; or
         d.   During the time within which such appeal from the court's action
can lawfully be taken. (Ord. 2025-5, 2-10-2025)
3-15-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation that engages in the business of contractor
without first obtaining a license in accordance with this chapter, who violates
any of the provisions of this chapter, will, upon conviction thereof, be fined
not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each offense; and a separate and distinct offense will be deemed
to be committed every day on which such person, firm or corporation continues
to operate contrary to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2025-5, 2-10-2025)
TITLE 4
HEALTH, SANITATION AND ENVIRONMENT
CHAPTER 1
NUISANCES
SECTION:
4-1-1: Definitions
4-1-2: Public Nuisances Declared
4-1-3: Public Nuisances Prohibited
4-1-4: Special Vehicle Provisions
4-1-5: Various Nuisances Enumerated
4-1-6: Spring Traps Prohibited
4-1-7: Abatement Procedure; Costs; Lien
4-1-8: Penalty
4-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, and words shall
have the meanings given to them in this section. All terms, phrases and words
used in this chapter but not defined in this section shall have the meanings
given to them elsewhere in this code.
COMMERCIAL VEHICLE: Any vehicle operated for the transportation of persons or
property in furtherance of any commercial or industrial enterprise, for hire or
not for hire, that is either:
A.   In excess of eight thousand (8,000) pounds in gross weight (including
vehicle and maximum load) ("class I commercial vehicle"); or
B.   Less than eight thousand (8,000) pounds in gross weight (including vehicle
and maximum load) and has: 1) property that is stored and/or transported in a
manner that is not safe or not completely enclosed within the vehicle; and/or
2) exterior commercial signage ("class II commercial vehicle").
INOPERABLE VEHICLE: Any vehicle that is incapable of being driven or used for
the purpose or use for which it was designed.
RECREATIONAL VEHICLE: Any vehicle or boat originally designed for living
quarters, recreation or human habitation and not used as a commercial vehicle,
specifically including, but without limitation, the following:
   Boats and other watercraft
   Camper trailers
   Motorized homes
   Off the road vehicles
   Racing cars or racing cycles
   Snowmobiles
   Tent trailers
   Travel trailers
   Truck campers
   Vehicle trailers
UNCOMPLETED BUILDING: Any building or structure, or any part thereof, for
which:
A.   A lawfully issued building permit has expired and has not been renewed
within three (3) months after the date of expiration; and
B.   No certificate of occupancy can lawfully be, or has lawfully been, issued.
UNLICENSED VEHICLE: Any vehicle without a current and valid license plate and a
current and valid village vehicle sticker.
UNSAFE BUILDING: Any building or structure, or any part thereof, that:
A.   Falls within the definition of unsafe structure as set forth in the
section of the most current adopted edition of the international building code;
or
B.   Is or has been vacant or abandoned for a period of thirty (30) days or
more and is inadequately guarded from unauthorized entry.
VEHICLE: Any device for carrying passengers, goods, or equipment, specifically
including, but without limitation, passenger automobiles, vans, trucks, buses,
recreational vehicles, commercial vehicles, and other vehicles used for
commercial, business, or governmental purposes.
WEEDS: Poison ivy, jimson, burdock, ragweed (giant), ragweed (common), thistle,
cocklebur, blue vervain, common milkweed, wild carrot, wild mustard, rough
pigweed, lamb's quarters, wild lettuce, wild hemp, and other like vegetation
that, due to pollination, are a menace to health or are otherwise injurious to
the public health or welfare. (Ord. 95-3, 2-27-1995; amd. 2009 Code)
4-1-2: PUBLIC NUISANCES DECLARED:
A.   Specific Public Nuisances: The following are hereby specifically declared
to be a public nuisance:
1.   Generally: Any act, occupation, omission, condition, place, thing or use
of property that shall:
a.   Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the comfort, health or safety of
the public; or
b.   Render the public insecure in life or in the use of public or private
property; or
c.   Greatly offend the public morals or decency; or
d.   Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or render dangerous
for passage any street, alley, sidewalk, highway, navigable body of water or
other public way.
2.   Recreational Vehicle Storage In Residence District:
a.   Private Property: Outdoor parking or storage of a recreational vehicle on
private property in a residence district for more than five (5) consecutive
days, or for more than five (5) days within any thirty (30) day period, unless
the recreational vehicle is parked in the rear or side yard of the lot and does
not substantially impair the supply of light or air to adjacent properties.
b.   Public Property: Outdoor parking or storage of a recreational vehicle on
public property in a residence district between the hours of nine o'clock (9:
00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.; provided, however, that the owners or
occupants of residential lots on which off street storage of recreational
vehicles is impossible may park or store a recreational vehicle on the street
in front of their lot for a period of not more than five (5) consecutive days,
or not more than five (5) days within any thirty (30) day period.
3.   Commercial Vehicle Storage In Residence District:
a.   Private Property: Outdoor parking or storage of a class I or a class II
commercial vehicle on private property in a residence district for more than
forty eight (48) consecutive hours, or for more than forty eight (48) hours
within any seven (7) day period.
b.   Public Property: Outdoor parking or storage of a commercial vehicle on
public property in a residence district between the hours of nine o'clock (9:
00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
4.   Unlicensed Or Inoperable Vehicles: Outdoor parking or storage of an
unlicensed or inoperable vehicle on public or private property in a residence
district.
5.   Buildings:
a.   Uncompleted: Any uncompleted building.
b.   Unsafe: Any unsafe building.
6.   Weeds, Grass: Unkempt weeds, grass, or plants (other than trees, bushes,
flowers, or other ornamental plants or farm or garden crops) with a height in
excess of eight inches (8").
7.   Diseased Trees: Any "diseased tree", as defined in section
10-11-9 of this code.
8.   Garbage, Offensive Substances, Junk, Dismantled Vehicles: The uncovered
depositing, dumping, abandoning, accumulating or storing of any offensive
substance, trash, garbage, ashes, junk or dismantled vehicle (or parts
thereof), offal or carcasses of dead animals or any other miscellaneous waste
or refuse. (Ord. 95-3, 2-27-1995)
9.   Leaf Blower And Powered Landscape Equipment Operation 1 : The operation of
any nonelectric backpack mounted, handheld, or wheel mounted leaf blower
("regulated leaf blower") or any powered (gas or electric) lawn maintenance
equipment, including, but not limited to, lawn mowers, trimmers, and tractors,
except during the following hours: Monday through Friday: eight o'clock (8:00)
A.M. - six o'clock (6:00) P.M., and Saturday/Sunday/holidays: nine o'clock (9:
00) A.M. - six o'clock (6:00) P.M.; provided, however, that this limitation
shall not apply to the use of:
a.   Equipment for the removal of snow, including, without limitation,
snowblowers, plows or power shovels; and
b.   The use of a regulated leaf blower or other nonelectric power equipment:
(1)   For golf course maintenance;
(2)   For ordinary public property maintenance activities occurring at least
one hundred feet (100') from the lot line of any residence;
(3)   For cleanup activities necessary as a result of extreme weather or other
emergency conditions as determined and authorized in advance by the village
administrator; or
(4)   For landscape maintenance activities performed by property owners on
their own property between six o'clock (6:00) P.M. and dusk ("exempt
maintenance activities").
10.   Contagious or Infectious Disease: To intentionally or recklessly engage
in any activity that promotes the spread of contagious or infectious diseases
throughout the Village, including, without limitation, the intentional or
reckless maintenance of unsanitary conditions, intentionally or recklessly
hosting gatherings or conducting business in violation of public health orders,
and the intentional or reckless failure to maintain or operate properties in
compliance with health and safety codes, regulations, ordinances, and orders.
This paragraph 10 of subsection
4-1-2 shall run concurrently with the Village President's March 18, 2020,
Declaration of Emergency, and shall apply only while such Declaration is in
effect.
11.   Unscheduled bus stops of intercity buses, in violation of Section
6-8-2 of this Code.
B.   Provisions Not Limiting: The identification of the public nuisances
identified in this section shall not be construed to exclude other acts,
omissions, places, conditions and things from constituting or being identified
by the village as public nuisances. (Ord. 95-3, 2-27-1995; amd. Ord. 2016-4, 2-
22-2016, eff. 4-2-2016; Ord. 2020-14, 8-10-2020; Ord. 2024-2, 1-8-2024)

1 1. See also subsection 10-7A-7B5 of this code.
4-1-3: PUBLIC NUISANCES PROHIBITED:
No person shall erect, contrive, cause, continue, maintain, or permit to exist
any public nuisance, including specifically, but without limitation, the public
nuisances set forth in section
4-1-2 of this chapter, within the village or within the police jurisdiction of
the village. (Ord. 95-3, 2-27-1995)
4-1-4: SPECIAL VEHICLE PROVISIONS:
The following standards and regulations shall apply to vehicles:
A.   Permanent Location Prohibited: No vehicle stored outdoors on a lot in a
residence district or on public property shall have its wheels removed or be
affixed to the ground so as to prevent the vehicle's ready removal.
B.   Residential Use Prohibited: No vehicle shall be used for living, sleeping
or housekeeping purposes at any time while parked or stored in the village.
C.   Utility Hookups: No vehicle shall be connected to any public utility at
any time, except for required servicing.
D.   Unsafe Conditions: No vehicle shall be parked or stored anywhere in the
village so as to create a dangerous or unsafe condition. The ground under or
surrounding the location wherein any vehicle is parked or stored shall be free
from weeds, debris or combustible material. (Ord. 95-3, 2-27-1995)
4-1-5: VARIOUS NUISANCES ENUMERATED:
It is hereby declared to be a nuisance for any person within the limits of the
village: (1970 Code § 49.01)
A.   Offensive Odors: To so negligently conduct any business or use any
premises as to create such an offensive odor as may taint the air and render it
unwholesome or disagreeable to the neighborhood. (1970 Code § 49.02)
B.   Offensive Noises: To produce or permit to be produced, in or upon any
premises, or upon any street or public place, any offensive noise to the
disturbance of the peace or quiet of the neighborhood, or of any person
residing in the vicinity of such premises. (1970 Code § 49.03)
C.   Deposits Of Offensive Matter:
1.   Watercourses And Wells: To throw or deposit, or cause to be thrown or
deposited, any offal or other offensive matter, or the carcass of any animal
into any watercourse, pond, spring or well, or into Lake Michigan within one
mile of any portion of the shore of said lake, lying within the limits of the
village. (1970 Code § 49.04)
2.   Streets And Public Ways: To deposit any nightsoil, dead animal or other
filthy, offensive or noisome substance upon any lot, street, alley, highway,
park or other place. (1970 Code § 49.05)
D.   Unwholesome Drinking Water: To corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the
water of any drinking hydrant, spring, stream, pond or lake, to the injury or
prejudice of others. (1970 Code § 49.06)
E.   Obstructing Navigable Waters: To obstruct or impede, without legal
authority, the passage of any navigable waters. (1970 Code § 49.07)
F.   Encroachment Upon Public Ways; Dirt On Pavements: To obstruct or encroach
upon public highways, private ways, streets, alleys, commons, wharves and
landing places, or to cause or suffer to be drawn, deposited or remain, any
mud, dirt or filth upon any paved street in the village. (1970 Code § 49.08)
G.   Offensive Or Unwholesome Businesses:
1.   Prohibited: To establish, maintain and carry on any offensive or
unwholesome business within the limits of the village or within one mile of the
limits thereof. (1970 Code § 49.09)
2.   Packinghouses, Renderies; Permission Required: To locate and carry on
without having obtained permission of the board of trustees to do so any
manufactories, steam laundry, packinghouses, renderies, tallow chandleries,
glue or bone factories, soap factories or tanneries within the village and
within the distance of one mile without the village limits. (1970 Code § 49.21)
H.   Cemeteries; Burials: To establish a cemetery, or to bury any person within
the village limits or within one mile thereof, outside of an established
cemetery. (1970 Code § 49.12)
I.   Dangerous Buildings; Inspection: To permit any building, structure or
place to remain in such a condition as to be dangerous to the public health or
safety in any way. Any such structure, building or place is hereby declared to
be a nuisance. No building or other premises which has been vacant or
untenanted continuously for a period of six (6) months or more shall be
occupied or otherwise used until the same has been inspected by the building
commissioner and a certificate of safety issued by such commissioner as herein
provided. If, upon such inspection, the commissioner shall find said building
or other premises to be in a safe condition, he shall issue such certificate
forthwith; otherwise, he shall specify in what respect said premises is not
safe, and such certificate shall not issue until such unsafe condition shall
have been corrected. At the time the application for such inspection is made,
the applicant shall pay the building commissioner an inspection fee in the
amount as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "construction/building fees". (1970
Code § 49.13; amd. 2009 Code)
J.   Gas Appliances Improperly Vented Or Safeguarded:
1.   Venting: To permit to exist in any building, house or premises in which
gas water heaters, gas clothes driers, gas incinerators, central house heating
gas appliances, space heaters (except radiant types unless the radiant type
consumes more than 30 Btu per hour per cubic foot of room content), are
maintained and used, unless the same are vented to a properly operating flue.
(1970 Code § 49.14)
2.   Safeguarding: To permit to exist in any building, house or premises
wherein gas appliances burning such a quantity of gas that the surrounding
atmosphere will be vitiated to an extent dangerous to life and health are
maintained and used, and where every automatically controlled gas appliance is
not properly safeguarded against the hazard resulting from extinction or
flashback of the burner flame, unless such appliances shall be connected to an
effective flue. (1970 Code § 49.15)
K.   Endangering Public Health: To commit or do any act which endangers the
public health or results in annoyance or discomfort to the public. (1970 Code §
49.16)
L.   Common Drinking Cups: To maintain any common drinking cup or cups, dipper
or other similar utensil for the use of more than one person in any public
hall, theater, store or other place frequented by the public. (1970 Code §
49.17)
M.   Offensive Premises: To keep or suffer to be kept in a foul, offensive,
nauseating or filthy condition, any chicken coop, cow house, stable 1 , cellar,
vault, drain, pool, sewer or sink upon any premises belonging to or occupied by
such person. (1970 Code § 49.18)
N.   Deposits Of Organic Or Combustible Matter: For any person, either as
owner, lessee, agent, tenant or otherwise, to throw, cast or deposit, or to
cause or permit to run, drop or remain, or to be thrown, cast, or deposited,
any decomposable organic matter which might act as a breeding place for flies
or as food for rats, discarded things capable of holding water which might
serve as a breeding place for mosquitoes, or combustible matter which might
serve to increase the fire hazard of neighboring property in or upon any vacant
lot or land, enclosed or otherwise, within the village, except at such place or
places designated or provided by the board of trustees; provided, that garbage,
manure, offal and other putrescible matter may be temporarily kept in suitable
cans, vessels, tanks or containers which are watertight and provided with
tightly fitting covers. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed as to
prohibit the depositing of manure upon any private property for the purpose of
cultivating the same. (1970 Code § 49.19)
O.   Stagnant Water: For any person, either as owner, lessee, agent, tenant or
otherwise, to permit or allow in or upon any vacant lot or premises within the
limits of the village, any water to collect or lie stagnant in which mosquito
larvae breed, or are likely to breed. (1970 Code § 49.20)
P.   Houses Of Ill Fame: To maintain, frequent or patronize any house of ill
fame or house of assignation, where men and women resort for the purposes of
prostitution. (1970 Code § 49.22)
Q.   Privies: For any person to erect or maintain any privy within the limits
of the village. (1970 Code § 49.23)
R.   Keeping Swine: To keep or suffer to be kept any swine in any enclosure or
pen in the village so as to be offensive to those residing in the vicinity.
(1970 Code § 49.24)
S.   Slaughtering Animals: To slaughter any meat cattle, hogs, or sheep, or
keep, maintain or use any house or place in which the business of slaughtering
any of said animals may be carried on in the village, without first having
obtained a permit so to do from the board of trustees; except, that the owner
of animals may slaughter them for his own use upon his own premises without
such permit. (1970 Code § 49.25)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  5-9A-5 of this code.
4-1-6: SPRING TRAPS PROHIBITED:
A.   Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any person to use or permit to be
used in the village any jump animal trap or similar device with spring
activated jaws, made out of steel or other hard substance, of the type commonly
used for the trapping of furbearing animals, which is capable of inflicting
cruelty upon dogs or cats or other types of animals, or which constitutes a
hazard to small children.
B.   Penalty: Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section
shall, upon a conviction thereof, be fined in an amount of not less than twenty
five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each such trap that is laid or used shall constitute a
separate violation. (Ord. 83-23, 12-12-1983; amd. 2009 Code)
4-1-7: ABATEMENT PROCEDURE; COSTS; LIEN:
A.   Inspection: The village administrator may inspect or cause to be inspected
any premises upon which it is believed that a public nuisance exists, and a
written report shall be made of the inspection.
B.   Emergency Abatement: If a public nuisance on private property constitutes
immediate danger to public health, safety, peace, morals or decency, the
village administrator may direct the police chief to serve a notice on the
owner, or, if the owner cannot be found, on the occupant or person causing,
permitting or maintaining the nuisance and to post a copy of the notice on the
premises. Such notice shall direct the owner, occupant or person causing,
permitting or maintaining the nuisance to abate or remove the nuisance within
twenty four (24) hours. The notice shall also state that if the nuisance is not
abated within twenty four (24) hours, the village may cause the nuisance to be
abated and will charge the costs of such abatement to the person to whom the
notice was sent. The village administrator may employ such village resources as
are necessary to abate or remove the nuisance.
C.   Court Ordered Abatement: If a public nuisance on private property does not
constitute an immediate danger to public health, peace, morals or decency, the
village administrator may cause an action to abate such nuisance to be
commenced in any court of proper jurisdiction in the name of the village.
D.   Cost Of Abatement: In addition to any other penalty or fee imposed by this
code for the erection, contrivance, creation, maintenance or continuance of a
public nuisance, the cost of abating a public nuisance by the village shall be
collected as a debt from the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or
maintaining the nuisance.
E.   Special Lien Authorization: The costs and expenses incurred by the village
to abate any public nuisance may be made a lien on the property on which any
such public nuisance is located pursuant to, and to the fullest extent provided
by, Illinois law. (Ord. 95-3, 2-27-1995)
4-1-8: PENALTY:
The owner of property on which a public nuisance is located, or the person
causing, permitting or maintaining a public nuisance, shall, upon conviction
therefor, be subject to a fine for the violation of this chapter of not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each such violation and for each day such violation
exists. (Ord. 95-3, 2-27-1995; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 2
WASTE AND RECYCLING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
4-2-1: Definitions
4-2-2: Services Required; Exclusive Franchises; Exemptions
4-2-3: Acceptable Containers
4-2-4: Presentation Of Materials For Collection
4-2-5: Waste Nuisances
4-2-6: Abatement At Owner’s Expense; Lien
4-2-7: Penalty
4-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this Chapter, the following terms, phrases, and words shall
have the meanings given herein:

                           An individual commercial, industrial, institutional entity, or building containing

4-2-2: SERVICES REQUIRED; EXCLUSIVE FRANCHISES; EXEMPTIONS:
A.   Scavenger Services Required. Every person or legal entity in possession of
any premises in the Village shall cause accumulations of scavenger materials to
be disposed of no less frequently than once every seven days by a licensed
scavenger. The use or occupancy of any premises shall be prima facie evidence
that scavenger materials are being produced and accumulating on the premises.
B.   Scavenger License Required. No scavenger services may be provided within
the Village except by a scavenger duly licensed by the Village pursuant to
Title 3, Chapter 4 of this Code. No person or legal entity other than a
scavenger may remove any scavenger materials placed out for collection by a
resident, tenant, and/or owner of a premises which is intended for collection
by a scavenger.
C.   Exclusive Residential Franchise. Scavenger services for residential
customers may only be provided pursuant to a franchise. Franchisees will
directly bill and charge the Village for the cost of basic waste collection
services under the franchise. The franchise may provide for a residential
customer to receive optional additional services, which shall be billed by the
franchisee to the person or legal entity requesting such services. The
franchisee shall be responsible for billing and collecting all charges for
services above the cost of basic waste collection services, and shall keep an
accurate record of all the premises served, including the address and amounts
collected from each. The franchisee shall assume any and all delinquent
accounts for services above the cost of basic waste collection services.
D.   Exclusive Commercial Franchise. Commencing November 1, 2022, except as
otherwise provided in this Section, scavenger services for commercial customers
may only be provided pursuant to a franchise. Provision of scavenger services
to a customer in violation of this Section shall be an offense chargeable to
both the customer and the scavenger. The penalty for violation of this Section
shall be as set forth in Section
1-12-3 of this Code.
E.   Billing and Fees. The fees for Scavenger Services shall be as provided in
Section
1-12-3 and shall be billed by the Franchisee in accordance with the terms of
the franchise.
F.   Specialized Services Exempted. A person or legal entity may if offered,
but is not required to, use a franchisee for any specialized services.
Construction or demolition debris generated within the Village is subject to
recycling.
G.   Exemption Requests from Commercial Franchise. Any person or legal entity
occupying a commercial property subject to a Franchise may file a written
request with the Village Administrator for an exemption from the franchise. The
request shall be accompanied by appropriate documentation specifying and
demonstrating the circumstances that necessitate the exemption, which may
include, without limitation:
1.   The requestor’s business is subject to a corporate contract for Scavenger
Services, the provisions of which are outside the requestor’s control;
2.   The requestor is subject to a written and binding contract for Scavenger
Services with a Scavenger previously licensed by the Village, which contract
was effective prior to August 1, 2021;
3.   The requestor’s business requires specialized services that cannot be
provided under the Franchise; or
4.   Exceptional hardship.
The Village Administrator shall either grant or deny the exemption, in his sole
and absolute discretion, within 30 days after receipt of a request. Any person
or legal entity denied an exemption may appeal the denial in writing to the
Village Board of Trustees within ten days after the date of the Village
Administrator’s written denial. (Ord. 2021-14, 7-12-2021; amd. Ord. 2022-34,
11-14-2022)
4-2-3: ACCEPTABLE CONTAINERS:
A.   Materials Must Be Stored in Acceptable Containers. Every person or legal
entity in possession of any premises in the Village shall provide a sufficient
number and capacity of containers to store any generated Scavenger Materials
until they are collected. No container may be used to store Scavenger Materials
unless it is one or more of the following:
1.   A covered container provided by a Franchisee for automated waste and
recycling collection.
2.   For Residential Properties only, a durable metal or plastic container with
a tight-fitting cover that is rodent-proof, fly-proof, waterproof, and leak-
proof. Such a container may not exceed 32 gallons in size and must be provided
with handles on the cover and two sides.
3.   For Organic Materials only, a biodegradable paper “kraft”-type bag not
exceeding 32 gallons in size.
4.   For exempt commercial customers only, any equivalent or specialized
covered container(s) provided by the Scavenger serving the property.
5.   A temporary roll-off container with an open or closed top may be used to
store construction and demolition debris, Scavenger Materials generated while
occupying or vacating a property, or other similar temporary needs.
B.   Maintenance of Waste Containers. All containers shall be maintained clean
and in good order and repair. Filthy, leaking or defective containers shall be
cleaned, repaired, or replaced by the owner or occupant of the premises at his
or her expense. (Ord. 2021-14, 7-12-2021)
4-2-4: PRESENTATION OF MATERIALS FOR COLLECTION:
A.   Materials Must Be Presented in Acceptable Containers; Exceptions. No
person or legal entity may present scavenger materials for collection outside
of an acceptable container, except that, for residential customers:
1.   Organic materials such as limbs that cannot reasonably be placed in an
acceptable container may be securely tied with biodegradable string or twine in
bundles not to exceed four feet in length and 24 inches in diameter.
2.   Individual bulky items that are too large or heavy to reasonably be placed
in an acceptable container may be placed at the curb for collection, but only
where a Scavenger has agreed, whether pursuant to a franchise or by arrangement
with an individual customer, that such an item will be collected within the
time limits prescribed by this Section.
B.   Preparation of Materials. Any scavenger materials presented for collection
shall be placed, wrapped, or secured in such a manner as not to be blown or
scattered by the wind. Containers shall be kept securely closed or covered.
Municipal waste must be securely bagged or wrapped to limit any spillage should
the container become uncovered or overturned.
C.   Location and Time of Collection.
1.   Residential Customers. Except for residential customers that have made
separate arrangements with their scavenger, each residential customer shall
cause all scavenger materials to be presented at the curbside for collection.
No person or legal entity shall place any scavenger materials curbside for
collection earlier than 4:00 P.M. on the day prior to a collection or to allow
any containers to remain curbside later than the day that collection occurs.
2.   Commercial Customers. Commercial customers shall store all containers in a
designated area approved by the Architectural Board of Review pursuant to
Section 10-4-2(H). For legal non-conforming properties where no such area has
been designated, commercial customers shall store all acceptable containers in
an area that is (i) paved and accessible for a scavenger’s trucks; (ii) not
visible from any public or private street; and (iii) not in any other location
so as to cause a public or private nuisance or danger. Such containers shall
not be presented at the curbside for collection and instead shall be collected
from their storage location; except that, where approved by the Architectural
Board of Review, containers may be placed at the curb subject to the
restrictions applicable to residential customers. (Ord. 2021-14, 7-12-2021)
4-2-5: WASTE NUISANCES:
It shall be a violation of this Code and is hereby declared a public nuisance
for any person or legal entity to, whether willfully or by negligence:
A.   Allow scavenger materials to accumulate in such a manner that they attract
rats, flies, or vermin or otherwise create a danger to the health or safety of
the Village or any person.
B.   Deposit, place, or dump in any manner whatsoever any scavenger materials
or construction or demolition debris or any other thing in or upon any
sidewalk, street, alley, parkway, park, stream or body of water, ravine, bluff,
beach, school, private property, public place, or other public right of way,
whether or not a “No Dumping” sign is posted on said property, except: (i) as
necessary for collection by a scavenger; (ii) at Village facilities provided
for the drop-off of scavenger materials, but only when deposited in compliance
with the posted rules and regulations of the facility; or (iii) when done
temporarily in the necessary course of trade for a period not to exceed two
hours.
C.   Deposit or place any scavenger materials in another person or legal
entity’s private collection containers; or to place scavenger materials
generated outside the Village in a collection container.
D.   Burn or bury any scavenger materials within the Village except as provided
in Chapter 3 of this title.
E.   Place for collection, except with the knowledge and consent of a Scavenger
and in accordance with all federal, state, and local laws and regulations, any:
radioactive, volatile, corrosive, highly flammable, explosive, biomedical,
infectious, biohazardous, toxic, or hazardous material as defined by applicable
federal, state, or local laws or regulations including, but not limited to, the
Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. §§6901-6992k.
F.   To store or present for collection any Scavenger Materials except in the
manner provided in this Chapter. (Ord. 2021-14, 7-12-2021)
4-2-6: ABATEMENT AT OWNER’S EXPENSE; LIEN:
A.   If the owner of any private property in the Village upon which there is
deposited any scavenger materials in violation of this Chapter refuses or
neglects to remove such scavenger materials within five days after receiving
written notice from the Village Administrator to do so, the Village may remove
the same and may collect from the owner the reasonable cost thereof. If the
Village Administrator determines that these conditions create an immediate
hazard to the public health, safety, and welfare, the Village Administrator may
order abatement immediately and without prior notice.
B.   If the owner fails to pay the Village’s costs and expenses incurred within
60 days of a written demand to do so, either the Village or the contractor
performing work on the Village’s behalf may cause a lien to be filed against
the property as provided in 65 ILCS 5/11-20-13 or pursuant to such other
authority available to the Village. Any lien filed pursuant to this Section may
be foreclosed in the manner provided for mortgages or mechanics’ liens under
Illinois law.
C.   The payment or lien of the Village’s abatement costs is in addition to,
and not in lieu of, any penalty provided for a violation of this Chapter. (Ord.
2021-14, 7-12-2021)
4-2-7: PENALTY:
Any person or legal entity who violates any provision of this Section shall,
upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine for the violation of this Section
of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum
provided in Section
1-4-1 of this code for each such violation and for each day such violation
exists. (Ord. 2021-14, 7-12-2021)
CHAPTER 3
OPEN BURNING
SECTION:
4-3-1: Definitions
4-3-2: Open Burning Authorized By Permit For Natural Area Management Only
4-3-3: Open Burning Permit Requirements
4-3-4: Rules And Regulations For Permitted Open Burning
4-3-5: Penalty
4-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, and words shall
have the meanings given to them in this section. All terms, phrases, and words
used in this chapter but not defined in this section shall have the meanings
given to them elsewhere in this code.
BURN AREA: The location of open burning as designated in an open burning
permit.
FIRE CHIEF: The fire chief of the village or his or her designee.
GARBAGE: Any refuse, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, discarded paper,
wrappings, or similar materials; waste resulting from the handling, processing,
preparation, cooking, and consumption of food, and waste from the handling,
processing, storage, and sale of produce; and any other combustible waste,
refuse or rubbish.
LANDSCAPE WASTE: All accumulations of grass clippings, shrubbery and vine
cuttings, leaves, tree limbs, and other materials accumulated as the result of
the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines, trees, and other natural landscaping.
NATURAL AREA MANAGEMENT: Prescribed open burning conducted for the purpose of
maintaining the growth of vegetation in a designated natural area.
OPEN BURNING: The combustion or burning of any matter in the open or in an open
dump, excluding burning that the fire chief determines is conducted solely
within a residential recreational fire pit.
OPEN BURNING PERMIT: A permit for open burning issued by the fire chief
pursuant to this chapter.
PRESCRIBED BURNING 1 : A form of open burning consisting of the planned
application of fire to naturally occurring vegetative fuels under specified
environmental conditions and following appropriate precautionary measures,
which causes the fire to be confined to a predetermined area and accomplish the
planned land management objectives. (Ord. 2013-21, 9-23-2013)
 
Notes
1 1. 525 ILCS 37/10.
4-3-2: OPEN BURNING AUTHORIZED BY PERMIT FOR NATURAL AREA MANAGEMENT ONLY:
A.   Prescribed Burning For Natural Area Management Authorized By Permit: Open
burning is permitted in the village only for the purposes of conducting
prescribed burning for natural area management and only pursuant to an open
burning permit.
B.   All Other Open Burning Prohibited: Open burning of landscape debris or
garbage or for any purpose other than prescribed burning for natural area
management is prohibited, provided, however that burn piles of natural area
cuttings and trimmings may be considered by the fire chief for inclusion in the
permitted burning activity.
C.   Permit Required; Violations: Any open burning conducted without a permit
shall be considered a violation of this chapter and is hereby declared a public
nuisance. The village may pursue all available remedies at law concerning a
violation of this chapter including, without limitation, the revocation of such
permit and the imposition of those fines and penalties set forth in section
4-3-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 2013-21, 9-23-2013)
4-3-3: OPEN BURNING PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A.   Application And Required Data: Prior to issuance of any open burning
permit, the person requesting the open burning permit must submit an
application to the fire chief that includes the following information:
1.   A complete and validly issued permit issued by the Illinois environmental
protection agency, or such other agency as may have jurisdiction, authorizing
the applicant to conduct open burning, including all pages of the issued permit
and all application materials submitted to the state of Illinois in applying
for such state permit.
2.   A map and aerial photograph of the proposed burn area clearly showing the
boundaries of the proposed burn area, including, without limitation, depictions
of all fire lanes and/or containment methods which will be used to prevent the
spread of fire beyond the proposed burn area.
3.   A list of the persons who will be in charge of the open burning and their
fire control experience with acknowledgment that those persons must be on
location at the burn area for the duration of the open burning. The person in
charge of the open burning must make an in person report to the village's
public safety dispatch personnel confirming a valid in force permit is on file
and wind and weather conditions are within the allowable range, and,
immediately after completion of the open burning, must make an in person report
to the village's public safety dispatch personnel confirming that the fire is
completely extinguished.
4.   A list of similar open burning performed by the applicant in the past
year, if any, including the communities, size of burn area and fire department
with which coordination was accomplished.
5.   A list of equipment that will be on location of the burn area throughout
the burn.
6.   The proposed primary date and proposed alternate dates to be used if
conditions are not acceptable on the primary date of the burn, the proposed
time of the burn and an estimate of length of time for the burn activities.
7.   Proof of general liability insurance policy in the amount of one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and a minimum of two million dollars
($2,000,000.00) aggregate naming the village as additionally insured party with
no endorsements or modifications limiting the coverage provided to the village
concerning the open burning activities being requested, in a form acceptable to
the village.
8.   Confirmation that notice to adjoining residents will be provided by the
applicant as required pursuant to subsection 4-3-4D of this chapter, including,
without limitation, a sample of the notices to be sent.
B.   Inspection Of Area: The burn area must be inspected by the fire chief
prior to issuance of an open burning permit, and all areas to be burned, if so
directed by the fire chief, must be cleared of all growth of an average height
of more than twenty four inches (24") (except for native trees which are not
planned to be affected by the proposed burn), with the cut debris removed from
the site and properly disposed of prior to issuance of the permit. Upon
approval of an open burning permit, areas with growth exceeding this limit may
be burned if, on inspection, the fire chief determines this will not
significantly increase the potential hazard of the burn in the specific area
involved.
C.   Evaluation Of Permit Application: The fire chief shall, in his sole
discretion, approve, approve with conditions, or deny an application for an
open burning permit. The fire chief may deny any application for an open
burning permit when the fire chief determines that the proposed open burning
would present an unreasonable hazard to the public health, safety and welfare.
If any application for an open burning permit is denied, the applicant may
appeal such denial to the village administrator pursuant to subsection 4-3-4G
of this chapter.
D.   Conditions On Issuance Of Permit; Conditions; Multiple Sites; Term;
Renewal:
1.   Conditions: If the fire chief determines that an open burning permit
should issue, the fire chief may establish such conditions or restrictions on
that permit as he deems reasonable and necessary to protect the public health,
safety, and welfare.
2.   Multiple Sites: Multiple physically adjoining sites of up to ten (10)
acres each may be covered in the same permit provided that all such sites
comply with the provisions of this chapter.
3.   Term; Renewal: Permits are valid only for a period of ninety (90) days
from the date of issuance. The fire chief may, but shall not be obligated to,
renew a permit for an additional period of up to ninety (90) days. (Ord. 2013-
21, 9-23-2013)
4-3-4: RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR PERMITTED OPEN BURNING:
A.   Notice To Fire Department: The permittee must contact the fire department
for final approval the morning of the proposed burn.
B.   Hours Restricted: Burning will only be allowed during daylight hours.
C.   Wind And Weather Conditions: Burning will only be allowed when the wind
speed, as determined by the fire chief or his designee, is greater than five
(5) miles per hour, but not greater than fifteen (15) miles per hour. Allowable
wind direction may be specified by the fire chief in the issued permit if the
fire chief determines that downwind areas may be negatively impacted by the
proposed burn. Notwithstanding the wind speed requirements of this subsection,
if the fire chief or his designee determines that specific weather conditions
on the day of the burn will result in open burning causing a threat to the
public health, safety, or welfare, the fire chief or his designee may, in his
or her sole discretion, cancel or reschedule the planned open burning or
immediately halt a burn if already in progress.
D.   Notice To Adjoining Residents: All residents adjoining all property for
which the open burning permit is sought shall be notified of the open burning
by the permittee in writing at least seventy two (72) hours in advance of the
proposed burn. Such notice shall give the location of the proposed burn, the
primary date and any approved alternate dates of the burn, approximate times
and length of burn and provide a telephone number that the resident can call to
receive further information if desired. The permittee shall concurrently
provide a copy of this notice to the fire chief. If any such neighboring
resident shall advise the village that persons residing in his or her household
have a medical condition which may be aggravated by the proposed burn, the
permittee will be required to notify such person the morning of the burn,
before commencement of the burn activity, provided the person is at home. Based
on the information specified in the permit application and any information
provided by residents adjoining the property for which the permit is sought,
the fire chief may require that notice, as specified above, be provided to
additional residents as the department deems appropriate. Those additional
residents requiring notification will be listed on the permit when issued or
added by modification to an issued permit should they become known after
issuance of the permit. The fire chief will take any comments by neighboring
residents into account when determining whether the open burning permit should
issue.
E.   Mutual Aid; Fees:
1.   The permit holder shall be responsible to pay the village the complete
cost of any response by the Lake Bluff fire department, or any other fire
department requested by the Lake Bluff fire department for mutual aid, due to
an emergency response to contain an open burn, including, without limitation,
the use and deployment of engines, grass fire trucks, manpower, equipment or
supplies, each at the costs, charges and fees set out in section
1-12-3 of this code.
2.   The determination as to need of the response of fire units to an open burn
will be made by the fire chief, provided that the permit holder can request
fire department response for an emergency.
F.   Revocation Or Termination: If the fire chief determines that the permit
holder of an open burning permit has not complied with any aspect of this
chapter, or that any ongoing open burning presents an unreasonable hazard to
the public health, safety and welfare, the fire chief may immediately revoke
the open burning permit and such permit shall be of no further force or effect.
G.   Appeal: A permit applicant or permit holder may appeal a decision of the
fire chief under this chapter by filing a written application with the village
administrator. The village administrator must issue a written decision within
fifteen (15) days after receipt of the appeal from the permit applicant. That
decision must be transmitted promptly to the applicant. A failure of the
village administrator to issue a written decision within fifteen (15) days will
be deemed a denial of the appeal. All decisions by the village administrator
are final.
H.   Disaster Burning: Open burning pursuant to the declaration of a natural
disaster shall be permitted as approved by the village board pursuant to their
authority to declare a natural disaster under state and federal law and shall
comply with the provisions of this chapter unless otherwise specified by the
village board pursuant to its declaration of such natural disaster. (Ord. 2013-
21, 9-23-2013)
4-3-5: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this section shall, upon conviction
thereof, be subject to a fine for the violation of this section of not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each such violation and for each day such violation
exists. (Ord. 2013-21, 9-23-2013)
CHAPTER 4
HAZARDOUS MATERIALS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Administration And Enforcement Officials
4-4-2: Definitions
4-4-3: Nuisance Declared
4-4-4: Liability For Abatement Of Nuisance
4-4-5: Use, Storage Or Production Of Hazardous Materials
4-4-6: Movement Of Hazardous Materials
4-4-7: Disposal Of Hazardous Materials
4-4-8: Disclosure Requirements
4-4-9: Posting Notices
4-4-10: Penalty
4-4-1: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS:
The fire prevention bureau of the village is charged with the administration of
the provisions of this chapter and shall enforce the same in coordination with
the fire chief and the chief of police of the village. (Ord. 88-22, 4-25-1988)
4-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise clearly requires, the following definitions are
hereby established:
DISCHARGE: Leakage, seepage or other release.
FACILITY, EQUIPMENT OR VEHICLES: Includes private, governmental or commercial
in nature whether by motor vehicle, truck, aircraft, railroad, boats, ships or
any means of transportation, storage or use.
HAZARDOUS MATERIAL: A substance or material in a quantity and form determined
by the Illinois department of transportation, the United States department of
health, education and welfare, or by the United States department of
transportation to be capable of posing an unreasonable risk to health and
safety or property.
HAZARDOUS MATERIALS ACCESS ROUTE: Any street which has been designated pursuant
to this chapter for the purpose of providing vehicular access from the primary
hazardous material route to locations within the village where hazardous
materials are used, produced, or stored. The following named streets are hereby
designated as hazardous materials access routes:
   Albrecht Drive
   Carriage Park Avenue
   North Shore Drive
   Sherwood Drive
   Sherwood Terrace
PERSON: Any natural person or individual, governmental body, firm, association,
partnership, copartnership, joint venture, company, corporation, joint stock
company, trust, estate or any other legal entity, or their legal
representative, agent or assigns, and includes public or private utilities,
governmental bodies or agencies other than the village of Lake Bluff, common
carriers, railroads, airplanes and ships and boats.
PRIMARY HAZARDOUS MATERIALS ROUTE: Includes only the following streets in the
village:
A.   U.S. Route 41 (Skokie Highway).
B.   Illinois State Route 43 (Waukegan Road).
C.   Illinois State Route 176 (Rockland Road) west of the westerly right of way
freight line railroad tracks of Union Pacific railway.
D.   Sheridan Road from the northern limits of the village to East Scranton
Avenue.
E.   Scranton Avenue from Sheridan Road easterly to Evanston Avenue.
TOXIC SUBSTANCE: Any substance, mixture, or compound containing a substance
which is listed in:
A.   The code of federal regulations, 29 CFR 1910.1000 through 1910.1500,
inclusive, and all amendments thereto.
B.   820 Illinois Compiled Statutes 255/1 et seq., and all amendments thereto.
C.   The United States department of health and human services, public health
service national toxicology program, second annual report on carcinogens -
December 1981 and its periodic updates. (Ord. 88-22, 4-25-1988; amd. 2009 Code;
Ord. 2014-21, 10-27-2014)
4-4-3: NUISANCE DECLARED:
A.   Within Village: The actual or threatened discharge of hazardous materials
within the village is hereby declared a nuisance.
B.   Outside Village: The actual discharge of hazardous materials outside the
corporate limits of the village which permeates or discharges into any portion
of the village is hereby declared a nuisance. (Ord. 88-22, 4-25-1988)
4-4-4: LIABILITY FOR ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE:
A.   Within Village: Any person who owns, leases, operates or controls any
facility or equipment, whether by railway, air, land or water, or vehicles,
including private, governmental or commercial, from which a discharge of
hazardous materials has occurred or threatened to occur in the village shall be
liable jointly and severally to the village for any expenses incurred by the
village in connection with preventing, cleaning up or disposing of or
attempting to prevent, clean up or dispose of any such discharge or threatened
discharge. This provision shall not release the owner of the hazardous material
from a simultaneous liability for cleanup or disposal.
B.   Outside Village: Any person who owns, leases, operates or controls any
facility, equipment or vehicles from which a discharge of hazardous materials
has occurred outside of the village and which permeates or discharges in any
part of the village, shall be liable jointly and severally to the village for
any expenses incurred by the village in connection with preventing, cleaning up
or disposing of or attempting to prevent, clean up or dispose of any such
discharge. This provision shall not release the owner of the hazardous material
from a simultaneous liability for cleanup or disposal. (Ord. 88-22, 4-25-1988)
4-4-5: USE, STORAGE OR PRODUCTION OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS:
Every person who uses, produces or stores hazardous materials or toxic
substances at any location within the village shall abide by and operate in
conformance with all of the requirements and provisions of the regulations and
directives therefor promulgated by the fire prevention code of the village as
set forth in section
5-3-3 of this code, as amended, and shall abide by and operate in conformance
with all of the provisions of title III (emergency planning and community right
to know) of the super fund amendment and reauthorization act (SARA) of the
United States code. (Ord. 88-22, 4-25-1988)
4-4-6: MOVEMENT OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS:
A.   Use Of Certain Streets Required:
1.   It shall be unlawful to move or transport in any way, any "hazardous
materials", as defined in section
4-4-2 of this chapter, within the village except upon the streets heretofore
designated as primary hazardous materials routes or hazardous materials access
routes.
2.   Every motor vehicle which displays or is required to display a hazardous
materials placard shall be operated within the village only on the primary
hazardous materials route established pursuant to the provisions of this
chapter.
B.   Request For Route:
1.   Every person who uses, produces or stores hazardous materials at a
location within the village shall request from the fire department a hazardous
materials access route to and from such location.
2.   Every operator of a motor vehicle which displays or is required to display
a hazardous materials placard who does not know the primary hazardous materials
routes of the village or the hazardous material access route to and from the
location in the village from which he is coming or to which he is destined
shall request directions concerning said routes from the fire department before
operating said vehicle in the village.
C.   Assignment Of Route: Any person who uses, produces, or stores hazardous
materials at a location within the village shall be assigned a hazardous
materials transportation route after he has submitted a request for such a
route to the village fire department on a form provided by the fire department.
Upon receipt of such a request, the fire department shall assign to such person
a route which, in the judgment of the fire department and all other interested
departments, is consistent with and implements the purpose of this chapter.
D.   Streets Designated: No motor vehicle which displays or is required to
display a hazardous materials placard shall be operated on any street within
the village other than U.S. Route 41 (Skokie Highway) or Illinois State Route
43 (Waukegan Road), Illinois State Route 176 (Rockland Road) east of Skokie
Boulevard, Sheridan Road from the northern limits of the village to East
Scranton Avenue, and Scranton Avenue from Sheridan Road east to Evanston Avenue
unless such vehicle is coming from or destined for a location within the
village on an approved access route as provided for herein.
E.   Certain Vehicles Exempt: The following types of vehicles are exempt from
the provisions of this section:
1.   Placarded vehicles making residential deliveries of home heating fuel.
2.   Placarded vehicles making residential deliveries of medical supplies.
3.   Placarded vehicles which are not required under the provisions of this
chapter to request a hazardous materials access route, that are picking up or
delivering nonhazardous materials at a location within the village, may use the
most direct route to and from the location as close as possible to said
location on the primary hazardous materials route or a hazardous materials
access route assigned to a business in the vicinity of said location. (Ord. 88-
22, 4-25-1988)
4-4-7: DISPOSAL OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS:
A.   Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of hazardous
materials within the village unless such disposal is conducted in accordance
with applicable local, state and federal rules and regulations pertaining to
the disposal of such materials.
B.   Nuisance Declared: The unlawful disposal of hazardous materials within the
village is hereby declared a nuisance.
C.   Liability For Abatement: Any person who engages in the unlawful disposal
of hazardous materials within the village shall be liable to the village for
any and all expenses in connection with cleaning up and lawfully disposing of
said materials. (Ord. 88-22, 4-25-1988)
4-4-8: DISCLOSURE REQUIREMENTS:
Every person who uses, produces, transports or stores hazardous materials or
toxic substances at a location within the village shall provide the fire chief
with all information concerning the use, production and storage of such
materials, which such person is required to provide to the local fire
department under all governing laws and regulations enacted or promulgated from
time to time by either the state of Illinois or the United States of America
and departments thereof. (Ord. 88-22, 4-25-1988)
4-4-9: POSTING NOTICES:
The village administrator shall cause the posting of notices at each entrance
to the village giving notice to vehicular traffic of the regulations contained
in this chapter. Said notice shall be by signs erected in accordance with the
standards and specifications as required by law or the statutes of the state of
Illinois or any other regulatory body having jurisdiction. (Ord. 88-22, 4-25-
1988)
4-4-10: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be fined in an amount of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor
more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day that a violation exists or continues to exist
shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 88-22, 4-25-1988; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 5
SMOKING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Introduction
4-5-2: Title; Purpose
4-5-3: Definitions
4-5-4: Applicability Of Smoke Free Illinois Act
4-5-5: Prohibitions And Exceptions
4-5-6: Signs And Ashtrays
4-5-7: Owner And Occupant Responsibility
4-5-8: Penalty
4-5-1: INTRODUCTION:
Smoking creates the hazard of injury to the personal health of those in the
environment of such smoke as well as the potential damage to property which may
result from the combustible nature of such substance. It has been determined
that breathing ambient smoke is a health hazard to both smokers and nonsmokers.
Cigarette smoking also produces several substances that are considered
hazardous to health including carbon monoxide, hydrogen cyanide, nitrous oxide
and formaldehyde. Secondhand smoke (68 percent of the smoke produced by a
cigarette) affects the health of the bystander, interfering with respiratory
tract defenses, often causing nonsmokers to have allergic or irritative
reactions, and is a known cause of lung cancer.
The use of e-cigarettes, as an alternative to smoking traditional cigarettes,
has proliferated in recent years. Although often marketed as safe, the United
States food and drug administration has issued a caution related to e-
cigarettes because the safety and efficacy of e-cigarettes have not been fully
researched and studied, and it is not known if the use of e-cigarettes may lead
young people to try tobacco products, including conventional cigarettes, which
are known to cause disease and lead to premature death.
Because the hazards of smoking and the use of e-cigarettes have a potentially
harmful effect, material and direct, on the public health, safety, welfare,
comfort and property of residents of the village, it is, therefore, necessary
and desirable to establish regulations that prohibit smoking and the use of e-
cigarettes in all enclosed public places, in all places of employment, and in
certain unenclosed public places. (Ord. 2015-15, 9-28-2015)
4-5-2: TITLE; PURPOSE:
This chapter may be cited as the LAKE BLUFF SMOKING BAN ORDINANCE, the purpose
of which is to protect the public health, comfort and environment by
prohibiting smoking and the use of e-cigarettes in all enclosed public places,
all places of employment, and in certain unenclosed public areas, in order to
ensure that nonsmokers may breathe air free from the hazardous effects of
secondhand smoke. (Ord. 2015-15, 9-28-2015)
4-5-3: DEFINITIONS:
Wherever the following words or phrases are used, they shall, for purposes of
this chapter, have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except when
the context otherwise indicates. If a word or phrase is not specifically
defined in this section, it shall have the meaning ascribed thereto in the
smoke free Illinois act.
CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT: The area defined as such by the village of Lake
Bluff zoning map.
E-CIGARETTE: An electronic device that typically includes a mouthpiece, a
heating element or atomizer, a battery, and electronic circuits; provides a gas
derived from a liquid that includes nicotine, propylene glycol, or similar
substance and perhaps other substances; and is inhaled by a user in a manner
that simulates or resembles smoking. The term "e-cigarette" includes all manner
of these devices, regardless of the details of a device's appearance or
marketed name, that are manufactured to resemble a cigarette, cigar, pipe, or
other smoking device. The term "e-cigarette" includes the cartridges and
component parts of an e-cigarette, individually or in any combination.
ENTRANCE:
A.   The doorway or other entrance to a public place that is open to, and
intended for use by, the general public for ingress and egress to the public
place; and
B.   The doorway or other entrance to a place of employment that is open to,
and intended for use by, the general public or business invitees for ingress
and egress to a place of employment, or where employees are required or
permitted to enter or exit.
LAKE BLUFF GOLF COURSE: A public 18-hole golf course owned by the Lake Bluff
park district, which is located at 355 Washington Street in Lake Bluff,
Illinois.
OUTDOOR EATING AREA: A seating area open to the air that is accessory to a
restaurant.
OUTDOOR VENUE: An outdoor theater, amphitheater, plaza, street or other
improved area that is used as a public venue or forum to which members of the
general public are invited to listen, view or otherwise participate in an event
that is organized, licensed or permitted by the owner of the venue, and
including, without limitation, parking lots located on the same property as the
theater, amphitheater, plaza, street, or other improved area.
PARK GROUNDS: All unenclosed areas of a park, beach or playground: a) that is
owned or operated by the village, the park district of Lake Bluff, or a public
school district; and b) to which members of the general public have been
granted a right of access. Park grounds shall include, without limitation,
parking lots located on the same property as the park or playground.
PUBLIC MEETING: A meeting open to the public pursuant to the Illinois open
meetings act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/1 et seq.
SCHOOL GROUNDS: All unenclosed areas of property on which a public or private
school, or school related use, is located, which areas shall include, without
limitation, parking lots located on the same property as the public or private
school or school related use.
SMOKE FREE ILLINOIS ACT: The smoke free Illinois act, 410 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 82/1 et seq., as may be amended.
VILLAGE GREEN: The village owned parcel located within the central business
district that is surrounded by Scranton Avenue, Sheridan Road and Center
Avenue. (Ord. 2008-8, 4-28-2008; amd. Ord. 2015-15, 9-28-2015)
4-5-4: APPLICABILITY OF SMOKE FREE ILLINOIS ACT:
The village hereby acknowledges that the smoke free Illinois act is applicable,
and is in full force and effect, within the village. No person shall smoke, or
use an e-cigarette, in any place in the village within which smoking is
prohibited pursuant to the smoke free Illinois act. In the event of a conflict
between the smoke free Illinois act and the provisions of this chapter, the
most restrictive provision shall control. (Ord. 2015-15, 9-28-2015)
4-5-5: PROHIBITIONS AND EXCEPTIONS:
A.   Unenclosed Public Places: No person shall smoke, or use an e-cigarette, in
the following unenclosed public places:
1.   Outdoor venues;
2.   Park grounds;
3.   School grounds;
4.   Public transportation loading areas and platforms;
5.   Public golf driving ranges;
6.   The Lake Bluff Golf Course, except for those areas on the golf course
located at least seventy five feet (75') from the clubhouse building;
7.   Village owned parking lots;
8.   Outdoor eating areas; provided, however, that this prohibition shall not
apply to any person who is temporarily in any portion of an outdoor eating area
that is located on a public sidewalk for the sole purpose of walking or
traversing through such area;
9.   Public sidewalks within twenty five feet (25') of an outdoor eating area;
provided, however, that this prohibition shall not apply to any person who is
temporarily in such area for the sole purpose of walking or traversing through
such area;
10.   The Village Green; and
11.   Gasoline or fuel stations.
B.   Entrances: Smoking, and the use of e-cigarettes, shall be prohibited
within twenty five feet (25') of an entrance to any place (enclosed or
unenclosed) within which smoking is prohibited; provided, however, that this
prohibition shall not apply to any person who is temporarily in such area for
the sole purpose of walking or traversing through such area.
C.   Public Meetings: Smoking, and the use of e-cigarettes, shall be prohibited
in all public meetings.
D.   Common Residential Areas: No person shall smoke, or use an e-cigarette, in
any common or public place (including, without limitation, lobbies, hallways,
reception areas, public restrooms, and elevators) of any apartment building,
condominium, dormitory building, nursing home, long term care facility, or
other multiple-family residential structures; provided, however, that smoking,
and the use of e-cigarettes, shall be permitted in semiprivate rooms in a
nursing home or long term care facility of which all of the occupants: 1) are
smokers and/or habitual users of e-cigarettes; and 2) have requested in writing
to be placed or to remain in a room where smoking, and/or the use of e-
cigarettes, is permitted. (Ord. 2015-15, 9-28-2015)
4-5-6: SIGNS AND ASHTRAYS:
Each owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of any place within
which smoking or the use of e-cigarettes is prohibited pursuant to this chapter
shall:
A.   Signs Posted: Conspicuously post signs indicating that smoking is
prohibited in the same manner as is described in sections 20(a) and 20(b) of
the smoke free Illinois act; provided, however, that in the event that there is
no clearly defined entrance to a place within which smoking is prohibited
pursuant to this chapter, such signs shall be posted on or adjacent to an
existing identification sign located on the property; and
B.   Ashtrays Removed: Remove all ashtrays from the place within which smoking
is prohibited, in the same manner as is described in section 20(c) of the smoke
free Illinois act. (Ord. 2015-15, 9-28-2015)
4-5-7: OWNER AND OCCUPANT RESPONSIBILITY:
It shall be unlawful for any person who is the owner, occupant, or lessee of
any place where smoking or the use of e-cigarettes is prohibited pursuant to
this chapter to permit smoking or the use of e-cigarettes in that place. (Ord.
2015-15, 9-28-2015)
4-5-8: PENALTY:
Any person who violates section
4-5-4,
4-5-5 or
4-5-6 of this chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor
more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each and every offense. Each day on which a violation of
this chapter occurs or exists shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense.
(Ord. 2008-8, 4-28-2008; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 6
LEAF BLOWER REGULATIONS
SECTION:
4-6-1:   Purpose And Intent
4-6-2:   Definitions
4-6-3:   Use Of Leaf Blowers
4-6-4:   Use Of Leaf Blowers For Spraying Pesticide Prohibited
4-6-5:   Exceptions
4-6-6:   Penalty
4-6-1:   PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose of this chapter is to promote sustainable landscape practices in
the Village by transitioning from the use of gas-powered leaf blowers to the
use of other more sustainable methods and means. (Ord. 2023-5, 3-13-2023)
4-6-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, and words shall
have the meanings given to them in this section. All terms, phrases and words
used in this chapter but not defined in this section shall have the meanings
given to them elsewhere in this Code.
 
ELECTRIC LEAF BLOWER:    Any leaf blower that is powered solely by electricity.
GAS POWERED LEAF BLOWER: Any leaf blower that is powered by gasoline or
                         propane.
                         Includes both stand-alone fossil fuel powered
PORTABLE GENERATOR:      generators and generators powered by vehicle engines.
                         (Ord. 2023-5, 3-13-2023)
 
4-6-3:   USE OF LEAF BLOWERS:
A.   Gasoline powered or propane powered leaf blowers may not be used during
the following days of the year: May 15 to September 30.
B.    Electric leaf blowers may continue to be used with no seasonal
restrictions.
C.    The use of portable generators to power electric leaf blowers or to
recharge leaf blower batteries is prohibited.
   Leaf blower usage is prohibited on all recognized national holidays. (Ord.
2023-5, 3-13-2023)
4-6-4:   USE OF LEAF BLOWERS FOR SPRAYING PESTICIDE PROHIBITED:
The use of any type of leaf blower to spray pesticide is prohibited. (Ord.
2023-5, 3-13-2023)
4-6-5: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to:
A.   Prior to April 1, 2025, public parks, school playgrounds, and athletic
fields;
B.   In-play areas of public golf courses;
C.   Construction projects involving paving, repair, or patching of public
streets; and
D.   Cleanup activities necessary as a result of extreme weather or other
emergency conditions as determined and authorized in advance by the Village
Administrator. (Ord. 2023-5, 3-13-2023)
4-6-6: PENALTY:
Any person or legal entity who violates any provision of this section shall,
upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine for the violation of this section
of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum
provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code for each such violation and for each day such violation
exists. (Ord. 2023-5, 3-13-2023)
TITLE 5
POLICE AND PUBLIC SAFETY
CHAPTER 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
5-1-1: Established; Composition
5-1-2: Chief Of Police And Deputy Chief Of Police
5-1-3: Police Officers
5-1-3A: Part-Time Police Officers
5-1-4: Auxiliary Police
5-1-5: Police Pension Fund Contributions
5-1-6: Penalty
5-1-1: ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION:
A.   Membership: There is hereby created and established a department of the
village to be known as the police department which shall be under the
supervision of the village administrator. The police department shall consist
of a chief of police, a deputy chief of police if determined by the board of
trustees, and such number of police officers of grade and rank as may be deemed
necessary and proper by the board of trustees, employed pursuant to the rules
and regulations of the board of fire and police commissioners of the village.
B.   Chief Of Police And Deputy Chief Of Police: The chief of police and deputy
chief of police shall be employed as provided in section
1-6F-1 of this code, and the terms of their employment shall be as determined
by the board of trustees.
C.   Reduction In Number Of Police Officers: The board of trustees may, in its
discretion, reduce the number of police officers. In that event, any employment
made shall be terminated in accordance with the rules and regulations of the
board of fire and police commissioners then in effect, relating thereto, based
upon seniority and other applicable requirements imposed by law.
D.   Part-Time Police Officers: There is created the position of part-time
