police officer; a position of employment of the village. Part-time police
officers will be appointed, disciplined, and discharged by the village
administrator and chief of police and will have the powers and duties set forth
in this chapter. Part time police officers will not be assigned, under any
circumstances, to supervise or direct full time police officers of the police
department. The number of part-time police officers serving the village will be
determined by the village administrator, with the advice and consent of the
corporate authorities. (Ord. 2014-4, 2-24-2014; amd. Ord. 2024-6, 4-9-2024)
5-1-2: CHIEF OF POLICE AND DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE:
A.   Chief Of Police:
1.   Bond: The chief of police shall execute, acknowledge and deliver to the
village treasurer a bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00),
in the usual form, or as is or shall hereafter be provided by law, with good
and sufficient surety to be approved by the village board of trustees, and the
cost of the premium of said bond to be borne by the village, said bond
conditioned on the faithful performance of his official duties.
2.   Oath: The chief of police shall also take the customary oath of office
before entering upon the duties of such office.
3.   Powers And Duties: The chief of police shall:
a.   Be the commanding officer of all sworn police officers and civilian
personnel employed by the village in the police department. The chief of police
shall perform such duties as are imposed upon him by law or ordinance and, in
addition thereto, such other duties as may be assigned to him by the village
administrator. He shall, under the supervision of the village administrator,
pursuant to guidance from the village board of trustees, have full management
and control of the police department, and all regulations and orders of the
police department shall be promulgated through him. The chief of police shall
see that all members of the police department are prompt and faithful in the
discharge of their duties and that they take such measures as may be deemed
expedient for the preservation of peace and good order and the enforcement of
the laws and ordinances of the village.
b.   Cause the public peace to be preserved and to see that the laws and
ordinances are enforced, and whenever any violation thereof shall come to his
knowledge, or be reported to him, he shall attend to the prosecution of the
offender.
c.   Be the custodian of all property provided for the use of the police
department and shall also be the custodian of all stolen goods or other
property received and retained by police authority.
d.   Be the keeper of the village public safety building and its jail and shall
have the custody of all persons incarcerated therein.
e.   Report to the village attorney all breaches of the village ordinances as
in his judgment require village attorney attention, and shall aid the attorney
in the prosecution thereof.
f.   Pay to the proper custodian thereof, all monies collected by him within
two (2) days after receiving the same.
g.   Report in writing to the village administrator at the beginning of each
month, the activities of the police department, and such other information he
deems necessary or appropriate, and such other information requested by the
village administrator.
B.   Deputy Chief Of Police:
1.   Oath: The deputy chief of police shall take the customary oath of office
before entering upon the duties of such office.
2.   Powers And Duties: The deputy chief of police shall:
a.   Have those powers, duties, and responsibilities as established by the
chief of police in consultation with the village administrator, pursuant to the
rules and regulations of the police department.
b.   Have, in the absence of the chief of police, all of the powers, duties,
and responsibilities of the chief of police as authorized by state statute and
this code.
C.   Residency: All newly appointed chiefs of police and deputy chiefs of
police of the village shall reside within the village within twelve (12) months
after the date of their appointment unless otherwise authorized by the board of
trustees. (Ord. 2014-4, 2-24-2014)
5-1-3: POLICE OFFICERS:
A.   Qualifications:
1.   All members of the police department shall be United States citizens and
meet such additional qualifications as established from time to time by the
board of fire and police commissioners.
2.   Police personnel shall reside either in the village limits or within a
radius of ten (10) miles of the village limits within twelve (12) months after
the date of their appointment to the police department.
B.   Neglect Of Duty: Any sworn member of the police department who shall
neglect or refuse to perform any duty required by ordinance of the village or
who, in the discharge of his duties, shall be guilty of fraud, extortion,
oppression, favoritism, wilful wrong or injustice, shall be subject to
disciplinary action before the board of fire and police commissioners of the
village. (1988 Code § 7-1A-3)
5-1-3A: PART-TIME POLICE OFFICERS:
A.   Appointment. The village administrator and chief of police may appoint
part-time police officers as employees in such number as the board of trustees
will approve. In making such appointments, the village administrator and chief
of police, in their discretion, may consult with the board of police and fire
commissioners. Part-time police officers will be members of the regular police
department, except for pension purposes. Part-time police officers may not be
used as permanent replacements for permanent full time police officers.
B.   Background Check. Prior to appointment, a part-time police officer will be
subject to a background check, including without limitation a fingerprinting
verification by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Illinois State
Police, Bureau of Identification. No person who has been convicted of a felony
or other crime involving moral turpitude may be appointed as a part-time police
officer. The chief of police in their discretion may administer any other
additional tests allowed by state law or required for full-time police officers
for part-time police officer applicants.
C.   Qualifications. Part-time police officer applicants must meet the
qualifications established from time to time by the village administrator in
consultation with the chief of police.
D.   Training. Part-time police officers will be trained under the
Intergovernmental Law Enforcement Officer's In-Service Training Act, 50 ILCS
720/1 et seq., as amended, in accordance with the procedures for part-time
police officers established by the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards
Board.
E.   Hiring Standards. The following standards will apply at the time of
application:
   1.   The applicant must be twenty-one (21) years of age or older.
   2.   The applicant must possess a diploma from an accredited high school or
a General Equivalency Diploma (GED).
   3.   The applicant must have the following qualifications:
      a.   United States citizenship.
      b.   Valid Class D Illinois driver's license.
      c.   No felony convictions or disqualifying criminal histories.
      d.   Eye sight of not worse than 20/100 correctable to 20/20.
   4.   The applicant must satisfy all other requirements for part-time police
officers required pursuant to the laws of the State of Illinois.
F.   Powers and Duties.
   1.   Part-time police officers will be assigned to perform duties by the
chief of police.
   2.   Part-time police officers at all times during the performance of their
duties will be subject to the direction and control of the chief of police.
Part-time police officers will be subject to discipline and discharge by the
chief of police.
G.   Compensation. Part-time police officers will be paid an hourly wage for
each hour of service that is performed at the direction of the chief of police.
H.   Coverage by Worker's Compensation. Part-time police officers will be
considered employees of the village and, as employees, will be covered by the
village's worker's compensation insurance. (Ord. 2024-6, 4-8-2024)
5-1-4: AUXILIARY POLICE:
A.   Appointment: The village administrator may, with the advice and consent of
the village board of trustees, appoint auxiliary police officers in such number
as the village administrator shall from time to time deem necessary.
B.   Supervisory Authority: Such auxiliary police officers shall at all times
during the performance of their duties be subject to the direction and control
of the chief of police.
C.   Duties: Such auxiliary police officers shall not be members of the regular
police department. Such auxiliary police officers shall not supplement members
of the regular police department in the performance of their assigned and
normal duties, except as otherwise provided herein. Such auxiliary police
officers shall only be assigned to perform the following duties:
1.   To aid or direct traffic.
2.   To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters.
3.   To aid in case of civil disorder as directed by the chief of police;
provided, that in cases which render it impractical for members of the regular
police department to perform the normal and regular police duties, the chief of
police is hereby authorized to assign auxiliary police officers to perform such
normal and regular police duties.
D.   Identification: Identification symbols worn by such auxiliary police
officers shall be different and distinct from those used by members of the
regular police department.
E.   Firearms: Such auxiliary police officers shall not carry firearms except
with the permission of the chief of police, and while in uniform and in the
performance of their duties.
F.   Conservators Of The Peace: Such auxiliary police officers when on duty
shall also be conservators of the peace and shall have the powers as specified
in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-15-25.
G.   Training: Auxiliary police officers, prior to entering upon any of their
duties, shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other
police procedures as shall be appropriate in the exercise of the powers
conferred upon them under this section, which training and course of study
shall be determined and provided by the chief of police.
H.   Fingerprinting; Background Check: Prior to the appointment of any
auxiliary police officer, fingerprints shall be taken, and no person shall be
appointed as such auxiliary police officer if he has been convicted of a felony
or other crime involving moral turpitude. (1988 Code § 7-1A-4)
5-1-5: POLICE PENSION FUND CONTRIBUTIONS:
A.   Employee contributions to the police pension fund shall be paid by the
village on behalf of all employees enrolled in the fund upon receipt of a
ruling from the internal revenue service that, pursuant to section 414(h) of
the United States internal revenue code, such employer paid contributions are
not included as gross income until they are distributed or made available.
B.   The payment shall be made by reducing the gross earnings payable to
employees by the amount of the contributions and by making payment of such
amount directly to the fund.
C.   Contributions, although designated as employee contributions, are being
paid by the employer in lieu of contributions by the employee.
D.   The employee does not have the option of choosing to receive the
contributions directly instead of having them paid by the employer to the plan.
(Ord. 92-31, 11-23-1992)
5-1-6: PENALTY:
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than the
maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each and every offense. (1988 Code § 7-1A-5; amd. 2009
Code)
CHAPTER 2
FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
5-2-1: Established; Composition; Duties
5-2-2: Compensation
5-2-3: Fire Chief
5-2-4: Officers Of Department
5-2-5: Fees For Services Outside Corporate Limits
5-2-6: Prohibited Acts
5-2-7: Penalty
5-2-1: ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION; DUTIES:
A.   Department Established; Composition: There is hereby established a
department of the municipal government of the village which shall be known as
the fire department and which shall embrace one fire chief, fire officers, a
secretary, a treasurer and the members of the fire department. (1988 Code § 8-
1-1)
B.   Duties Generally: The fire department shall respond and assume control of
all fires and other situations that threaten the lives or property of the
residents of the village, except those that are the duties of the police
department. (1988 Code § 8-1-1; amd. 2009 Code)
5-2-2: COMPENSATION:
The board of trustees may, from time to time, by resolution or ordinance,
provide for such compensation for the fire chief and members of the fire
department as it deems just and reasonable. (1988 Code § 8-1-2)
5-2-3: FIRE CHIEF 1 :
A.   Employment And Dismissal:
1.   Term Of Employment: A person shall be employed by the village as fire
chief and shall be the head of the fire department. Such employment shall be by
ordinance or resolution of the board of trustees and shall continue until a
successor shall be employed.
2.   Authority To Discharge: The village president shall have the right to
discharge the fire chief; provided, that the president shall report such
discharge to the board of trustees at their next regular meeting. If such
discharge is not concurred by a majority of the members present at said
meeting, the fire chief shall be reemployed.
B.   Powers And Duties:
1.   Manage Department; Employ And Remove Members: The fire chief shall have
the management and control of all matters and things pertaining to said fire
department. The fire chief shall employ and remove officers and members of the
fire department. Appeals to the termination of any officer or member may be
made to the village administrator.
2.   Authority And Control: The fire chief shall have sole and absolute control
and command over all persons connected with the fire department of the village
while on duty.
3.   Establish Rules And Regulations: The fire chief shall possess full power
and authority over the fire department organization, government and discipline,
and to that end may prescribe and establish, from time to time, such rules and
regulations as deemed advisable, subject to the approval of the village
administrator.
4.   Custody Of Equipment: The fire chief shall have the custody of the
engines, equipment and property belonging to the fire department.
5.   Investigate Fires; Right Of Entry: The fire chief or other fire department
members as designated by the fire chief shall investigate the cause and origin
of all fires and other incidents responded to by the fire department, as well.
The fire department shall have the right to enter upon the premises where an
emergency has occurred to perform such investigation.
6.   Submit Reports: The fire chief shall submit a monthly report to the board
of trustees, via the village administrator, listing the number and types of
fire department responses, training received by the fire department members,
and any unusual occurrences. In addition, an annual report shall be submitted
in January of each year to the board of trustees through the village
administrator, showing the total annual responses by the fire department by
category, description of buildings and property destroyed or damaged, and any
other information, statistics or suggestions the fire chief feels the board of
trustees should know regarding the response capabilities of the fire
department, and the causes and origins of fires responded to by the fire
department.
7.   Attend Fires: It shall be the duty of the fire chief, if the chief is
able, to attend all fires happening in the village, and in case of the absence
of the fire chief from any fire, it shall be the duty of another officer to
take charge of the department, and during the absence of the chief, such
officer shall have and exercise all the powers of the fire chief.
8.   Examine Dangerous Buildings: The fire chief shall examine all buildings or
walls reported dangerous or damaged by fire or accident and shall, whenever
necessary, make a report of the condition thereof to the board of trustees.
9.   Prescribe Limits At Emergency Scene: The fire chief, or other officer in
command, may prescribe limits in the vicinity of any emergency scene, within
which only those given permission by a fire department officer may go, and the
police department shall, on request of the fire chief or other officer in
command, enforce the provisions of this subsection B9.
10.   Remove Property: The fire chief, or other officer in command, may cause
the removal of any property whenever it shall become necessary for the
preservation of such property from fire, or to prevent the spreading of fire,
or to protect adjoining property. The fire chief may direct the members of the
fire department to cut down or remove any building, erection, fence or trees
for the purposes of checking the progress of any fire. (1988 Code § 8-1-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 1-6G-1 of this code.
5-2-4: OFFICERS OF DEPARTMENT:
A.   Secretary: A secretary of the fire department shall be elected by the
members of the fire department at a meeting to be held in May of each year. The
secretary shall keep a record of all meetings of the fire department and
perform such other duties as directed by the fire chief.
B.   Treasurer:
1.   Election And Duties: A treasurer of the fire department shall be elected
by the members of the fire department at their regular meeting held in May of
each year. The treasurer shall keep a record of all monies received on account
of the foreign fire insurance tax and keep such monies separate and apart from
all other funds. The proceeds of said foreign fire insurance tax shall be paid
out only on checks signed by the fire chief and treasurer after an
authorization vote of the majority of members present at a regular or special
fire department meeting. (1988 Code § 8-1-5)
2.   Bond: The village shall secure a bond to be executed by the treasurer to
the village. The premiums for such bond shall be paid for by the village. The
penal sum of said bond shall be equal to twice the amount of the funds expected
to be produced from the foreign fire insurance tax. The treasurer shall submit
all records for the foreign fire insurance tax to the auditors designated by
the village board whenever requested. (1988 Code § 8-1-5; amd. 2009 Code)
5-2-5: FEES FOR SERVICES OUTSIDE CORPORATE LIMITS:
A.   Services Provided On Fee Basis: Subject to the provisions contained in
subsection C of this section, fire protection service shall be afforded on a
fee basis as provided for herein to those residents and entities in those
portions of Shoreacres, Arden Shore North and Arden Shore South not situated
within the corporate limits of the village. (Ord. 92-15, 7-13-1992)
B.   Fees:
1.   Responses And Services: The fees for the following responses and services
shall be pursuant to the service agreement:
a.   Each fire engine dispatched to an out of district emergency.
b.   Each pickup truck dispatched to an out of district emergency.
c.   Each individual dispatched to an out of district emergency.
d.   The cost of any supplies used or expended during an emergency incident
including, but not limited to, foam, salvage covers, etc.
e.   Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary, minimum charge
for calls, whether genuine or false. (Ord. 92-15, 7-13-1992; amd. 2009 Code)
2.   Proration: No proration will be made for a part of an hour on any of the
above fees.
C.   Response At Discretion Of Department Officer: No response will be made by
the fire department to fire calls from owners of property outside the corporate
limits of the village in the event of prior or coincident fire calls involving
property located in the village, or if, for any reason, in the judgment of the
officer then in charge at the headquarters of the fire department, such
response would jeopardize fire protection service to the village. (Ord. 92-15,
7-13-1992)
5-2-6: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A.   Refuse To Obey Orders; Hindering Firefighters: All persons who are present
at an incident shall be subject to the orders of the fire chief and other
officers of the fire department. In case any person shall refuse to obey any
such orders, such person shall be fined as provided for herein. Any person who
shall wilfully offer any hindrance to any officer or firefighter in the
performance of his duty at an emergency incident, or who injures, destroys or
defaces any fire department equipment shall, for each offense, be fined as
provided for hereinafter.
B.   Driving Over Fire Hose: No person shall drive any vehicle over unprotected
equipment of the fire department unless directed or permitted by a member of
the fire department. Any person violating any of the provisions of this
subsection shall be responsible for the cost of damage or repair or replacement
of such equipment, and the fine provided in section
5-2-7 of this chapter.
C.   Obstructing Fire Hydrants: No person shall in any manner obstruct the use
of any fire hydrant, or have or place any material within five feet (5') in any
direction of said fire hydrant. Any person violating any of the provisions of
this subsection shall be fined as provided in section
5-2-7 of this chapter. (1988 Code § 8-1-3)
5-2-7: PENALTY:
Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with
any provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than
seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1988 Code § 8-1-6; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 3
FIRE PREVENTION BUREAU
SECTION:
5-3-1: Established; Composition
5-3-2: Duties
5-3-3: Fire Prevention Code Adopted
5-3-4: Exemptions
5-3-5: Police Powers Of Village
5-3-6: Hazardous Waste Regulations Enforcement
5-3-7: Prosecution Does Not Relieve Compliance
5-3-8: Violations; Penalty
5-3-1: ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION:
There is hereby established in the village a bureau of fire prevention. The
members of the bureau of fire prevention shall consist of the chief of the fire
department, fire inspectors of the fire department, and village trustees who
are members of the public safety committee. (1988 Code § 8-2-1)
5-3-2: DUTIES:
A.   Enforce Laws: It shall be the duty of the bureau of fire prevention to
enforce all laws and ordinances of the village having as their object, or
relating to, the prevention of fires and the preservation of lives and property
of the residents of the village.
B.   Recommendations To Village Board: It shall be the further duty of the
bureau of fire prevention to investigate and to recommend to the board of
trustees such additional ordinances or amendments to existing ordinances as
shall be deemed necessary for safeguarding life and property in the village.
C.   Investigations: The bureau of fire prevention shall cause to be made an
investigation of all buildings, structures or places used for manufacturing,
storage or commercial purposes, or occupied or frequented by large numbers of
people, including, but not limited to, all school buildings, public halls,
churches, hospitals, theaters, hotels, apartment buildings and all other places
of amusement, recreation or employment, for the purposes of determining the
safety of the occupants of such buildings, structures or places, in the event
of fire, panic or accident.
D.   Review Building Plans And Specifications:
1.   Review Of Plans: The bureau of fire prevention shall cause to be reviewed
all plans for new or altered premises in the village, with the exception of
single-family or two-family residences, and determine if any occupancy permit
may be issued prior to occupancy of such premises.
2.   Noncompliance; Notice To Remedy: In case it shall be found that any
village ordinance is not being complied with, the fire inspector shall give
written notice to the owner, occupant, lessee or person in charge or control of
such premises to make such changes or alterations to bring the premises into
compliance with village ordinances within fifteen (15) days from date of
notice.
3.   Issue Citation: In case such violations are not corrected within the
specified time shown on the notice of violation, a citation shall be issued to
the violator by the inspector.
4.   Right Of Entry: For the purposes of inspection, a fire inspector may enter
any building or premises within the village for the purpose of inspection under
the provisions of this chapter.
E.   Require Key Boxes: Whenever access to a structure will be unduly difficult
because of secured openings, and where immediate access will be required for
lifesaving and fire protection purposes, the chief of the fire department or
the fire prevention bureau may require a key box to be installed in a readily
accessible location. The key box shall be of a type approved by the chief of
the fire department or the fire prevention bureau. (1988 Code § 8-2-2)
5-3-3: FIRE PREVENTION CODE ADOPTED:
In order to provide for rules and regulations for the purpose of enforcement of
this title, and establishment of the standards of safety, and the protection
against fire and other hazards, there is hereby adopted by this chapter, the
fire prevention code of the National Fire Protection Association, NFPA, 2004
edition, and its incorporated standards and codes as published in the national
fire codes of the National Fire Protection Association and listed in annex A of
the NFPA fire prevention code for the year 2004. The same are hereby adopted
and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, except as otherwise
provided herein to the contrary. Whenever the term "fire prevention code of the
National Fire Protection Association, NFPA", is used herein, such reference
shall be to said code currently in effect, and all amendments thereto. Not less
than one copy of the adopted issue of the fire prevention code of the National
Fire Protection Association, NFPA, and the adopted standards and codes of the
national fire code shall be filed in the office of the village clerk, and the
provisions thereof shall be controlling within the village. (1988 Code § 8-2-3;
amd. 2009 Code)
5-3-4: EXEMPTIONS:
Except as provided in subsection 5-3-2D of this chapter to the contrary, the
provisions of this chapter shall not apply to one- or two-family dwellings.
(1988 Code § 8-2-4)
5-3-5: POLICE POWERS OF VILLAGE:
This chapter shall be deemed in the exercise of the police powers of the
village for the preservation and protection of the public health, peace, safety
and welfare and all the provisions hereof shall be liberally construed for that
purpose. (1988 Code § 8-2-5)
5-3-6: HAZARDOUS WASTE REGULATIONS ENFORCEMENT:
A.   Fire Prevention Bureau: It shall be the duty and responsibility of the
fire prevention bureau of the village to administer the hazardous materials
ordinances and regulations of the village 1 .
B.   Fire Chief: The fire chief shall manage, control and command all persons
in carrying out such responsibilities and, in coordination with the chief of
police, shall enforce the ordinances and regulations of the village. (Ord. 88-
21, 4-25-1988)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 4, chapter 4 of this code.
5-3-7: PROSECUTION DOES NOT RELIEVE COMPLIANCE:
Prosecution of any owner or occupant of any violation of this chapter shall not
relieve such person from compliance with this chapter or any provision hereof.
(1988 Code § 8-2-6)
5-3-8: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or the code
hereby adopted, or who shall fail to comply therewith or who shall build in
violation of any details, statements, specifications or plans submitted or
approved thereunder, or shall operate not in accordance with the provisions of
any certificate, permit or approval issued thereunder, or who shall fail to
comply with any order of the bureau of fire prevention or its inspectors,
shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in an amount not less than seventy
five dollars ($75.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. The imposition of a penalty for any violation shall not
excuse the violation, nor shall the violation be permitted to continue. Each
and every day a violation is allowed to continue or exist shall be deemed a
separate violation of this chapter. (1988 Code § 8-2-7; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 4
AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLES
SECTION:
5-4-1: Designation Of Authorized Emergency Vehicles
5-4-2: Notice To Village Board Prior To Designating An Authorized Emergency
Vehicle
5-4-1: DESIGNATION OF AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLES:
Pursuant to section 1-105 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/1-105, the Village Administrator shall have the authority to
designate vehicles operated by the Village's Police and Fire Chiefs and Deputy
Chiefs as "authorized emergency vehicles", as defined by the Illinois Vehicle
Code. Upon a vehicle's designation as an authorized emergency vehicle, such
vehicle shall have the authorities and rights granted to authorized emergency
vehicles by the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-101,
et seq., and any other applicable State Statutes. The Village Administrator
shall also have the authority to revoke such designation. (Ord. 2018-28, 11-12-
2018)
5-4-2: NOTICE TO VILLAGE BOARD PRIOR TO DESIGNATING AN AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY
VEHICLE:
The Village Administrator shall notify the Village Board within seven (7) days
upon designating a vehicle an authorized emergency vehicle pursuant to section
5-4-1 of this chapter. Upon receipt of the notice submitted by the Village
Administrator, or any time thereafter, the Village Board shall have the
authority to revoke such designation by resolution duly adopted. (Ord. 2018-28,
11-12-2018)
CHAPTER 5
CIVIL EMERGENCIES
SECTION:
5-5-1: Definitions
5-5-2: Declaration Of Civil Emergency
5-5-3: Orders By The Village President
5-5-4: Notice
5-5-5: Term; Extension; Termination
5-5-6: Violations; Penalty
5-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
In this chapter, the definitions set forth in the Illinois Emergency Management
Agency Act 1 , as amended, shall be applicable unless the context clearly
indicates otherwise.
 
                 A "Disaster" as defined in the Illinois Emergency Management
                 Agency Act, as amended. Specifically, and without limitation
CIVIL EMERGENCY: of the foregoing, a "civil emergency" includes the appearance
                 of a novel or previously controlled or eradicated infectious
                 agent or biological toxin. (Ord. 2020-09, 3-18-2020)
 
 
Notes
1 1 20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.
5-5-2: DECLARATION OF CIVIL EMERGENCY:
Pursuant to the authority granted by State law including, without limitation,
Section 11-1-6 of the Illinois Municipal Code, and the Village's home rule
authority, whenever the Village President determines that a civil emergency
exists in the Village, the Village President shall have the extraordinary power
and authority to exercise by executive order all such powers of the corporate
authorities and other officers of the Village as may be reasonably necessary or
appropriate to eliminate or minimize the dangers arising from such civil
emergency and for the protection of the health, safety and general welfare of
the public; provided, however, that prior to exercising any such extraordinary
power and authority, the Village President shall have executed under oath a
written declaration of civil emergency containing the following:
A.   An express declaration that a civil emergency exists; and
B.   A statement of facts known to the Village President, either directly or
upon information and belief, which describes the nature of the civil emergency
and substantiates the finding that a civil emergency exists.
Unless expressly stated otherwise, a declaration issued pursuant to this
Chapter shall be considered a local disaster declaration made pursuant to
Section 11 of the Emergency Management Agency Act. (Ord. 2020-09, 3-18-2020)
5-5-3: ORDERS BY THE VILLAGE PRESIDENT:
The Village President may, upon the issuance of a declaration of civil
emergency in accordance with Section
5-5-2, issue orders to implement any or all of the following:
A.   The imposition of a curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the
Village or to the Village as whole, as deemed advisable by the Village
President, and applicable during such hours of the day or night as deemed
necessary by the Village President in the interest of the public safety and
welfare;
B.   The discontinuance of selling, distributing, or giving away of gasoline or
other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container other than a
gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle;
C.   The closure of any business establishment anywhere within the Village for
the period of civil emergency, including, without limitation, businesses
selling intoxicating liquors, gasoline, or firearms;
D.   The closure any public street, thoroughfare or vehicle parking areas to
vehicular and/or pedestrian traffic;
E.   The calling upon regular and auxiliary law enforcement agencies and
organizations without or within the Village to assist in preserving and keeping
the peace within the Village;
F.   The authorization of the Village President, the Village Administrator, or
the coordinator of the Lake Bluff emergency disaster service agency to enter
into contracts for the procurement of supplies and services necessary to
address the civil emergency that would normally require the approval of the
full Village Board;
G.   The incurrence of obligations, the appropriation of funds, and the
provision of emergency assistance reasonably necessary to respond to or
mitigate the civil emergency;
H.   The prohibition of increases in the prices of goods and services sold
within the Village; and
I.   Any other actions reasonably necessary to address the civil emergency and
protect life and property. (Ord. 2020-09, 3-18-2020)
5-5-4: NOTICE:
A declaration of civil emergency shall be: (i) filed with the Village Clerk as
soon as practicable; (ii) promptly disseminated to the news media; and (iii)
promptly posted at Village Hall, the post office, and on the Village's social
media pages and website. (Ord. 2020-09, 3-18-2020)
5-5-5: TERM; EXTENSION; TERMINATION:
A.   Term: A declaration of civil emergency shall expire and automatically
terminate, if not extended pursuant to subsection B of this section, not later
than: (i) the adjournment of the first regular or special meeting of the
Village Board; or (ii) seven (7) days after the declaration is issued,
whichever occurs first.
B.   Extension: The Village Board may by motion extend the initial duration of
a declaration of civil emergency and any orders issued by the Village President
in connection therewith. The extension shall be for the duration necessary and
in the best interest of the Village and the public to address the continuing
civil emergency as determined by the Village Board.
C.   Termination by the Village President: A declaration of civil emergency may
be otherwise terminated at any time in writing and executed by the Village
President. (Ord. 2020-09, 3-18-2020)
5-5-6: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
A.   Any person violating the provisions of this chapter or any executive order
issued pursuant this Chapter, shall be guilty of an offense against the Village
and shall be punishable by a fine as provided in the general penalty provisions
of section
1-4-1 of this code.
B.   Person that uses property or operates a business in violation of any order
issued pursuant to this Chapter shall constitute a nuisance in fact for the
purposes of this code. (1988 Code § 8-3B-6; amd. 2009 Code; Ord. 2020-9, 3-18-
2020; Ord. 2020-14, 8-10-2020)
CHAPTER 6
ALARM SYSTEMS
SECTION:
5-6-1: Title
5-6-2: Purpose And Scope
5-6-3: Definitions
5-6-4: Alarm System Permit Requirements
5-6-5: Standards Of Construction And Maintenance
5-6-6: Building Permit Requirements
5-6-7: Entering Premises During Emergency
5-6-8: Fees And Charges
5-6-9: Maintenance Requirements
5-6-10: Penalties; Exemptions
5-6-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the ALARM PERMIT ORDINANCE OF THE VILLAGE OF
LAKE BLUFF. (1988 Code § 7-5-1)
5-6-2: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
The purpose of this chapter is to set forth regulations concerning alarm
systems located within, or causing alarms to be transmitted to, any facility of
the village, the establishment of fees therefor and the fines for violations
thereof. This chapter shall be applicable to new and existing alarms and alarm
systems. (1988 Code § 7-5-2)
5-6-3: DEFINITIONS:
 
          Any mechanical, electrical, electronic or other type of devices (or interconnected group
          of devices serving one location) of any nature or description, which act as a method of
          detecting fire, the discharge of gases, unauthorized access into a building, structure,
          facility, area, or property, real or personal, which, when actuated, emit a sound or
          transmit a signal or message by any means of communication to summon a police or fire
ALARM     department response, and all other warning systems for smoke, fire, gas, or emergency
SYSTEM:   conditions, except for interior smoke, heat or gas alarms or detectors that do not
          transmit a message outside of the premises or emit an exterior signal or alarm, and
          audible alarms affixed to motor vehicles and motorcycles. “Alarm System” includes systems
          commonly known as “automatic holdup alarm system,” “burglar alarm system,” “holdup alarm
          system,” “manual alarm system,” “fire alarm system,” “medical alert alarm system”, “CO
          gas detection alarm system” and “burglary, robbery, trespass alarm.”
DIRECTLY  Any alarm system which is directly connected to, by dedicated wires or other technology,
MONITORED and causes an alarm to be directly monitored by municipal or county communications
ALARM     centers.
SYSTEMS:
          Any alarm which is caused by equipment malfunction, by the setting off, intentionally or
FALSE     unintentionally, of an alarm by a member, occupant, employee, contractor, invitee, or
ALARM:    licensee of the premises, or an alarm call from a dispatching facility or another
          governmental agency or private entity, without any existing emergency or a request for
          emergent response when such need does not exist.
MONITORED Any alarm system which causes an alarm to be displayed at any facility of any agency
ALARM     which provides alarm monitoring services.
SYSTEM:
 
(1988 Code § 7-5-3; amd. Ord. 2024- 19, 9-9-2024)
5-6-4: ALARM SYSTEM PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required; Renewal: An alarm system permit must be obtained prior
to the installation of any alarm system within the village or which is designed
to cause an alarm to be transmitted to any monitoring service, and must be
renewed annually as of May 1 of each calendar year.
   B.   Application For Permit: Application for an alarm system permit must be
made on such forms as are prescribed by the village. Application forms will
require the applicant to provide the name, address and telephone number of the
person or persons who will render service or repairs during any hour of the day
or night, and if more than one individual is designated, the hours of contact
for such individual and the names and current addresses and current telephone
numbers of at least three (3) individuals who have keys or access to the
premises in the event of any emergency. In addition, applicants for such
permits must agree to furnish any changes in the information provided in an
application within ten (10) days after such change occurs.
   C.   Separate Applications And Fees; Records Confidential: An application
forms and fees will be required for any alarm system. All applications and
permits will be further subject to all ordinances, resolutions and
administrative directives of the village; provided further, that all such
applications and permits will be considered confidential, and all records
thereon will be maintained only in the office of the police department. (1988
Code § 7-5-4; amd. Ord. 2024-19, 9-9-2024)
5-6-5: STANDARDS OF CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE:
Standards for the construction and maintenance of alarm systems shall be as
promulgated by the village. These standards and regulations shall include
adherence to the electrical and building regulations of the village, and any
other related ordinances. All alarm systems shall be constructed and maintained
so as to distinguish between a police alarm type call, a fire alarm type call,
or a medical emergency. Whenever technically feasible, all alarm systems shall
contain devices which will enable monitoring personnel to ascertain whether an
alarm is actuated by trouble in the system or whether it is a true alarm. (1988
Code § 7-5-5)
5-6-6: BUILDING PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Filing Of Fire Alarm Plans: No fire alarm system shall be installed
within the village unless a building permit is issued by the building
commissioner, except a property owner may replace wireless smoke detectors in
single family residences without obtaining a building permit. Except for
single-family residences, no monitored alarm systems will be allowed for fire
alarms unless a Knox Box of such type as specified by the fire chief is
provided, installed and maintained with current building access keys by the
alarm permit holder. Building permit fees may be waived for alarm systems
installed in single-family residences.
   B.   The initial registration application and fee for a burglar alarm system
will suffice as the required building permit unless the installation includes
any smoke alarms, fire alarms, and/or CO alarms and does not conflict with any
other established building code requirement(s). (1988 Code § 7-5-6; amd. Ord.
2024-19, 9-9-2024)
5-6-7: ENTERING PREMISES DURING EMERGENCY:
The initial filing of an application for an alarm system permit, whether the
registration is renewed or not, will constitute consent for police and fire
department personnel to take whatever action is reasonable and necessary to
gain access to the premises for which an alarm has been received to ascertain
the nature and extent of any emergency. Execution of an alarm system
application acknowledges that the property owner or tenant agree to hold
harmless the village and its police and fire department personnel from any
claims of liability resulting from reasonable entry onto the premises, or
failure to gain access to the premises in responding to an activated alarm. The
permit applicant must certify that he or she has full power and authority to
execute such consent, or will have the signature of the property owner or
tenant affixed to the permit request. (1988 Code § 7-5-7; amd. Ord. 2024-29, 9-
9-2024)
5-6-8: FEES AND CHARGES:
The following permit fees are hereby established for the issuance and renewal
of alarm system permits:
   A.   Within Village: An annual registration fee in the amount as set forth
in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "alarm fees", will be paid for the
issuance and renewal of each permit for an alarm system located in the village.
   B.   Outside Village: An annual registration fee for the issuance and
renewal of each permit for an alarm system located outside of the village will
be set by contract as set forth in section
1-12-3. No such permits will be issued for the initial registration without the
approval of the police chief of the fire chief, based upon the type of alarm.
Approval of the police chief or fire chief is not required for permit renewal,
unless the alarm system or its structure have changed substantially from its
initial registration.
   C.   Initial Connection Fee: In addition to the fees provided in subsections
A and B of this section, the fees in the amounts as set forth in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "alarm fees", will be paid for the
issuance and renewal of each permit for a monitored alarm system. (1988 Code §
7-5-8; amd. 2009 Code)
   D.   Exceptions To Connection Fees And Maintenance Charges:
      1.   When any alarm system for which a connection fee, relay deposit fee
or maintenance charge is imposed, is connected directly into the system of
another municipality, or agency, the connection fee, relay deposit fee, and
maintenance charge of such other municipality will be paid to that
municipality, and will not be due to the village; provided further, that such
alarm will also be registered annually with the village, and the fee paid
therefor.
      2.   No fee will be due for registration of an alarm system for
individual medical emergency purposes only.
   E.   Proration Of Fees: No proration of fees for any permit will be made
except as specifically provided for herein. (1988 Code § 7-5-8; amd. Ord. 2024-
19, 9-9-2024)
5-6-9: MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS:
All holders of alarm system permits shall maintain their alarms in serviceable
condition at all times. All alarms emitting an audible sound outside the
premises shall be equipped with an automatic reset system which shall stop the
alarm after ten (10) minutes of warning sounds if not otherwise manually reset.
All other alarm systems shall have a reset function which prevents a continuous
alarm from being activated for a period in excess of thirty (30) minutes. (1988
Code § 7-5-9)
5-6-10: PENALTIES; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   The village may determine and assess penalties for false alarms or
malfunctions in accordance with the following provisions:
      1.   Definition: The term "twelve (12) month period", as used in this
subsection, means the twelve (12) month interval occurring on a rolling basis
beginning on the date of the first false alarm and ending twelve (12) months
after the date of the first false alarm .
      2.   False Alarms; Permit Holders Liable:
      Any person causing a false alarm of an alarm system will be obligated to
pay a false alarm fee in an amount set forth in section
1-12-3 which is provided for reference as follows:
 
Number of False Alarms occurring during a Burglar False Alarms Fire False Alarm
12 month period
1-4                                       No charge            No charge
5                                         $50.00               $50.00
6-8                                       $100.00              $100.00
9                                         $150.00              $150.00
10 and thereafter                         $250.00              $250.00
 
   For the first four (4) fire false alarms or first four (4) burglar false
alarms in a twelve (12) month period, a written warning notice will be given to
the permit holder. The Village will make a reasonable effort to provide a
similar warning to the property owner of the premises, its tenant, and the
person in control of the premises when there is no other registered alarm
system contact information.
      3.   Property Owner Or Occupant Liability: In addition thereto, the
property owner of the premises, its tenant or person in control will also be
subject to the respective penalties set forth in subsection A2 of this section.
      4.   Malfunction, Excused Alarm: In any instance where an alarm
malfunctions, and the permit owner, property owner of the premises, tenant or
person in control has the same repaired, and the repair facility certifies that
the cause of the malfunction has been corrected, said alarm will be considered
an excused alarm and not a false alarm.
      5.   Continuous Ringing: The permit of any alarm system that malfunctions
and rings for a period of two (2) or more hours will be subject to suspension
or revocation.
      6.   Penalty: Any person who fails to secure or maintain a current alarm
system permit for an alarm system located within the village, or an alarm
system which causes an alarm to be received by the police or fire department of
the village will be subject to a fine in the amount of twenty five dollars
($25.00) for the first violation thereof, and fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
second and subsequent violations thereafter within any twelve (12) month
period. Each day that an alarm is not registered after notice of the second
violation thereof will constitute a separate offense for which a separate and
additional penalty may be recovered. All penalties must be paid within ten (10)
days after written notice. (1988 Code § 7-5-10)
   B.   Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter, for
which a specific fine is not otherwise prescribed, will, upon conviction
thereof, be fined in the amount of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor
more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (1988 Code § 7-5-
12; amd. 2009 Code)
   C.   Alarm Testing: An alarm system may be tested or serviced at any time
during installation or any time after installation; provided, however the alarm
user or its designee must first notify the monitoring service or the Village's
emergency communications center of the test. Any activation of an alarm system
during a test or demonstration, without prior notice to, and approval of, the
Village will be deemed a false alarm.(1988 Code § 7-5-11; amd. Ord. 2024-19, 9-
9-2024)

5-7-9: Penalty
5-7-1: OFFENSES AGAINST PERSONS:
5-7-1-1: ASSAULT:
No person shall commit an assault in the village. A person commits assault
when, without lawful authority, he engages in conduct which places another in
reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery. (1988 Code § 7-2-1-1)
5-7-1-2: BATTERY:
No person shall commit a battery in the village. A person commits battery if he
intentionally or knowingly without legal justification and by any means:
A.   Causes bodily harm to an individual; or
B.   Makes physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with an
individual. (1988 Code § 7-2-1-2)
5-7-1-3: SOLICITING A MISDEMEANOR:
A.   Elements Of The Offense: No person shall solicit a misdemeanor within the
village. A person commits solicitation when, with intent that an offense be
committed, other than a felony, he commands, encourages or requests another to
commit that offense. (1988 Code § 7-2-1-3)
B.   Penalty: A person convicted of solicitation may be fined not to exceed the
maximum provided by section
1-4-1 of this code. (1988 Code § 7-2-1-3; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-1-4: ATTEMPT:
A.   Prohibition: No person shall attempt to commit any offense defined in this
chapter.
1.   Elements Of The Offense: A person commits an attempt when, with intent to
commit a specific offense, he does any act which constitutes a substantial step
towards the commission of that offense.
2.   Impossibility: It shall not be a defense to a charge of attempt that
because of a misapprehension of the circumstances it would have been impossible
for the accused to commit the offense attempted.
B.   Sentence: A person convicted of an attempt may be fined not to exceed the
maximum provided for the offense attempted. (1988 Code § 7-2-1-4)
5-7-1-5: RECKLESS CONDUCT:
No person shall engage in any reckless conduct in the village. A person who
causes bodily harm to or endangers the bodily safety of an individual by any
means commits reckless conduct if he performs recklessly the acts which cause
the harm or endangers safety, whether they otherwise are lawful or unlawful.
(1988 Code § 7-2-1-5)
5-7-2: OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY:
5-7-2-1: THEFT UNDER THREE HUNDRED DOLLARS:
It is unlawful to commit the offense of theft under three hundred dollars
($300.00) in the village. A person commits theft when, with respect to property
having a value less than three hundred dollars ($300.00), he knowingly:
A.   Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner; or
B.   Obtains by deception, control over property of the owner; or
C.   Obtains by threat, control over property of the owner; or
D.   Obtains control over stolen property knowing the property to have been
stolen or under such circumstances as would reasonably induce him to believe
that the property was stolen, and:
1.   Intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the
property; or
2.   Knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the property in such manner as to
deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit; or
3.   Uses, conceals or abandons the property knowing such use, concealment or
abandonment probably will deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit.
(1988 Code § 7-2-2-1)
5-7-2-2: RETAIL THEFT:
A.   Elements Of The Offense: A person commits the offense of retail theft when
he or she knowingly:
1.   Takes possession of, carries away, transfers, or causes to be carried away
or transferred, any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in
a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of retaining such
merchandise or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the
possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail
value of such merchandise; or
2.   Alters, transfers, or removes any label, price tag, marking, indicia of
value, or any other markings which aid in determining value affixed to any
merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile
establishment and attempts to purchase such merchandise personally or in
consort with another at less than the full retail value with the intention of
depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or
3.   Transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a
retail mercantile establishment from the container in or on which such
merchandise is displayed to any other container with the intention of depriving
the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or
4.   Underrings with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail
value of the merchandise; or
5.   Removes a shopping cart from the premises of a retail mercantile
establishment without the consent of the merchant given at the time of such
removal with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the
possession, use or benefit of such cart; or
6.   Represents to a merchant that he or another is the lawful owner of
property knowing that such representation is false, and conveys or attempts to
convey that property to a merchant who is the owner of the property in exchange
for money, merchandise credit, or other property of the merchant; or
7.   Uses or possesses any theft detection shielding device or theft detection
device remover with the intention of using such device to deprive the merchant
permanently of the possession, use or benefit of any merchandise displayed,
held, stored, or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment without
paying the full retail value of such merchandise; or (1988 Code § 7-2-2-2)
8.   Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner and
thereby intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the
property when a lessee of the personal property of another fails to return it
to the owner, or if the lessee fails to pay the full retail value of such
property to the lessor in satisfaction of any contractual provision requiring
such, within ten (10) days after written demand from the owner for its return.
A notice in writing, given after the expiration of the leasing agreement, by
registered mail, to the lessee at the address given by the lessee and shown on
the leasing agreement shall constitute proper demand; and (2009 Code)
9.   The value of the merchandise does not exceed one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00). (1988 Code § 7-2-2-2)
B.   Presumptions: If any person conceals upon his or her person or among his
or her belongings, unpurchased merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered
for sale in a retail mercantile establishment, and removes that merchandise
beyond the last known station for receiving payments for that merchandise in
that retail mercantile establishment, such person shall be presumed to have
possessed, carried away or transferred such merchandise with the intention of
retaining it or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the
possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail
value of such merchandise.
C.   Detention:
1.   Any merchant who has reasonable grounds to believe that a person has
committed retail theft may detain such person, on or off the premises of a
retail mercantile establishment, in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable
length of time for all or any of the following purposes:
a.   To request identification.
b.   To verify such identification.
c.   To make reasonable inquiry as to whether such person has in his possession
unpurchased merchandise and to make reasonable investigation of the ownership
of such merchandise.
d.   To inform a peace officer of the detention of the person and surrender
that person to the custody of a peace officer.
e.   In the case of a minor, to inform a peace officer, the parents, guardian
or other private person interested in the welfare of that minor of this
detention and to surrender custody of such minor to such person.
2.   A merchant may make a detention as permitted herein off the premises of a
retail mercantile establishment only if such detention is pursuant to an
immediate pursuit of such person.
3.   A merchant shall be deemed to have reasonable grounds to make a detention
for the purposes of this section if the merchant detains a person because such
person has in his possession either a theft detection shielding device or a
theft detection device remover. (2009 Code)
5-7-2-3: LIBRARY THEFT:
No person shall commit the offense of library theft within the village. A
person commits the offense of library theft when such person:
A.   Knowingly and intentionally removes any library material having an
aggregate value of less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) from the premises
of a library facility without authority to do so; or
B.   Knowingly and intentionally conceals any library material having an
aggregate value of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) upon his or
her person or among his or her belongings, while still in the premises of a
library facility, and in such manner that the library material is not visible
through ordinary observation although there may be some notice of its presence,
and removes such library material beyond the last point in the premises of that
library facility at which library material may be borrowed in accordance with
procedures established by that library facility for the borrowing of library
material; or
C.   With the intent to deceive, borrows or attempts to borrow any library
material having an aggregate value of not more than three hundred dollars
($300.00) from a library facility by: 1) use of a library card issued to
another without the other's consent; or 2) use of a library card knowing that
it is revoked, canceled or expired; or 3) use of a library card knowing that it
is falsely made, counterfeit or materially altered; or
D.   Borrows from a library facility library material which has an aggregate
value of fifty dollars ($50.00) or more pursuant to an agreement with or
procedure established by the library facility for the return of such library
material, and wilfully, without good cause, fails to return the library
material so borrowed in accordance with such agreement or procedure, and
further, wilfully, without good cause, fails to return such library material
within thirty (30) days after receiving written notice by registered mail from
the library facility demanding the return of such library material. (1988 Code
§ 7-2-2-3)
5-7-2-4: MUTILATION AND VANDALISM OF LIBRARY MATERIAL:
No person shall mutilate and vandalize any library material within the village.
A person commits the offense of mutilation and vandalism of library material
when such person knowingly tears, marks on, maliciously renders imperfect or
otherwise damages or destroys library material having an aggregate value of
three hundred dollars ($300.00) or less. (1988 Code § 7-2-2-4)
5-7-2-5: CRIMINAL DAMAGE TO PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to criminally damage property of another
within the village. A person commits an illegal act when such person:
A.   Knowingly damages any property of another without his consent, if the
damage to property does not exceed three hundred dollars ($300,00); or
B.   Recklessly, by means of fire or explosive, damages property of another, if
the damage to property does not exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00); or
C.   Knowingly starts a fire on the land of another without his consent, if the
damage to property does not exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00); or
D.   Knowingly injures a domestic animal of another without his consent, if the
damage to property does not exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00); or
E.   Knowingly deposits on the land or in the building of another, without his
consent, any stink bomb or any offensive smelling compound and thereby intends
to interfere with the use by another of the land or building; or
F.   Damages any property, if the damage to property does not exceed three
hundred dollars ($300.00), with intent to defraud an insurer; or
G.   Knowingly damages the property of another without his consent by defacing
such property by the use of paint or any other similar substance, if the damage
to property does not exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00). (1988 Code § 7-2-
2-5; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-2-6: CRIMINAL DAMAGE TO FIREFIGHTING APPARATUS, HYDRANTS OR EQUIPMENT:
It shall be unlawful for anyone to wilfully and maliciously cut, injure,
damage, tamper with or destroy or deface any fire hydrant or any fire hose or
any fire engine, or other public or private firefighting equipment, or any
apparatus appertaining to such equipment, or intentionally open any fire
hydrant without proper authorization. (1988 Code § 7-2-2-6)
5-7-2-7: CRIMINAL TRESPASS TO VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly and without authority to enter any
part of or operate any vehicle, aircraft, watercraft or snowmobile of another.
(1988 Code § 7-2-2-7)
5-7-2-8: CRIMINAL TRESPASS TO REAL PROPERTY:
A.   It shall be unlawful to: 1) knowingly and without lawful authority enter
or remain on the land or a building of another; 2) enter upon the land or a
building of another, after receiving prior to such entry, notice from the owner
or occupant that such entry is forbidden; 3) remain upon the land or in a
building of another after receiving notice from the owner or occupant to
depart; or 4) present false documents, or falsely represent his or her identity
or purpose for entry orally to the owner or occupant of a building or land in
order to obtain permission from the owner or occupant to enter or remain in the
building or on the land.
B.   A person has received notice from the owner or occupant within the meaning
of subsection A of this section if he has been notified personally, either
orally or in writing, or if a printed or written notice forbidding such entry
has been conspicuously posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such land or
the forbidden part thereof. (Ord. 2018-4, 2-26-2018)
5-7-2-9: CRIMINAL TRESPASS TO GOVERNMENT SUPPORTED LAND:
A.   Any person who shall enter upon land supported in whole or in part with
government funds administered or granted through government agencies or any
building on such land, after receiving, prior to such entry, notice from the
appropriate governmental authority or its representative to depart, and who
thereby interferes with another person's lawful use or enjoyment of such
building or land, commits the offense of criminal trespass to government
supported land.
B.   A person has received notice from the governmental authority within the
meaning of subsection A of this section, if he has been notified personally,
either orally or in writing, or if a printed or written notice forbidding such
entry to him or a group of which he is a part, has been conspicuously posted or
exhibited at the main entrance to such land or the forbidden part thereof.
(1988 Code § 7-2-2-9)
5-7-3: OFFENSES AGAINST MORALITY:
5-7-3-1: PUBLIC INDECENCY:
A.   Any person of the age of seventeen (17) years and upwards who performs any
of the following acts in a public place commits the offense of public
indecency:
1.   An act of sexual penetration or sexual conduct.
a.   "Sexual penetration" means any contact, however slight, between the sex
organ or anus of one person by an object and the sex organ, mouth or anus of
another person, or any intrusion, however slight, of any part of the body of
one person or of any animal or object into the sex organ or anus of another
person, including, but not limited to, cunnilingus, fellatio or anal
penetration. Evidence of emission of semen is not required to prove sexual
penetration.
b.   "Sexual conduct" means any intentional or knowing touching or fondling of
the victim by the accused, either directly or through clothing, of the sex
organs, anus or breast of the victim by the accused, or any part of the body of
a child under thirteen (13) years of age, for the purpose of sexual
gratification or arousal of the victim or the accused.
2.   A lewd exposure of the body done with the intent to arouse or to satisfy
the sexual desire of the person.
B.   Breast feeding of infants is not an act of public indecency.
C.   "Public place", for purposes of this section, means any place where the
conduct may reasonably be expected to be viewed by others. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-
1; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-3-2: PROSTITUTION:
A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any act of prostitution
within the village. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-2; amd. 2009 Code)
B.   Any person who performs, offers or agrees to perform any act of "sexual
penetration", as defined in subsection C of this section, for any money,
property, token, object, or article or anything of value, or any touching or
fondling of the sex organs of one person by another person for any money,
property, token, object, or article or anything of value for the purpose of
sexual arousal or gratification, commits an act of prostitution.
C.   "Sexual penetration" means any contact, however slight, between the sex
organ or anus of one person by an object, the sex organ, mouth or anus of
another person, or any intrusion, however slight, of any part of the body of
one person or of any animal or object into the sex organ or anus of another
person, including, but not limited to, cunnilingus, fellatio or anal
penetration. Evidence of emission of semen is not required to prove sexual
penetration. (2009 Code)
5-7-3-3: SOLICITATION FOR PROSTITUTION:
Any person who performs any of the following acts commits the offense of
soliciting for a prostitute:
A.   Solicits another for the purpose of prostitution; or
B.   Arranges or offers to arrange a meeting of persons for the purpose of
prostitution; or
C.   Directs another to a place knowing such direction is for the purpose of
prostitution. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-3)
5-7-3-4: KEEPING A PLACE OF PROSTITUTION:
Any person who has or exercises control over the use of any place which could
offer seclusion or shelter for the practice of prostitution who performs any of
the following acts commits the offense of keeping a place of prostitution:
A.   Knowingly grants or permits the use of such place for the purpose of
prostitution; or
B.   Grants or permits the use of such place under circumstances from which he
could reasonably know that the place is used or is to be used for purposes of
prostitution; or
C.   Permits the continued use of a place after becoming aware of facts or
circumstances from which he could reasonably know that the place is being used
for purposes of prostitution. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-4)
5-7-3-5: PIMPING:
Any person who receives money, property, token, object, or article, or anything
of value from a prostitute, not for a lawful consideration, knowing it was
earned in whole or in part from the practice of prostitution, commits the
offense of pimping. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-5; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-3-6: RESISTING OR OBSTRUCTING A PEACE OFFICER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to resist or obstruct a peace officer. A
person commits the offense of resisting or obstructing a peace officer when
such person knowingly resists or obstructs the performance by one known to the
person to be a peace officer of any authorized act within his official
capacity. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-11)
5-7-3-7: HARASSMENT BY TELEPHONE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to harass another by telephone. It shall be
unlawful for any person to commit the offense of harassment by telephone. For
purposes of this section, harassment by telephone is use of telephone
communications for any of the following purposes:
A.   Making any comment, request, suggestion or proposal which is obscene,
lewd, lascivious, filthy or indecent with an intent to offend; or
B.   Making a telephone call, whether or not conversation ensues, with intent
to abuse, threaten or harass any person at the called number; or
C.   Making or causing the telephone of another repeatedly to ring, with intent
to harass any person at the called number; or
D.   Making repeated telephone calls, during which conversation ensues, solely
to harass any person at the called number; or
E.   Knowingly permitting any telephone under one's control to be used for any
of the purposes mentioned herein. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-12)
5-7-3-8: TRANSMISSION OF OBSCENE MESSAGES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to transmit any obscene messages. A person
who sends messages or uses language or terms which are obscene, lewd or immoral
with the intent to offend by means of or while using a telephone or telegraph
facility, equipment or wires of any person, firm or corporation engaged in the
transmission of news or messages to or from the village commits the offense of
transmission of obscene messages. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-13)
5-7-4: OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE:
5-7-4-1: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
It shall be unlawful to engage in disorderly conduct within the village. A
person commits disorderly conduct when such person knowingly:
A.   Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another
and to provoke a breach of the peace.
B.   Transmits in any manner to the fire department of any city, town, village
or fire protection district a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such
transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such fire
exists.
C.   Transmits in any manner to another a false alarm to the effect that a bomb
or other explosive of any nature is concealed in such place that its explosion
would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission that there
is no reasonable ground for believing that such bomb or explosive is concealed
in such place.
D.   Transmits in any manner to any peace officer, public officer or public
employee a report to the effect that an offense has been committed, knowing at
the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing
that such an offense has been committed.
E.   Enters upon the property of another and for a lewd or unlawful purpose
deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any window or other
opening in it.
F.   While acting as a "collection agency" as defined in the collection agency
act 1  or as an employee of such collection agency, and while attempting to
collect an alleged debt, makes a telephone call to the alleged debtor which is
designed to harass, annoy or intimidate the alleged debtor.
G.   Transmits a false report to the department of children and family services
under section 4 of the abused and neglected child reporting act 2 . (1988 Code
§ 7-2-4-1)
H.   Knowingly transmits a false report to the department of public health
under the nursing home care act 3 . (1988 Code § 7-2-4-1; amd. 2009 Code)
I.   Transmits in any manner to the police department or fire department of any
municipality or fire protection district or any privately owned and operated
ambulance service, a false request for an ambulance, emergency medical
technician/ambulance or emergency medical technician/paramedic knowing at the
time there is no reasonable ground for believing that such assistance is
required. (1988 Code § 7-2-4-1)
J.   Transmits a false report under article II of an act in relation to victims
of violence and abuse, approved September 16, 1984, as amended. (1988 Code § 7-
2-4-1; amd. 2009 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 425/1 et seq.
2 2. 325 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
3 3. 210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq.
5-7-4-2: POSSESSION OF ILLEGAL DRUGS; UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLY INVOLVING ILLEGAL
DRUGS:
A.   Definitions: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this
section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
   CANNABIS: Any substance as defined in section 3 of the cannabis control act,
720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., as the same may, from time to
time hereafter, be amended.
   CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE: Any substance as defined and included in the schedules
of article II of the controlled substances act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes
570/201 et seq., as the same may, from time to time hereafter, be amended.
   DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: All equipment, products, and materials as defined in the
drug paraphernalia control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 600/1 et seq.,
as the same may, from time to time hereafter, be amended.
   ILLEGAL DRUGS: Any controlled substance, cannabis, or unprescribed drug.
   KNOWINGLY: Having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief or
ground for belief which warrants further inquiry or inspection.
   UNPRESCRIBED DRUG: Any drug as defined in paragraph (b) of section 3 of the
pharmacy practice act of 1987, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 85/1 et seq., as
the same may, from time to time hereafter, be amended, that is obtained without
a prescription or otherwise in violation of the law.
   VEHICLE OR PREMISES: Any privately owned and operated motor vehicle,
conveyance or vessel; any house or apartment; any hotel, motel, or bed and
breakfast room or any similar premises to which the general public is not
normally admitted.
B.   Possession Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to possess
illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia in the village, except as, and only to the
extent, otherwise explicitly authorized by state or federal law.
C.   Responsibility Of Owner: It shall be unlawful for any owner of, or other
person having control over, any vehicle or premises to knowingly initiate,
suffer, permit, or allow one or more occupants, invitees, visitors, guests,
trespassers, or other persons to assemble or be assembled in such vehicle or
premises in possession of any illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia.
D.   Responsibility Regarding Renting Premises: It shall be unlawful for any
person to knowingly rent, or pay for, any hotel, motel, or bed and breakfast
room or facility from the proprietor or agent thereof for the purpose of using
such room or facility for the consumption or intake of illegal drugs.
E.   Presumptions Of Knowledge And Permission: For purposes of this section, a
person shall be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to have
knowingly permitted a violation of this section if: 1) such person is present
within any vehicle or premises of which such person is the owner, lessee,
permittee, bailee, legal possessor, or occupier thereof at the time that a
violation of the provisions of this section is occurring; and 2) such person
has not informed the Lake Bluff police department thereof. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-
1995)
5-7-4-3: CERTAIN ASSEMBLIES; PERMIT REQUIRED:
(Rep. by Ord. 2020-14, 8-10-2020)
5-7-4-4: DISTURBING RELIGIOUS ASSEMBLIES:
It shall be unlawful to disturb any congregation or assembly met for religious
worship by making any noise or by rude or indecent behavior or profane
discourse within any place of worship or so near to the same as to disturb the
order or solemnity of the meeting. (1988 Code § 7-2-4-5)
5-7-4-5: RESIDENTIAL PICKETING:
It is unlawful to picket before or about the residence or dwelling of any
person, except when the residence or dwelling is used as a place of business.
However, this section does not apply to a person peacefully picketing his own
residence or dwelling and does not prohibit the peaceful picketing of the place
of holding a meeting or assembly on premises commonly used to discuss subjects
of general public interest. (1988 Code § 7-2-4-6)
5-7-4-6: MOB ACTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the offense of mob action in the
village. Mob action consists of any of the following:
A.   The use of force or violence disturbing the public peace by two (2) or
more persons acting together and without authority of law; or
B.   The assembly of two (2) or more persons to do an unlawful act; or
C.   The assembly of two (2) or more persons, without authority of law, for the
purpose of doing violence to the person or property of anyone supposed to have
been guilty of a violation of the law, or for the purpose of exercising
correctional powers or regulative powers over any person by violence. (1988
Code § 7-2-4-7)
5-7-4-7: FALSE PERSONATION 1 :
It shall be unlawful to commit the offense of false personation in the village.
A person commits the offense of false personation when such person:
A.   Falsely represents himself to be an attorney authorized to practice law or
a public officer or a public employee.
B.   Falsely represents himself to be a member of any police, fraternal or
veterans' organization, including the Illinois Police Association, or a
representative of any charitable organization or when any person exhibits or
uses in any manner, any decal, badge or insignia of any police organization
when not authorized to do so by such police organization. (1988 Code § 7-2-4-8)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 5-7-7-8 of this chapter.
5-7-4-8: PUBLIC DEMONSTRATIONS:
It is unlawful for any person, group or organization to conduct or participate
in any march, assembly, meeting on any public place in the village, or
gathering on roadways in more than one specific area of or location in the
village on any one given day unless a demonstration permit is issued by the
village, or if not, with the permission of the police chief. (1988 Code § 7-2-
4-9)
5-7-4-9: SWIMMING FROM LILLIAN DELLS DRIVE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person or a person to allow their pets to enter
the water of Lake Michigan from Lillian Dells Drive. (Ord. 2022-3, 1-24-2022)
5-7-5: WEAPONS OFFENSES:
5-7-5-1: UNLAWFUL POSSESSION OF FIREARMS OR AMMUNITION:
It shall be an offense for any person to unlawfully possess any firearms or
firearms ammunition in the village. A person commits the offense of unlawful
possession of firearms or firearm ammunition when:
A.   He is under eighteen (18) years of age and has in his possession any
firearm of a size which may be concealed upon the person; or
B.   He is under twenty one (21) years of age, has been convicted of a
misdemeanor other than a traffic offense or adjudged delinquent and has any
firearm or firearm ammunition in his possession; or
C.   He is a narcotic addict and has any firearms or firearm ammunition in his
possession; or
D.   He has been a patient in a mental hospital within the past five (5) years
and has any firearms or firearm ammunition in his possession; or
E.   He is mentally retarded and has any firearms or firearm ammunition in his
possession; or (1988 Code § 7-2-5-1)
F.   He has in his possession any "explosive bullet". For purposes of this
subsection, "explosive bullet" means the projectile portion of an ammunition
cartridge which contains or carries an explosive charge which will explode upon
contact with the flesh of a human or an animal. "Cartridge" means a tubular
