metal case having a projectile affixed at the front thereof and a cap or primer
at the rear end thereof, with the propellant contained in such tube between the
projectile and the cap. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-1; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-5-2: MINORS:
A.   Furnishing Firearms To: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, loan
or furnish to any minor any gun, pistol or other firearm within the limits of
the village.
B.   Air Guns, BB Guns; Persons Under Thirteen Years: It shall be unlawful for
any parent or guardian or other person to purchase for, or furnish to, give to
or permit the possession by, any child under the age of thirteen (13) years
within the village any air gun, air rifle, air pistol, spring gun, spring
pistol, pellet gun, BB gun, or any implement that is not a firearm which impels
a pellet constructed of hard plastic, steel, lead or other hard material with a
force that reasonably is expected to cause bodily harm. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-2)
5-7-5-3: CARRYING OR TRANSPORTING FIREARMS:
It shall be unlawful to carry or transport any gun, pistol, fowling piece or
other firearm, or any air gun, air pistol or slingshot within the corporate
limits of the village which contains any explosive substance, nor shall any
such weapon be carried or transported unless in a case, dismantled or broken
down. Any weapon so broken must have a cord, strap or cloth tied around the
weapon in such manner as to render it incapable of being discharged without
first removing such cord, strap or cloth. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-3)
5-7-5-4: CANNONS AND ARTILLERY; PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to discharge or fire any cannon or piece of artillery
within the corporate limits of the village without written permission from the
village administrator. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-4)
5-7-5-5: DISCHARGING FIREARMS PROHIBITED:
No person shall at any time discharge or set off anywhere within the village,
or carry the same for such purpose, any firearm, gun, pistol, rifle, air rifle,
cannon, or any other gun that discharges projectiles either by air, spring,
explosive substance or any other force. The prohibitions contained herein shall
also apply to the discharge of toy firearms and toy cannons of any nature or
description, but shall not apply to the carrying of unloaded toy firearms and
toy cannons, or the carrying or discharge of toy water pistols and cap guns.
(1988 Code § 7-2-5-5)
5-7-5-6: POSSESSING, USING OR DISCHARGING WEAPONS:
A.   "Weapons", as used in this section, includes firearms, but also includes
bludgeons, blackjacks, slingshot, sand club, sandbag, metal knuckles, throwing
stars, or any knife commonly referred to as a switchblade knife, which has a
blade that opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or
other device in the handle of the knife, or a ballistic knife which is a device
that propels a knifelike blade as a projectile by means or a coil spring,
elastic material or compressed gas, a dagger, dirk, billy, straight razor,
stiletto, broken bottle or other piece of glass, stun gun or taser, nunchaku,
tear gas gun projector or bomb or any object containing noxious liquid, gas or
substance, other than an object containing a nonlethal noxious gas or substance
designed solely for personal defense carried by a person eighteen (18) years or
older. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-6; amd. 2009 Code)
B.   No person shall possess any weapon, gun, pistol, rifle, shotgun, or
firearm of any nature or description, or slingshot, crossbow, bow and arrow or
explosive bullets or projectiles the possession of which is prohibited by the
state. No person shall discharge or carry any firearm or weapon described
herein, or other devices prohibited by the laws of the state within the
corporate limits of the village. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-6)
5-7-5-7: EXCEPTIONS TO POSSESSION AND DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS:
The restrictions on the possession and discharge of firearms shall not apply to
police officers of the village in the performance of their duties, nor to
officers of any court whose duty it is to serve warrants or make arrests, nor
to those individuals exempted under 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-2 who
comply with the provisions of said statute and use such weapons in accordance
therewith. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the possession and
discharge of a weapon when such use is in self-defense of a person, home or of
property. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-7)
5-7-6: FIREWORKS:
5-7-6-1: DEFINITION:
The term "fireworks" shall mean and include any combustible or explosive
compositions or any substances or articles prepared for the purpose of
producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration or
detonation. (Ord. 92-29, 11-9-1992)
5-7-6-2: RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to at any time sell, offer for sale, give away, possess,
store, discharge or otherwise use fireworks of any kind within the village;
provided, however, that upon a permit being issued therefor by the board of
trustees, fireworks may be stored and used for public exhibitions. (Ord. 92-29,
11-9-1992)
5-7-6-3: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provisions of this section
5-7-6 shall be punished by a fine of not less than seventy five dollars
($75.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during which such violation occurs and continues. (Ord. 92-
29, 11-9-1992; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-7: MISCELLANEOUS VIOLATIONS:
5-7-7-1: INTERFERENCE WITH EMERGENCY COMMUNICATION:
It shall be unlawful to interfere with any emergency communication in the
village.
A.   A person commits the offense of interference with emergency communication
when he knowingly, intentionally and without lawful justification interrupts,
disrupts, impedes, or otherwise interferes with the transmission of a
communication over any mode of communication, the purpose of which
communication is to inform or inquire about an emergency.
B.   For the purpose of this section, "emergency" means a condition or
circumstance in which an individual is, or is reasonably believed by the person
transmitting the communication to be, in imminent danger of serious bodily
injury or in which property is, or is reasonably believed by the person
transmitting the communication to be, in imminent danger of damage or
destruction. (1988 Code § 7-2-6-1)
5-7-7-2: LITTERING:
A.   Definition: "Litter", as used herein, means any discarded, used or
unconsumed substance or waste. "Litter" may include, but is not limited to, any
garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish, grass clippings or other lawn or
garden waste, newspaper, magazines, glass, metal, plastic or paper containers
or other packaging construction material, abandoned vehicles, motor vehicle
parts, furniture, oil, carcass of a dead animal, any nauseous or offensive
matter of any kind or any object likely to injure any person or create a
traffic hazard, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature, which
has been discarded, abandoned or otherwise disposed of improperly.
B.   Deposits Prohibited; Exception: It shall be unlawful for any person to
dump, deposit, drop, throw, discard, leave, cause or permit the dumping,
depositing, dropping, throwing, discarding or leaving of litter upon any public
or private property in the village, or upon or into any river, lake, pond or
other stream or body of water in the village, unless:
1.   The property has been designated by the state or the village for the
disposal of litter, and the litter is disposed of on that property in
accordance with the applicable rules of the Illinois pollution control board of
the state, and the ordinances of the village; or
2.   The litter is placed into a receptacle or other container intended by the
owner or tenant in lawful possession of that property for the deposit of
litter; or
3.   The person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of the property or
has first obtained the consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession, or
unless the act is done under the personal direction of the owner or tenant, and
does not create a public health or safety hazard, a public nuisance or a fire
hazard; or
4.   The person is acting under the direction of proper public officials during
special cleanup days; or
5.   The person is lawfully acting in or reacting to an emergency situation
where health and safety is threatened, and removes and properly disposes of
such litter when the emergency situation no longer exists.
C.   Deposits From Vehicles And Property: No person shall dump, deposit, drop,
throw, discard or otherwise dispose of litter in the village from any motor
vehicle upon any public highway, upon any public or private property or upon or
into any river, lake, pond, stream or body of water except as permitted under
subsection B of this section; nor shall any person transport by any means
garbage or refuse from any dwelling, residence, place of business, farm or
other site and deposit such material in, around or on top of trash barrels or
other receptacles placed along public highways at any point.
D.   Accumulations Of Litter: No person shall allow litter to accumulate upon
real property, of which the person charged is the owner or tenant in control,
in such a manner as to constitute a public nuisance or in such a manner that
the litter may be blown or otherwise carried by the natural elements onto the
real property of another person.
E.   Abandoned Vehicles: No person shall abandon a motor vehicle in the village
on any highway or road, on any public property or on any private property of
which he is not the owner or tenant in lawful possession in the village. The
person to whom last was issued the certificate of title to the vehicle by the
secretary of state of Illinois is presumed to be the person to have abandoned
that vehicle, but such presumption may be rebutted.
F.   Vehicle Operator Presumed Guilty: Whenever litter is thrown, deposited,
dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle not carrying passengers for hire, the
presumption is created that the operator of the motor vehicle committed the
act, but that presumption may be rebutted.
G.   Places Of Public Assembly; Receptacles Required:
1.   In order to assist the public in complying with this section, the owner or
person in control of any property which is held out to the public as a place
for assemblage, the transaction of business, recreation or as a public way
shall cause to be placed and maintained receptacles for the deposit of litter,
of sufficient volume and in sufficient numbers to meet the needs of the number
of people customarily coming on or using the property.
2.   For purposes of this subsection, property held out to the public for the
transaction of business includes, but is not limited to, commercially operated
parks, campgrounds, drive- in restaurants, automobile service stations,
business parking lots, car washes, shopping centers, marinas, boat launching
areas, industrial parking lots, boat moorage and fueling stations, piers,
beaches and bathing areas, shopping malls, and property held out to the public
for assemblage, recreation or as a public way and includes, but is not limited
to, any property that is publicly owned or operated for any of the purposes
stated in this subsection G2 for property held out to the public for the
transaction of business, but excludes state highway rights of way. (1988 Code §
7-2-6-2)
5-7-7-3: VANDALISM:
A.   Prohibited Acts: It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully,
maliciously, or negligently break, deface, injure, or destroy any property
within the village, whether such property is owned by the state, county,
village, or any other governmental body, or owned by any private person. Acts
prohibited under this section include, but are not limited to, the following:
1.   Injury To Public Or Private Grounds: To cut, injure, mark, or deface any
building not his own or any tree, grass, shrub, or walk in any public or
private grounds or any sewer, water pipe, or hydrant laid or placed by the
village; provided, further, that an abutting property owner or tenant is
authorized to mow grass, and trim trees and shrubs on parkway property adjacent
to his property.
2.   Paint, Mark Or Mutilate: To paint or mark on, cut into or deface, or
mutilate in any manner any public sidewalk, street, or any other public
property without permit issued therefor by the village.
3.   Lights And Utilities: To break, deface, disturb, interfere with, carry
away, or in any way injure or destroy any electric light globe or any part or
appurtenance to any lamp or light of any kind used in, upon, or about any
street, public or private place in the village, or any telephone, electric,
cable television, communications or telegraph wire, or any appurtenances
thereto at any place within the limits of the village.
4.   Stones And Missiles: To throw or cast any stone or other missile upon or
at any building, railroad car, tree, or other public or private property, or
upon or at any person, in any public or private place, or to aid or abet in the
same. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
5.   Damage To Buildings And Property: To engage in the knowing infliction,
without consent, of damage to: a) any church, synagogue, or other building,
structure, or place used for religious worship or other religious purpose; b)
any cemetery, mortuary, or other facility used for the purpose of burial or
memorializing the dead; c) any school, educational facility, or community
center; d) any grounds adjacent to, and owned or rented by, any such
institution, facility, building, structure, or place; or e) any personal
property contained in any such institution, facility, building, structure, or
place, by reason of the actual or perceived race, color, creed, religion,
national origin, ancestry, gender, sexual orientation, or physical or mental
disability of another individual or group of individuals. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-
1995; amd. 2009 Code)
B.   Parental Responsibility:
1.   Definitions: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this
section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
         KNOWINGLY: Having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief
or ground for belief which warrants further inquiry or inspection.
         LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a
minor by a circuit court of this state, but does not include a person appointed
guardian or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705
Illinois Compiled Statutes 405/1-1 et seq.
         MINOR: A person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
         PARENT: A natural or adoptive parent or a court designated guardian.
         UNEMANCIPATED MINOR: A minor still under the care and custody of at
least one of his or her parents or a legal guardian.
         WILFUL: Proceeding from a conscious and voluntary intentional motion
of the will.
2.   Parental Responsibility For Failure To Supervise: It shall be unlawful for
any parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor to knowingly suffer,
permit, or allow such minor to wilfully or maliciously damage or destroy any
property or to injure any person or animal.
3.   Parental Responsibility For Damages: The parent or legal guardian of an
unemancipated minor shall be liable to the full extent permitted by law, for
actual damages for: a) such minor's acts of vandalism occurring within the
village; and b) the wilful or malicious acts of such minor that occur within
the village and that cause injury to a person, animal, or property. (Ord. 95-
42, 12-11-1995)
5-7-7-4: UNLAWFUL EXCAVATIONS OF PUBLIC WAYS:
It shall be unlawful to dig, cut or remove any sod, gravel, sand or earth from
any of the public streets or property of the village without authority of the
village administrator, or from any private lot or tract of land without the
consent of the owner thereof. (1988 Code § 7-2-6-5)
5-7-7-5: LADDERS; SCAFFOLDS; TOOLS:
It shall be unlawful to place any scaffolds or ladders in such a position that
they overhang or can fall upon any public street, alley or other public way in
the village unless such ladder or scaffold shall be firmly and properly
constructed and safeguarded; and it shall be unlawful to place or leave any
tools or articles on any such scaffold or ladder in such a manner that such
tools or articles can fall upon such street, alley or other public way from a
greater height than four feet (4'). (1988 Code § 7-2-6-8)
5-7-7-6: CURFEW 1 :
A.   Beaches Or Lake Front Property: Notwithstanding anything contained in this
section to the contrary, it shall be unlawful for any person, other than
municipal officials and employees conducting official business, to be or remain
upon any and all public beaches or public lake front property in the village
between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. the
following day, without a written permit issued by or pursuant to the proper
authority.
B.   Village Green Vacant Property: Notwithstanding anything contained in this
section to the contrary, it shall be unlawful for any person, other than
municipal officials and employees conducting official business, to be or remain
upon any other public property in the village except for the streets, alleys,
sidewalks, and public rights of way, nor any vacant property or any part
thereof between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and five o'clock (5:00)
A.M. of the following day, without a written permit issued by or pursuant to
the proper authority. (1988 Code § 7-2-6-10)
C.   School Curfew For Minors:
1.   Definitions: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this
subsection, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection C1,
except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
         KNOWINGLY: Having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief
or ground for belief which warrants further inquiry or inspection.
         LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a
minor by a circuit court of this state, but does not include a person appointed
guardian or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705
Illinois Compiled Statutes 405/1-1 et seq.
         MINOR: A person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
         PARENT: A natural or adoptive parent or a court designated guardian.
         UNEMANCIPATED MINOR: A minor still under the care and custody of at
least one of his or her parents or a legal guardian.
         WILFUL: Proceeding from a conscious and voluntary intentional motion
of the will.
2.   Curfew Imposed; Exceptions: It shall be unlawful for any minor who is
enrolled in any public, private, or parochial school to be present at or upon,
or to loiter, wander, stroll, or play in or upon, any street, alley, sidewalk,
parkway, park, playground, or other public place, or in or on any public
building, place of amusement or entertainment, or any vacant lot in the
village, other than school, during any hours when school is in session during
the regular school term, unless such minor is:
a.   Traveling to or from school by the most direct route; or
b.   Engaged in school related activities with written approval of school
authorities or as otherwise authorized by written school policy; or
c.   Engaged in personal business, including, without limitation, employment,
medical care, and religious activities, with prior written consent from a
parent, legal guardian, or other adult having lawful custody or supervision of
such person to school authorities; or
d.   Accompanied and supervised by a parent, legal guardian, or other adult
having lawful custody or supervision of such person.
3.   Investigatory Detention: Any police officer may stop and detain a person
whom the police officer reasonably suspects to be violating this subsection for
purpose of verifying the detained person's identity, age, school enrollment and
authority to be absent from school. The police officer shall immediately inform
the detained person of the reason for the detention and that he or she will be
released upon verification of authorization to be absent from school. If the
detained person refuses to provide the police officer with the necessary
information, or if authorization to be absent from school cannot be verified
within fifteen (15) minutes of the detention, the detained person shall, if
practicable, be taken to school authorities or a parent or legal guardian or
other adult having lawful custody or supervision of such person. (Ord. 95-42,
12-11-1995)
4.   First And Subsequent Violations: Any person who violates this subsection
shall be warned by any police officer forthwith to comply with such provisions,
and such officer shall also, without delay, report such violation to his or her
superior officer, who shall cause a written notice to be served upon the
parent, legal guardian or other adult having lawful custody or supervision of
such person, setting forth the manner in which this subsection has been
violated. In case any person under the age of eighteen (18) years, after such
warning, shall again violate any of the provisions of this subsection, he or
she shall be taken into custody as a juvenile delinquent and dealt with as
provided under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705 Illinois Compiled Statutes
405/1-1 et seq. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995; amd. 2009 Code)
5.   Parental Responsibility: It shall be unlawful for any parent or legal
guardian of an unemancipated minor to knowingly suffer, permit, or allow such
minor to violate any provision of this subsection. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 5-8-1 of this title.
5-7-7-7: RENDERING AID TO OFFICERS REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person in the village, when called upon by the
chief of police or any member of the police department or by any officer of the
Village possessing police powers, to refuse to promptly aid and assist him in
the execution of his duties. (1988 Code § 7-2-6-11)
5-7-7-8: IMPERSONATING POLICE OFFICERS 1 :
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a member of the Police
Department or one legally vested with police powers, to assume to act as a
police officer in any capacity within or without the Village. A person commits
the offense of impersonating when such person uses a star, badge or other
similar device identifying such person to be a member of the Lake Bluff Police
Department or one legally authorized to act on behalf of the Police Department,
and such person is not a member of the Police Department. (1988 Code § 7-2-6-
12)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 5-7-4-7 of this chapter.
5-7-7-9: GAMBLING PROHIBITED:
A.   Purpose: It is the purpose of this section to have broad application in
order to encompass all existing activities which are considered gambling and
any such activities which may be conceived in the future.
B.   Definitions: The following terms have the definitions herein ascribed to
them:
      GAMBLING DEVICE:
      Means:
         (1)   Any clock, tape machine, slot machine, or other machine or
device for the reception of money or other thing of value on chance or skill or
upon the action or which money or other thing of value is staked, hazarded,
bet, won or lost:
         (2)   Any mechanism, furniture, fixture, equipment or other device
designed primarily for use in a gambling place: and
         (3)   Any video gaming terminal as defined in the Illinois Video
Gaming Act. 230 ILCS 40/5. The term "Gambling Device" does not include the
following, as defined by Illinois law at 720 ILCS 5/28-2fa1:
            a.   Coin-in-the-slot operated mechanical devices played for
amusement only. which reward players with the right to replay the device:
            b.   Vending machines:
            c.    Crane games: and
            d.   Redemption machines that reward a player proportionally based
on a score with a ticket that may be redeemed at the establishment for prizes.
      LOTTERY: Means any system, scheme, or procedure whereby one or more
prizes are distributed by chance among persons who have paid or promised
consideration for a chance to win such prizes, whether such system, scheme, or
procedures is called a lottery, raffle, gift, sale, or some other name. The
term "Lottery" does not include lotteries authorized by Illinois law or
specifically authorized by this Code.
      POLICY GAME: Means any system, scheme, or procedure whereby a person
promises or guarantees by any instrument, bill, certificate-writing, token, or
other device that any particular number, character, ticket, or certificate will
in the event of any contingency in the nature of a lottery entitle the
purchaser or holder to receive money, property, or evidence of debt.
      SWEEPSTAKES: Means a contest, drawing, or similar activity, whether
online or not and with or without an entry requirement, where a prize, cash,
trip, or other reward may be awarded to a winner or winners.
C.   Gambling Prohibited: Except as specifically authorized by the village
pursuant to title 3, chapter 14 of this Code or by the Illinois Charitable
Games Act. 230 ILCS 30/1 et seq.. all of the following acts, actions, and
undertakings are unlawful:
1.   To gamble.
2.   To conduct or participate in any lottery or policy game, or to make a bet,
or to buy or sell any chance or tickets in any gambling game, arrangement, or
device.
3.   To use any gambling device.
4.   To possess or expose for public use any gambling device with the intent to
use that gambling device for an unlawful purpose.
5.   To conduct or participate in any lottery or policy game.
6.   To keep and provide for public use a sweepstakes terminal or console or
other form of on-line sweepstakes access.
7.   To maintain or to patronize any establishment maintained for a gambling
house or resort.
8.   To advertise any gambling house or resort in any street, alley, or other
public area or right of way within the Village. (Ord. 2009-24, 10-26-2009; amd.
Ord. 2017-11, 6-12-2017; Ord. 2019-22, 9-9-2019)
5-7-8: OFFENSES AGAINST ANIMALS:
5-7-8-1: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS 1 ; ANIMAL FIGHTS; IMMORAL DISPLAY OF ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful to commit any cruel act towards animals, instigate, cause
or procure any fights between animals, or in any manner instigate, cause,
procure or assist in any indecent or immoral show or exhibition of any animal.
(1988 Code § 7-2-7-1)
 
Notes
1 2. See also section 5-9A-2 of this title.
5-7-8-2: KILLING OR WOUNDING BIRDS:
It shall be unlawful to kill or wound or attempt to kill or wound, by use of
any firearms, slingshot, bow and arrow or otherwise, any bird within the limits
of the Village, or to shoot any arrow or throw a stone or club or other missile
at any bird within any private or public grounds, or take the eggs or young of
any such bird, or enter upon any private enclosure or public ground for the
purpose of doing any act prohibited by this section. (1988 Code § 7-2-7-2)
5-7-9: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided, any person violating any provision of this chapter
or committing an "offense", as defined herein, shall be fined not less than
fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day on which a violation occurs or continues and for each
separate offense committed. (1988 Code § 7-2-8-1; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 8
MINORS
SECTION:
5-8-1: Curfew
5-8-2: Alcohol
5-8-3: Parental Responsibility
5-8-4: Tobacco Products And E-Cigarettes
5-8-1: CURFEW 1 :
A.   Age And Hour Restrictions: It is unlawful for a person less than eighteen
(18) years of age to be present at or upon any public assembly, building,
place, street, or highway at the following times unless one of the exceptions
listed in subsection B of this section applies:
   Between one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00)
A.M., Saturday;
   Between one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00)
A.M., Sunday; and
   Between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Sunday to Thursday, inclusive, and
six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the following day.
B.   Exemptions: This section shall not apply to any person less than eighteen
(18) years of age who is:
1.   Accompanied and supervised by a parent, legal guardian, or other
responsible companion at least eighteen (18) years of age;
2.   Engaged in a business or occupation which the laws of Illinois authorize a
person less than eighteen (18) years of age to perform;
3.   Attending or traveling to or from an official school, religious, or civic
activity;
4.   Attending or traveling to or from any assembly activity for which a permit
has been lawfully issued;
5.   Involved in an emergency involving the protection of a person or property
from an imminent threat of serious bodily injury or substantial damage; or
6.   Traveling between states or internationally from a location outside of
Illinois to another location outside of Illinois.
C.   Enforcement Restrictions: A police officer shall not take any enforcement
action under this section unless the police officer reasonably believes that a
violation of this section has occurred and that no exception listed in
subsection B of this section is applicable.
D.   Responsibility Of Parent, Guardian Or Other Persons: It is unlawful for a
parent, legal guardian, or other person to knowingly permit a person in his or
her custody or control to violate this section. (Ord. 2004-13, 4-26-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 5-7-7-6 of this title.
5-8-2: ALCOHOL 1 :
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give, deliver or make available
alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of twenty one (21) except in
the performance of a religious ceremony or service. This prohibition shall not
apply to the consumption of alcoholic liquor by a minor under the direct
supervision and approval of the parents or legal guardians of such minor in the
privacy of the home of said parents or legal guardians. (1988 Code § 7-3-2)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 3-2-25 of this code.
5-8-3: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
A.   Definitions: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this
section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
      KNOWINGLY: Having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief or
ground for belief which warrants further inquiry or inspection.
      LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor
by a circuit court of this state, but does not include a person appointed
guardian or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705
Illinois Compiled Statutes 405/1-1 et seq.
      MINOR: A person under the age of twenty one (21) years.
      PARENT: A natural or adoptive parent or a court designated guardian.
      UNEMANCIPATED MINOR: A minor still under the care and custody of at least
one of his or her parents or legal guardian.
      WILFUL: Proceeding from a conscious and voluntary intentional motion of
the will.
B.   Inciting Violations By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any person,
including a parent or legal guardian, to knowingly or wilfully cause, aid or
encourage any minor to violate or attempt to violate any state or federal law
or municipal ordinance or to knowingly or wilfully act in such a manner as to
directly tend to cause a minor to violate or attempt to act in such a manner as
to directly tend to cause a minor to violate or attempt to violate any state or
federal law or municipal ordinance.
C.   Parental Responsibility For Violations By Minors: It shall be unlawful for
any parent or legal guardian or an unemancipated minor to knowingly suffer,
permit or allow such minor to violate any provision of this code.
D.   Parental Responsibility For Unpaid Penalties: The parent or legal guardian
of an unemancipated minor shall be liable for any fine, condition or
restriction or reparation imposed by a court upon such minor for a violation of
any provision of this code, but only if: 1) such minor has not paid the fine or
made restitution or reparation within the time ordered by the court; and 2)
said parent or legal guardian has been served with summons or notice to appear
in the original cause as provided by law.
E.   Improper Supervision Of Minors: It shall be unlawful for any parent or
legal guardian of an unemancipated minor to fail to make all reasonable efforts
to prevent such minor from violating any of the provisions of this code,
including specifically, but without limitation, provisions concerning
vandalism, curfew for minors, alcoholic liquor and illegal drugs.
F.   Presumptions Of Knowledge And Permission:
1.   Knowingly Permitting: The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated
minor shall be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to have
knowingly permitted such minor to have committed a violation of this code if:
a.   Such minor shall have either: 1) been adjudicated to be in violation of;
2) incurred nonjudicial sanctions from an official public agency resulting from
an admission of guilt of violation of; or 3) received a written warning or
citation by the Lake Bluff police department of a potential or probable
violation of any provision of this code concerning vandalism, curfew for
minors, alcoholic liquor or illegal drugs; and
b.   The parent or legal guardian shall have received a written notice from the
village police department of such adjudication, sanction, or warning; and
c.   Within three (3) years following receipt of the notice set forth in
subsection F1b of this section, such minor either: 1) is adjudicated to have
violated the same provision of this code; or 2) shall have incurred nonjudicial
sanctions from an official public agency resulting from an admission of guilt
of violation of the same provision of this code.
2.   Not Knowingly Permitting: Notwithstanding the foregoing, such parent or
legal guardian shall not be presumed to have knowingly permitted such minor to
have committed such violation if such parent or legal guardian shall have,
prior to the occurrence of the repeated violation: a) delivered written notice
to the village chief of police of his or her inability to prevent such
continued or repeated violation; and b) requested the village chief of police,
or the proper public authority, to take the necessary legal proceedings toward
having such minor declared and dealt with as a delinquent minor. All notices
required to be delivered pursuant to this subsection shall be delivered either
by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, or by personal
service, with a certificate of personal service returned.
G.   Persons Or Entities Entitled To Enforce Provisions: The village is
entitled to enforce the liability imposed by this section.
H.   Common Law Damages: This section shall not affect the recovery of damages
in any other cause of action where the liability of the parent or legal
guardian is predicated on a common law basis. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
5-8-4: TOBACCO PRODUCTS AND E-CIGARETTES:
A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following terms,
phrases, and words shall have the meanings given to them in this subsection.
All terms, phrases, and words used in this section but not defined in this
subsection shall have the meanings given to them elsewhere in this code.
    E-CIGARETTE: An electronic device that typically includes a mouthpiece, a
heating element or atomizer, a battery, and electronic circuits; provides a gas
derived from a liquid that includes nicotine, propylene glycol, or similar
substance and perhaps other substances; and is inhaled by a user in a manner
that simulates or resembles smoking. The term "e-cigarette" includes all manner
of these devices, regardless of the details of a device's appearance or
marketed name, that are manufactured to resemble a cigarette, cigar, pipe, or
other smoking device. The term "e-cigarette" includes the cartridges and
component parts of an e-cigarette, individually or in any combination.
   MINOR: A person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
   TOBACCO PRODUCT: Any item, product, or substance containing tobacco leaf,
including specifically, but without limitation, cigarettes, cigars, snuff, and
pipe, chewing, or dipping tobacco.
B.   Sale By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any minor to sell, give,
dispense, furnish, or otherwise distribute any tobacco product or e-cigarette
to any person or business within the corporate limits of the village.
C.   Sale To Minors: It shall be unlawful for any person or business to sell,
give, dispense, furnish, or otherwise distribute any tobacco product or e-
cigarette to any minor within the corporate limits of the village.
D.   Purchase By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any minor to purchase or
otherwise acquire any tobacco product or e-cigarette within the corporate
limits of the village.
E.   Possession And Use By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any minor to
possess or use a tobacco product or e-cigarette within the corporate limits of
the village; provided, however, that the possession or use of any tobacco
product or e-cigarette by any minor under the direct supervision and control of
the parent or guardian of any such minor in the privacy of such parent's or
guardian's home shall not be unlawful.
F.   Notice Required:
1.   It shall be unlawful for any person or business to engage in the sale or
distribution of tobacco products or e-cigarettes within the corporate limits of
the village unless such person or business prominently displays as part of
every display of tobacco products or e-cigarettes offered for sale the
following notice:
THE PURCHASE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS OR E-CIGARETTES BY ANY PERSON UNDER AGE OF 18
IS PROHIBITED BY LAW.
2.   Such notice shall be displayed in red letters at least one inch (1") in
height on a white background.
G.   Responsibility For Agent Or Employee: Any act constituting a violation of
this section by an agent or employee of any person or business shall be deemed
and held to be the act of such person or business, and such person or business
shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act had been done by such
person or business personally.
H.   Penalties:
1.   Any minor who violates any provision of this section shall be punished by
a fine not to exceed twenty five dollars ($25.00) for a first offense, fifty
dollars ($50.00) for a second offense, and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a
third or subsequent offense.
2.   Any person, other than a minor, who violates any provision of this section
shall be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a
first offense, four hundred dollars ($400.00) for a second offense, and six
hundred dollars ($600.00) for a third or subsequent offense. (Ord. 2015-15, 9-
28-2015)
CHAPTER 9
ANIMAL CONTROL
ARTICLE A. GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
5-9A-1: Application Of Provisions
5-9A-2: Animal Houses
5-9A-3: Location (Rep. by Ord. 2025-21, 7-14-2025)
5-9A-4: Vicious, Dangerous Or Nondomesticated Animals
5-9A-5: Destroying Dangerous Animals
5-9A-6: Penalty
5-9A-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this article apply to all fowl and animals, domestic or
nondomestic, except for dogs or cats as defined in article B of this chapter.
(Ord. 2025-10, 2-24-2025)
5-9A-2: ANIMAL HOUSES:
No owner of any animal will cause or permit any stable or place where any cow,
horse or other animal or fowl is kept to become unclean, filthy or unwholesome,
nor will such owner allow any animal or fowl infected with a contagious disease
to remain therein without the permission of the health officer. (Ord. 2025-10,
2-24-2025)
5-9A-3: LOCATION:
(Rep. by Ord. 2025-21, 7-14-2025)
5-9A-4: VICIOUS, DANGEROUS OR NONDOMESTICATED ANIMALS:
No person may keep or allow to be kept on any premises in the village, any type
of vicious, fierce or dangerous nondomestic animals or nondomestic pets or any
type of poisonous snake or other type of poisonous reptile at any time whether
or not under guard, control or security. (Ord. 2025-10, 2-24-2025)
5-9A-5: DESTROYING DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
The members of the police department, or any person in cases of emergency, are
authorized to euthanize dangerous animals of any kind when necessary for the
protection of any person or property. (Ord. 2025-10, 2-24-2025)
5-9A-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article will be fined not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. A separate offense will be deemed
committed on each day during or on which the violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2025-10, 2-24-2025)
ARTICLE B. DOGS
SECTION:
5-9B-1: Definitions
5-9B-2: Registration And County License Required; Fee
5-9B-3: Rabies Vaccination Required
5-9B-4: Collar And Tags
5-9B-5: Term Of License
5-9B-6: Running At Large; Impoundment Procedures
5-9B-7: Nuisance Dogs
5-9B-8: Vicious, Dangerous Dogs
5-9B-9: Destruction Of Certain Dogs
5-9B-10: Rabies Control
5-9B-11: Defecation Restrictions
5-9B-12: Violations; Penalties
5-9B-1: DEFINITIONS:
AT LARGE: Off the premises of the owner or custodian of the dog and not held by
leash, nor under the control of the owner or custodian of the dog or a member
of his immediate family of the age of fifteen (15) years or older.
ATTACK: To chase any person under any circumstances, including, but not limited
to, chasing a person on a bicycle or tricycle upon any street or sidewalk or to
otherwise charge at or upon any person with apparent intent to bite or
otherwise injure or molest such person.
DOG: All animals of the canine species, both male and female, wild and
domesticated, singular and plural.
LEASH: A cord or chain not more than six feet (6') in length, by which a dog is
controlled by the person accompanying it. (1988 Code § 7-4B-1)
5-9B-2: REGISTRATION AND COUNTY LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
Every owner of an unlicensed dog shall register the same with the county
department of health within five (5) days after he becomes the owner or keeper
of such dog, and each year as required by the county. At the time of
registration, the owner shall produce evidence of inoculation as required in
section
5-9B-3 of this article by a veterinarian certifying the inoculation for rabies
is valid for a period of at least one year and secure a county license by the
payment of the annual or alternative county license fee as provided in the
county animal/rabies control ordinance. (Ord. 97-8, 4-14-1997; amd. 2009 Code)
5-9B-3: RABIES VACCINATION REQUIRED:
A.   Inoculation Requirements: Every owner of a dog in the village shall have
such dog inoculated for rabies as soon after he becomes the owner of the dog as
is practicable, by a veterinarian duly licensed as such by the state, or if
given by a veterinarian of another state, the veterinarian must possess
professional qualifications similar to those required by the state of Illinois,
and shall have in his possession at all times a certificate of such
veterinarian setting forth the date on which such dog was inoculated for
rabies. Except as otherwise provided herein, such inoculations shall be
performed before May 1 of each year, and shall be valid for such period of time
as certified by the state department of agriculture or its successor agency.
Rabies vaccines administered shall comply with the requirements established by
the state department of agriculture, and of rabies vaccine approved by the
United States department of agriculture and the state department of
agriculture. Failure to have such inoculations performed and reported to the
village clerk shall be deemed a violation of this article, and shall subject
the owner or custodian of such dog to penalty as provided herein.
B.   Age Of Dog: Unless provided otherwise by laws, rules or regulations of the
state department of health, state department of agriculture and the United
States department of agriculture and the county health department, no dog of
less than four (4) months of age shall be required to be immunized. The owner
or keeper of a dog who reaches four (4) months of age shall immediately cause
such dog to be immunized and file certification thereof with the village clerk
within ten (10) days after any such dog reaches four (4) months of age. (1988
Code § 7-4B-4)
5-9B-4: COLLAR AND TAGS:
A.   Every owner of a licensed dog shall maintain a collar or harness around
the neck of such dog with the current county license tag securely attached
thereto, and, in addition thereto, a metal tag bearing the name of the dog and
the name and address of the owner thereof. No person shall remove or take away
the collar or harness or license tag or ID tag from any dog.
B.   It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any dog to possess,
harbor or keep any dog in the village without a current county license tag
attached to its collar or harness, or to harbor, keep or possess any dog for
which a license has been revoked. (1988 Code § 7-4B-5; amd. 2009 Code)
5-9B-5: TERM OF LICENSE:
All dogs shall be licensed by the county department of health as provided in
the county animal/rabies control ordinance. No county license shall be valid
for a period in excess of the duration of the effectiveness of the rabies
inoculation. (Ord. 97-8, 4-14-1997; amd. 2009 Code)
5-9B-6: RUNNING AT LARGE; IMPOUNDMENT PROCEDURES:
A.   Prohibited; Females In Heat:
1.   Leash Required: It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any dog
to permit such dog to run at large within the village at any time off the
premises of its owner or custodian. No female dog in heat shall be permitted to
be out of doors, except when controlled by the owner or custodian or other
person authorized by him, and firmly held upon an adequate hand leash, and any
female dog in heat not so held and controlled shall be deemed at large.
2.   Nuisance Declared; Impoundment: Any dog running at large in violation of
this section is hereby declared a public nuisance and may be picked up and
impounded in such place as is designated by the chief of police, if it is
licensed; or if unlicensed, shall be disposed of by the police department.
3.   Disposal By Police Department: Any dog found at large within the village
without a current county license tag attached to its collar or harness or for
which a county license has been revoked shall be deemed a nuisance and shall be
disposed of by the police department.
B.   Notice Requirements: The provisions relative to notice upon impounding,
redemption, county license fee, impounding fees and costs and inoculation as
set forth in subsection C of this section shall apply, provided nothing
contained herein shall relieve the owner of any impounded dog from prosecution
for violation of this article or any portion hereof. (1988 Code § 7-4B-7)
C.   Redemption; Fees: Upon the impounding of any dog by the police department,
the owner or custodian of such dog shall be immediately notified, if the same
can be determined, and redemption shall be permitted subject to limitations
provided herein and in other sections of this article; provided such redemption
is made within three (3) days of impounding; and, further provided, that the
owner or custodian shall pay any county license fee required, together with an
amount as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code for the cost of impounding such dog, and if the dog is in
the village pound, an amount as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code for the keeping of such dog, or when in such other
designated facility, the actual cost charged for keeping such dog. The owner or
custodian of any dog impounded who cannot produce evidence of current
inoculation shall cause such dog to be properly inoculated at the time of
making redemption of said dog. (Ord. 94-11, 4-11-1994; amd. 2009 Code)
D.   Third Impound: Upon the third impounding of any dog for running at large
in the village, said dog shall be declared a nuisance and the dog license of
its owner revoked by the village clerk, and said dog shall be permanently
removed from the village.
E.   Disposition Of Unredeemed Dog: If any dog is unredeemed at the end of
three (3) days after notice to the owner or custodian thereof or three (3) days
after reasonable efforts have been concluded by the police department to
determine and notify such owner or custodian, it shall be the duty of the chief
of police or other person designated by him to deliver the dog to a recognized
animal welfare shelter or to make such other disposition of the dog.
F.   Hindering Enforcement Officials Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to hinder
or molest any police officer, animal warden or other authorized person engaged
in the enforcement of this section. (1988 Code § 7-4B-7)
5-9B-7: NUISANCE DOGS:
A.   Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of a dog to
suffer or permit such dog to bark or howl in a disturbing degree, to attack
other animals or persons, to damage public or private property or otherwise
create a public nuisance.
B.   Investigation And Hearing: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this
article, the chief of police may, upon investigation and hearing, determine a
dog to be a nuisance and to pose a threat to the health, welfare and safety of
the village.
C.   Revocation Of Dog License; Disposition Of Dog: On making such a
determination, the village clerk may, in his discretion, revoke the dog license
issued for such dog and direct the owner or custodian to remove such dog
permanently from the village or direct the chief of police or his
representative to take possession of such dog and dispose of it as deemed
necessary by the chief of police.
D.   Custody Of Police Department: If deemed essential to the public
protection, the village president or village administrator may direct the chief
of police or his representative to take immediate possession of, and hold
custody of, any such dog pending investigation under this section. (1988 Code §
7-4B-8)
5-9B-8: VICIOUS, DANGEROUS DOGS:
A.   Determination Of Threat; Disposition Of Dog: Notwithstanding any other
provisions of this article, the chief of police may, on investigation,
determine a dog to be vicious and/or dangerous and to pose a threat of physical
injury to the person. Upon such determination, such vicious dog shall be
confined as provided in subsection B of this section, or the village clerk may,
in his discretion, direct the owner or custodian to remove such dog permanently
from the village or direct the chief of police or his representative to take
possession of such dog and dispose of it as deemed necessary by the chief of
police. If deemed essential to the public protection, the village president,
village clerk or village administrator may direct the chief of police or his
representative to take immediate possession of, and hold custody of, any such
dog pending investigation under this section.
B.   Confinement; Impoundment; Redemption: Any vicious and/or dangerous dog
shall be confined by its owner on the owner's premises at all times in such
manner that it cannot reach persons who may have occasion to lawfully enter
upon said premises. Any such dog which is not confined on its owner's premises
as provided herein is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and such dog may
be apprehended and impounded upon the order of the chief of police or any
person charged with the enforcement of this article, and the village clerk
shall revoke the county license for such dog. The owner shall have no right to
redeem such dog unless he shall remove the same from the village immediately
upon redemption and shall not thereafter keep, harbor or maintain such dog in
the village at any time. A dog which has, without provocation, either bitten or
attacked any person shall, for a period of twenty four (24) months thereafter,
be presumed to be a dangerous dog for the purposes of this section. (1988 Code
§ 7-4B-9)
5-9B-9: DESTRUCTION OF CERTAIN DOGS:
Any member of the police department may destroy any vicious or rabid dog found
at large within the village which poses an immediate threat of physical injury
to the residents and which cannot be taken up and impounded without undue risk
of physical injury. (1988 Code § 7-4B-10)
5-9B-10: RABIES CONTROL:
A.   Proclamation Of Emergency:
1.   Notice To Confine Dogs: Whenever deemed necessary for reasons of public
health, or whenever danger from hydrophobia or rabies is deemed to exist in the
village, the village president, by proclamation or notice published in one or
more newspapers having a general circulation in the village, may notify all
persons owning or keeping dogs, whether licensed or not, to keep them confined
within an enclosure from which escape is impossible, or to keep them securely
muzzled or restrained by a leash composed of chain or other indestructible
material for such time as may be designated by the proclamation or notice.
(1988 Code § 7-4B-11)
2.   Impoundment; Redemption; Fee: The running at large of any dog during the
period set forth in the proclamation or notice is hereby declared a nuisance,
and any dog found running at large shall be impounded in the manner herein
provided for unlicensed dogs; provided, that the redemption fee for cost of
impounding hereunder shall be an amount as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code.
3.   Unmuzzled Dogs: The provisions of impounding, redeeming and disposing of
unlicensed dogs shall also apply to such unmuzzled dogs except as specifically
modified in this subsection. (1988 Code § 7-4B-11; amd. 2009 Code)
B.   Dog Bites; Confinement:
1.   Confinement And Observation; Examination By Veterinarian: It shall be
unlawful for the owner of any dog, when notified by the village or the police
department that such dog has bitten any person or animal, to sell or give away
such dog or to permit or allow such dog to be taken beyond the limits of the
county. It shall be the duty of such owner of a biting dog, upon receiving
notice from the village, to deliver said dog within twenty four (24) hours to a
licensed veterinarian for confinement and observation, at the expense of the
owner, for a period of ten (10) days. If, however, the dog is examined by a
licensed veterinarian within twenty four (24) hours after notification by the
village and found to be free of signs of rabies and the licensed veterinarian
is presented evidence that such dog has been inoculated against rabies more
than thirty (30) days prior to the biting and less than one year if a one year
vaccine is used, or less than three (3) years if a three (3) year vaccine is
used, and such veterinarian certifies that such dog is, in his opinion, free of
rabies, such dog shall, in lieu of veterinary hospital confinement, be confined
in the house of its owner in a manner that will prohibit said dog from escaping
or from biting any person or animal for the ten (10) day period, if the
licensed veterinarian adjudges such confinement satisfactory. At the end of the
ten (10) day confinement period, the owner shall present the dog for
reexamination by the licensed veterinarian. Should the dog become ill, die or
escape during the ten (10) day period, the owner shall immediately notify the
village police department.
2.   Escape From Confinement: Any dog that escapes or is allowed to escape
during a period of home confinement shall, for the remainder of any confinement
period, be confined with a licensed veterinarian at the expense of the owner.
C.   Destruction Of Rabid Dogs: Any dog found to be rabid upon examination by a
veterinarian shall immediately be destroyed by the chief of police or a person
designated by him, or a licensed veterinarian, at the expense of the owner or
custodian of such dog. (1988 Code § 7-4B-12)
5-9B-11: DEFECATION RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of a dog to suffer or permit
such dog, whether on leash or not, to perform any bowel movements or
eliminations of any kind on any public property or upon any private property
not owned by the owner or custodian of such dog. (1988 Code § 7-4B-13)
5-9B-12: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A.   Fines For Certain Violations: Any person violating any of the provisions
of section
5-9B-4, subsection 5-9B-6A or subsection 5-9B-10B or C of this article,
excepting the harboring or keeping of a dog for which a license has been
revoked, who complies with the provisions of this article before the
impoundment of his dog, may pay a fine without prosecution, by mailing or
delivery of the fine by check, money order or currency to the police
department. The fine for the first ticket on any dog shall be ten dollars
($10.00). The fine for a second violation by the same dog within any one
hundred eighty (180) day period of any prior violation shall be twenty dollars
($20.00). The fine for a third violation by the same dog within any one hundred
eighty (180) day period of any prior violation shall be thirty five dollars
($35.00). The fine for a fourth or subsequent violation within any one hundred
eighty (180) day period shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). All of the fines
herein enumerated, except that for a fourth or subsequent violation within any
one hundred eighty (180) day period, may be paid to the police department,
together with a signed plea of guilty and waiver of hearing, and must be made
within forty eight (48) hours after receipt of notice of the violation. Upon
the occurrence of a fourth or subsequent violation, and upon conviction thereof
within any one hundred eighty (180) day period, the owner or custodian of the
dog will be required to show cause, if any he can, before the village president
and board of trustees or any committee therefrom designated by the board, why
the dog should not be declared a public nuisance and removed from the village.
B.   Failure To Timely Pay; Fine Escalation: Upon the failure of the violator
to pay said fine within said forty eight (48) hour period, a second notice may
be sent, no earlier than five (5) days after the first notice of violation, and
the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of
fifteen dollars ($15.00) for the first violation as defined herein, thirty
dollars ($30.00) for the second violation as defined herein and in the amount
of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a third violation as defined herein, provided
said fines are paid within ten (10) days after the date of the second notice of
violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine after a second
notice within ten (10) days thereafter, a final notice may be sent, no earlier
than twelve (12) business days after the second notice of violation, and the
fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of
twenty dollars ($20.00) for a first violation, and in the amount of forty
dollars ($40.00) for a second violation, and in the amount of seventy five
dollars ($75.00) for a third violation of this article as defined herein.
Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to require the giving of any
additional notices after the first notification is made. The transmittal of a
notice by registered or certified mail shall be deemed sufficient notice, if
mailed to the last known address of the violator, and notice shall be deemed to
have been accomplished even if there is a failure or refusal of the individual
to whom said notice is sent to receipt or accept the same.
C.   Payment Without Prosecution: Any owner or keeper of an unlicensed dog may
pay a fine without prosecution by mailing or delivery of the fine by check,
money order or currency to the police department. The fine shall be five
dollars ($5.00) if paid within forty eight (48) hours after receipt of the
notification of the violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay said
fine within forty eight (48) hours, a second notice may be sent, no earlier
than five (5) days after the first notification of violation, and the fine
therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of ten
dollars ($10.00), provided said fine is paid within ten (10) days after the
date of the second notice of violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay
said fine after a second notice within ten (10) days thereafter, a final notice
may be sent, no earlier than twelve (12) days after the second notice of
violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be
in the amount of fifteen dollars ($15.00), provided the same is paid within ten
(10) days after the date of any such notice. Nothing contained herein shall be
deemed to require the giving of any additional notice after the first
notification is made. The transmittal of a notice by registered or certified
mail shall be deemed sufficient notice if mailed to the last known address of
the violator, and notice shall be deemed to have been accomplished even if
there is a failure or refusal of the individual to whom the notice is sent to
receipt or accept the same. All fines paid pursuant to the provisions contained
herein shall be accompanied by a signed plea of guilty and a waiver of hearing.
D.   General Penalty: Unless otherwise provided herein, any owner or person who
violates any provision of this article, or any section hereof, shall, upon
conviction, be fined in the sum of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) for the
first offense, not less than twenty dollars ($20.00) for a second offense
within any ninety (90) day period, not less than thirty five dollars ($35.00)
for a third offense within any ninety (90) day period, and not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) for a fourth or subsequent offense during any ninety (90) day
period, nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (Ord. 96-21, 8-26-1996; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE C. CATS
SECTION:
5-9C-1: Definitions
5-9C-2: Registration And County License Required; Fee
5-9C-3: Rabies Vaccination Required
5-9C-4: Collar, Tags And Bell
5-9C-5: Term Of License
5-9C-6: Stray Cats; Running At Large; Impoundment Procedures
5-9C-7: Nuisance Cats
5-9C-8: Vicious, Dangerous Cats
5-9C-9: Destruction Of Certain Cats
5-9C-10: Rabies Control
5-9C-11: Defecation Restrictions
5-9C-12: Violations; Penalties
5-9C-1: DEFINITIONS:
AT LARGE: Off the premises of the owner or custodian of the cat and not under
the control of the owner or custodian of the cat or a member of his immediate
family.
ATTACK: To chase any person under any circumstances, including, but not limited
to, chasing a person on a bicycle or tricycle upon any street or sidewalk or to
otherwise charge at or upon any person with apparent intent to bite or
otherwise injure or molest such person.
CAT: All animals of the feline species, both male and female, wild and
domesticated, singular and plural. (1988 Code § 7-4C-1)
5-9C-2: REGISTRATION AND COUNTY LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
Every owner of an unlicensed cat shall register the same with the county
department of health within five (5) days after he becomes the owner or keeper
of such cat, and each year as required by the county. At the time of
registration, the owner shall produce evidence of inoculation as required in
section
5-9C-3 of this article by a veterinarian certifying the inoculation for rabies
is valid for a period of at least one year and secure a county license by the
payment of the license fee as provided in the county animal/rabies control
ordinance. (Ord. 97-8, 4-14-1997; amd. 2009 Code)
5-9C-3: RABIES VACCINATION REQUIRED:
A.   Inoculation Requirements: Every owner of a cat in the village shall have
such cat inoculated for rabies as soon after he becomes the owner of the cat as
it is practicable, by a veterinarian duly licensed as such by the state, or if
given by a veterinarian of another state, the veterinarian must possess
professional qualifications similar to those required by the state of Illinois,
and shall have in his possession at all times, a certificate of such
veterinarian setting forth the date on which such cat was inoculated for
rabies. Except as otherwise provided herein, such inoculations shall be
performed before May 1 of each year, and shall be valid for such period of time
as certified by the state department of agriculture or its successor agency.
Rabies vaccines administered shall comply with the requirements established by
the state department of agriculture, and of rabies vaccine approved by the
United States department of agriculture and the state department of
agriculture. Failure to have such inoculations performed and reported to the
chief of police and the village clerk shall be deemed a violation of this
article, and subject the owner or custodian of such cat to penalty as provided
herein.
B.   Age Of Cat: Unless provided otherwise by laws, rules or regulations of the
state department of health, state department of agriculture and the United
States department of agriculture and the county health department, no cat of
less than four (4) months of age shall be required to be immunized. The owner
or keeper of a cat who reaches four (4) months of age shall immediately cause
such cat to be immunized and file certification thereof with the village clerk
within ten (10) days after any such cat reaches four (4) months of age. (1988
Code § 7-4C-4)
5-9C-4: COLLAR, TAGS AND BELL:
A.   Every owner of a licensed cat shall maintain a collar or harness around
the neck of such cat with the current county license tag securely attached
thereto, and in addition thereto, a metal tag bearing the name of the cat and
the name and address of the owner thereof. No person shall remove or take away
the collar or harness or county license tag or ID tag from any cat.
B.   It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any cat to possess,
harbor or keep any cat in the village without a current county license tag
attached to its collar or harness, or to harbor, keep or possess any cat for
which a license has been revoked.
C.   There shall also be attached to such cat a bell or other device capable of
making noise to serve as a warning to birds. (1988 Code § 7-4C-5; amd. 2009
Code)
5-9C-5: TERM OF LICENSE:
All cats shall be licensed by the county department of health as provided in
the county animal/rabies control ordinance. No license shall be valid for a
period in excess of the duration of the effectiveness of the rabies
inoculation. (Ord. 97-8, 4-14-1997)
5-9C-6: STRAY CATS; RUNNING AT LARGE; IMPOUNDMENT PROCEDURES:
A.   Stray Cats; Running At Large:
1.   Stray Cats Declared A Nuisance: Stray cats are a menace to public health
and endanger bird life, and the running at large of any cat within the limits
of the village is hereby declared to be a nuisance and prohibited. Any cats not
equipped with a tag around their collar identifying the owner thereof, or
without a bell or other device capable of making a noise shall be deemed a
stray cat.
2.   Running At Large Prohibited; Impoundment: It shall be unlawful for the
owner or custodian of any cat to permit such cat to run at large within the
village at any time off the premises of its owner or custodian. Any cat running
at large in violation of this section is hereby declared a public nuisance and
may be picked up and impounded in such place as is designated by the chief of
police, if it is licensed. If unlicensed, said cat shall be disposed of by the
police department.
3.   Disposal By Police Department: Any cat found at large within the village
without a current license tag attached to its collar or harness or for which a
license has been revoked shall be deemed a nuisance and shall be disposed of by
the police department.
B.   Notice Requirements: The provisions relative to notice upon impounding,
redemption, license fee, impounding fees and costs and inoculation as set forth
in subsection D of this section shall apply, provided nothing contained herein
shall relieve the owner of any impounded cat from prosecution for violation of
this article or any portion thereof. (1988 Code § 7-4C-7)
C.   Redemption; Fees: Upon the impounding of any cat by the police department,
the owner or custodian of such cat shall be immediately notified, if the same
can be determined, and redemption shall be permitted subject to limitations
provided herein and in other sections of this article, provided such redemption
is made within three (3) days of impounding; and, further provided, that the
owner or custodian shall pay any license fee required, together with the sum as
set out in section
1-12-3 of this code for the cost of impounding such cat, and if the cat is in
the village pound, the sum as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code for the keeping of such cat, or when in such other
designated facility, the actual cost charged for keeping such cat. The owner or
custodian of any cat impounded who cannot produce current evidence of
inoculation shall cause such cat to be properly inoculated at the time of
making redemption of said cat. (Ord. 94-11, 4-11-1994; amd. 2009 Code)
D.   Third Impound: Upon the third impounding of any cat for running at large
in the village, said cat shall be declared a nuisance and the cat license of
its owner revoked by the village clerk, and said cat shall be permanently
removed from the village.
E.   Disposition Of Unredeemed Cat: If any cat is unredeemed at the end of
three (3) days after notice to the owner or custodian thereof or three (3) days
after reasonable efforts have been concluded by the police department to
determine and notify such owner or custodian, it shall be the duty of the chief
of police or other person designated by him to deliver the cat to a recognized
animal welfare shelter or to make such other disposition of the cat as is
approved by the village president. (1988 Code § 7-4C-7)
F.   Female Cats In Heat: No female cat in heat shall be permitted to be out of
doors, except when controlled by the owner or custodian or other person
authorized by the owner or custodian of the age of fifteen (15) years or older,
and firmly held upon an adequate hand leash, and any female cat in heat not so
held and controlled shall be deemed at large. (1988 Code § 7-4C-7; amd. 2009
Code)
G.   Hindering Enforcement Officials Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to hinder
or molest any police officer, animal warden or other authorized person engaged
in the enforcement of this section. (1988 Code § 7-4C-7)
5-9C-7: NUISANCE CATS:
A.   Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of a cat to
suffer or permit such cat to meow in a disturbing degree, to attack other
animals or persons, to damage public or private property or otherwise create a
public nuisance.
B.   Investigation And Hearing: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this
article, the chief of police may, upon investigation and hearing, determine
that a cat is a nuisance and poses a threat to the health, welfare and safety
of the village.
C.   Revocation Of Cat License; Disposition Of Cat: On making such a
determination, the village clerk may, in his discretion, revoke the cat license
issued for such cat and direct the owner or custodian to remove such cat
permanently from the village or direct the chief of police or his
representative to take possession of such cat and dispose of it as deemed
proper by the chief of police. (1988 Code § 7-4C-9)
D.   Custody Of Police Department: If deemed essential to the public
protection, the village president or village administrator may direct the chief
of police or his representative to take immediate possession of, and hold
custody of, any such cat pending investigation under this section. (1988 Code §
7-4C-9; amd. 2009 Code)
5-9C-8: VICIOUS, DANGEROUS CATS:
A.   Determination Of Threat; Disposition Of Cat: Notwithstanding any other
provisions of this article, the chief of police may, upon investigation,
determine that a cat is vicious and/or dangerous and poses a threat of physical
injury to the person. Upon such determination, such vicious cat shall be
confined as provided in subsection B of this section, or the village clerk may,
in his discretion, direct the owner or custodian to remove such cat permanently
from the village or direct the chief of police or his representative to take
possession of such cat and dispose of it as deemed proper by the chief of
police. If deemed essential to the public protection, the village president or
village administrator may direct the chief of police or his representative to
take immediate possession of, and hold custody of, any such cat pending
investigation under this section. (1988 Code § 7-4C-10; amd. 2009 Code)
B.   Confinement; Impoundment; Redemption: Any vicious and/or dangerous cat
shall be confined by its owner on the owner's premises at all times in such
manner that it cannot reach persons who may have occasion to lawfully enter
upon said premises. Any such cat which is not confined on its owner's premises
as provided herein is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and such cat may
be apprehended and impounded upon the order of the chief of police or any
person charged with the enforcement of this article, and the village clerk
shall revoke the license for such cat. The owner shall have no right to redeem
such cat unless he shall remove the same from the village immediately upon
redemption and shall not thereafter keep, harbor or maintain such cat in the
village at any time. A cat which has, without provocation, either bitten or
attacked any person shall, for a period of twenty four (24) months thereafter,
be presumed to be a dangerous cat for the purposes of this section. (1988 Code
§ 7-4C-10)
5-9C-9: DESTRUCTION OF CERTAIN CATS:
Any member of the police department may destroy any vicious or rabid cat found
at large within the village which poses an immediate threat of physical injury
to the residents and which cannot be taken up and impounded without undue risk
of physical injury. (1988 Code § 7-4C-11)
5-9C-10: RABIES CONTROL:
A.   Proclamation Of Emergency:
1.   Notice To Confine Cats: Whenever deemed necessary for reasons of public
health, or whenever danger from hydrophobia or rabies is deemed to exist in the
village, the village president, by proclamation or notice published in one or
more newspapers having a general circulation in the village, may notify all
persons owning or keeping cats, whether licensed or not, to keep them confined
within an enclosure from which escape is impossible, or to keep them securely
muzzled or restrained by a leash composed of chain or other indestructible
material for such time as may be designated by the proclamation or notice.
(1988 Code § 7-4C-12)
2.   Impoundment; Redemption Fee: The running at large of any cat during the
period set forth in the proclamation or notice is hereby declared a nuisance,
and any cat found running at large shall be impounded in the manner herein
provided for unlicensed cats; provided, that the redemption fee for cost of
impounding hereunder shall be an amount as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code.
3.   Unmuzzled Cats: The provisions of impounding, redeeming and disposing of
unlicensed cats shall also apply to such unmuzzled cats except as specifically
modified in this subsection. (1988 Code § 7-4C-12; amd. 2009 Code)
B.   Cat Bites:
1.   Owner Requirements And Restrictions: It shall be unlawful for the owner or
keeper of any cat or other animal, when notified that such cat or animal has
bitten any person, to sell or give away such cat or animal or to permit it to
be taken beyond the control of the village. It shall be the duty of the owner
or keeper, upon receiving notice from the police department that the cat or
animal has bitten any person, to deliver such cat or animal to a licensed
veterinarian pursuant to the provisions of subsection B2 of this section for
confinement, observation and examination, and if the cat or animal is
determined to be rabid, for destruction as provided in said subsection. (1988
Code § 7-4C-8)
2.   Confinement And Observation; Examination By Veterinarian: It shall be
unlawful for the owner of any cat, when notified by the village or the police
department that such cat has bitten any person or animal, to sell or give away
such cat or to permit or allow such cat to be taken beyond the limits of the
county. It shall be the duty of such owner of a biting cat, upon receiving
notice from the village, to deliver said cat within twenty four (24) hours to a
licensed veterinarian for confinement and observation, at the expense of the
owner, for a period of ten (10) days. If, however, the cat is examined by a
licensed veterinarian within twenty four (24) hours after notification by the
village and found to be free of signs of rabies, and the licensed veterinarian
is presented evidence that such cat has been inoculated against rabies, more
than thirty (30) days prior to the biting, and less than one year if a one year
vaccine is used, or less than three (3) years if a three (3) year vaccine is
used, and such veterinarian certifies that such cat is, in his opinion, free of
rabies, such cat shall, in lieu of veterinary hospital confinement, be confined
in the house of its owner in a manner that will prohibit said cat from escaping
or from biting any person or animal for the ten (10) day period, if the
licensed veterinarian adjudges such confinement satisfactory. At the end of the
ten (10) day confinement period, the owner shall present the cat for
reexamination by the licensed veterinarian. Should the cat become ill, die or
escape during the ten (10) day period, the owner shall immediately notify the
police department.
3.   Escape From Home Confinement: Any cat that escapes or is allowed to escape
during a period of home confinement shall, for the remainder of any confinement
period, be confined with a licensed veterinarian at the expense of the owner.
C.   Destruction Of Rabid Cat: Any cat found to be rabid upon examination by a
veterinarian shall immediately be destroyed by the chief of police or a person
designated by him, or a licensed veterinarian, at the expense of the owner or
custodian of such cat. (1988 Code § 7-4C-13)
5-9C-11: DEFECATION RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of a cat to suffer or permit
such cat to perform any bowel movements or eliminations of any kind on any
public property or upon on any private property not owned by the owner or
custodian of such cat. (1988 Code § 7-4C-14)
5-9C-12: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A.   Fines For Certain Violations: Any person violating any of the provisions
of section
5-9C-4, subsection 5-9C-6A or G or subsection 5-9C-10B or C of this article,
excepting the harboring or keeping of a cat for which a license has been
revoked, who complies with the provisions of this article before the
impoundment of his cat, may pay a fine without prosecution by mailing or
delivery of the fine by check, money order or currency to the police
department. The fine for the first ticket on any cat shall be ten dollars
($10.00). The fine for a second violation by the same cat within any one
hundred eighty (180) day period of any prior violation shall be twenty dollars
($20.00). The fine for a third violation by the same cat within any one hundred
eighty (180) day period of any prior violation shall be thirty five dollars
($35.00). The fine for a fourth or subsequent violation within any one hundred
eighty (180) day period shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). All of the fines
herein enumerated, except that for a fourth or subsequent violation within any
one hundred eighty (180) day period, may be paid to the police department,
together with a signed plea of guilty and waiver of hearing, and must be made
within forty eight (48) hours after receipt of notice of the violation. Upon
the occurrence of a fourth or subsequent violation, and upon conviction thereof
within any one hundred eighty (180) day period, the owner or custodian of the
