cat will be required to show cause, if any he can, before the village president
and board of trustees or any committee therefrom designated by the board, why
the cat should not be declared a public nuisance and removed from the village.
B.   Failure To Pay: Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine within
forty eight (48) hours, a second notice may be sent, no earlier than forty
eight (48) hours after the first notice of violation, and the fine therefor may
be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of fifteen dollars
($15.00) for the first violation as defined herein, thirty dollars ($30.00) for
the second violation as herein defined herein and fifty dollars ($50.00) for a
third violation as defined herein, provided said fines are paid within ten (10)
days after the date of the second notice of violation. Upon the failure of the
violator to pay said fine after a second notice within ten (10) days
thereafter, a final notice may be sent, no earlier than twelve (12) business
days after the second notice of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in
the same manner, but shall be in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the
first violation, and in the amount of forty dollars ($40.00) for a second
violation, and in the amount of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for a third
violation of this article as defined herein. Nothing contained herein shall be
deemed to require the giving of any additional notices after the first
notification is made. The transmittal of a notice by registered or certified
mail shall be deemed sufficient notice, if mailed to the last known address of
the violator, and notice shall be deemed to have been accomplished even if
there is a failure or refusal of the individual to whom said notice is sent to
receipt or accept the same.
C.   Payment Without Prosecution: Any owner or keeper of an unlicensed cat may
pay a fine without prosecution, by mailing or delivery of the fine by check,
money order or currency to the police department. The fine shall be five
dollars ($5.00) if paid within forty eight (48) hours after receipt of the
notification of the violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay said
fine within forty eight (48) hours, a second notice may be sent, no earlier
than five (5) days after the first notification of violation, and the fine
therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of ten
dollars ($10.00), provided said fine is paid within ten (10) days after the
date of the second notice of violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay
said fine after a second notice within ten (10) days thereafter, a final notice
may be sent, no earlier than twelve (12) days after the second notice of
violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be
in the amount of fifteen dollars ($15.00), provided the same is paid within ten
(10) days after the date of any such notice. Nothing contained herein shall be
deemed to require the giving of any additional notice after the first
notification is made. The transmittal of a notice by registered or certified
mail shall be deemed sufficient notice, if mailed to last known address of the
violator, and notice shall be deemed to have been accomplished even if there is
a failure or refusal of the individual to whom the notice is sent to receipt or
accept the same. All fines paid pursuant to the provisions contained herein
shall be accompanied by a signed plea of guilty and a waiver of hearing.
D.   General Penalty: Unless otherwise provided herein, any owner or person who
violates any provision of this article, or any section hereof, shall, upon
conviction, be fined in the sum of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) for the
first offense, not less than twenty dollars ($20.00) for a second offense
within any ninety (90) day period, not less than thirty five dollars ($35.00)
for a third offense within any ninety (90) day period, and not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) for a fourth or subsequent offense during any ninety (90) day
period, nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (Ord. 96-21, 8-26-1996; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE D. ACCESSORY ANIMAL LICENSES
SECTION:
5-9D-1: Purpose
5-9D-2: General Provisions
5-9D-3: Advisory Review Of Initial Applications
5-9D-4: Inspections
5-9D-5: Chicken-Specific Regulations
5-9D-6: Bee-Specific Regulations
5-9D-7: Penalty
5-9D-1: PURPOSE:
Accessory animal licenses are established to provide a mechanism for the lawful
keeping of certain classes of animals that are uncommon in residential areas
and that, if kept improperly, would injure the public health, safety, comfort,
convenience, and general welfare. (Ord. 2021-2, 2-8-2021)
5-9D-2: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
A.   Enforcement Officer: The Village Administrator or his or her designee
shall be responsible for the review, issuance, enforcement, and revocation of
accessory animal licenses pursuant to this Article.
B.   Eligibility; License Types: Only a resident of a property used as a
single-family dwelling may apply for and receive an accessory animal license to
keep either chickens or bees on their property.
C.   Form of Application: Applications for an accessory animal license must be
made in a form and provided in a number determined by the Village
Administrator.
D.   License Term: Accessory animal licenses issued shall be valid from the
date of issuance until the next succeeding March 1. Licenses must be renewed
annually.
E.   Maximum Number of Licenses: A maximum of fifteen (15) accessory animal
licenses may be issued at any time.
F.   Application Fee: A non-refundable application fee shall accompany each
application in the amount specified in Section
1-12-3 of this Code. Said fee is imposed to defray the costs and expenses of
the Village's consideration of the application, regardless of the ultimate
approval or disapproval of the license sought.
G.   Non-Transferable License: Licenses issued shall only be valid for the
applicant listed on the application. A new license and application fee shall be
required in the event that an applicant or licensee moves to a new address or
transfers the chickens or bees to a person not already possessing an accessory
animal license.
H.   Conditions of Approval: At the time of issuance or renewal, the Village
Administrator may impose specific conditions upon the recipient of an accessory
animal license to prevent or minimize adverse effects upon other property in
the vicinity of the licensed activity. Such conditions shall be expressly set
forth in the license. Violation of any such condition or limitation shall be a
violation of this Article and shall constitute grounds for revocation of the
license.
I.   Revocation: Any license issued under pursuant to this Article may be
revoked by the Village Administrator for a violation of any condition imposed
upon a license, any provision hereof, or upon satisfactory proof that the
licensed activity was conducted in a manner detrimental to the public safety,
health, or morals. Such revocation may be in addition to the imposition of any
other fines or penalties under this Article or Code and shall be no defense to
a prosecution for such violation.
J.   Appeal: In the event any applicant or licensee shall be refused a license
by the Village Administrator, have their license revoked, or shall be otherwise
aggrieved by the administration of this Article, he or she shall have the right
to appeal from the decision of the Village Administrator to the Board of
Trustees, who shall have the power to reverse or otherwise modify the decision
of the Village Administrator. Such appeal shall be in writing, addressed to the
President and Board of Trustees setting forth in detail the grounds of such
appeal. An appeal must be sought no later than thirty (30) days after the date
of the contested action. (Ord. 2021-2, 2-8-2021; amd. Ord. 2022-1, 1-10-2022)
5-9D-3: ADVISORY REVIEW OF INITIAL APPLICATIONS:
Prior to reaching a decision upon an initial application for an accessory
animal license, the Village Administrator shall solicit the review and
recommendation of an advisory body of the Village as to whether the application
should be approved or disapproved and as to what, if any, protective conditions
should be imposed upon the license. The recommendation shall occur after a
public meeting held before the advisory body, only after the Village provides
notice to adjoining property owners and residents via first class mail at least
two (2) weeks in advance of the meeting. In reviewing the application and the
proposed license, among other factors, the advisory body shall give due
consideration to:
A.   General Standard: The extent that the application demonstrates the
applicant will provide adequately for the health, shelter, food, water, yard
conditions of the licensed animals.
B.   Compliance with the Regulations: The extent that the application
demonstrates that the applicant and the proposed activity will comply with all
standards provided in this Article.
C.   Lot Size and Situation: The shape, size, and location of the lot,
principal structure, and animal-keeping area; and the extent that these
conditions tend to mitigate or exaggerate the potential that an adjoining
property owner or others may be negatively affected by the proposed animal-
keeping.
D.   Prior Violations: If the applicant has been the subject of any valid
complaint documenting any violation of a nuisance, property maintenance or
animal control regulation contained in this Code.
E.   Experience or Training: The applicant's training, education, or prior
experience in keeping the subject type of animal.
F.   Unique Health Circumstances: If residents of adjoining or nearby property
present evidence that they suffer from a health condition whereby the proposed
animals may pose a unique risk to their health.
G.   Public Testimony: Testimony and other evidence received from the public
during the advisory body's consideration of the application, to the extent that
such testimony concerns the specific circumstances of the application and not
the general propriety of the proposed activity. (Ord. 2021-2, 2-8-2021)
5-9D-4: INSPECTIONS:
A.   Initial Inspection: An on-site inspection shall be performed prior to
first issuance of an accessory animal license, and from time to time as
described herein. The applicant or licensee shall permit such inspection at
reasonable times and upon reasonable notice. Said consent to inspect is a
condition of any accessory animal license, and refusal shall be cause for
rejection of an application or revocation of an accessory animal license.
B.   Additional Inspections: The Village Administrator may perform an
inspection of the property of an applicant or licensee for any of the following
reasons:
1.   The Village Administrator or his or her designee requires an inspection as
a condition of renewal of an accessory animal license;
2.   The applicant or licensee has received a citation for violation of any
provision of this Code related to animal-keeping within the preceding twelve
(12) months; or,
3.   The Village has probable cause to believe a violation of this Code related
to the licensed activity exists.
C.   Inspection Criteria: The inspection shall verify that the applicant or
licensee provides adequate shelter, food, water, yard condition, yard security,
and other necessary conditions to preserve the health of the animals; and
otherwise complies with the requirements of this Article. If any deficiency of
these conditions is found, the applicant or licensee must correct such
violation within such period of time as the Village shall direct. (Ord. 2021-2,
2-8-2021)
5-9D-5: CHICKEN-SPECIFIC REGULATIONS:
In addition to any other requirement of this Article, the following conditions
shall apply to the keeping of chickens authorized by an accessory animal
license:
A.   Limit Upon Number: No fewer than two (2) adult chickens, and no more than
six (6), adult chickens may be kept on the property of a licensee at any one
time.
B.   Female Chickens: Only female chickens may be owned or maintained on a
licensee's property.
C.   Sale of Eggs Prohibited: The licensee shall not sell eggs produced upon
the property.
D.   Slaughtering: No slaughtering of chickens shall occur in public view.
E.   Chicken Enclosure:
1.   Chickens shall be kept in a pen, coop, run, or chicken tractor.
2.   No chicken enclosure shall be erected or maintained within ten (10') feet
of any occupied residence other than that of the licensee.
3.   Chicken enclosures shall only be erected or maintained in the rear yard
and behind the principal structure on the licensee's lot; except that the
advisory body reviewing an application may, for good cause shown, allow
enclosures to be sited at an alternative location on a lot that provides a
similar level of visual screening, security, and privacy. No special notice or
procedure is required to grant this exception.
4.   Chicken enclosures shall provide at least four (4) square feet of area for
each chicken housed.
5.   Chicken enclosures must be maintained in a sound and useable condition.
6.   Chicken enclosures must be constructed of sturdy and weather-resistant
materials, such as, without limitation: sturdy wire, wood, hardware cloth.
7.   Chicken enclosures shall be resistant to predators. All access doors must
be able to be shut and locked. All opening windows and vents must be covered
with predator-proof wire with less than one (1") inch openings.
F.   Open Space: Chickens shall be provided with adequate open space in the
form of either an enclosed chicken run or a yard fully enclosed by a fence.
G.   Sanitation: The enclosure and open space must be kept clean and sanitary
at all times.
H.   Rodent Protection: All feed and other items associated with the keeping of
chickens shall be protected from or to prevent rats, mice, or other rodents
from gaining access to or coming into contact with the feed.
I.   Nuisances. No licensee shall permit:
1.   Noxious or offensive odors from chicken-keeping, including the odor of
chickens or manure, to be perceptible at or beyond the boundary of the
licensee's property;
2.   Offensive noise from chickens that disturbs the peace at any time; or
3.   Any other public or private nuisance resulting from the licensed activity,
whether by litter, droppings, feathers, waste, or attraction of pests or
rodents.
J.   State Registration. The licensee shall submit a livestock premises
registration form to the Illinois Department of Agriculture, and shall provide
a copy of the submitted form to the Village unless the Department shall stop
accepting residential chicken registrations. (Ord. 2021-2, 2-8-2021)
5-9D-6: BEE-SPECIFIC REGULATIONS:
In addition to any other requirement of this Article, the following conditions
shall apply to beekeeping authorized by an accessory animal license:
A.   Limit Upon Number: No more than three (3) hives may be kept upon a
property.
B.   Hives:
1.   No hive shall be erected or maintained within five (5') feet of any
property line; or within ten (10') feet of any sidewalk, path, or residence.
2.   Hives must have removable combs that can be inspected.
3.   Hives must be maintained in a sound and useable condition.
4.   Hives shall only be erected or maintained in the rear yard and behind the
principal structure on the lot.
C.   Fences and Barriers:
1.   Enclosure: Except where a residential rear yard is fenced, an area no less
than twenty (20') feet by twenty five (25') feet shall be enclosed by fencing
or a hedge with a secure gate.
2.   Flyway Barrier: A flyway barrier shall be maintained at least six (6')
feet in height consisting of a solid wall, fence, dense vegetation or
combination thereof that is parallel to the property line and extends ten (10')
feet beyond the colony in each direction so that all bees are forced to fly at
an elevation of at least six (6') feet above ground level over the property
lines.
3.   A single structure may satisfy both the enclosure and flyway barrier
requirements.
4.   Signage shall be posted on the licensed property warning of the presence
of a bee hive. Such signage shall comply with all other regulations of this
Code.
D.   Water: Each licensee must ensure that a convenient source of water is
available at all times to the bees so that the bees will not congregate at
swimming pools or other water sources where they may cause human, bird, or
domestic pet contact. The water shall be maintained so as not to become
stagnant.
E.   Queens: In any instance in which a colony exhibits unusually aggressive
characteristics by stinging or attempting to sting without due provocation, or
exhibits an unusual disposition towards swarming, the colony shall be re-
queened. Queens must be selected from stock bred for gentleness and non-
swarming characteristics.
F.   State Registration: The licensee shall submit a colony registration form
to the Illinois Department of Agriculture, and shall provide a copy of the
submitted form to the Village unless the Department shall stop accepting
residential hive registrations. (Ord. 2021-2, 2-8-2021)
5-9D-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Article shall be fined not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than the maximum provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which the violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2021-2, 2-8- 2021)
TITLE 6
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1
TRAFFIC CODE; GENERAL PROVISIONS; ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
6-1-1: Illinois Vehicle Code Adopted
6-1-2: Riding On Certain Vehicles Or Parts Of Vehicles
6-1-3: Snow Emergency; One-Way Traffic
6-1-4: Violations; Penalties
6-1-1: ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED:
Except insofar as the application thereof is clearly impractical or
inappropriate, in view of the context of purposes or penalty as provided, all
of the definitions, requirements, regulations, prohibitions, provisions and
sections of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100
et seq., as amended, are hereby adopted by the village. Any and all violations
thereof shall be considered violations of this title, and each such violation
shall subject the violator thereof to penalty provisions under this title if
proceeded hereunder. (2009 Code)
6-1-2: RIDING ON CERTAIN VEHICLES OR PARTS OF VEHICLES:
A.   Bicycles, Toy Vehicles, Skates:
1.   Bicycles, Motorcycles, Toy Vehicles: It shall be unlawful for any person
riding a bicycle, motorcycle or any toy vehicle on any street, to cling to or
to attach himself or his vehicle to any moving motor vehicle or wagon. (1970
Code § 25.29)
2.   Skates, Coasters: It shall be unlawful for any person upon skates,
rollerblades, skateboards 1 , line skates, a coaster, sled or other toy vehicle
to go upon any roadway other than at a crosswalk. (1970 Code § 25.30; amd. 2009
Code)
B.   Riding On Fenders, Running Boards: It shall be unlawful for any person to
ride upon the fenders, running board or outside step of any vehicle. (1970 Code
§ 25.31)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 7-1-17G of this code.
6-1-3: SNOW EMERGENCY; ONE-WAY TRAFFIC:
A.   Authority To Restrict Usage:
1.   Village President: Whenever deemed necessary, due to an accumulation of
snow upon any street or roadway within the village, the village president, or
in his absence, the president pro tem, shall be empowered to restrict usage
thereof to one-way vehicular traffic. (Ord. 79-1, 1-29-1979)
2.   Absence Of Village President: The member of the board of trustees with the
greatest seniority on the board of trustees, who is present in the area and
able to act, is hereby empowered and authorized to act as the president pro tem
for the purposes of this section, during the period of absence of the village
president, or during the period of his inability to act. (Res. 79-3, 2-13-1979)
B.   Time Period: Such restrictions shall continue until two-way traffic can be
reestablished, but in no event shall it exceed twenty one (21) days unless
approved by the board of trustees.
C.   Posting Signs: The village administrator shall, upon direction by the
village president or the president pro tem, cause the posting of emergency
traffic guidance signs on such streets and roadways as deemed necessary during
the period of such declaration of emergency.
D.   Noncompliance A Violation: It shall be a violation of this section for any
owner or operator of a vehicle to operate or permit the operation of any such
vehicle upon any such street or roadway during such period of emergency,
contrary to the posted traffic guidance signs. (Ord. 79-1, 1-29-1979)
6-1-4: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A.   Police Authority To Enforce: It shall be the duty of the chief of police
and the police officers of the village to patrol the streets in the village and
to make arrests for violations of the provisions of this title. (1970 Code §
25.54)
B.   Penalties And Fines Imposed:
1.   Misdemeanor Violation: It is a misdemeanor for any person to violate any
of the provisions of this title unless such violation is by any other act or
law of this state declared to be a felony.
2.   Misdemeanor Penalty:
a.   Penalty: Every person found guilty of a misdemeanor for a violation of any
of the provisions of this title for which another penalty is not provided shall
be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than the
maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (1970 Code § 25.55; amd. 2009 Code)
b.   Remittance Of Fines; Failure To Pay: Fines shall be remitted in the amount
of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for any such offense. Upon the failure of the
violator to pay said fine within five (5) village business days, a second
notice may be sent no earlier than ten (10) days after the first notification
of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall
be in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). Upon failure of the violator to pay
said fine after a second notice within twenty (20) days thereafter, a final
notice may be sent, no earlier than thirty (30) days after the second notice of
violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be
in the amount of seventy five dollars ($75.00). Nothing contained herein shall
be deemed to require giving of any additional notice after the first
notification is made. The transmittal of a notice by registered or certified
mail shall be deemed sufficient notice, if mailed to the last known address of
the violator, and notice shall be deemed to have been accomplished even if
there is a failure or refusal of the individual to whom the notice is sent to
receipt or accept the same. All fines paid pursuant to the provisions contained
herein shall be accompanied by a signed plea of guilty, and a waiver of
hearing. (Ord. 96-21, 8-26-1996)
c.   Suspension Of Driving Privileges: In addition to any fines or penalties
herein provided for the violation of provisions of this title, any court of
record may, upon conviction therefor in such court, enter an order prohibiting
such person so convicted from driving a motor vehicle in this state for a
period not exceeding one year. A violation of such order shall constitute a
contempt of court and may be punished accordingly. (1970 Code § 25.55)
d.   Excess Load Limits; Fine Pursuant To Statute: Any person violating any of
the load limit provisions of section
6-7-5 of this title shall be fined in the amount as set forth in the provisions
of the Illinois motor vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes, in effect
from time to time for the excess load limits, but not to exceed the amount
otherwise permitted by the statutes of the state for violations of municipal
ordinances. (Ord. 78-18, 7-24-1978)
C.   Disposition Of Fines And Penalties; Duties Of Officials:
1.   Fines and penalties recovered under the provisions of this title shall be
paid over to the village treasurer.
2.   Failure, refusal, or neglect on the part of any judicial or other officer
or employee receiving or having custody of any such fine or forfeiture to
account for or pay over any such fine or forfeiture to the village treasurer
shall constitute misconduct in office and shall be grounds for removal
therefrom. (1970 Code § 25.56)
D.   Liability Of Owner Or Operator: It is unlawful for the owner or any other
person employing or otherwise directing the driver of any vehicle to require or
knowingly to permit the operation of such vehicle upon a street of the village
in any manner contrary to this title. (1970 Code § 25.57)
CHAPTER 2
VEHICLE LICENSES
SECTION:
6-2-1: License Required; Liability Of Vehicle Owner Or Lessee
6-2-2: Application For License; Issuance
6-2-3: License Term And Fees
6-2-4: Stickers Required
6-2-5: Penalty
6-2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; LIABILITY OF VEHICLE OWNER OR LESSEE:
A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person residing within the
village to use or cause or permit any of its agents or employees to use any
wagon or motor vehicle upon the streets, avenues or alleys of the village
unless such wagon or vehicle be licensed as hereinafter provided. (1970 Code §
26.01)
B.   Owner Or Lessee Liable: The housing, garaging or otherwise keeping of any
wagon or motor vehicle in the village, or its usage primarily in the village,
shall subject the owner of said vehicle to the provisions of this title. The
registration of a wagon or motor vehicle with the state of Illinois with an
address in the village shall be prima facie evidence of the usage, keeping,
housing or garaging of said wagon or motor vehicle in the village. The
provisions of this chapter shall apply to both the owner of a wagon or motor
vehicle and the lessee thereof, and its registration to a leasing company or
lessor outside of the corporate limits of the village shall not relieve the
owner or lessee for responsibility of registration thereof.
C.   Exceptions:
1.   Taxing Agencies. All vehicles owned or operated by entities which levy
taxes are exempt from the provisions of this Chapter.
2.   New Residents. Starting on the day they establish residence, a new Village
resident has 30 days to obtain a license for any vehicles they own or lease
before being in violation of any Section of this Chapter.
3.   Vehicle Purchases. Starting on the day of sale or lease, the purchaser or
lessee of a vehicle has 30 days to obtain a license before being in violation
of any Section of this Chapter. (Ord. 75-20, 12-9-1975; amd. Ord. 2022-19, 5-
23-2022)
6-2-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE:
A.   Application: Any person desiring a license for any such wagon or vehicle
shall file an application with the village clerk upon a form to be provided by
him, setting forth the following:
1.   The name and address of the applicant;
2.   A description of the wagon or vehicle for which the license is desired;
3.   The place where such wagon, or vehicle for which the license is desired,
is usually kept when not in use and the place where such animal or animals
drawing such wagon or vehicle is or are to be kept;
4.   The number and kinds of other wagons or vehicles kept by said applicant at
such place;
5.   In case the application is made for a license for a motor vehicle, whether
or not such motor vehicle is used or is to be used for pleasure; and
6.   Such other information as may be prescribed.
B.   Issuance Of License: Upon the payment by the applicant of the license fee
hereinafter provided to the village clerk, the village clerk shall issue or
cause to be issued a license authorizing the use of such wagons or vehicles
within the village until the expiration of such license. (1970 Code § 26.02)
6-2-3: LICENSE TERM AND FEES:
A.   Term Of License: Commencing April 1, 1984, the annual license period for
all motor vehicles, trucks, motorcycles and motorized bicycles, tricycles and
vehicles of every other nature and description shall be for the period
beginning on April 1 of each year and ending on March 31 of the following year.
B.   Fees Imposed: The license fee, as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code,
under the category "license fees", to be paid annually to the village clerk,
shall be for the following:
      Motor vehicles other than those that fall within the categories listed
below.
      Each vehicle registered in the name of the person for persons sixty five
(65) years of age or older.
      Electric vehicles bearing an Illinois “EL” license plate shall be a
separate category of license until May 1, 2025.
      Trucks.
      Motorcycles, motorized bicycles, or motorized tricycles and other
motorized vehicles. (amd. 2009 Code)
C.   Prorate Fee: If an owner or operator comes into possession of any such
vehicle after the expiration of six (6) months of the license period, he shall
pay one-half (1/2) of the annual fee.
   D.   Reduced Fee For College Students: Notwithstanding anything contained in
this chapter to the contrary, whenever any such vehicle is located outside the
village, for over six (6) months of any year, and used by a college or
university student at such college or university, a reduced fee equal to one-
half (½) of the license fee set forth herein shall be paid for a vehicle
sticker for such automobile, subject to the following terms and restrictions:
1.   The reduced fee is applicable to one vehicle only, per student, and shall
be available only for that year or years of enrollment as a full time college
or university student.
2.   Applications must be accompanied by proof of registration in a full time
curriculum in a college or university located outside the village, and
certified by such institution.
E.   Failure To Pay Fee:
1.   Notification Of Violation; Payment Of Fine: Any person violating any of
the provisions of this section, who complies with the provisions of this
section before prosecution therefor, may pay a fine without prosecution by
mailing or delivery of the fine by check, money order, or currency to the
department of police of the village. The fine shall be five dollars ($5.00) if
paid within five (5) days after receipt of the notification of the violation.
Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine within five (5) days, a
second notice may be sent, no earlier than ten (10) days after the first
notification of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same
manner, but shall be in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00), provided said fine
is paid within ten (10) days after the date of the second notice of violation.
Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine after a second notice within
ten (10) days thereafter, a final notice may be sent, no earlier than twelve
(12) days after the second notice of violation, and the fine therefor may be
paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00),
provided the same is paid within ten (10) days after the date of any such
notice. Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to require the giving of any
additional notice after the first notification is made. The transmittal of a
notice by registered or certified mail shall be deemed sufficient notice if
mailed to the last known address of the violator, and notice shall be deemed to
have been accomplished even if there is a failure or refusal of the individual
to whom the notice is sent to receipt or accept the same. All fines paid
pursuant to the provisions contained herein shall be accompanied by a signed
plea of guilty and a waiver of hearing, an application for license accompanied
by the required fee therefor, and the penalty described in subsection E2 of
this section.
2.   Penalty Added To Annual Fee: A penalty of fifty percent (50%) will be
added to the annual license fee of the above described vehicles and trucks
unless payment therefor is made on or before May 1 of the year for which such
license is required.
F.   Sale Of Vehicle; License Transfer Fee: When any such motor vehicle, truck,
motorcycle, motor bicycle or motor tricycle, or other motorized vehicle is
sold, any valid existing and outstanding vehicle sticker issued therefor shall
be automatically revoked. The new owner of such vehicle, if subject to
licensing by the village, shall make application for a vehicle license in
accordance with the provisions of this section. If such motor vehicle is traded
in or otherwise exchanged by the owner thereof, for a new or used vehicle of
the same category, upon application for a vehicle license, a new license shall
be issued to such owner for the remainder of the unexpired term of the existing
license at a charge as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees", for transfer of such
vehicle license. (amd. 2009 Code) (Ord., 12-12-1978; amd. Ord. 82-13, 10-25-
1982; Ord. 88-2, 2-8-1988; Ord. 97-9, 4-24-1997; Ord. 2020-7, 4-27-2020)
6-2-4: STICKERS REQUIRED:
A.   Issuance Of Sticker; Display Required: Upon the issuance of said license,
the village clerk shall deliver to the applicant a sticker bearing the name of
the village and the number and name of the class to which said wagon or vehicle
belongs and the year for which said license is issued; and it shall be the duty
of such applicant to affix such sticker in a conspicuous place upon the front
of such wagon or vehicle or upon the right side of a horsedrawn wagon or
vehicle, or if such vehicle be an automobile of any kind, then such sticker
shall be placed upon the lower right hand side of the windshield as near to the
base of the same as possible; and it shall be unlawful for any person to use or
cause or permit any agent or employee to use any such wagon or vehicle,
although duly licensed, upon the streets, alleys or avenues of the village
unless such sticker is affixed as above provided. Village vehicle plates issued
for motorcycles or motor driven cycles shall be affixed to the rear license
plate on the lower right hand side thereof in such a manner as not to obstruct
the state of Illinois license plate. (1970 Code § 26.04; amd. Ord., 10-9-1973)
B.   Failure To Display Sticker: Any person who violates this section by
failure to display a necessary vehicle sticker, or who violates any of the
provisions of this chapter, and who obtains the necessary license for his motor
vehicle, may pay a fine without prosecution by mailing or delivery of the sum
of twenty five dollars ($25.00) by check, money order or currency to the
department of police of the village. Such remittance must be accompanied by a
signed plea of guilty and waiver of hearing, and must be made within five (5)
village business days after receipt of notice of the violation, or after such
notice is placed on the vehicle. (Ord. 96-21, 8-26-1996)
6-2-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
less than the amount set out in section
1-12-3 of this code nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each and every offense, and each day any wagon or
vehicle is used upon the streets, alleys or avenues of the village without
having procured a license and without having complied with the provisions of
this chapter shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. 96-21,
8-26-1996; amd. 2009 Code; Ord. 2014-9, 4-28-2014)
CHAPTER 3
BICYCLES
SECTION:
6-3-1: Purpose
6-3-2: License Required
6-3-3: Application For License; Conditions For Issuance; Fee
6-3-4: Term Of License
6-3-5: Transfer Registration And Plate; Fee
6-3-6: Report Loss Of License Plate; Duplicate License Fee
6-3-7: Disposition Of Revenues
6-3-8: Operating Regulations And Restrictions
6-3-9: Rental Agencies
6-3-10: Inspection Of Bicycles
6-3-11: Removal Of Serial Number Or License Plate
6-3-12: Use Of Bicycle Without Consent Of Owner
6-3-13: Acquiring Bicycle With Missing Serial Number
6-3-14: Bicycle Dealers Report To Police Chief
6-3-15: Enforcement; License Revocation Or Suspension
6-3-16: Penalty
6-3-1: PURPOSE:
For the purpose of promoting public welfare and safety, and for the prevention
of theft of bicycles, the regulations and restrictions hereinafter set forth
are hereby enacted governing the ownership and operation of bicycles in the
village. (1970 Code § 27.01)
6-3-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
From and after the effective date hereof, no person shall operate upon any
public street, alley or sidewalk within the village, any bicycle owned by a
resident of the village unless:
A.   The ownership of the bicycle has been registered as hereinafter provided.
B.   A license for the operation of the bicycle has been obtained as
hereinafter provided.
C.   The license plate is attached to the bicycle as hereinafter provided.
D.   The mechanical condition of the bicycle is such that it can be safely
operated.
E.   The bicycle is equipped as hereinafter provided. (1970 Code § 27.02)
6-3-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; CONDITIONS FOR ISSUANCE; FEE:
A.   Application:
1.   Application for registration and license for each bicycle shall be made by
the owner in writing, in duplicate, upon blank forms furnished by the village
clerk.
2.   Such application shall be signed by the owner, and if the owner is a
person under eighteen (18) years of age, the signature shall be witnessed by a
parent of the owner, or if no parent is living, then by the legal guardian of
the owner. The application shall state the full name and address of the owner
of the bicycle, the name of the manufacturer, the serial number of the frame
thereof, the approximate date when the owner obtained title thereto, and if not
new when obtained, the name and address of the person from whom it was
obtained.
B.   Examination Of Bicycle:
1.   Such application shall be presented to the chief of police at the police
station of the village. The bicycle to be registered and licensed shall be
brought to the police station at the time of presenting the application for the
purpose of examination by the chief of police.
2.   The chief of police shall examine the bicycle, and if he finds the
mechanical condition thereof such that it can be safely operated, and that it
is equipped with reflectors as herein provided, and further finds that the
statements made in the application are true, he shall mark the application and
duplicate "approved", attach his signature, and return the same to the
applicant. (1970 Code § 27.03)
C.   Filing Application; Fee: The applicant shall thereupon file the
application with the village clerk and pay to the clerk a license fee as set
out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees". (Ord., 10-27-1975; amd.
2009 Code)
D.   Issuance Of License: The village clerk shall, upon receiving such
application and license fee, issue to the owner of the bicycle a registration
card which shall contain the name and address of the owner and the description
of the bicycle contained in the application. The applicant shall affix his
signature to the registration card when issued in the presence of the village
clerk; said clerk shall, with said certificate, also issue to the owner a
license plate which shall contain the words "Lake Bluff Bicycle License", and
the number of the license. The registration card and the license plate shall
have the same number. The license plate shall be attached to the bicycle on the
front thereof immediately below the steering bar or wheel.
E.   Endorsement; Keep On File: After the issuance of the registration card and
license plate, the village clerk shall endorse upon the application and
duplicate the date of the issuance and the number thereof. The original
application shall be kept on file in the office of the village clerk, and the
duplicate thereof shall be delivered to the chief of police, which shall be
kept on file in his office. (1970 Code § 27.03)
6-3-4: TERM OF LICENSE:
The license so issued shall be effective so long as the applicant shall
continue to be the owner of the bicycle. (1970 Code § 27.04)
6-3-5: TRANSFER REGISTRATION AND PLATE; FEE:
When any bicycle which has been registered and licensed, as herein provided, is
sold, or is otherwise disposed of or destroyed, the licensee shall immediately
surrender to the chief of police the registration card and the license plate
issued therefor, with the name and address of the new owner, if any, written on
the back of the registration card, and the chief of police shall immediately
make proper endorsement thereof on his records, and thereupon deliver the card
and plate to the village clerk, who shall immediately make proper endorsements
on his records and retain the card and plate. Upon the sale or other transfer
of a licensed bicycle, the licensee may, upon proper application, have the said
plate assigned to another bicycle owned by the applicant and shall pay to the
village clerk a transfer fee in the amount as set out in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees". (1970 Code § 27.05;
amd. Ord., 10-27-1975; 2009 Code)
6-3-6: REPORT LOSS OF LICENSE PLATE; DUPLICATE LICENSE FEE:
A.   Issue Duplicate License; Fee: The licensee shall report immediately to the
chief of police the loss or destruction of the license plate of the licensee,
and the circumstances surrounding the loss or destruction thereof. With the
approval of the chief of police, the village clerk shall issue a duplicate
license upon payment to the village clerk by the licensee of a fee as set out
in section
1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees". (1970 Code § 27.06;
amd. Ord., 10-27-1975; 2009 Code)
B.   Denial Of Duplicate License Plate: If the chief of police shall not
approve the issuance of a duplicate license plate, the licensee shall be
required to make a new application for registration and license, and attach to
such application the existing registration card or satisfactory account for the
inability to do so. (1970 Code § 27.06)
6-3-7: DISPOSITION OF REVENUES:
The village clerk shall pay over to the village treasurer the license fees
received. The fees shall be used for the purpose of improving, paving,
repairing or maintaining the streets and other public roadways within the
village; provided, that the actual cost in connection with the issuance of such
licenses and the collection of the fees may be deducted from the total amount
collected as provided by statute. (1970 Code § 27.17)
6-3-8: OPERATING REGULATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
Every person operating a bicycle upon any street, alley or sidewalk in the
village shall obey strictly the following regulations and restrictions
pertaining thereto:
A.   Riding In Double Or Single File: When more than two (2) persons in a group
are operating bicycles on a roadway, they shall ride in double file or in
single file.
B.   Clinging To Vehicles: No person operating a bicycle shall cling to or
attach himself or herself or the bicycle to any other moving vehicle.
C.   Emerging From Alleys, Driveways And Garages: The operator of a bicycle
emerging from an alley, driveway, garage or private sidewalk shall stop the
bicycle immediately prior to driving onto or across a public sidewalk, or onto
or across a public sidewalk line projected across an alley, and shall exercise
extreme care in these cases.
D.   Extra Passenger: No person operating a bicycle shall carry another person
on the same bicycle. This restriction shall not apply to tandem bicycles which
are built for two (2) riders.
E.   Intoxication; Drug Use; Physical Inability: No person shall operate a
bicycle while under the influence of liquor or drugs or while physically or
mentally unfit to safely operate the same. (1970 Code § 27.07)
F.   Lights And Reflectors: No bicycle shall be operated between the hours of
sunset and sunrise without having securely attached one white lamp on the
front, and a red reflector on the rear thereof, each of which shall be not less
than one inch (1") in diameter. Such lighted lamp and reflector shall be
clearly visible under normal atmospheric conditions for a distance of at least
two hundred feet (200') ahead and to the rear respectively. No other lights
shall be used on a bicycle; except, that a red light similarly visible may be
substituted for a red reflector on the rear of any bicycle. The above mentioned
white front headlamp, and red rear lamp when provided, shall be lit and
illuminated at all times when riding between the hours of sunset and sunrise.
(Ord., 1-12-1971)
G.   Mechanical Condition: No person shall operate a bicycle which is not in
such mechanical condition that the same can be safely operated.
H.   Operating On Sidewalks: Bicycles may be operated on sidewalks in public
parks and in the residence district, but in single file only. Under all
circumstances, the rider shall yield the right of way to pedestrians using the
sidewalk, and due and proper care shall at all times be exercised by the rider
for the pedestrians. When approaching a pedestrian on the sidewalk, the speed
of the bicycle shall be reduced to a speed which is no greater than necessary
to continue the operation of the bicycle without the rider dismounting, and
shall not be increased until the pedestrian has been passed.
I.   Parking Bicycles: Bicycles, when parked in the business district, shall be
parked in zones, parking racks, or other places officially designated for that
purpose. Bicycles shall not, at any time, in any place, be indiscriminately
parked by anyone along buildings in such a manner as to interfere with
pedestrians, or along roadways where they may interfere with traffic, or with
persons getting into or out of motor vehicles. No person shall move or in any
manner interfere with any bicycle properly parked, nor shall any person
interfere or in any manner hinder any person from properly parking a bicycle;
except, that a member of the police department or fire department may move, or
in proper cases prevent the parking of the bicycle, when, in the judgment of
the police officer or firefighter, his action is necessary in order to properly
safeguard persons or property.
J.   Keeping To Right: All bicycles, when operated on roadways, shall be kept
to the right and shall be operated as near as practicable to the right hand
edge of the roadway.
K.   Signaling Device: Each bicycle shall be equipped with a signaling device,
in good working order and audible at a distance of fifty feet (50') when
sounded.
L.   Speed: No bicycle shall be operated at any time faster than is reasonable
or proper, and every bicycle shall be operated with reasonable regard to the
safety of the rider and of other persons and property.
M.   Traffic Regulations: Every person operating a bicycle shall strictly
observe all traffic signs and signals and all other traffic rules and
regulations applicable thereto, and shall obey the orders and directions of
every officer of the village authorized to direct or regulate traffic.
N.   Trick Riding: No person shall operate a bicycle in any manner except
through the use of both hands upon the handlebar thereof or otherwise to
indulge in any kind of trick or unsafe riding.
O.   Method Of Turning; Signals: The operator of a bicycle on a roadway, when
making a right turn, shall follow the right hand edge of the roadway, and the
operator of a bicycle on a roadway when making a left turn, shall approach the
point of turning in the traffic lane nearest the center of the roadway and
shall not cut the left hand corner. No operator of a bicycle shall suddenly
start, slow down, stop or attempt to turn without first giving the standard
signal required by state law for the operation of motor vehicles under the same
circumstances.
P.   Following Firetruck; Operation Near Fires: No person operating a bicycle
within the village shall follow or attempt to follow any firetruck, nor shall
any person operate a bicycle within one block of a fire which is being
extinguished by the fire department.
Q.   Compliance With State Traffic Laws: Every person operating a bicycle upon
a roadway shall be subject to the provisions of the act of the legislature of
the state of Illinois, entitled "an act in relation to the regulation of
traffic", approved July 9, 1939, and all amendments thereto 1 , insofar as the
provisions of said act by their nature can have application to the operation of
a bicycle, except as otherwise provided herein.
R.   The riding of bicycles shall be prohibited on the following roadways in
the Village:
1.   Sheridan Road throughout the Village;
2.   West Scranton Avenue from Sheridan Road west to Waukegan Road;
3.   Green Bay Road from Signe Court south to the Village’s southern limit.
(1970 Code § 27.07; amd. Ord. 98-3, 1-26-1998)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS.
6-3-9: RENTAL AGENCIES:
Bicycles offered for rent by a rental agency shall be equipped by the rental
agency as required by this chapter and shall be kept in good and safe working
condition. Rental agencies shall comply, in all respects, with the provisions
of this chapter and shall be responsible for the condition of the bicycles they
rent. The chief of police shall make periodical inspections of rental agencies
to ascertain that they are complying with the provisions of this chapter. (1970
Code § 27.08)
6-3-10: INSPECTION OF BICYCLES:
Each member of the police department is hereby authorized to inspect any
bicycle, at any reasonable time, for the purpose of making a checkup of the
license plate, license number, and serial number for the purpose of determining
the mechanical condition of the bicycle. No person shall in any manner
interfere with or hinder the making of such inspection. (1970 Code § 27.09)
6-3-11: REMOVAL OF SERIAL NUMBER OR LICENSE PLATE:
It shall be unlawful for any person wilfully or maliciously to remove, destroy,
mutilate, or alter the serial number of any bicycle licensed pursuant to this
chapter or to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any license plate or
registration card during the time in which the license plate or registration
card is in force. The chief of police is hereby authorized to stamp numbers on
the frame of a bicycle in a distinguishable manner, for identification
purposes, upon which no serial number can be found, or upon which the serial
number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. (1970 Code §
27.10)
6-3-12: USE OF BICYCLE WITHOUT CONSENT OF OWNER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate any bicycle within the
village without the consent of the owner. (1970 Code § 27.11)
6-3-13: ACQUIRING BICYCLE WITH MISSING SERIAL NUMBER:
It shall be unlawful for any person residing in the village, or any dealer in
bicycles operating in the village, to purchase, receive in trade, or otherwise
acquire any bicycle from which the serial number on the frame has been removed,
destroyed, mutilated or altered, without first reporting the same to the chief
of police. (1970 Code § 27.12)
6-3-14: BICYCLE DEALERS REPORT TO POLICE CHIEF:
Every person engaged in the business of selling, buying or trading new or used
bicycles within the village is hereby required to make a written report to the
chief of police, at the end of each month, or more often if requested by said
chief of police; such report shall contain the following information:
A.   The name and address of all persons to whom and from whom a bicycle was
sold, purchased or traded during the period covered by the report, not
including, however, purchase of new bicycles from regularly established jobbers
or wholesalers.
B.   A description of the bicycle involved in each such transaction consisting
of the name of the manufacturer, the serial number on the frame, and the
license number of the bicycle, if the bicycle has been registered and a license
issued to the owner by the village.
C.   Such additional information as the chief of police may require. (1970 Code
§ 27.13)
6-3-15: ENFORCEMENT; LICENSE REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
The chief of police is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce the
provisions of this chapter. The chief of police is hereby authorized and
empowered to suspend, for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or to revoke
any license issued under the provisions of this chapter for the violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter and to impound for a period of not to
exceed thirty (30) days any unregistered or improperly registered bicycle, or
the bicycle of any person with which a violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter has been committed. The action of the chief of police in
suspending or revoking any license or revoking or impounding any bicycle, as
provided in this section, shall be conclusive and final. The suspension or
revocation of a license or the impounding of a bicycle shall not preclude the
prosecution of the offender for the violation of this chapter and the
infliction of any other penalty provided herein. (1970 Code § 27.14)
6-3-16: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be, upon
conviction, punished by a fine of not more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each and every offense. (1970 Code § 27.15; amd. 2009
Code)
CHAPTER 4
PARKING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
6-4-1: Displaying Vehicle Or Merchandise For Sale
6-4-2: Parking For Persons With Disabilities
6-4-3: Lake Bluff Train Station Parking Lot
6-4-4: Mawman Avenue Resident Parking Lot
6-4-5: General Parking Lot Regulations; Penalty
6-4-6: Temporary Parking Regulations
6-4-1: DISPLAYING VEHICLE OR MERCHANDISE FOR SALE:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of
displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business street from
which vehicle merchandise is peddled. (1970 Code § 25.49)
6-4-2: PARKING FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES:
A.   Parking Prohibited: It is unlawful to park any motor vehicle which is not
bearing registration plates or decals issued pursuant to the Illinois motor
vehicle code to a handicapped person, as defined in the Illinois motor vehicle
code, in any parking place, including any private or public off street parking
facility specifically reserved for handicapped or disabled persons by the
posting of an official sign. (Ord. 87-28, 8-10-1987; amd. 2009 Code)
B.   Penalty: Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of subsection
A of this section shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) in addition to
any costs or charges connected with the removal or storage of any such motor
vehicle. The fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) may be paid without
prosecution in accordance with the provisions of subsection
6-1-4B of this title, as amended; except, that the amount of the fine shall be
one hundred dollars ($100.00), and no notices need be sent for failure to pay
such fine before action is taken for further prosecution. (Ord. 96-21, 8-26-
1996)
6-4-3: LAKE BLUFF TRAIN STATION PARKING LOT:
A.   Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle
within the Train Station Parking Lot, being the public parking lot adjacent to
the Lake Bluff Train Station located at 600 Sheridan Road, except as provided
herein.
B.   Classes of Permits Established. The following classifications of parking
permits for the Train Station parking lot are hereby established. The fee
payable to obtain each permit shall be as set out in Section
1-12-3, under the category "Permit Fees," and shall be paid in advance of
parking.
   1.   Daytime Parking Permit. A daytime parking permit may be issued on an
annual or daily basis.
   2.   Overnight Parking Permit. An overnight parking permit may be issued on
an annual or daily basis.
   3.   Central Business District (CBD) Merchant Parking Permit. A CBD merchant
parking permit may be issued on an annual basis to the owner, operator, or
employee of any business with physical offices or operations within the
Village's Central Business District as defined by the Village's Zoning Map. A
CBD merchant parking permit may be lawfully displayed and used by any owner,
operator, or employee of the same business, provided that the Village
Administrator or their designee has first been given and accepted notice of
each person and vehicle utilizing the permit in a form determined by the
Village Administrator.
C.   Central Business District (CBD) Merchant Parking Spaces. All spaces
designated for "Central Business District merchant parking only" within the
Train Station parking lot may be used for the parking of vehicles as follows:
   1.   Except between the hours of three o'clock (3:00) a.m. and six o'clock
(6:00) a.m. daily, only by the holders of CBD merchant parking permits.
   2.   Between the hours of three o'clock (3:00) a.m. and six o'clock (6:00)
a.m. daily, no parking of any vehicles is permitted.
D.   Overnight Parking Spaces. All spaces designated for "overnight parking
only" within the Train Station parking lot may be used for the parking of
vehicles as follows:
   1.   Between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) a.m. and ten o'clock (10:00)
a.m., Monday through Friday, only by the holders of:
      a.   Daytime parking permits; and
      b.   CBD merchant parking permits.
   2.   Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and three o'clock (3:00) a.m., Monday
through Friday, by any vehicle.
   3.   Between the hours of six o’clock (6:00) a.m. and three o’clock (3:00)
a.m., Saturday and Sunday, by any vehicle.
   4.   Between the hours of three o’clock (3:00) a.m. and six o’clock (6:00)
a.m. every day, only by the holders of overnight parking permits.
E.   All Other Spaces (Daytime Spaces). All parking spaces not otherwise marked
or restricted for specific purposes within the Train Station parking lot may be
used for the parking of vehicles as follows:
   1.   Between the hours of six o’clock (6:00) a.m. and ten o’clock (10:00)
a.m., Monday through Friday, only by the holders of:
      a.   Daytime parking permits; and
      b.   CBD merchant parking permits.
   2.   Between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00) a.m. and three o’clock (3:00)
a.m., Monday through Friday, by any vehicle.
   3.   Between the hours of six o’clock (6:00) a.m. and three o’clock (3:00)
a.m., Saturday and Sunday, by any vehicle.
   4.   Between the hours of three o’clock (3:00) a.m. and six o’clock (6:00)
a.m. every day, no parking of any vehicles is permitted. (amd. 2009 Code) (Ord.
86-2, 2-24-1986, eff. 4-1-1986; amd. Ord. 88-3, 2-8-1988; Ord. 88-11, 3-28-88;
Ord. 96-21, 8-26-1996; Ord. 97-9, 4-24-1997, eff. 5-1-1997; (Ord. 2014-21, 10-
27-2014; Ord. 2015-3, 3-23-2015; Ord. 2020-8, 5-11-2020; Ord. 2022-38, 12-12-
2022; Ord. 2022-35, 11-28-2022)
6-4-4: MAWMAN AVENUE RESIDENT PARKING LOT:
A.   Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle
within the Mawman Avenue Resident Parking Lot, being located generally at the
northeast corner of Scranton Avenue and Mawman Avenue, except the holders of
parking permits in the manner provided herein.
B.   Classes of Permits Established. The following classifications of parking
permits for the Mawman Avenue Resident Parking Lot are hereby established. The
fee payable to obtain each permit shall be as set out in Section
1-12-3, under the category "Permit Fees," and shall be paid in advance of
parking.
   1.   Daytime Parking Permit. A daytime parking permit may be issued on an
annual basis only to residents of the Village for a vehicle bearing a valid
motor vehicle license pursuant to Section
6-2-3. The holder of a daytime parking permit may park in the Mawman Avenue
Resident Parking Lot between the hours of six o’clock (6:00) a.m. and three
o’clock (3:00) a.m. daily.
   2.   Overnight Parking Permit. An overnight parking permit may be issued on
an annual basis only to residents of the Village for a vehicle bearing a valid
motor vehicle license pursuant to Section
6-2-3. The holder of an overnight parking permit may park in the Mawman Avenue
Resident Parking Lot at any time. (amd. 2009 Code) (Ord. 86-3, 2-24-1986, eff.
4-1-1986; Ord. 88-12, 3-28-1988; Ord. 97-9, 4-24-1997, eff. 5-1-1997; Ord.
2014-21, 10-27-2014; Ord. 2020-8, 5-11-2020; Ord. 2022-38, 12-12-2022; Ord.
2022-35, 11-28-2022)
6-4-5:  GENERAL PARKING LOT REGULATIONS; PENALTY:
The following regulations apply to the use of all Village off-street parking
lots, for the parking of motor vehicles including, without limitation, the use
of the Train Station Parking Lot (Section
6-4-3) and the Mawman Avenue Resident Parking Lot (Section
6-4-4).
A.   Parking Holidays. Any parking space that is reserved for a paid permit
established by this Chapter may be utilized without a permit on the following
holidays: January 1 (New Year's Day); the fourth Monday in May (Memorial Day);
July 4 (Independence Day); the first Monday in September (Labor Day); the
fourth Thursday in November (Thanksgiving Day); December 25 (Christmas Day);
and December 31 (New Year's Eve). The holiday shall start at 12:01 a.m. on the
applicable holiday and extend until 2:59 a.m. on the day following the holiday.
B.   Annual Permits.
   1.   Form of Application. An application for an annual parking permit shall
be made in the form and number, and including such information, as determined
by the Village Administrator.
   2.   Expiration of Permits. Every annual permit established herein shall
expire on May 1 annually. Starting on June 1, the initial purchase fee shall be
prorated monthly, such that the fee is reduced by 1/12th on the first day of
each month.
   3.   Location of Annual Permit Sticker. The Village Administrator or his or
her designee shall issue a sticker or decal to the purchaser of an annual
parking permit at the time of purchase. Every effort should be made to affix
the sticker or decal to the lower left hand corner of the front windshield.
Stickers or decals shall not be obstructed from view from the exterior of the
vehicle.
   4.   Transfer. Except as may be provided otherwise, a permit is valid for
only a single vehicle and a single owner. A permit may be transferred to a
different vehicle owned by the same owner upon the owner's sale of the vehicle
for which the permit was issued, but only upon paying the transfer fee set out
in Section
1-12-3, under the category "Permit Fees."
   5.   Refunds. The Village Administrator may issue a partial refund upon
surrender of the sticker or decal. The refund shall be in the amount paid for
the sticker, less a reduction of 1/12th for each month elapsed, in part or in
full, since the purchase date. No refunds shall be given for stickers or decals
on or after February 1 of each year.
C.   Conduct Within Parking Lots.
   1.   Parking Within Designated Parking Space Lines: When the Village shall
cause lines or marks to be placed in any parking area designating individual
parking spaces, it shall be unlawful for any person to park or allow to be
parked or placed any such motor vehicle in such parking area except within the
lines so designated or so as to encroach upon an adjacent designated space.
   2.   "No Parking" Areas. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or
place any motor vehicle in any part of such parking area marked and indicated
by lettering "No Parking" or otherwise prohibited parking.
   3.   Backing Into Parking Spaces. It shall be unlawful for any person to
back into any parking space.
   4.   Following Proper Direction Of Travel: When signs are erected giving
notice thereof, or when lines or markings have been placed upon the pavement or
parking lot surface indicating the direction of travel to be followed, it shall
be unlawful for any person (except when emerging from a marked parking space)
to operate a motor vehicle in any direction other than that indicated by such
lines, markings, or signs, or to disregard the instructions of any such signs
with respect to ingress or egress to such areas, lots, tracts, or parcels of
land.
   5.   Obstructing Pedestrian Areas: It shall be unlawful for any person to
park upon, block or otherwise obstruct for any period of time any pedestrian
areas adjacent to a parking lot or designated for pedestrian access or egress.
   6.   Duty To Lock Vehicles; Nonliability Of Village: It shall be and is
hereby declared to be the duty of any person who shall park or permit the
parking of any motor vehicle in any such parking area to lock and secure the
said motor vehicle for the prevention of theft of the vehicle or its contents,
and the village shall not be liable in the maintenance of such parking area to
any person for loss or damage to any motor vehicle or contents of any motor
vehicle placed in said parking area, nor for the injury to persons or property
arising from the use and maintenance of any such parking area.
   7.   Unattended Vehicles. Notwithstanding any other provision of this
Chapter, and even with a valid permit, it shall be unlawful for a person to
permit a vehicle to remain unmoved for a period of seven days or longer without
the giving of prior notice accepted by the Police Department.
D.   Temporary Parking Regulations. The Village Administrator, upon determining
that temporary parking regulations are necessary to address an emergency or
other special condition or event, is authorized to make and enforce parking
regulations that temporarily supersede the permanent parking regulations in
this chapter. Such temporary traffic regulations may be in effect only during
the period of the emergency or special condition or event, as determined by the
Village Administrator, but in no event longer than ninety (90) days without
approval by resolution of the Village Board of Trustees. The Village
Administrator or his designee must install and maintain appropriate signage at
the locations affected by the temporary traffic regulations advising motorists
of those regulations.
E.   Removal and Impoundment of Vehicles (Towing). The Chief of Police or their
designee is authorized to immediately and without prior notice tow away, or
cause to be towed away, any vehicle in a Village parking lot where the vehicle
meets any of the following conditions:
   1.   The vehicle is in such a state of disrepair that it is incapable of
being driven or constitutes a hazard to the public.
   2.   The vehicle has been unmoved for a period of seven days without the
giving of prior notice accepted by the Police Department.
   3.   The vehicle occupies more than one parking space or is otherwise parked
in a manner that impairs the safety of motorists, bicyclists, pedestrians, or
the use of the parking lot by other patrons.
   4.   The vehicle is unlawfully occupying a space designated for use by
persons with disabilities pursuant to Section
6-4-2.
   5.   The vehicle does not bear valid registration plates, except that
expired or non-renewed registration plates are not cause to tow unless at least
one month has elapsed since the date of expiration.
   6.   The vehicle is subject to impoundment pursuant to any other section of
this Municipal Code or statute.
F.   Violations.
   1.   General Penalty. Any person who violates any of the provisions of this
Chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in an amount of not less than
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each
day that any violation exists or continues shall be deemed a separate offense
for which a separate fine may be levied.
   2.   Prima Facie Responsibility: Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation
of any provision of this Chapter, the person in whose name the vehicle is
registered with the Secretary of State of Illinois shall be prima facie
responsible for the violation and subject to the penalty therefor.
   3.   Additional Revocation of Permit. In addition to any other remedy
provided herein, a person who fails to pay a violation due within five days
after written notice is transmitted by mail or otherwise, the Village
Administrator may, in addition to any other remedy provided herein, revoke all
annual permits held by the violator, and no refunds shall be made therefor.
   4.   Additional Payment of Towing and Storage Fees. Any towing and storage
fees for a vehicle impounded pursuant to this Chapter shall be separate from,
and in addition to, any fine or penalty imposed for the parking violation.
   5.   Payment Of Fine; Notice: Any person violating any of the provisions of
this Chapter, except for parking in a handicapped space, and who removes his or
her vehicle before the same is impounded, may pay a fine, without prosecution,
in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Such remittance must be
accompanied by a signed plea of guilty and waiver of hearing, and be made
within forty-eight (48) hours after receipt of notice of the violation or after
such notice is placed on the vehicle. (Ord. 2022-38, 12-12-2022; amd. Ord.
2022-35, 11-28-2022)
6-4-6: TEMPORARY PARKING REGULATIONS:
The village administrator, upon determining that temporary parking regulations
are necessary to address an emergency or other special condition or event, is
authorized to make and enforce parking regulations that temporarily supersede
the permanent parking regulations in this chapter. Such temporary traffic
regulations may be in effect only during the period of the emergency or special
condition or event, as determined by the village administrator, but in no event
longer than ninety (90) days without approval by resolution of the village
board of trustees. The village administrator or his designee must install and
maintain appropriate signage at the locations affected by the temporary traffic
regulations advising motorists of those regulations. (Ord. 2009-21, 9-14-2009)
CHAPTER 5
TRAFFIC SCHEDULES
SECTION:

6-5-2: Stop Streets

6-5-9: Weight Limits

6-5-11: Yield Right-Of-Way Streets
6-5-12: Use Of Certain Streets By Bicycles And Pedestrians
6-5-1: THROUGH STREETS:
Every driver of a vehicle traversing any street intersecting with any street
designated as a through street shall stop such vehicle before entering upon
such through street unless a go signal is given at such intersection by a
traffic officer or a traffic sign. (1988 Code § 9-4-10)
A.   North Terrace Subdivision Residential Streets: At any time, it shall be
unlawful to utilize Garfield Avenue, West Washington Avenue, Pine Court,
Hancock Avenue, Lincoln Avenue, Rockland Avenue, Mawman Avenue, or Main Street,
or any combination thereof, as through streets to travel from West Scranton
Avenue to Green Bay Road or from Green Bay Road to West Scranton Avenue. (Ord.
97-2, 1-13-1997)
B.   Through Streets Designated: The following streets and parts of streets are
designated as through streets:
      Green Bay Road, except where the same intersects with State Route 176,
throughout its length in the Village.
      Sheridan Road, throughout its length in the Village.
      State Route 176, throughout its length in the Village. (1988 Code § 9-4-
10)

6-5-4: LIMITED PARKING AREAS:
A.   Snow Removal: It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle on any street in the
village between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00)
A.M. after November 15, and before April 1 of each year or after a two inch
(2") snowfall until snow removal is completed. (Ord. 97-34, 12-8-1997)
B.   Time Limit Parking: It shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand in
any of the following places during the times specified, or for a longer period
of time than indicated, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other
traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic
signal:
1.   Fifteen minute parking:
a.   Generally:
East Center Avenue, in the one on street public parking space along and upon
the east side immediately north of and adjacent to the entrance drive directly
south of 38 East Center Avenue from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to five o'clock
(5:00) P.M.
Walnut Avenue, in the three (3) on street public parking spaces along and upon
the west side between East Scranton Avenue and the alley behind 20 East
Scranton Avenue from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) P.M.
b.   Between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M.:
East Scranton Avenue, in the two (2) on street public parking spaces on the
north side immediately west of Walnut Avenue.
      2   Two hour parking:
a.   Generally:
East North Avenue, south side, between the easterly right of way line of
Sheridan Road and forty feet (40') west of the westerly right of way line of
Walnut Avenue.
East North Avenue, south side, between the easterly right of way line of Walnut
Avenue and the westerly right of way line of Evanston Avenue.
East Washington Avenue, south side, between the easterly right of way line of
Sheridan Road and the westerly right of way line of Oak Avenue.
Woodland Avenue, south side, between the easterly right of way line of Sheridan
Road and the westerly right of way line of Oak Avenue.
b.   Between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. (except
for the 15 minute spaces established in subsection B1b of this section):
East Center Avenue, east side, between Oak Avenue and East Scranton Avenue.
East Center Avenue, west side, between Oak Avenue and East Scranton Avenue.
East Scranton Avenue, north and south sides, immediately west of Evanston
Avenue and immediately east of Sheridan Road.
Oak Avenue, in the four (4) on street public parking spaces along and upon the
west side between East Scranton Avenue and the entrance driveway directly south
of 117 East Scranton Avenue.
Walnut Avenue, east side, between East Scranton Avenue and the alley behind 20
East Scranton Avenue. (amd. 2009 Code)
3.   Four hour parking:
a.   Between six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.:
Oak Avenue, in the eight (8) public parking spaces along and upon the west side
between East Center Avenue and the private driveway access to the condominium
units located at 52 - 66 East Center Avenue.
4.   Thirty minute parking:
a.   Generally:
Oak Avenue, in the three (3) on street public parking spaces along and upon the
east side between East Scranton Avenue and the public library entrance drive
directly south of 123 East Scranton Avenue (public library).
5.   Three hour parking:
Walnut Avenue public parking lot located at the southwest corner of North
Avenue and Walnut Avenue. Except between three o’clock (3:00) A.M. and five
o’clock (5:00) A.M. when all parking is prohibited.
C.   Parking East Of Moffett Road: There is no parking on village streets east
of Moffett Road from April 1 to September 30 between the hours of nine o'clock
(9:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Ord. 97-34, 12-8-1997; Ord. 2006-16, 6-
12-2006; Ord. 2008-4, 1-28-2008; Ord. 2009-21, 9-14-2009; Ord. 2010-13, 6-14-
2010; Ord. 2015-3, 3-23-2015; Ord. 2020-8, 5-11-2020)
6-5-5: SPEED LIMITS:
A.   25 m.p.h. Speed Limit Established For Residential Streets. No person shall
drive a vehicle upon any public highway at a speed greater than is reasonable
and proper having regard to the traffic and the use of the way or so as to
endanger the life or limb or injure the property of any person. Unless
otherwise provided in this Chapter, if the rate of speed of any motor vehicle
through the urban district of the Village exceeds twenty (20) miles an hour, or
if the rate of speed of any such motor vehicle operated on any public highway
where the same passes through a residential district of the Village exceeds
twenty-five (25) miles an hour, or if the rate of speed of any such motor
vehicle operated on any public highway in other districts exceeds 35 m.p.h.,
such rates of speed shall be prima facie evidence that the person operating
such motor vehicle is running at a rate of speed greater than is reasonable and
proper having regard to the traffic and use of the way or so as to endanger the
life or limb or injure the property of any person.
B.   Urban Streets With Speed Limits Greater Than 20 m.p.h. The following
streets are exceptions to division A. of this section and are urban streets
whose speed limits are greater than 20 m.p.h.:
1.   East Scranton Avenue between Sheridan Road and Evanston Avenue shall have
a speed limit of 20 m.p.h.
2.   Carriage Park Avenue between Waukegan Rd. to Albrecht Drive should have a
speed limit of 25 m.p.h.
3.   Albrecht Drive between Carriage Park Avenue to Waukegan Road should have a
speed limit of 25 m.p.h.
4.   North Shore Drive between Waukegan Road and Sherwood Terrace shall have a
speed limit of 25 m.p.h.
5.   Sherwood Terrace between North Shore Drive and Sherwood Drive shall have a
speed limit of 25 m.p.h.
6.   Sherwood Drive between Sherwood Terrace and Waukegan Road shall have a
speed limit of 25 m.p.h.
C.   Residential Streets With Speed Limits Less Than 25 m.p.h.
1.   Sylvan Road between Evanston Avenue to Moffett Rd. shall have a speed
limit of 15 m.p.h.
2.   Ravine Forest Drive between East Sheridan Road and Oak Terrace shall have
a speed limit of 15 m.p.h.
D.   Residential Streets With Speed Limits Greater Than 25 m.p.h.
1.   Green Bay Road between Route 176 and the Village limits shall have a speed
limit of 30 m.p.h. (Ord. 96-25, 9-9-1996; amd. Ord. 97-30, 11-24-1997)

indicating the direction of traffic are erected at each intersection where
movement in the opposite direction is prohibited, vehicular traffic shall move
only in the indicated direction.

6-5-9: WEIGHT LIMITS:
A.   Specific Streets: It shall be unlawful to drive or operate any truck in
excess of the weight limits hereinafter set forth, upon the streets designated
herein, at any time:
Mawman Avenue, between West Scranton Avenue and West Blodgett Avenue, any truck
in excess of two (2) tons. Any person violating this provision shall be fined
not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than the maximum provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code for each and every offense. Each usage of any roadway upon
which such truck traffic is prohibited shall be considered a separate offense,
whether committed on the same day or another day. (Ord. 80-6, 4-8-1980; amd.
2009 Code)
B.   Union Pacific Railway Bridge, Green Bay Road:
1.   Definitions: Definitions of any terms or words used herein shall be in
accordance with the provisions of the Illinois motor vehicle code, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-101 et seq. (Ord. 81-17, 9-8-1991)
2.   Weight Restriction: It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or move
on, upon or across, or for the owner or operator to cause or knowingly permit
to be driven or moved on, upon or across a certain bridge over the Union
Pacific railway right of way located on Green Bay Road in the village,
designated as bridge number 0496800 by the department of transportation of the
state of Illinois, any vehicle of any nature and description which, together
with its load, exceeds ten (10) tons in weight. (Ord. 81-17, 9-8-1981; amd.
Ord. 2014-21, 10-27-2014)
3.   Exception; Emergency Vehicles: The foregoing weight limitation shall not
apply to fire apparatus, equipment used for snow and ice removal operations,
vehicles involved in providing paramedic and rescue services, and other
vehicles owned, operated or requested by the village. Said usage is required
for emergency reasons, provided such usage is approved by the structural
engineer as an exception to his inspection report of March 1980 on said bridge
(Del Leuw, Cather And Company or Illinois department of transportation). (Ord.
81-17, 9-8-1981)
4.   Posting Of Signs: The village administrator or his authorized
representative is hereby authorized and directed to post weight limitation
signs at both approaches to said bridge crossing in accordance with the
standards for such construction.
5.   Most Restrictive Provisions Apply: Notwithstanding anything contained
herein to the contrary, whenever a more restrictive weight limitation is
imposed by any other governmental body or agency having jurisdiction over said
bridge structure, or by the owner, person or entity responsible for the
maintenance of said bridge structure, the most restrictive provisions shall
apply.
6.   Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this subsection
shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than the maximum
provided in section
